HEADLINE: Bulb Lighted by Radio Waves May Last for Up to 14 Years

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
In what appears to be a significant advance in the technology of efficient lighting, a bulb will be introduced today that uses a high-frequency radio signal instead of a filament to produce light.
The new bulb is more cost effective than existing types and will last 14 years if lighted 4 hours a day, which is typical household use, electrical engineers say. 
 Compared with a 100-watt incandescent bulb, which would cost about 30 cents a week to buy and operate for 4 hours daily, a 25-watt version of the new bulb would provide as much light but cost only 9 cents a week.
The bulb is expected to have a life of at least 20,000 hours, in contrast to most incandescent bulbs, which burn out after 750 to 1,000 hours. The compact fluorescent bulbs introduced a few years ago last about 7,000 to 10,000 hours, but are bulkier than the new bulbs, limiting the places they fit.
 
Expected Early Next Year
 The developers of the bulb, which is to be available early next year, say they expect it to be used first in spotlights and in other commercial applications where the cost of bulb replacement is a major expense. A version for standard household use will follow soon after.
An independent expert, Howard S. Geller, the executive director of the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy, said he had not seen the bulb itself but had seen the makers' description of it. If it works as described, he said, "then it would be a real breakthrough."
The new bulb, which the makers have called the E-Lamp, for electronic lamp, will sell for about the same price as existing compact fluorescent bulbs, or $12 to $15 each, said Richard E. Disbrow, the chairman and chief executive of the American Electric Power Company, of Columbus, Ohio, the nation's second-largest electric utility company after the Atlanta-based Southern Company.
Compact fluorescent bulbs, which are priced at about 15 times the cost of an incandescent bulb, have had limited appeal to consumers. But the new bulbs will last much longer and the price is expected to drop as they are produced in larger quantities, said Pierre G. Villere, the president of Intersource Technologies, a small Silicon Valley company that developed the bulb with backing from American Electric Power and will make and market it.
Mr. Villere said that as a bulb that would last for years, the E-Lamp was "not a disposable good, but a durable good, like an appliance."
Mr. Disbrow said American Electric would probably offer the bulb at a discount to its 2.1 million electricity customers in parts of seven states.
 
After Years, Gradually Dims
 The E-Lamp works by generating a high-frequency radio signal. The rapidly oscillating radio waves excite a gas mixture in a sealed globe, and the gas in turn gives off light outside the visible spectrum. When this light hits a phosphor coating on the inside surface of the bulb's glass shell, the phosphor glows with visible light.
Existing fluorescent bulbs use an electrode to generate a current in the gas. The E-Lamp lasts longer because there is no electrode to burn out, but after years of use the bulb gradually dims because the phosphor wears out.
American Electric Power and Intersource Technologies, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said the new bulb had other advantages as well: it can be used with a dimmer switch like an incandescent bulb and will be smaller and more energy efficient than most compact fluorescent bulbs now on the market.
"The bulb will fit in any fixture, and it will operate upside down, sideways and even outdoors," Mr. Disbrow said in a telephone interview. His company's engineers are "wildly enthusiastic," he said.
According to the two companies, the bulb will switch on or off in less than a second, with no flicker. It will also work in the cold, unlike existing compact fluorescents, which require mild or warm temperatures to light.
At the Electric Power Research Institute, a utility consortium in Palo Alto, Calif., Karl F. Johnson, the manager for commercial building systems, said engineers had been experimenting for years with bulbs that ran on radio waves but had always had trouble preventing the waves from leaking out and interfering with other electric devices. If the new bulb has solved that problem, he said, "it would be a very neat product; it would be wonderful."
E-Lamp's makers say they have indeed found a way to prevent the radio signals from leaking.
 
Managing Electricity Demand
 The companies plan to introduce the bulb today in Columbus, Ohio, where the Edison Electric Institute, the trade association of investor-owned utilities, is beginning its annual meeting.
Mr. Villere of Intersource said the bulb would come on the market in the first quarter of 1993 but probably would not be widely available for a few months until the company had expanded its manufacturing capacity to produce the bulb by the millions.
American Electric is not generally known in the utility industry as a leader in conservation efforts. Mr. Disbrow said, however, that his company saw the bulb as a valuable tool in "demand-side management," an approach in which utilities stress greater efficiency in electric use, rather than construction of new generating stations.
American Electric owns 9.9 percent of Intersource. The company has not taken a larger stake, Mr. Disbrow said, because American Electric is regulated under a 1935 Federal law that places strict controls on diversification by multistate utility companies.

HEADLINE: TOKYO BID TO SEND ITS TROOPS ABROAD SUFFERS A SETBACK

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 31

 BODY:
In what appeared to be a major setback to its plans to send Japanese forces abroad for United Nations peacekeeping operations, the Government yielded to a compromise this weekend that would in effect create a symbolic military force but prevent it from leaving Japanese shores for years.
The compromise came in a last-ditch effort to overcome widespread objections to the plans in Parliament, which is expected to act on establishing a peacekeeping organization in the next few weeks. The national debate over sending Japanese forces abroad for the first time since World War II grew out of international criticism during the Persian Gulf war that Japan was willing to write a check to maintain world peace, but not to put its own citizens at risk. 
 Ever since, the governing Liberal Democratic Party has been trying to lift the postwar ban on sending Japanese troops abroad, drafting legislation and reinterpreting the Constitution to allow military personnel to serve under United Nations command for the first time.
 
A 'Freeze' on Deployments
 Government officials, trying to put the best face possible on the agreement, said that under revisions to the bill, which Parliament is expected to act on this week, the Japanese military would be permitted to play some limited non-combat roles, like providing medical aid or logistical help or observing elections. But to win support of some key opposition parties, the Government had to agree to "freeze" any deployment of peacekeeping for an unspecified period, and to allow Parliament to vote separately on each dispatch of troops. If the gulf war was any guide, that process could take months, opening Japan to more criticism that it is slow to respond.
More than any other initiative taken by Tokyo in the postwar era, the peacekeeping bill has become the symbol of how far Japan is willing to go in fulfilling its pledges to take a greater political role in world affairs, one that would be more commensurate with its economic might.
But as the debate unfolded, it became clear that many of Japan's leaders envision a far more active, risky role than do many of its citizens, who see little advantage in dispensing with the postwar prohibition on sending forces abroad. Under most current interpretations of the Constitution, which was written by the American occupying force here after Japan's surrender, the country's Self-Defense Forces are strictly prohibited from venturing beyond Japan's shores or engaging in acts of "collective security."
Since the gulf war, when Japan contributed $12 billion but no personnel to the multinational force that liberated Kuwait, debate has raged here over whether the post-cold-war era requires a fundamental change in Japanese policy.
Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa declared passage of the bill one of his top priorities, and many political analysts here believe that his tenure may depend on how skillfully he secures its passage without harming his party's chances in a critical election this summer. Many political leaders here also consider passage a prerequisite if Japan hopes to realize its ambitions to become a member of the United Nations Security Council in coming years.
 
Public Is Opposed
 Nonetheless, polls show that the Japanese public is clearly opposed to any plan to send its troops into combat areas, with many questioning whether they can yet trust their Government to keep a rein on the military. As a result, the governing party -- fearful that its efforts to pass some kind of peacekeeping bill could be defeated for a third time -- has been struggling for ways to pass the core elements of the bill, while at the same time at least seeming to be responsive to the public's apprehensions. And it is possible the fragile coalition being built around the bill could still collapse, perhaps leading to the dissolution of both houses of Parliament and the calling of a general election.
"The cold war is over, and we need to begin to think about playing a different role in the future," Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, who heads one of the larger factions in the governing party, said in an interview recently. "But we have to do it in a way that allows Japanese public opinion to mature." That task, he said, will take several years.
For the time being, however, the Liberal Democrats have been involved in weeks of political horse-trading with two small but crucial opposition parties, the Komeito and the Democratic Socialists. Without their support, the bill would die in the upper house of Parliament, where the Liberal Democrats lost their majority in a major setback three years ago.
Until this weekend, the two parties have wavered on the bill. But over the weekend they reached an agreement to support it, under conditions that seemed to underscore the depth of Japan's ambivalence and uneasiness about changing what has become a a tenet of the country's postwar national identity.
 
Freeze on Deployments
 The agreement calls for a "freeze" on deploying any armed missions that would play a role in separating warring factions. Ending the prohibition would require an act of Parliament, something that could take months or years if Japan's reaction to the gulf war is any guide.
The Government also agreed that that once it is lifted, Parliament would have to vote separate approval any time the military is to be sent to join a United Nations peacekeeping force.
The message of such broad concessions, which the Government had fought for months, was clear: When gunfire breaks out, Japanese troops will be nowhere around. But the legislation would permit non-military activity, from providing medical care to supervising elections.
No one seemed very happy with the compromise. Mainichi Shimbun, one of Japan's largest dailies, today called it "a compromise hodgepodge reached to secure an adopted at all costs" and termed it an effort to lull the public into acceptance of the sending Japanese troops aborad.
"It is the utmost irresponsibility to enact this defect-ridden bill into law," it said.
A senior official of the Foreign Ministry who was involved in the negotiations defended the decision to freeze any deployment, saying: "It is not for any cowardly reasons. The public just needs a bit of time to swallow this."
The largest opposition party, the Socialist Party, has vowed to continue its longstanding battle against any effort to send Japanese troops abroad. The Communist Party and some minor parties also oppose the legislation.
Some Socialist leaders are blaming the United States for pressing the bill's passage.
"The trouble with America is that you are always trying to encourage us to increase our military capability," Masao Kunihiro, one of the leading opponents of the bill in the upper house, said recently. "I know that the day will come when you will regret it."
American officials here and in Washington have been careful to express no opinion on the bill itself, saying Japan has to decide for itself what role it is comfortable playing in United Nations peacekeeping activities. But it is clear that American pressure, or at least the perception of it, has played a critical roll in keeping the issue at the top of Japan's agenda. Last fall, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d criticized Japan in a speech here for failing to go beyond "checkbook diplomacy."
 
Advice From U.S. Envoy
 During the gulf war and after, the United States Ambassador here, Michael Armacost, said repeatedly that Japan must begin to put its citizens "at risk" to keep world peace -- presumably with global medical teams, logistics workers or troops -- but he has declined to be more specific.
In contrast, several of Japan's neighbors, especially those who vividly recall Japan's invasion of Asian neighbors in the 1930's and 40's, have offered grave reservations about the bill. China's leaders have urged caution, and Singapore's former Prime Minister, Lee Kuan Yew, once compared lifting the the prohibitions on sending Japanese troops abroad to giving liquor candies to an alcoholic.
Yet it is in Asia where Tokyo assumes it would first send Japanese peacekeepers. Japan was peripherally involved in last year's agreement to disarm the warring factions in Cambodia, and the leader of the United Nations presence there is a Japanese, Yashushi Akashi. Mr. Akashi has repeatedly called for Japan to take an active role in the peacekeeping effort there, and has even asked it to set up a "staging area" for supplies on Japanese soil.
But under the bill, it seems unlikely that significant numbers of Japanese would be deployed to Cambodia anytime soon. And when they were sent there, they could not be placed between the factions or anywhere else where hostilities seemed imminent.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Senate Race
Primaries for Cranston's Seat Expose Rifts in California Parties' Ideologies;
Republicans View Contest for Heart of Their Party

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 31

 BODY:
An election year challenge sure to stump even the most astute Republicans in this state: Name one issue on which the party's two main contenders for a six-year Senate term agree.
Give up? So do the candidates themselves. 
 Bruce Herschensohn, a conservative television commentator from Los Angeles, and Representative Tom Campbell, a moderate from the Silicon Valley, hardly sound like they belong to the same party.
"I'm running against him the way I would run against a liberal Democrat in the general election," said the outspoken but jovial Mr. Herschensohn. "We have different philosophies that stretch across almost every major issue."
 
Possible Turning Point
 The more cerebral Mr. Campbell, who was a Stanford University economist before he went to Congress, said his opponent believes that "if you're not 100 percent with the far right on everything, then you're not credible." Mr. Campbell added, "He represents the past of the Republican Party and his positions are very extreme."
While there are several bitter Republican rivalries this year for the California Legislature that pit the religious right against more moderate candidates, it is the Campbell-Herschensohn competition that could be a turning point in the decades-old struggle for the heart of the state's Republican Party.
"There are hundreds of contested primaries in which there are significant ideological differences," said Dan Schnur, a spokesman for Gov. Pete Wilson, who has made no endorsement but is believed to favor the more like-minded Mr. Campbell. "The difference is that you've got two equally matched competitors, and they're fighting on a statewide stage. That heightens the interest and the intensity."
Tom Bethell, a media fellow at the Hoover Institution, said the contest could be "one of the more important G.O.P. races in the state's history -- its outcome is likely to influence the state G.O.P. in the years ahead."
 
Conservatives Waning
 The conservative wing of the Republican Party, which catapulted Ronald Reagan to the Governorship, has been waning since the 1980's, particularly with the election of Governor Wilson in 1990. So a victory by Mr. Herschensohn could reinvigorate those who preach his pure, hard-line Republicanism. But a victory by Mr. Campbell could signal the rise of a more moderate state party whose positions align with Democrats on issues like abortion rights, homosexual rights and the environment.
The stakes are particularly high because the state's Republicans may be on the verge of becoming the ruling party in California. This could be the year that the Republicans outnumber Democrats in the state's Congressional delegation, and many analysts predict that Republicans will take control of the State Legislature by 1994 or 1996.
There is also a race for California's other Senate seat, to fill the two years remaining in the term Mr. Wilson gave up when he became Governor.
That Republican contest, between John Seymour, the moderate who is now holding the seat on an interim basis, and Representative William E. Dannemeyer, a staunch conservative, has drawn less attention and is not viewed as a critical ideological test. Mr. Seymour is widely viewed as the favorite.
The full six-year seat, open because of the retirement of Senator Alan Cranston, is critical, said Bruce E. Cain, a political science professor at the University of California at Berkeley. "It's the only shot the conservatives have," he said.
"If Campbell defeats Herschensohn, what you're talking about are two moderate Republicans potentially winning seats in the U.S. Senate," he added. "That's pretty demoralizing to the conservative wing of the party."
There is a third candidate for the full Senate term, Sonny Bono, the former Mayor of Palm Springs who is best known as an entertainer. He has lagged in third place in pre-election polls.
 
Race Gets Dirtier
 Mr. Herschensohn, (pronounced HERSH-en-son) who is 59 years old, said there was no overriding issue in the race, which he said would hinge on whether Republicans want "a conservative versus liberal" candidate.
"I would enter legislation for a balanced budget, for a flat-rate tax, to repeal all bilingual laws," he said in an interview. "I would enter an amendment to the Constitution for voluntary prayer in school. And I would do everything in my power to maintain our defense budget."
Scoffing at his opponents' attempts to tag him as a liberal, the 39-year-old Mr. Campbell emphasizes his fiscal conservatism. But he said his support for the right to choose abortion was "the deciding issue" in the campaign. "If the Republicans of California chose me as their candidate," he said in an interview, "the party had better have a pro-choice point of view."
The race has turned nasty in recent weeks. In his latest commercial, Mr. Herschensohn accused Mr. Campbell of distorting his position in a way that is "symbolic of what's wrong with the arrogant, spoiled, liberal Congress." Mr. Campbell says flatly, in his advertising and in person, that Mr. Herschensohn is a liar.
 
Different Geography
 Despite their ideological differences, the race could also turn on how well Mr. Campbell and Mr. Herschensohn tap their vastly different geographic bases. After more than a decade as a television and radio commentator in Los Angeles, Mr. Herschensohn, who admits he prefers television appearances to the grind of endless campaign appearances, is well known in Southern California but sought to raise his popularity in the San Francisco area by campaigning with Oliver L. North, well known from the Iran-contra affair.
Though he has never held elective office, Mr. Herschensohn finished second in 1986 Senate primary to Representative Ed Zschau, who vacated the House seat now held by Mr. Campbell but lost the election to Mr. Cranston.
Mr. Campbell, who has represented Palo Alto for two terms, has sought to build his name recognition in Southern California. While recent polls show a tight race between Mr. Campbell and Mr. Herschensohn, they give Mr. Campbell a thin lead.
If the turnout is low, Mr. Herschensohn would probably benefit because he is backed by many of the conservative loyalists who are usually most inclined to vote.
No matter what the outcome, some Republicans are not bracing for the end of intraparty warfare after Tuesday's primary. "I don't think," Mr. Schnur said, "there will be any apocolyptical fallout on either side."

HEADLINE: In Sarajevo, Anger and Grief Amid Ruins

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, May 31

 BODY:
When the Serbian Orthodox priests lifted the top off Predrag Marjanovic's coffin for his family's last farewells today, his grandmother leaned over, moved the black scarf from his face and kissed him.
"Your brothers who survive you will avenge you!" she said, her anguished voice rising above the wailing of the dead man's mother and sister. 
Around them, in the caramel-colored church in the hills above this besieged city, Serbian men in camouflage fatigues with pistols, knives and grenades strapped to their belts wept for their comrade, a 27-year-old Serbian policeman. He died on Friday when a sniper in Sarajevo shot him in the back as he pulled his pajamas from a clothesline.
After their farewells, the mourners stepped out into the drizzle and vowed to keep fighting until Sarajevo was "liberated" from the Croats and Muslim Slavs who control much of the city.
"If this land is not going to be Serbian, it will be nobody's," said a 30-year-old Serbian policeman, also named Predrag, who gave only his first name.
A day after the United Nations Security Council imposed sweeping sanctions on Serbia and identified it as the principal aggressor in Bosnia and Herzegovina's civil war, the mood among the ethnic Serbian forces encircling Sarajevo, the Bosnian capital, was defiant, and at times apocalyptic.
In their vows to keep fighting, to avenge lost comrades and to capture Sarajevo -- or at least to carve out Serbian enclaves that can be governed as part of an autonomous Serbian republic -- the fighters offer little hope that they will yield at any time soon to international pressure.
On the Serbian front lines, along the slopes of the 6,500-foot mountains that cradle Sarajevo, the mood was one of a people who consider themselves maligned, above all by the United States, which led the drive for sanctions.
Sometimes in anger, sometimes in what seemed like despair, officers and men alike assailed American reporters entering Sarajevo for what they said were misleading Western news accounts that had helped push the United Nations into the embargo on trade, oil, civil aviation and sports.
At the funeral, at paramilitary checkpoints along the rutted mountain roads that are the Serbs' supply lines, and at military barracks on Sarajevo's outskirts where Serbian commanders direct their operations, the Serbs insisted that atrocities attributed to their forces -- including a mortar attack on a bread line in the center of Sarajevo in which at least 20 people died -- were "provocations" by Muslim Slav units seeking to push the world into punitive actions against Serbia.
 
Fear of Extinction
 The Serbs also represented themselves as men fighting to save their historic foothold in Sarajevo against the Muslim-dominated Government of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which they said was committed to a program of Islamic fundamentalism, and ultimately to the extinction of the Serbian Orthodox Church and other aspects of Serbian culture that have been rooted here since Sarajevo in its present form was founded 535 years ago.
Finally, the Serbs said, they were fighting to save their families and fellow military men who have been trapped in Sarajevo by the fighting.
As mortar and machine-gun fire broke the stillness outside his office, Col. Tomislav Sipcic of the newly formed army of the so-called Serbian Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, was preoccupied with the plight of Serbs trapped in Sarajevo. At intervals during the evening, the granite faced officer at the Lukavica barracks in Sarajevo's outskirts picked up a telephone on his candle-lit desk to speak with a Croatian commander of the opposing Muslim-Slav and Croatian forces in Sarajevo.
Until 12 years ago, Colonel Sipcic, who is 50 years old, was an officer in the Yugoslav Army It has transferred at least 55,000 troops to the new army after the Serbian Government, under pressure to respect Bosnia and Herzegovina's independent status, ordered Yugoslav forces to withdraw. Now, in addition to maintaining a blockade on Sarajevo, the Colonel's tasks include bargaining with the Croatian commander, Col. Stjepan Siber, over 734 Serbs who are trapped in the Marshal Tito barracks in the heart of Sarajevo.
For more than two months, the Serbs, who include 486 women and children and 248 officers and teen-age military cadets, have been besieged in the barracks by Croatian and Muslim Slav forces. Inside the huge military encampment, covering the equivalent of 10 city blocks, the Serbs are trapped without electrical power or fresh food, and their fate has become intertwined with that of Sarajevo itself. In effect, they have become hostages to the heavy bombardment of the city by Serbian artillery, mortar and rocket batteries in the surrounding hills.
Tonight, in one of the curious human twists to the Sarajevo battle, Colonel Sipcic agreed to allow a Muslim Slav chess team safe passage on their way to the World Chess Olympiad in the Philippines if Colonel Siber, a former army colleague, held to an agreement to allow the evacuation of the Marshal Tito barracks on Monday.
Similar agreements have been made and broken at the last moment, raising fears of a massacre if the walls of the barracks should be breached.
But if ties forged in the old Yugoslavia still count for something among military officers, much else about Sarajevo attests to the rupturing of human bonds and the resurgence of the ethnic and religious hatreds of the past. Many of the Serbian fighters described their Muslim foes as lazy, and as under the spell of Alija Izetbegovic, the President of Bosnia and Herzegovina, a man they described as a Muslim extremist.
"What they didn't succeed in achieving 500 years ago they want now," said Grujo Sudzum, a 36-year-old Serbian mechanic serving as a military volunteer, referring to the Turkish drive into Europe in the 15th century.
As dusk settled over the low hills separating the Lucavica barracks, Mr. Sudzum was surrounded by a group of Serbian volunteers. Asked if they would agree to United Nations demands that they stop fighting if it meant the end of their bid for a Serbian republic within Bosnia, they replied in a chorus: "Never!"
One man exclaimed: "I lost my house!" Another man said he had lost contact with his wife and three children in Pofalici, a district where, the fighters said, Muslim Slav militiamen had killed at least 70 civilians 15 days ago, burning some alive in their homes.
In the village of Pale, 10 miles from Sarajevo, the funeral of Mr. Marjanovic left no doubt about the bitterness stirred by the fighting. After Serbian priests in black and golden vestments had performed a liturgy over the coffin, and mourners with lighted candles had filed under the oil-painted icons to kiss the dead policeman, Nedeljko Rasevic, a 41-year-old hotel manager now serving as a military volunteer, blamed President Bush for what he said was the United Nations' victimization of the Serbs.
"If Mr. Bush was here he wouldn't do such things to our people," Mr. Rasevic said. "He should come here to see the truth. He should come here and learn about the eight people that the Muslims took to a school basement in Sarajevo and burned alive. We are burying our people all the time."

HEADLINE: TENS OF THOUSANDS CALL FOR REMOVAL OF SERBIA'S LEADER

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 31

 BODY:
Tens of thousands of demonstrators crowded downtown streets today calling for the resignation of Serbia's President as the first effects of United Nations sanctions were being felt.
The President, Slobodan Milosevic, criticized the sanctions imposed on Saturday, saying Serbia was not responsible for the fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina, which continued today. 
 "This is the price we have to pay for supporting Serbs outside Serbia," Mr. Milosevic said early this morning after he cast his vote in elections for the Yugoslav Parliament. "As far as the accusations that we have committed aggression against Bosnia and Herzegovina are concerned, surely every citizen of Serbia knows that they are ridiculous. We have not committed any aggression against Bosnia."
 
Election Boycotted
 Mr. Milosevic appeared tired as he voted today. All major opposition parties were boycotting the elections in Serbia and Montenegro, the only remaining Yugoslav republics, and the Serbian Orthodox Church denounced the vote.
Polls opened just hours after the United Nations Security Council imposed the economic sanctions.
[Bush Administration officials Sunday expressed deep reluctance to use military force to enforce the sanctions, saying Washington's immediate goal was to force the Serbian-backed military to lift its two-month blockade of Sarajevo. Administration officials said they wanted to assess the effects of the embargo before taking any further steps to punish Yugoslavia. Page A8]
The first outward signs of the embargo were lines forming at gasoline stations in the Belgrade area and the disruption of air links.
 
Flights Are Canceled
 This morning, hundreds of stranded travelers milled around Belgrade Airport watching the word "Canceled" click up next to one departing flight after another on the large black timetable. Within hours, only flights for Paris, Copenhagen, Moscow and London were left and it was unclear whether they would actually depart.
Yugoslavia also has been disqualified from the European soccer championship in Sweden as a result of the United Nations embargo.
The peaceful demonstrators, many dressed in black, took over downtown Belgrade streets for about three hours this afternoon, unfurling a mile-long black banner along the city's main shopping thoroughfare before protesting outside the television station, the hub of the Serbian Government's propaganda network.
Demonstrators jeered and shouted "Slobo Must Go!" outside the republic's Presidency Building, referring to President Milosevic.
The demonstration was the largest anti-Government gathering in Serbia since violent protests in March 1991 brought Yugoslav Army tanks to Belgrade streets.
 
Bombing of Belgrade
 "I am against the war and the regime that has sucked our sons into war," said a Yugoslav Airline flight attendant, laid off last week after 30 years on the job because of the cancellation of the airlines' landing rights by the United States and Canada.
"I want to show the world that all Serbs are not the same," she said. "We all expect to be bombed, and we remember when the Americans bombed Belgrade in 1944."
Slobodanka Karic, a 50-year-old health worker, said, "It's only a matter of time before the armed conflict comes to Belgrade. The international community should stop all the armed attacks by all sides, and then the Communists must be removed."
The demonstrators scoffed at today's elections, calling them a "farce."
 
Reports on Turnout
 Election officials reported only a 38 percent turnout at Serbian polling stations at 2 P.M., and by evening were asserting that 60 percent of the electorate had voted. In Montenegro, turnout reports ranged from 6 to 60 percent. About 7.3 million people are eligible to vote. Final results are not expected until Wednesday.
Western diplomats said a weak turnout would not necessarily be interpreted as a vote of no confidence in Mr. Milosevic, who rose to power through the Communist Party's apparatus and has deflected criticism and held power by appealing to Serbian nationalism and controlling the republic's large enterprises and most influential media.
Serbia's main opposition parties, the Serbian Renewal Movement, Democratic Party and Serbian Liberal Party called for the boycott because they said the Government pushed through the country's new Constitution without adequate discussion, allowed only a short period for campaigning and refused to end its virtual monopoly on the country's main television channel.
 
'Duty to Liberate Serbia'
 The leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement, Vuk Draskovic, said: "The Serbs' enemies are not in London, New York, Paris or Moscow. They are right here in Belgrade. It's our duty to liberate Serbia."
"The Serbian people are not guilty," Mr. Draskovic said. "Sanctions are needed against the regime, not the people."
The Serbian Orthodox Church denounced the Serbian and Yugoslav Governments last week, disassociated itself from the new Constitution and the elections and called for the formation of a government of national salvation.
Only the renamed Communist Party of Serbia and Montenegro, two ultra-nationalist parties, and several dozen tiny political groups ran candidates.
 
Successor to Old Yugoslavia
 The elections were scheduled after the new Yugoslavia was formed on April 27 in an attempt to claim the status of the successor to the Yugoslav Federation as well as its assets.
Government leaders say the elections are important because they will allow the Yugoslav Government to begin functioning normally again after huge gaps were torn in the Legislature and administration by the secession of Croatia, Slovenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Macedonia.
Officials of the United Nations peacekeeping forces in Sarajevo today won agreements from Serbian leaders in Bosnia and Herzegovina's government for a new cease-fire scheduled to begin on Monday at 6 P.M. local time, an official in Sarajevo said. The cease-fire agreement provides for the evacuation of a besieged Yugoslav Army barracks in the city center.
Bosnian Serb forces this morning continued their bombardments of Sarajevo, while Yugoslav Army and Bosnian Serb forces also shelled the historic port city of Dubrovnik, lobbing about 17 shells into the walled Old Town.
More than 2,300 people have been killed and 7,700 wounded since the Serbs began their military campaign to seize most of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The fighting has driven well over 700,000 people from their homes.

HEADLINE: Attention Italian Shoppers: Find Your Bargains Here;
For These New York Visitors, 'Buy American' Ranks With Major Tourist Attractions

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER

 BODY:
It was Alberto Frambrosi's first visit to the United States, and the tourist from Milan knew exactly where to find the real America. It had nothing to do with the Empire State Building or the Statue of Liberty or anything else New Yorkers might expect.
Mr. Frambrosi landed at Kennedy International Airport, dumped his luggage at his hotel in midtown Manhattan, and hurried to Curacao Export Ltd., a small and bustling store, four flights above West 57th Street off Fifth Avenue, that is a mecca for Europeans, especially Italians. Here, in abundance, were the American products Mr. Frambrosi and his friends covet -- Timberland shoes, Swatch watches, Levi's jeans, Sony Walkmans -- and pay dearly for at home. 
 Ray-Ban sunglasses, the Olympian model, were his first purchase. $60! In Milan, he had paid twice as much for his other five or six pairs, he said.
 
'Still the Fabled Land'
 "I love them," said Mr. Frambrosi, who heads a software company. "I love them a lot. I don't know why." With his new Ray-Bans, he said, he was ready to hit the other places on his list of New York musts -- Central Park, Fifth Avenue, Benihana's.
The approach of summer means the annual migration of foreign tourists to New York, and despite the reports of economic recession and murder in the subways, the visitors are arriving by the tens of thousands, as always.
"New York is still the fabled land," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner for the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics. And New York, he added, counts on tourism as one of its major industries.
In 1990, the last year for which figures are available, tourists spent $9.66 billion in the city, with more than a third coming from international visitors, according to the city's Convention and Visitors Bureau. The money amounted to an increase of 4.5 percent over the year before, and came at a time when the city was sinking into a deep recession.
This year the Europeans, benefiting from a favorable exchange rate, are spending freely. "New York is the bargain capital of the world," Mr. Ehrenhalt said. " 'I can get it for you wholesale' was invented in New York." And while the Italians may be outnumbered by visitors from England, West Germany and France, they are the most exuberant of the European spenders, store owners and tour company directors say.
Americans in Italy want Ferragamo shoes and Gucci bags. But not the Italians. Buy American -- or in America -- is their motto.
"It's got to be American, even if it's made in Taiwan," said Daniela Marino, marketing director for USA Travel, which books Italian tours to New York.
Besides Curacao, one of the hot spots here is McCreedy & Schreiber Boots and Shoes, at 37 West 46th Street, where Italians in New York go for Timberland, the casual shoe with the little tree logo on its side, which is wildly popular among fashion-conscious Italians. Why Timberland? Mr. Schreiber said that in early 1980's Giovanni Agnelli, chairman of the Italian automaker Fiat, was photographed in Timberland shoes. The rest, Mr. Schreiber said, is history.
 
220,000 Italian Visitors
 Recently, Mr. Agnelli was quoted about his fondness for Brooks Brothers clothes, Mr. Schreiber said. "Now the big thing is Brooks Brothers," Mr. Schreiber said.
Each year, 220,000 Italians visit New York, according to the Convention and Visitors Bureau. Some get a piece of New York without leaving home. Antonella Ierubino, the operations manager of the New York City office of the tour company Gastaldi USA, received a fax several weeks ago from a young woman who works in Gastaldi's Palermo office. His translation:
"What point have you reached with my Swatch watches, Timberland shoes and Michael Jordan sneakers from Nike? Please let me know. I can't take it anymore."
Mr. Ierubino went shopping. Another fax: "I received the two Swatch watches. Wonderful!!! I am overwhelmed with joy. For the Nikes, I'll wait for your news. Perhaps in August, I'll come to NYC!!!"
Mr. Ierubino says Italians love the Mediterranean colors of Swatch. The Ray-Ban craze, he says, may have started with the actor Tom Cruise, who wore them in "Risky Business" and, later, in "Top Gun."
 
Beyond Shopping
 To the Italians, Timberland shoes for $100, Swatch watches for $70, and Levi's for $40 are a bargain. Like Ray-Bans, those brands cost two, three and even four times as much at home.
Monica Detullio, who is 22, was at Curacao last Saturday, buying five pairs of Ray-Bans ($46 apiece), a pair of Levi's 501 jeans ($38), a Walkman ($51), and a cordless phone ($57). In her hand was an Italian guidebook to New York City, with the Curacao entry marked in black pen. It was only 1 P.M. on the first day of Miss Detullio's first trip in America. Six days to go.
"I am not happy," Miss Detullio's father, Nicola Detullio, said dryly. Mr. Detullio, an engineer, was bankrolling the spending spree.
But shopping isn't everything. Italians also want to eat teriyaki at Benihana's and American steak at Beefsteak Charlies. They want to drink espresso at Cafe Lucca in Greenwich Village. They want to see Fifth Avenue, Wall Street, Little Italy and Harlem.
Gabriele Malacrido, a 27-year-old traffic engineer from Como, and his 21-year-old bride, Mara, arrived last Tuesday night on their honeymoon. They had three days in New York. At 9:20 A.M. Wednesday they boarded a minibus outside the Sbarro's restaurant, at Broadway and 46th Street, for a four-hour tour of Manhattan.
Mr. Malacrido's first question for the tour guide: "Is it possible to go to the Bronx?"
It wasn't. "I'd like to see all the town," Mr. Malacrido explained. "I've heard about the Bronx. They say it's very dangerous, and there are a lot of poor people."
The bus went from Rockefeller Center to the Cathedral of St. John the Divine to the Apollo Theater to Little Italy to Winter Garden and back to midtown.
"Very beautiful city," Mr. Malacrido said.
"Horrible coffee," said Golob Branka, a banker.
Mr. Malacrido, who left town Friday, said he decided his excursion to the Bronx was not meant to be, thus depriving himself of the chance to see first hand that there is more to the borough than poor people and danger.
"It did not disappoint me, New York," he said. "But three days is not enough. You must stay here, I think, a week, maybe, or 10 days."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Black Cable Channel's Wild Ride

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
When BET Holdings Inc., the cable-television company whose core business is Black Entertainment Television, went public last fall, the stock took off like a rocket.
And little wonder. BET had lots of cachet as the first publicly traded black-owned company on the New York Stock Exchange, and as the purest-play stock in the fast-growing cable programming business. The service's programming was distinctive, with black-oriented music videos, talk shows, comedy and news. 
 Best of all, BET had a stunning earnings record, unlike many cable companies whose high cash flows are eaten up by high depreciation costs.
But since that October offering, the company and its new investors have found themselves riding more of a roller coaster than a rocket. The stock price has lurched between the mid-teens and mid-20's as expectations soared, only to fall rapidly more than once on disappointing earnings and confusing financial reports.
Through it all, Robert Johnson, the company's founder, chairman and its largest shareholder, has maintained goals different from what he sees as the self-limiting ones of other black entrepreneurs.
"I want to build the first black media company," said Mr. Johnson, 45 years old, in an interview in his office in the Georgetown section of Washington. "Most black companies are family businesses. They are concerned about giving family members security. They don't grow. If we are able to buy those businesses, we can build a major company."
To build such a company, Mr. Johnson is now investing in BET's programming and expanding the company's two monthly magazines, YSB (Young Sisters and Brothers), aimed at black teen-agers, and Emerge, aimed at young black professionals. YSB has about 65,000 paid subscribers. Emerge has 100,000.
Mr. Johnson, who controls 46 percent of BET's stock, said the shares' volatile performance stemmed from Wall Street's frenzied infatuation with his company, tough times for cable and the company's lack of familiarity with the stock market.
He said the confusion was now behind BET. Indeed, a number of cable analysts are turning bullish on the company again. What was happening to BET partly reflected the situation most cable programmers were in. But there were the additional challenges of a small, minority-owned company making its debut on Wall Street, attracting both an enormous response and high expectations.
When it was initially offered at $17 a share, BET's stock was vastly oversubscribed and the shares traded as high as $26.375 on Oct. 30, the first day it traded, before closing at $23.50.
 
Disappointing Earnings
 But then came disappointing earnings for the company's first fiscal quarter, ended Oct. 31. And then confusion over some important financial data and the number of cable subscribers combined to undermine investor confidence and pushed the stock down to $15.875 in December.
The stock recovered to $23.375, only to plunge as low as $12 in early March after a disappointing second quarter, which ended on Jan. 31. Both times the stock dropped so sharply that BET asked for trading to be halted. The stock closed at $15.75 on Friday.
When Mr. Johnson started the company in Washington in 1979, cable television was a fast-growing business and he was convinced that there was room for a black-oriented television service.
Partly financed by Tele-Communications Inc., the service grew so rapidly that by the end of 1991, it had 29 million subscribers. And since much of BET's programming day consisted of low-cost music videos, the company posted its first profit in 1985. That was unusually fast for the cable industry. Most publicly traded cable companies own cable systems, whose high construction costs generally hold down earnings. As the overall market for stock in new companies surged, Mr. Johnson saw the chance to tap the investing public for capital.
 
Enormous Enthusiasm
 When it was courting analysts and potential investors, the company indicated that it hoped to add three million new cable subscribers a year, said Dennis Leibowitz, an analyst who follows BET for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. BET also indicated that advertising growth, which had slowed during the recession, would begin to pick up.
The enthusiasm for the deal was enormous. Initial orders for stock exceeded 70 million shares. BET ultimately sold four million shares as planned, though it raised the offering price twice as demand swelled.
The First Boston Corporation, the lead underwriter, was also extremely bullish. Internal data prepared by First Boston's analyst, Mary Kukowski, before BET went public projected earnings of $15 million, or 74 cents a share, for the 1992 fiscal year. Actual earnings for the 1991 fiscal year, which ended in July, totaled $9.3 million.
By contrast, Mr. Leibowitz of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette is now forecasting 1992 fiscal year earnings of $12 million, or 58 cents a share.
 
Subscribers in Doubt
 BET did report solid profits when it released its first-quarter earnings in December, but the numbers were still disappointing to investors. They were hoping for 30 percent growth, not the 15 percent rise, to $2.3 million, the company reported.
Perhaps even more important, there was some confusion about the number of cable subscribers that BET actually had. Its earnings release alluded to 31.6 million subscribers, but it actually had about 29 million and many of them were not paying full price.
The 31.6 million figure referred to numbers from the A. C. Nielsen Company that included viewers who were getting the service illegally. It took several days to explain the difference to Wall Street. Even so, the growth rate in new subscribers proved slower than anticipated. Instead of the annual growth of three million, it had only acquired 400,000 in the quarter.
Mr. Johnson said cable system owners, fearful of reregulation, were hesitant to pay for new services like BET. That has slowed subscriber growth, he said.
Still, after BET's second-quarter earning came in below Wall Street's expectations, "people even began to think there might be no earnings-per-share growth," said Mr. Leibowitz of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. Revenues did grow by 18 percent, but costs grew faster, he said, jumping 36 percent primarily because of programming expenses and costs associated with the two new magazines.
 
Optimistic About Growth
 Mr. Johnson said he was optimistic about BET's growth potential. "We are only in about 50 percent of all cable homes," he said, adding that BET's ratings were good.
John Kornreich, who follows the company for Sandler & Company, a New York investment firm, said that expectations for BET's performance were unrealistically high. He contends that the company's profit margins were not sustainable because, as he puts it: "In such a competitive environment, they will have to spend more on programming and promotion. That will hurt their margins short term, but long term it will insure their growth."
Despite pressures to spend more, Mr. Johnson is taking his time. As he points out, advertisers pay a premium for other so-called target programming cable stations, from Cable News Network to the Weather Channel. He believes that the same is true of BET. Like other cable programmers, he is trying to negotiate new 10-year contracts with cable systems, twice what had been the normal term.
Until he sees what he will get, he is likely to move cautiously. As the cable audience fragments and programmers seek new niches, Mr. Johnson is determined to maintain and expand his core black audience.

HEADLINE: At Poverty Conference, Gloom and Dashed Hope

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MADISON, Wis., May 28

 BODY:
Robert Lampman, the intellectual architect of the war on poverty, stepped to the lectern and reported the good news: poverty has all but vanished, the economy is booming and wages are soaring for those at the bottom.
Then the 71-year-old economist delivered the punch line.
"Not!" he said. 
 Humor was a help this weekend as some of the nation's most eminent poverty researchers gathered at the University of Wisconsin to survey decades of disappointments and a future of seemingly pinched prospects.
 
Thwarted Hopes
 When Mr. Lampman helped start the university's Institute for Research on Poverty in 1966, he predicted a short life for the institute, anticipating that the days of poverty itself were numbered. That was 965 discussion papers, 44 books and 52 special reports ago.
Then the economy hit a wall, growing more slowly and giving less to those at the bottom. Government programs disappointed. Family breakdown accelerated. The percentage of Americans who fall below the poverty line, which had dropped to about 11 percent in 1973, reversed direction, staying at 13 percent or more throughout the 1980's.
"It's all pretty disappointing, I'm afraid," said Mr. Lampman. "I'm pretty pessimistic, particularly on the race question."
Mr. Lampman's former colleague on President John F. Kennedy's Council of Economic Advisers, James Tobin, was also on hand. He too envisioned poverty's early demise, writing in 1967 that it could be eradicated in nine years.
But speaking at the institute's conference last weekend, he traced the story of how macro-economic growth was doing less and less for the poor, and other forces -- drugs, guns and AIDS -- were doing more to them.
He did not speak for all of social science, but it was nonetheless telling when the Nobel Prize winner concluded of these blights, "Understanding them or prescribing remedies are outside my competence."
 
Knowing and Doing
 The conference, planned before the Los Angeles rioting but tinged with its tragic coloration, raised two questions: "What do we know?" and "What should we do?"
The answer to the first, in some respects, is quite a lot. Now there is an abundant literature about what might be called the anatomy of poverty: how much education the poor have, how much they work, how many leave welfare quickly.
There is also a body of literature on program effectiveness that shows, for instance, that training programs help increase the earnings of women on welfare, albeit quite modestly.
Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution, offered an explanation for why anti-poverty programs are not more successful in ending poverty: most do not even try.
Big programs, like Medicaid, housing assistance or food stamps, he said, ameliorate poverty rather than eradicating it. By contrast, programs to make the poor self-sufficient through education or training are much smaller and have suffered the biggest cuts.
"Most programs for the poor achieve their objectives to a limited degree," Mr. Burtless said, arguing, for instance, that while Medicaid does not reduce poverty, it probably improves the health of the poor.
 
Tougher Question
 "What should we do?" was a tougher question.
There was something of a consensus here that the working poor -- a large portion of the 13.5 percent of Americans below the poverty line -- could be substantially helped with health insurance and more generous tax credits.
But what to do about what some call "the underclass," a group of persistently poor people mired in apathy and crime, was more problematic; indeed, the scholars do not even agree whether an underclass exists.
Is this a cause for pessimism? "I would put a different spin on it," said Sheldon Danziger, a former director of the institute. "We know how to cut the poverty rate in half tomorrow with a modest amount of new spending -- $20 billion."
But Robert Haveman, also a former institute director, caused a modest stir with a dimmer assessment, describing the usual call for an expanded Head Start program, more tax credits and more job training as "ho hum."
Mr. Burtless said such policies may be familiar, but similar ones work in Western Europe where poverty rates are much lower.
"If that is boring, too bad," he said.
 
Room for Hope
 There were two possible bright spots. One is that some things may get bad enough to get good: as health insurance problems start affecting the middle class, for instance, there is more pressure on government to control costs and expand coverage.
Another bright spot may simply be the scholars' poor history in making predictions about poverty.
Hugh Heclo of George Mason University quoted from a poem by Artur Miedzyrzecki called "What the Political Scientist Knows." But perhaps the insight applies to anyone immersed in an expert's data:
 
It doesn't occur to him
That no one knows when
Irrevocable changes may appear
Like an ice floe's sudden cracks.

HEADLINE: Wide Awake Journal;
Ghost Town for Sale: Elves Included

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WIDE AWAKE, Colo., May 31

 BODY:
No one has lived in this town for many years, except, of course, for the Tommyknockers, the mischievous elves that miners swore they heard, and sometimes even glimpsed, especially after a drink or two.
But the Tommyknockers might soon have company. Wide Awake is up for sale. 
 All that remains of the old mountain town, which is still named on some maps, are remnants of a post office that collapsed in a jumbled heap, the concrete foundation of the stamping mill and a tiny wood and tin shack that was home to Wide Awake's last resident, Wallace Stevens, a retired shepherd, who died in 1964. Seven miles from the nearest town, a four-wheel-drive vehicle is needed to get here across an unpaved and unmarked road.
Like so many ghost towns in the West, the darkness of night, and perhaps an avid imagination, bring some eerie sounds to Wide Awake. "It's really kind of creepy up there," said Verla Clemens, who owns the town with her husband, Richard. "The ground creaks and heaves. You hear sounds like shrieks and screams."
Miners with picks, shovels and dreams struck gold here in the 1860's, and by the turn of the century, more than 500 people lived in Wide Awake, about 50 miles west of Denver. According to legend, the miners had been struggling to come up with a name for the town. As they tossed out possible names late into the night, one sleepy miner supposedly said to another, "Let's just wait until morning, when we're more wide awake."
One of the miners responded: "That's it! We'll name it Wide Awake."
The mine, the linchpin of the town's economy, closed in the late 1920's, although the Clemenses say gold deposits remain in these hills.
The town, which includes 46 acres of private property and 175 acres of deeded Federal land, runs up against the Arapahoe National Forest. Deer and black bear prance across the land, which is covered with juniper, aspen and lodgepole pine. The asking price is $250,000.
The rugged terrain of Gilpin County was forbidding territory to all but the heartiest. And its settlers, who often ended up chasing off to Alaska for the next gold rush, left a legacy of colorful stories. For generations, tourists have come to Black Hawk and Central City for the Old West honky-tonk flavor. The writer Jack Kerouac stopped here to take notes and quench his thirst in the 1950's.
But unlike its neighbors, Wide Awake, an isolated patch in the Rockies, faded into history. Except for an occasional wilderness hiker, tourists would scarcely know that a town had existed here. But the property value has risen in the last year as legalized gambling triggered a boom in Central City and Black Hawk. At the same time, taxes have jumped. And Mr. and Mrs. Clemens, who are retired in Paonia in Western Colorado, say they cannot afford to keep it.
"With all the history, I hate to let the town go," Mrs. Clemens said. "But the taxes are $100 a month now. And with retirement, you know, it's hard to keep up with it. We're hoping somebody with money will rebuild the town, the way it used to be."
Mrs. Clemens's father-in-law, Jesse Clemens, bought the town in the 1930's. When he died in 1987, he left the town to his son, Richard.
The Clemenses' real estate agent, Steve Higgins, said that he had fielded a few serious calls, but that most of the inquiries have come from curiosity seekers.
Wide Awake's last resident, Mr. Stevens, who died at age 97, was said to enjoy the solitude. He stored his food in a tree perch that he enclosed with screens to keep animals away.
"Could he ever tell stories," Mrs. Clemens said. "I went rabbit hunting with him once. I couldn't keep up. He chased off and left me in the snow drifts. I was about 17. He was about 87."
Mr. Stevens's daughter was not pleased that he was living alone in the mountains and persuaded him to spend winters with her in town. When he approached 90, the daughter put him in a nursing home, where he complained vehemently about being cooped up.
He appealed for help to his old friend, Jesse Clemens. "So Jesse went and got him out of the nursing home," Mrs. Clemens said, "and took him back to the mountains."

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Money and Other Excuses Hinder Inner-City Growth

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
"THEY haven't been off the boat a year before they open up their own place," Coconut, a sidewalk savant in Spike Lee's film "Do the Right Thing," says as he surveys a grocery owned by Korean immigrants. "They already have got a place in our neighborhood -- a good business occupying a building that had been boarded up for longer than I care to remember."
"It's got to be because we are black," M. L., another character in the film, says. "There ain't no other explanation." 
 To which a third street-corner philosopher replies: "Tired of hearing that old excuse."
Mr. Lee, more prescient than most politicians, captured that raw resentment in 1989, months before a black group began a prolonged boycott of a Brooklyn grocery owned by Korean immigrants, also before blacks and others from the South Central section of Los Angeles vented their rage against Korean-owned stores.
Only three banks in the nation have been chartered specifically to invest in reviving depressed neighborhoods, like South Central. One is in Chicago, another in Arkadelphia, Ark. The third, Community Capital, opened last year in Brooklyn. It is beginning to make a dent in seemingly unbreachable racial or economic barriers that have denied many nontraditional borrowers money.
Last month, Mayor David N. Dinkins announced a program that will tap money from, among other sources, a consortium of banks to spur business in New York's poorer neighborhoods. But Lyndon Comstock, Community Capital's chairman, says that competition is little concern. "I'm not aware of any loans that we lost to other banks," he said.
Already, "Ross Perot" and "Murphy Brown" have replaced "Los Angeles" as the two-word political capsules that the public seems able to digest at any one time. "Urban crisis" is no longer on most politicians' lips either. Nor have most of them been willing to join the debate between M. L. and his friend, much less offer more than another phrase, "enterprise zones."
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan obliquely addressed the M. L. syndrome last month while rebutting Attorney General William P. Barr's argument that family breakdown, crime and the Los Angeles riots were a "grim harvest" of Great Society programs enacted a quarter-century ago. The Senator dismissed Mr. Barr's argument, but not entirely.
"For a brief time, the Great Society gave great influence in social policy to viewpoints that rejected the proposition that family structure might be a social issue," Mr. Moynihan said. "Accordingly, even if social policy might have produced some effective responses, no such policies were attempted."
Since it began 18 months ago, Community Capital Bank has nearly tripled its assets, to $18 million (deposits are Federally insured). Because its market-rate loans range from $50,000 to $450,000, many are packaged with money from other institutions.
The bank has granted $3 million in loans or letters of credit from its own resources and has committed another $1.5 million -- help for more than two dozen borrowers who might have been rejected by conventional banks. Nonetheless, Community Capital was listed among the nation's highest-rated banks last year by Sheshunoff Information Services, a service that rates banks' financial health.
Community Capital approved loans to about 1 in 10 of the business people who applied. One is opening Harlem's first Ben & Jerry's ice cream franchise this summer with a nonprofit group that intends to hire homeless people. Other borrowers include the Settlement Housing Fund, which is rehabilitating 40 apartments in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn; a group building a nursing home in the South Bronx for AIDS patients and their families, and a hardware store owner in East Flatbush, Brooklyn.
Mr. Comstock says he is surprised that many more imaginative entrepreneurs have not applied. Community Capital grants loans in low- to moderate-income communities all over New York City instead of pumping money into a single neighborhood.
"The only thing that represents a long-term concern is that the number of community development projects going on at any one time is nowhere near what the city needs it to be," he said. "It's not even remotely at an acceptable level."
Which suggests that money is only one solution. Another is to address the sidewalk debate between M. L. and his friend, who has tired of old excuses.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: New Jersey;
In All Corners, Volunteers for Perot Set Up Camp

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FRANKLIN PARK, N.J., May 28

 BODY:
Cole Kleitsch rummaged through his files. He was at his desk in the back room of his light-flooded Hallmark card shop in a strip shopping mall here. He had a file for his bank papers, a file for his taxes and, the one he was hunting for, a file for Ross Perot.
The chatty, 30-year-old Mr. Kleitsch said he had never been a political agitator. "I never before saw a political candidate whom I would lift a finger for," he said. But two months ago, he volunteered to work as one of the foot soldiers in the New Jersey campaign to elect Mr. Perot President. Now there is no slipping out of the Hallmark shop with a birthday or get-well card without also getting an earful about Ross Perot. 
 Along the humming highway that runs beside Mr. Kleitsch's shop, he has pasted a poster championing Mr. Perot. A Perot sticker and two clipboards greet patrons at the checkout counter. One clipboard holds petitions to get Mr. Perot on the November ballot in New Jersey. The other is for people wishing to do campaign work for Mr. Perot.
"There are people, myself included, who feel their needs are not being met by the political parties," Mr. Kleitsch said. "We're being offered Coke and Pepsi again. What we want is Seven-Up."
He said that it might seem improbable for Mr. Perot to be elected, but added, "Even a tidal wave looks small when you see it on the horizon before it hits the beach."
The Perot volunteers will have no direct roll in the New Jersey primary on Tuesday, since their candidate is not on the ballot and their efforts are directed toward November. New Jersey counts write-ins in primary elections, but the Perot organizers are discouraging a write-in campaign because Mr. Perot has said he wants to avoid disrupting the primary process.
A drive down the highways and backroads of New Jersey shows Mr. Perot's supporters nearly everywhere. They live in Teaneck and Hopewell, in Summit and Newark, in Fort Lee and Clifton. They are a broad cross-section, none entirely sure what their man stands for, but all united in fervently wanting him to lead the country.
About 9,000 Perot volunteers are scattered around the state. Newcomers sign on daily. The majority seem to be novices at the tortuous regimen of political campaigning, but disillusionment with the major-party candidates and the quirky magnetism of Mr. Perot have conspired to kindle an enthusiasm.
"Most of the people have never worked as part of any party, except maybe a rescue party," Mr. Kleitsch said.
Volunteers have defected from the camps of the Republicans and the Democrats. Many are resolute independents. Even some of the apolitical have been roused. One woman in her mid-30's said she had recently registered to vote for the first time so she could cast her ballot for Mr. Perot.
Tom O'Neil, a 54-year-old business consultant from Lawrence Township, is the state's Perot coordinator. After watching Mr. Perot on television, he said he called Dallas, asked what he could do and was told to organize New Jersey. For the time being, his living room is the state Perot headquarters.
He asked his friend, Pat O'Neil, an unemployed 43-year-old businessman from Princeton who is unrelated, to be deputy coordinator. Pat O'Neil said he had agreed after spending a few days reassuring himself that Tom O'Neil had not lost his mind.
 
Trying in Every District
 At organizational meetings, the volunteers were split into three regions: Northeast, Central and South. Each of the state's 21 counties has been assigned a coordinator, as have about three-fourths of the 547 municipalities. The objective now is to appoint a Perot coordinator and team of 3 to 10 members in each of the state's more than 6,000 election districts.
Only 800 signatures are needed to put Mr. Perot on the state's November ballot, and supporters filed petitions on May 13 that they said included nearly 3,000 names. But they are continuing to solicit more signatures to demonstrate the support that exists. They think 100,000 is a nice number.
The fact that Perot volunteers do not yet know precisely what their candidate stands for does not seem to bother them overly.
"At this point, I don't care what they bring out about him; I'm voting for him," said Peg Meyers, a 65-year-old volunteer in Kendall Park. "When I first heard him, he didn't say what he was for. But what he said was enough for me."
Her husband, Day, also 65, chimed in, "My feeling is the American people don't know what's going on down in Washington. I'm not a smart man. In fact, I didn't go further than the sixth grade, because I had to go work in the mines. But I know things are a mess. I think Perot's going to win big."
 
'A Lot of Havoc'
 Rita Kusler, a 39-year-old unemployed accountant who lives in Plainsboro, likes him beause she thinks he will "create a lot of havoc." She describes herself as a liberal Democrat who always voted for the Democratic nominee, except in 1976, when she wrote in Morris Udall.
When Marie Tuskey heard the name early this year, she at first thought people were talking about Hercule Poirot, the Agatha Christie sleuth. Now she is ready to do anything to get Ross Perot elected. "The way he was brought up is the way I was brought up," said Mrs. Tuskey, who is 66 and lives in Kendall Park. "Close family ties. Always a father and mother. I have six children and we're all close. He said his children got the same medical care his workers got, and I liked that."
She said her children have been enlisted to back Perot, too. But her 9-year-old grandson, Jonathan, whom she was babysitting, said he was in the Bush camp. Mrs. Tuskey did not feel she had to sway him. "Ah," she said, "he can't vote anyway."

HEADLINE: Fiscal Hurdle for City Hall: Pay Talks

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Despite an agreement on Saturday between Mayor David N. Dinkins and the City Council on the shape of a $29.5 billion budget, City Hall still faces a final fiscal hurdle: reaching an agreement with the municipal labor unions on pay raises.
City officials and labor leaders will sit down this week to begin a new round of contract negotiations, and union officials say they will demand a share of the city's budget surplus for their members, who are working without contracts and have not had raises for more than a year. 
 But Mayor Dinkins has maintained that the city is still in poor fiscal health and cannot afford to share the surplus -- estimated at $515 million last week -- because most of it will be used to allow the city to avoid borrowing to meet its expenses over the next 12 months. He has vowed not to grant any raises to union workers for the next two years beyond what can be financed through productivity gains.
 
A Hard-Line Approach
 In an interview yesterday in London, where he is on an economic-development trip, Mr. Dinkins suggested that union leaders were pandering to their members by indicating that the surplus could be spent on payrolls. "I think they know what the situation is," the Mayor said. "Where are we going to get all this money?"
Sticking to a hard-line approach could be a costly political move for the Mayor and even raises the possibility of a work slowdown or other job action by angry unions. The unions, which can offer large amounts of political contributions, volunteers and votes, are also crucial to Mr. Dinkins's re-election next year. But recently union leaders have said publicly that despite their strong support for him in 1989, they are reassessing whether to endorse him next year.
"The Mayor simply cannot say there is no money around for raises," said Barry Feinstein, president of Teamsters Local 237, representing 12,000 city workers. "We don't want to hear that and we will not accept that. I would prefer for this not to be a knockdown, drag-out fight, but if the administration continues to lie to us, then so be it." Union leaders say the administration is exaggerating fiscal problems to gain concessions.
After losing thousands of jobs and agreeing to work furloughs and other concessions to help the administration close huge budget deficits in the last two years, labor leaders are under increasing pressure from members to get raises. The unions represent more than 200,000 city workers.
Mr. Feinstein said he believed the administration could come up with the money for a wage increase for the unions, given the magnitude of the city's budget. "It's a huge general fund and they know they can move money around, here and there, when they absolutely need it, and we fully expect them to do it," he said.
 
Keeping Pace With Inflation
 Labor leaders will not say how large a raise they plan to seek, but to keep pace with inflation, the unions will need one of at least 3 to 4 percent. City budget officials estimate that a 1 percent wage increase costs the city about $150 million a year.
First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel denied there was money tucked away in the budget for raises. "It's impossible for us to cook the books in such a way as to hide those kinds of dollars in the budget," he said. "Our position is and will continue to be that we have no other money for raises except through productivity gains."
Relations between the administration and labor have been rocky since at least the fall of 1990, when City Hall warned of the need for widespread layoffs to help offset budget deficits. The city has since eliminated more than 20,000 jobs with layoffs and attrition, and labor leaders say their members should be compensated for heavier workloads that have resulted.
The city is close to completing a delayed round of settlements with the unions that began in the fall of 1990 with the United Federation of Teachers and went on to include District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the city and transit police unions, teamsters and sanitation workers. Those contracts provided a 4.5 percent raise over 15 months.
But those contracts have already expired, and the city begins a new round of contract talks on Wednesday with a coalition of labor unions, including the teamsters and District Council 37, which represents more than 140,000 members. Unions representing firefighters, correction officers and superior law-enforcement officers have not yet settled in the earlier round and are still working under old contract provisions.
James F. Hanley, the city's chief labor negotiator, said the administration would take a hard negotiating line but declined to be more specific.
Perhaps the most important issue in the contract talks will be exactly how the city defines an increase in productivity and whether such efficiencies can be achieved in all city jobs to qualify for wage increases.
For example, productivity gains can clearly be achieved in such areas as sanitation and highways, where there are teams of workers who could agree to work in smaller numbers in exchange for a wage differential. But in other areas, like teaching, welfare or elderly care, it is more difficult to gauge productivity gains for union workers without assessing the delivery and quality of services. Thus, some union workers might qualify for raises through such productivity gains while others might not.
"You can't expect teachers to self-fund our raises," said Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers. "Class sizes are already too large and we are already underpaid, so how do you increase productivity?"
Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private group, said he expected the Dinkins administration to be firm in its union negotiations after being accused of giving away the store in the last round of negotiations when the city initially gave the teachers a 5.5 percent raise. But he predicted that the city would ultimately find some money to help finance union raises.
