HEADLINE: Port-au-Prince Journal;
A Settlement in Haiti? 'Mr. America' Is in the Way

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 30

 BODY:
When Haiti's military-backed Government published a new law calling for the formation of a "national consensus" Government on Friday, one name seemed to be on everyone's lips as the man most likely to be named to the powerful job of Prime Minister.
Squeezed badly by an international embargo, increasingly racked by violence, and scorned by an outside world that has not forgiven the overthrow of the country's first democratically elected Government last September, Haiti's army is now widely believed to be leaning heavily in favor of installing Marc L. Bazin as head of the Government. 
 Mr. Bazin's supporters say he is just the man to solve Haiti's crisis. In a country that has been called one of the world's leading kleptocracies, he was an incorruptible Finance Minister. A stint at the World Bank consolidated his image as the kind of modern technocrat that this anything-goes country has sorely lacked.
Most important, however, is Mr. Bazin's reputation for entree in Washington, a city that has never seemed far from the tangled intrigues of Haitian politics. For this the 60-year-old politician has been widely called Mr. America here, a name that earns him envy from some and loathing from others.
 
Signs of U.S. Anger
 But the issue of Mr. Bazin's influence in Washington is clearly not as simple as his reputation here would indicate. After the violent overthrow of the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide last September, American diplomats here and in Washington discussed what they called Mr. Bazin's "unhelpful role" in the crisis gingerly. But recently there have been signs of raw anger at Mr. Bazin, once an American favorite -- signs strongly suggesting that he will be powerless to ease Haiti's isolation.
At a recent meeting at the American Embassy here, when a participant inquired about a letter-writing campaign by influential Haitians aimed at persuading the United States to ease its embargo of Haiti, Ambassador Alvin P. Adams Jr. listened quietly, apparently doodling on a piece of paper.
When the speaker finished, several people present said, Mr. Adams held up the paper on which he had written "BAZIN," crumpled it and threw it in a trash can, thus dismissing the anti-embargo effort and the man who has become Washington's nemesis at the same time.
Similarly blunt messages have been sent by American diplomats to the Haitian Army. There can be no solution without recognition of Father Aristide, soldiers have been told. Furthermore, Washington has insisted that the deposed President be allowed to choose his own Prime Minister.
Under the army-backed plan for a "consensus" Government, a new Prime Minister will be proposed before the National Assembly sometime in the next few days. If he is approved, he will form a new Government. The presidency will deliberately be left open, but nowhere is there any mention of Father Aristide.
Few animosities are stronger than those separating Father Aristide and Mr. Bazin. Their enmity dates back well before Father Aristide, a last-minute candidate, drubbed Mr. Bazin and his well-oiled machine in national elections 17 months ago.
Father Aristide speaks unrelentingly about "the people," by which he sometimes too obviously meant only the dispossessed for the comfort of some here. Mr. Bazin, the son of senator and the husband of a woman born into a presidential family, is a more traditional Haitian politician.
There is little talk of involving ordinary people in his discourse. Rather, by his political thinking, called pragmatic or cynical depending on one's point of view, a true leader must slowly gain the confidence of the dominant forces here: the army, business and the conservative church. Only then, he says, will change come to Haiti.
In February, rather than accept an agreement negotiated in Washington that called for Father Aristide's eventual return, and the naming of a rival politician as Prime Minister, Mr. Bazin fought strenuously to make the deal fall through, diplomats say. "Every time we think we have put something together, there is Bazin, pulling it apart," said a disgusted diplomat from the Organization of American States.
 
'What's in It for Me?'
 Asked in a recent interview why he could not support Mr. Aristide simply for the sake of national peace, Mr. Bazin replied in his accentless English, "What's in it for me?"
The price tag on this stubbornness has not been small, diplomats say. Dozens of lives have since been lost in the continuing strife here. Thousands of boat people who have set out for the United States might have conceivably stayed home had there been a settlement. And there has been much embarrassment for both the O.A.S. and the State Department.
"I don't give a damn about what Washington thinks about me," Mr. Bazin said, seemingly lightened by the removal of his Uncle Sam label. "Nobody has worked harder to bring democracy to this country than me. What do they expect me to say: O.K., I'll go home now, my job is done. I don't expect any further role? I don't know how it is in your country, but that is certainly not how politics are played in Haiti."
For Haitians on his left, the conservative Mr. Bazin has long been hated for his exuberant Americanisms, and his ready-made, classic economic answers. To these, they have recently added new reasons for their antipathy.
Although he strongly denies it, after the anti-Aristide coup Mr. Bazin was widely quoted here as calling into question the importance of elections in a country where illiteracy predominates.
 
No Apologies for His Stand
 Now, even as he sheds the American stripes for which he was loathed in some quarters, many have latched onto statements like these and what they say is an unseemly eagerness to curry favor with the army and the remnants of the Duvalier dictatorship's brutal Tontons Macoute.
Mr. Bazin offers no apologies. "Either you are in politics or morality," he said, condemning the international community's unwillingness to recognize or even deal with the military-installed Government that replaced Father Aristide. "There are a number of sectors in this country which are powerful in the decision-making process, and they have to be involved."
Told that his fate in power may well be the same enduring scorn, Mr. Bazin professed serenity. A man who once boasted that through his contacts in Washington he could quickly obtain a half-billion dollars in aid and investment, badly needed by the hemisphere's poorest country, he now says that investment is not crucial.
"The lack of foreign investment is no excuse not to do the things you have to do," Mr. Bazin said, speaking in the cool shade of his front porch in one of the capital's most prestigious hillside neighborhoods. "For years, the foreign advisers have been saying you have to get your own house in order, and this will be a good occasion for that."

HEADLINE: Riots' Victims Begin Getting $638 Million in Aid

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 31

 BODY:
A month after rioting swept the nation's second-largest city, financial aid promised by the Government is beginning to reach those who lost jobs, homes and businesses.
Recipients say they are surprised and delighted to get the money this quickly. But some community leaders and local officials say thousands of people are still going hungry or homeless because of the riots, and they have called on Federal agencies to do more to make people aware of the programs and help them apply. 
 When they picked up their $7,000 low-interest loan from the Small Business Administration on Thursday to rebuild a wheelchair-repair business devastated by looters, Sheila and Ernie Tousant said that before the riots they had consistently been turned down for bank loans. But the Government, Mrs. Tousant said, "removed all the red tape and actually gave us a chance."
"I'm shocked," she said, "because I was here in the Watts riots, and I saw the money go to everyone except the people who needed it."
 
'Long Way to Go'
 Visiting Los Angeles on Friday, President Bush said of the rebuilding, "We have a long way to go," but he praised the Federal relief effort as "massive" and "quick."
The Government is financing some efforts to address deep-rooted urban problems. The Justice Department, for example, is providing $19 million for anti-crime and anti-poverty programs. But the emphasis is on patching up the damage from the riots, and some residents said they were angry that money was being spent to aid business owners while little was being provided to help those who had been homeless and hungry long before the riots.
A pastor at the First African Methodist Episcopal Church at the edge of South-Central Los Angeles said that as late as last week up to 1,500 people a day had still been arriving to pick up donated food.
"There's a problem that's not being addressed," said the pastor, the Rev. Leonard B. Jackson. "It seems to me that if people can find the church to get food, then the Government agencies that are coming in can find us and do more to help these people."
Evelyn White, a volunteer at an encampment for homeless people set up in South-Central Los Angeles by the Brotherhood Crusade, a black community organization, said: "Every person you see here needs aid, but they needed it before all of this started. That's why all this happened."
Through Wednesday, nearly 15,000 people had visited one of the nine disaster application centers run by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which is overseeing the process of taking requests for help from victims of the riots and routing them to the appropriate Government agencies.
 
Relatively Few Applications
 The centers offer "one-stop shopping" for people needing almost any kind of assistance, from money for food and clothing to low-interest loans for businesses. But the number of people who have actually completed applications for aid under the programs remains relatively small.
The Small Business Administration, for example, said that although it had passed out 11,000 applications, as of Thursday it had received 528 completed requests for assistance.
As of May 23, 4,876 people had filed claims with the state for unemployment insurance after losing jobs because of the riots. By some estimates, tens of thousands of people lost jobs, at least temporarily, because of the damage to businesses.
"I appreciate how fast the Federal Government has moved, but we need to work harder," said Deputy Mayor Linda Griego. "And they need to work harder to do the outreach and the follow-up to make sure people are getting what they need.
 
More Applications Expected
 Federal officials said they expected the numbers of applications to some programs, especially those for small businesses, to increase sharply in coming weeks. They said that Federal agencies had been working hard to inform the community about the programs by meeting with local groups, answering questions and providing assistance with filling out forms at the application centers.
The city, too, has stepped up its efforts to encourage people to seek help, Ms. Griego said. Concerned that undocumented workers are not applying for aid out of fear that they might be reported to the immigration authorities or the Internal Revenue Service, the city has set up programs with churches and other groups to reassure people that none of the information from relief applications will be used against them.
Federal officials said they were trying to shore up weaknesses in their response. Eleven days ago, after complaints that the Government was not providing food fast enough, the Agriculture Department authorized the purchase of $2 million worth of food to be distributed through food banks to riot victims. The first shipments will reach the food banks this week.
The Agriculture Department also loosened restrictions on providing food stamps, dropping, for example, a rule disqualifying people who own cars.
 
More Money Pledged
 President Bush pledged in the week following the riot that the Federal Government would make available almost $638 million in financial assistance through a variety of existing programs, and perhaps hundreds of millions of dollars more, depending on spending decisions made by Congress. On Friday, he said he had authorized an additional $12 million for job training and public-service jobs.
The amount of Federal money actually disbursed since the riots is relatively small, totaling about $3.2 million as of Thursday. The largest chunk of that, $2.8 million, came from the Small Business Administration for 42 low-interest loans totaling $2.8 million, mostly to owners of small businesses that were looted or burned.
The Federal Emergency Management Agency, which had received 4,694 applications for emergency housing assistance so far, had processed 299 grants totaling $372,000. Under another program to replace personal possessions, like clothing, appliances and cars, the agency had paid out $43,000 to eight applicants as of Wednesday.
 
'A Great Relief Effort'
 At the Disaster Application Center at the old Ambassador Hotel on the edge of Koreatown, James Baker, his wife, Carolyn, and their 2-month-old son, James Jr., were among the more than 200 people a day who had continued to stream in during the previous week seeking aid.
Mr. Baker said he had not found work since he lost his job as a stock person at a Newberry's discount store when it was burned in the rioting. After spending 45 minutes filling out forms and talking to officials from several government agencies and the Red Cross, he said the process of applying for help had gone very smoothly and that he had been assured he would qualify for food stamps, unemployment insurance and grants to help pay the family's rent temporarily.
"This is a great relief effort," he said. "They have all the agencies you need here to take care of each aspect of your life."

HEADLINE: Jobs Outlook Turns Brighter

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, May 31

 BODY:
A quarter of the nation's companies plan to hire new workers this summer, painting a rosy employment picture similar to that of 1983, when a solid recovery rescued the country from recession, according to a quarterly hiring survey released today by Manpower Inc.
The prospective gains in employment were the strongest since the aborted recovery of the second half of 1991, and this time pointed to a sustainable economic upturn, said Mitchell Fromstein, the president of the temporary hiring concern based in Milwaukee. 
"It appears that the hiring recovery is sustainable through the balance of the year and should begin to reduce the unemployment rate as we move toward the fall period," he added.
Of the 15,000 companies surveyed, 25 percent said they planned to add staff between July and September. Only 8 percent reported plans to reduce staff.
The figures compared with a survey a year earlier that showed 22 percent of businesses planned to hire staff and 10 percent said they would lay off workers.

HEADLINE: Dinkins's Trip Off to Profitable Start

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, May 31

 BODY:
Taking a break before the serious work of drumming up business in Europe for New York, Mayor David N. Dinkins was making his way today through the bustling Petticoat Lane Market when business came up to him.
As the Mayor bought nine souvenir T-shirts for his two grandchildren, Ian Gordon, the manager of the market, approached him and said he was interested in opening a similar street fair in lower Manhattan. Without missing a beat, Mr. Dinkins waved to his recently appointed Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, Barry F. Sullivan, and shouted: "Barry, we got a customer!" 
 Mr. Dinkins's weeklong European trade mission seemed off to a good start. And, with a deal on the city budget securely in his pocket, Mayor Dinkins arrived emotionally upbeat and politically robust, an optimism that seemed to rub off on the dozen or so of New York's business elite in tow.
The visit to the market is one of about 10 courtesy calls and tour-like appearances Mr. Dinkins will make this week. The flea market was purposely pushed on to the Mayor's crowded schedule by his press aides as part of a strategy to have him seen out among common people rather than flanked by the European business elite, his aides said.
 
Mayors Compare Notes
 The marketplace was a far cry from a quaint English farmers market. The air was filled with the sounds of reggae and American rock-and-roll. Vendors, many of them from Indian or Caribbean families, sold trendy clothing, music, Rastafarian hats and foreign food rather than traditional British goods. So multi-cultural was the scene that it could easily have been in New York.
Besides buying the T-shirts, Mr. Dinkins hugged two babies, talked to dozens of curious Londoners and even ran into a few vacationing New Yorkers who asked him to have their pictures taken with him.
In the afternoon, Mr. Dinkins held a traditional English tea for the Lord Mayor of Westminster, Dr. Cyril Nemeth, at the Churchill Hotel on Portman Square, where the delegation is staying. The two Mayors compared notes on dealing with stubborn trade unions and privatizing certain city agencies.
For the next three days, the Mayor and the business delegation will hold more than 21 meetings with various business leaders in London, Paris, Frankfurt and Hamburg. He will also meet with French and British Government officials and lay a wreath at a Holocaust memorial in Frankfurt.
 
Ill Feelings Evaporating
 Following the advice of Mr. Sullivan, Mr. Dinkins said he would try to attract middle-sized European companies to New York and to cement relations with the 2,500 foreign concerns already rooted in the city.
By heading the delegation, the Mayor also aims to patch up his relations with big business in New York City. Some of the business leaders on the trip have been critical of him, saying that he did not sell the city enough to foreigners and that his fiscal leadership last year was anemic.
Many of those ill feelings appeared to have evaporated today. Several business leaders on the trip said Mr. Dinkins's stock was rising in their eyes because he hammered out a tight budget with the Council and would end this fiscal year with a $560 million surplus, enabling the city to avoid requesting new taxes from the State Legislature.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor David N. Dinkins talking with two British police officers in the Petticoat Lane market in London. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Forget Peoria. It's Now: 'Will It Play in Tulsa?'

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TULSA, Okla., May 29

 BODY:
Blame it on the musical "Oklahoma!," John Steinbeck's "Grapes of Wrath" and the oil business. The nation's image of Tulsa, complains Rusty Linker of the Metropolitan Tulsa Chamber of Commerce, remains one of amiable cowpokes, oil rigs and parched plains.
It scarcely seems fair. Tulsa, with a population of 367,000, is a tree-lined city with twice the average rainfall of San Francisco. The local economy is more dependent on high-technology services like the computer center that handles reservations for American Airlines than on oil. The only cowboys in town are the dress-up urban variety. 
 And according to an analysis of 1990 census data, Tulsa is the most typical town in America.
 
Ideal for Surveys
 That may not appear to be much of a distinction. Yet Corporate America thinks otherwise. Business looks to the country's most middle-of-the-road cities as ideal test markets for new consumer products.
It can be argued that typical has been devalued, because the growing ethnic and racial diversity of American society means no single city is truly a microcosm of the national market anymore. With America now more a mosaic than a melting pot, the mass market is dead, some say. And, to a degree, that is undoubtedly true.
Still, for all manner of mainstream consumer items -- soft drinks, beer, snack foods, detergents, over-the-counter drugs and others -- the product proving grounds of representative communities remain a vital tool of modern marketing. These days, sophisticated computer models have been developed to predict how shoppers will react to new products.
"But whenever possible, I want to test a product on the shelf," said Dwight Riskey, vice president of new products for Frito-Lay Inc., which tested a new Cheetos cheese-flavored snack in Tulsa before distributing it nationally a year ago.
The big consumer-product companies carry out their test marketing with a grim seriousness, big promotional budgets, the utmost secrecy and even shady tricks like buying a competitor's new product by the cartful just to spoil the test-market results.
"It's high-stakes poker par excellence," said Tom Pirko, president of Bevmark Inc., a Los Angeles-based consultant to the food and beverage industries.
Tulsa came closest of all cities with more than 50,000 people to matching the national averages for age distribution, racial mix and housing prices in a recent study by Donnelley Marketing Information Services for American Demographics magazine. Seventy-nine percent of Tulsa's population is white, 14 percent black, nearly equal to the national figures of 80 percent white and 12 percent black.
"It's very significant that Tulsa keeps popping to the top of the list -- it's moving with the nation," said Judith Waldrop, the research editor of American Demographics, who noted that Tulsa was also most representative in an analysis of 1980 census data. "And struggling to keep up economically, as Tulsa has done, is representative of America."
The city's American Indian population is higher than the national percentages and the Hispanic share somewhat lower. Its median home value, at $60,500, is less than the national median of $79,100. Yet Tulsa's blend of children, young adults, baby boomers, middle-aged adults and elderly, and its age distribution, which is a crucial variable in consumer buying patterns, is almost identical to the nation's.
 
Other Typical Cities
 After Tulsa, the most typical American cities are Charleston, W. Va.; Midland, Tex., and Springfield, Ill. Wichita, Kan., Indianapolis and Oklahoma City also ranked in the top 10 by Donnelley's calculations. But some of Corporate America's traditional test markets -- Peoria, Ill.; Fort Wayne, Ind.; Green Bay, Wis., and Syracuse -- are no longer as representative as they once were.
Throughout the postwar years, companies have scouted for typical towns as proving grounds. The traditional technique was to get the national census data each decade and select places that seemed typical -- often medium-sized cities in the Midwest. Then, if local polling data pretty much matched the most recent national averages, the city was decreed representative and companies began assaulting local residents with new products.
That technique was humorously portrayed in the 1947 movie "Magic Town," in which Jimmy Stewart plays a polltaker who declares a Midwest town the "mathematical miracle" of the United States. The resulting national attention ruins the place, at least before Mr. Stewart's character sees the error of his ways, repents and, in the best Hollywood tradition, gets the girl (Jane Wyman).
That single-handed approach has been overtaken by a cottage industry of demographic analysts, who, armed with computer firepower and new techniques, are culling, prodding and massaging the 1990 census data. Eventually, they will be able to provide marketers with demographic profiles and household characteristics, from commuting times to plumbing fixtures, on a block-by-block basis. And that will enable companies to aim at prospective customers with laser-like precision by mail or telephone.
 
Comprehensive Ranking
 For clues on promising test markets, the American Demographics/ Donnelley study is apparently the most comprehensive ranking of places ever done. For comparison, American Demographics also published a list of typical cities in 1985, using less exacting criteria and working from 1980 census data. Most of the top 20 from that ranking have dropped off the list, reflecting population migrations or economic swings, or have stayed the same while the nation became more diverse.
That Tulsa ranked No. 1 in both surveys is a surprise, given the wrenching economic adjustment it went through in the 1980's. Tulsa lost half its employment in the oil industry during the decade, but adapted by investing in education and economic development. It eventually more than made up for the lost oil jobs by attracting companies in the fields of transportation, communications and services.
And in the last decade, Tulsa has become more diverse racially and ethnically, but not at the rapid pace seen in major coastal cities like Miami, Los Angeles or New York.
Yet as a test market, Tulsa still suffers from its cow-town image.
"Tulsa has not been a real hot spot for test marketing," said Barry Sinrod, president of the Sinrod International Marketing Group, a consultant in Boca Raton, Fla. "How many people want to go to Tulsa?"
When Wendy Liebmann, president of WSL Marketing, a consultant in New York, selected Tulsa for a 1990 study of trends in mass-market retail distribution, some marketing experts "told us we were crazy for going to an oil town that was very Southwest ethnic and parochial," she said.
Rick Bahlinger, president of Golden Eagle Distributing, which markets the beers of the Anheuser-Busch Companies in the Tulsa area, noted that the brewer had just finished a two-year test of Busch Cold-Filtered Draft here. But he acknowledged that Tulsa was not one of the company's favorite test markets.
"Tulsa is middle America to the max," he said. "But people haven't really discovered it yet."
But that is starting to change, said Roberta Cunningham, president of Cunningham Field Service Ltd., a Tulsa company that does the legwork for consumer goods companies, surveying how buyers react to test-marketed products. The family company has six offices nationally, but its Tulsa office has doubled its business in the last year, doubling its staff to 36 employees.
Once marketers get beyond the cow-town-and-tumbleweeds image of Tulsa, Mrs. Cunningham said, they find a representative market where shoppers are willing guinea pigs. The refusal rate, people declining to cooperate with telephone or face-to-face surveys, in Tulsa is far below the national averages, and scheduled 15-minute surveys tend to go on longer as Tulsans digress to talk about their children, gardens, cars or whatever.
 
Generic Styles
 Walking through Tulsa's malls, shopping strips and downtown, the faces, the styles and the goods for sale may vary. Most people under 50 seem to be dressed in the moderately priced, generically stylish garb pioneered by the Gap and mimicked by mass-market department stores like J. C. Penney and Sears. Every discount store seems to be trying to copy the Wal-Mart formula of clean, well-stocked outlets with a scattering of service people trying to act friendly.
Doug White, general manager of the big J. C. Penney store in the Woodland Hills Mall, says he is stocking fewer $350 men's suits and $300 women's suits, the high-priced range at Penney, than he did a few years ago.
"We've moved with the market to sell more of the lower price-points now," Mr. White said. "That's what Middle America wants now."
Mark Hunter, general manager of the Woodland Hills Mall, the largest in Oklahoma, where 15 million customers spend more than $200 million a year, agrees: "Customers aren't as driven by names and brands as they were a couple of years ago. They are still spending, but they are doing it more conservatively."
But there are quirky surprises in the spending habits of this typically American city. In the Woodland Hills Mall, for example, the runaway success of the last few years is Glamour Shots, a store where women spend $150 or so for a cosmetic makeover and a cover-girl-style photo session. There is always a line of women waiting to get in.
The appeal of Glamour Shots, apparently, is that it is a few hours of fantasy, a breakaway from the ordinary. "Every woman wants to be a cover girl," said Julie McCarthy, the manager.

HEADLINE: BASKETBALL;
Stage Has Been Set For Drexler's Rise

BYLINE: By MICHAEL MARTINEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore.

 BODY:
This could be Clyde Drexler's finest moment, a time in his life when everything evolves in slow motion, where he is the central character in a play that unfolds in seven parts, right there on national television, in prime time, in front of Michael Jordan.
It could be. But it probably won't. 
 Drexler wants none of it. None of the national news media attention, none of the public praise, none of the inevitable comparisons with Jordan. What he wants is a championship.
Drexler will accompany the Portland Trail Blazers into this week's National Basketball Association finals against Jordan and the Chicago Bulls with a riveting six-game victory over the Utah Jazz behind them. He was, simply, serenity in motion.
The Blazers are this far into the season because of their remarkable talent, but also because of Drexler's inspiring contributions. Even so, he is more likely to deflect the spotlight than to embrace it. And although a league title is the one thing that separates him from his contemporaries -- from Jordan and Magic Johnson and Larry Bird and Isiah Thomas -- it is something he wants for his teammates as much as for himself.
"You need to have a great team to win," he says, repeating his own theme. "There have been some very great players in the N.B.A. who haven't won. In basketball, unlike golf and tennis, you have to rely on other people. You can't say that guys like Charles Barkley or Hakeem Olajuwon or David Robinson aren't super players.
"Before Michael won, did anyone doubt that he was a super player?"
There remain few doubters regarding Drexler, but the defining moment of a player's career has always been a championship. And Drexler has always fallen short. At the University of Houston, he reached the Final Four twice but never won. Two years ago, the Blazers got to the finals before losing to Thomas and the Detroit Pistons.
And while Drexler's professional career has been full of personal achievement, singular recognition has typically escaped him.
He played 28 spectacular minutes in last February's All-Star Game, but it was Johnson who was named the day's best player, fittingly so. He enjoyed a season of great individual triumph, but it was Jordan who won the league's most valuable player award, and by a sizable margin. He is widely regarded as the game's second-best performer, yet it wasn't until recently, eight months after the first 10 players were selected, that he was added to the United States Olympic team.
Drexler, who will turn 30 years old on June 22, is still reaching for the thing that will elevate him. He does not acknowledge it -- in fact, he denies it emphatically -- but others understand its importance.
"As far as being compared to those great players," said Terry Porter, a teammate, "they've all won at least one championship. I think Clyde needs it to be considered with them. I don't think it would affect him so much, but it would help him get the recognition he deserves."
Even so, it is not necessarily a recognition that Drexler courts. When praise is passed around, he accepts only small portions. Privately, he has said that he dreads the unavoidable parallels that will be drawn between him and Jordan during the coming series, preferring to merely blend in as part of the team.
But they will be there, like it or not.
"That's great and dandy," he said. "I think it's an honor to be compared to Michael, but the real satisfaction comes in seeing how well your team does. For me, that's the ultimate."
Is a comparison fair? Perhaps not. Jordan walks on air; Drexler soars to the basket as if he were riding on a hang glider. Jordan dunks with a sudden and dramatic resolve; Drexler lays the ball into the basket gently, the ball rolling off his fingertips. Every step is an economy of movement.
Same results, but not necessarily with the same elan.
"If there is anyone in this game who comes close to Michael in terms of talent, it's Clyde Drexler," said Bulls Coach Phil Jackson. "Basketball aficionados think his game is absoltely terrific."
Statistically, Drexler is a near copy of Jordan. He averaged 25 points a game during the regular season -- the sixth consecutive season he was over 20 -- plus 6.6 rebounds and 6.7 assists. He finished fourth in the league in scoring, made the All-Star team for the sixth season in a row and was the only player in the league to lead his team in scoring and assists.
But while Jordan was anointed the league's newest superstar upon his arrival, Drexler's climb was slow and deliberate.
"Like all great players, Clyde's gotten better every year," said Geoff Petrie, a former Blazer player and now the team's senior vice president of operations. "A great example of that is that we asked more of him this year, putting him in the low post, which was not something we had in our offense a year ago. Now, he has become a very effective, creative low-post player.
"It was also the maturation and experience that you get just being in the league. Even the great players have their best years between 28 and 32, because that's when the intellectual side -- the understanding of how the game is played -- combines with physical talent. That's the closest thing to a whole package that you're going to get. Clyde was always a great player. He's greater now."
But the universal respect that Drexler receives now wasn't always apparent. Early in his career, he bickered with former coaches Jack Ramsay and Mike Schuler, and when Schuler was fired three seasons ago, Drexler took the heat.
 
'Somebody Had to Be Blamed'
 "Somebody had to be blamed," said Petrie. "There was a lot of disappointment because, at that point, we thought we had arrived as a team. But that reputation hasn't stood the test of time. A lot of people who said negative things about him have now recanted them."
Buck Williams, a teammate who joined the Blazers in 1989, said of Drexler: "I used to think he was selfish. I thought he was responsible for getting Coach Schuler fired. But once I got here, I found out that it wasn't true. He's been misread tremendously."
There was also Drexler's supposed penchant for wanting the ball, then for refusing to share it. Not so.
"I thought he was a ball hog," Williams said. "I realized he's a fine passer, very unselfish. If you watch him from a distance, you see that. He's a very nice person."
Drexler was nice, but displeased, when he was overlooked for the United States Olympic team that will compete in Barcelona, Spain, this summer. When he was finally named, he caused a brief stir by suggesting that a gold medal might be worth more to him than a league title. In these parts, it was blasphemy.
He has his priorities straight now.
"It was never a controversy with me," he said. "Right now, winning the N.B.A. championship is much more important. The Olympics is down the line, and that's going to be a nice event. I'm looking forward to it, but this is the most important thing right now."
And so it is. But when the finals begin Wednesday in Chicago, Drexler will likely find himself facing two opponents: the Bulls and the specter of a larger-than-life Jordan.
"When I hear people compare me to Michael Jordan," he said not long ago, "it's the highest compliment. I'm always honored. But I don't compete against Michael. I do what I can do for Portland. That's what matters."
He knows, though, that each move will be compared with Jordan. That winning, as Jordan did last season, may remove all doubt about his gifts and his leadership. That if the Blazers do win, fans will speak of Michael and Magic and Larry and Clyde in the same breath.
"Larry and Magic, to me, are the best I ever played with and against," said Danny Ainge, the former Boston Celtic and current Blazer. "I think Clyde is getting close to that level. But sometimes it's unfair to evaluate them because those guys had better supporting casts. Larry has played with some great players, like Kevin McHale, and Magic had Kareem all those years.
"Clyde does more than Bird -- he shoots the 3-pointer, he rebounds, he runs the fast break, he blocks shots and makes steals -- but that doesn't mean he's better."
Would a championship make him better? Perhaps, in the eyes of some.
"I don't think Clyde has to prove anything to anyone who's ever seen him play," said Ainge. "If he had Kareem and James Worthy on his team, he'd have a championship ring by now."

HEADLINE: Fiscal Insanity Amendment

 BODY:
Gargantuan deficits threaten economic growth. So Congress wants to approve a constitutional amendment mandating a balanced budget. Problem solved? No, problem worsened. By basing rules on ill-conceived accounting concepts, the amendment would tilt the Federal budget in precisely the wrong direction: away from long-term investment and economic growth.
There are other reasons to reject this reckless amendment. It would invite cynical evasion and, by forcing spending cuts and tax hikes when revenues fall off, accelerate recessions. But the fatal flaw lies at its core: Not all deficits are bad; cutting them can sometimes do unspeakable harm. 
 When the Government runs a deficit, it pays bills by borrowing money that entrepreneurs might have used to create new plant and equipment. The danger is that the economy would be left with less productive capital, a key to economic growth.
But when the Government borrows to create public capital -- fiber-optic cables, mass-transit systems, research facilities -- it does the economy enormous good.
The amendment would require cutting the deficit by a daunting $550 billion or $600 billion over five years. More than $100 billion would probably come from non-defense discretionary programs, including investments in education, training and scientific research. Those cuts would amount to death knells for the economy.
By lumping public consumption with public investment, and requiring everything to be paid out of current revenue, the amendment would steer Congress toward consumption and away from investment. Spending tens of millions on farm subsidies would become irresistible when stacked up against spending tens of billions on fiber-optic cables. Which do you suppose helps America more: 21st-century investments or paying farmers not to work?
Prof. Robert Eisner, past president of the American Economic Association, points out other ways the amendment overlooks basic accounting. Inflation erodes the value -- in 1991, by $80 billion -- of the Government's outstanding debt. That means the Treasury could borrow $80 billion without raising total debt one iota. And debt poses little threat unless its growth outstrips growth of the economy; by that token, the U.S. could run $200 billion deficits with impunity.
But even after taking proper account of public investment, inflation and growth, the proponents of the amendment are right in one important respect. By the end of the decade, deficits are expected to soar above $400 billion, high enough to threaten private capital formation.
The problem is overwhelmingly due to explosive growth of entitlements, specifically Medicaid and Medicare. The straightforward solution is health-care reform that clamps medical costs. There will be need to prune consumption-oriented discretionary programs and, yes, to raise taxes. But there won't be need for a mindless constitutional straitjacket.

HEADLINE: Graduates Feel Anxious, Not Just About Jobs;
Women's Pay Gain

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Is it that news has become by definition bad news, or is your reporting simply a vestige of the male-dominated era? Your front-page story on May 14, "Pay of College Graduates Is Outpaced by Inflation," makes no reference to what leaps out in the accompanying chart: that only male college graduates lost income.
Women college graduates gained as did women at nearly every other education level. Thus, the claim that "most Americans" lost income between 1989 and 1991 really means "most men." 
 All in all, the chart (but not the story) shows that women's earnings increased dramatically compared with men's. On average, men's earnings fell by 7.2 percent between 1979 and 1991, while women's rose by 7.8 percent. Surely a 15-point reduction in the "gender gap" deserves some comment.
 
JAMES W. FOX
Fairfax, Va., May 16, 1992

HEADLINE: Post Sanctions, Invest Wisely in Pretoria

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While New York's Mayor David N. Dinkins is considering "what sanctions to lift" from South Africa (news article, May 14), the rest of us who supported the sanctions movement of the 80's should be asking American corporations to be similarly selective in which types of business they should be willing to resume in that country.
In conversations with leaders of the African National Congress in Cape Town in March, it was plain to me that in due time they too want sanctions lifted, but lifted under a policy that encourages foreign investment in the priority needs of the new South Africa: housing, health, education, land reform. 
 Already the United States Government is practicing modest selective aid in relation to such needs. "But we won't stand by idly and permit capitalists to move back into South Africa as predators," said one A.N.C. leader. "We intend to keep our fingers on their pulse, and we won't give very high priority to diamond mining."
Corporations like a free hand in making their investments. Those of us who supported the sanctions movement in the 80's should be consistent enough to continue to say to American government and business: "Profit, yes, but humane priorities too." Come to think of it, not a bad rule for their investments in our own country.
 
DONALD W. SHRIVER JR.
New York, May 16, 1992
 
The writer is president emeritus, Union Theological Seminary.

HEADLINE: Europe Sees Oil Tax as a Way to Dampen Demand

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, May 31

 BODY:
As Europe's environmental debate moves swiftly from science to economics, the richest governments are turning to the market place as they grapple with the difficult question: what price the environment?
Their most ambitious attempt at an answer so far came this month when the European Community proposed a plan to fight pollution and global warming by imposing an energy tax on oil, coal, natural gas and other non-renewable forms of energy harmful to the environment. The extra cost is expected to discourage use of such fuels; the revenues would be used to help protect the environment. 
 By proposing the tax on the eve of the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro this week, the Europeans have signaled their view that more drastic measures are needed to limit demand for carbon-based fuels.
Although they have not yet made a final decision on the energy tax, the 12 community governments want to use their proposal to seize the moral high ground at the summit, taking advantage of the low profile of Washington.
 
Opposition to Energy Tax
 But already the plan has drawn opposition from the United States and major Mideast oil producers -- the United States because Washington resents pressure to adopt similar measures and the oil producers because they fear a drop in demand for oil.
The Bush Administration's fear that environmental measures will stifle economic growth was evident when it managed to delete firm commitments and timetables to curb emissions of gases that could cause global warming from a pact that is to be signed in Rio.
But European governments are expected to argue that energy taxes must be part of any strategy to fight global warming and that the price of all goods and services must reflect their cost to the environment.
Public concern over environmental issues continues to rise in Europe's crowded quarters. If the European plan is approved at home, as many people here expect it will be, the plan's supporters hope that higher energy prices will change the consumption patterns of the region's industry and its 340 million inhabitants and make them save energy. Another goal is to tilt the market toward energy sources like wind, sun and waves and stimulate the development of more efficient technology.
The heart of the plan is to use market mechanisms to fight pollution, not administrative measures like standards and regulations. The idea is to start the levy next year at $3 a barrel of oil or oil equivalent, reaching $10 by 2000. (A barrel holds 55 gallons.)
"Our plan will give a decisive boost to the new thinking that international environmental solutions must be found via the market," said Carlo Ripa di Meana, the community's Commissioner for the Environment, a strong advocate of the plan. "In that sense the scope of this plan is revolutionary."
The European Community Executive Commission has adopted the plan, making it in effect a draft law that will be presented for approval by the 12 members and by the European Parliament. The plan conditions European application of the taxes to application by other nations, including the United States and Japan, but leaves the door open to proceed even if this does not happen. Washington objects to this attempt to link United States policy to European policy.
 
Anger at Europe
 In the days before the plan was announced, Mr. Ripa de Meana said in a recent interview, United States diplomats complained that the condition would make the European Community look good at the Earth Summit while "embarrassing" Washington.
"We have let the Community know that whatever it does, we have no intention of imposing an energy tax for a period of time," said an United States diplomat in Brussels.
Major Middle East oil producers have been outspoken in denouncing the plan as an unfriendly act and have threatened trade sanctions. Their complaints dominated a recent meeting in Kuwait of Persian Gulf states and European Community ministers.
Oman and other oil exporters have since suggested raising crude oil prices by $3 a barrel, in effect to reap the tax benefits for themselves.
The sharpest criticism has come from the Saudi oil minister, Hisham Nazir, who told Community foreign ministers that the energy tax was "yet another form of excise tax to raise government receipts." The 12 community governments earned $210 billion from oil taxes last year, more than three times the value of their oil imports, he said.
 
Europeans Divided
 The executive commission in Brussels is recommending that the income from energy taxes be used for incentives to protect the environment. It also notes that the levy will weigh most on the dirtiest fuels, the coal and lignite that are still widely used in Europe.
In Northern Europe, governments are already starting to impose energy taxes, and economists there are also deeply involved in the complicated process of recalculating the prices of many goods and services to reflect environmental costs.
The 12 governments who must approve the tax are divided.
The Germans, who lead the drive in favor of the tax, are strongly supported by the Danes and the Dutch. Most opposed are Spain, Greece and Portugal, which have shown little interest in environment issues and worry about their growth. Spain, the most militant opponent, fears adverse effects on its ailing coal industry.
Reactions by industrial and trade lobbies have been mixed.
Many argue that environmental taxes will put them at a competitive disadvantage. Last year, when the Netherlands said it would impose energy taxes regardless of Community action, seven large corporations threatened to take their business elsewhere.
In Germany, the Federation of German Industries has said it is against taxes in just one or a few countries, but will go along if applied throughout the European Community.
In their analyses and forecasts, European industries increasingly uphold the example of Japan, which has among the highest energy prices but is also the world's most energy-efficient nation. And Japan, they note, is already rushing to turn environmental technology into a boom industry.
But in the short run, the question of competitiveness haunts European industries. To soften the blow, Brussels proposes selective exemptions for the biggest energy consumers, like glass, aluminum and paper industries, provided they implement their own plans to curb energy use and emissions.
 
The Practical Effects
 The plan could widen the gap between American and European energy prices and possibly pollution levels. The community, with 340 million inhabitants, accounts for 13 percent of global carbon dioxide; the United States, with 240 million people accounts for close to 23 percent. Gasoline prices in Europe are already three to four times higher than in the United States.
Brussels experts reckon that the plan would most affect utilities and industries because it would push up the price of natural gas by one-third and of coal by almost 60 percent. It would add 6 percent to gasoline prices at the pump and 11 percent to prices of diesel oil. Home electricity bills would rise by almost 13 percent.
Other measures in the plan include energy-saving standards for cars, appliances, factories, homes and offices. The executive commission in Brussels has also announced new backing for research on other energy sources and said it hoped to raise such sources from 4 percent to 8 percent in the 12 years.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 2, 1992, Tuesday

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Europe's environmental debate misstated the number of gallons in a barrel of oil. It is 42, not 55.

HEADLINE: Board Room Back-Scratching?

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
At first glance, the latest proxy statement from the B. F. Goodrich Company sounds all the right notes in the executive pay debate. It details for the first time how the company links pay and performance and boasts that executive pay is reviewed by a board committee that "consists entirely of outside directors."
What the proxy does not spotlight is that until a year ago one of the outside directors who helped set the pay for Goodrich's chief executive, John D. Ong, was Joseph A. Pichler, the chief executive of the Kroger Company - whose compensation committee included Mr. Ong as an outside director. Thus, Mr. Pichler's $890,370 pay for 1991 was partly determined by a man whose own $905,113 pay Mr. Pichler helped set.
Such interlocking arrangements, which are difficult to detect from public documents, do not in themselves constitute impropriety. Indeed, Mr. Ong's 1991 pay dropped by about a million dollars from 1990. 
Yet in a year when politicians, investors and even the Japanese are pointing to executive pay as a symbol of corporate America's ills, the potential for conflicts is being singled out by some shareholder activists and others as evidence that some board rooms are closed societies where friends often decide sensitive issues among themselves.
"That's the worst sort of potential conflict of interest, when you're serving on each other's jury to determine compensation," said Thomas J. Neff. President of Spencer Stuart, an executive search firm that conducts about 50 director searches a year in the United States. "There's the temptation and the risk of not being objective."
A recent computer search of the proxy statements of the 788 largest public companies by Directorship, a Westport, Conn., consulting firm, disclosed 39 instances, or nearly 5 percent, where heads of companies sit on each other's boards. Five of those couplings have unusual influence over each other's pay since they also sit on each other's compensation committees.
Besides Goodrich and Kroger, they are Conagra Inc. and Valmont Industries; the Kellogg Company and the Upjohn Company; the Sonoco Products Company and the Nationsbank Corporation, and Allergan Inc. and Beckman Instruments Inc.
It is only in the last few years that computers have been enlisted to help analyze the minutiae contained in corporate documents that disclose executive pay. But sociologists, business historians and others who have studied the issue believe that the incidence of interlocking directorships has remained fairly constant since the early part of the century, when the fear was collusion.
Catapulting the issue back into the spotlight today is the public's concern over the spectacle of an already well-paid corporate elite more preoccupied with their pay packages than corporate performance. Now, there is growing apprehension that those charged with policing pay are not always independent.
The mere presence of interlocking directors does not automatically raise improprieties. Indeed senior executives at 3 of the 10 companies in question including Goodrich saw their total compensation tumble in 1991, while the others for the most part took home pay packages that were roughly clustered around the $2 million or so that the average chief executive earned in those years. But the abundance of interlocking directorships may be symptomatic of some of the deeper problems in the board room.
Not surprisingly, 5 of the 10 companies with interlocking compensation committee members include other members whose independence could be questioned. For instance, 4 of the 10 companies have executives on their compensation committees whose business dealings with the company are extensive enough that they have to be disclosed in the proxy statements. Relatives on Committee
Sonoco Products, a packaging concern based in Hartsville, S.C., describes the members of its compensation committees as nonemployees of the company. Nonetheless, it has one executive on its compensation committee who once worked for the company and another whose objectivity could very well be tested: He is F .L. H. Coker, brother of the chief executive, C. W. Coker.
The company does show some restraint. Also on its board, though not on its compensation committee, is a third Coker, J. L., the chief executive's cousin, and a fourth director, J. C. Fort, whom a company spokesman described as a distant relative of Mr. Coker, though that fact is omitted from the proxy. A Coker family ancestor founded the company, although none of the four descendants on the board individually own more than 2 percent of the company's stock.
And indeed, the precise makeup of the committee may be moot. According to the proxy, the committee annually "reviews the salaries of executive officers and recommends increases as deemed appropriate." The possibility of salary decreases is never broached.
"Last year was just about the second time in over 20 years when our earnings from continuing operations didn't better the previous year," said Richard Puffer, Sonoco's spokesman. "So, we normally do have increases."
Asked about the propriety of these symbiotic relationships, the 10 companies insisted that such people should be counted as outside directors so long as they were not currently on the payroll.
Even Goodrich and Kroger, which took Mr. Ong and Mr. Pichler off each other's compensation committees last year, defended the arrangement while it lasted and explained the moves as nothing more than the normal rotation of committee assignments. "The important thing to focus on is whether the company's compensation program is performance-based, and ours is," said Gary Habegger, Goodrich's vice president for human resources. "If it is, you have much less chance for that type of situation to be a real issue."
Two companies, Nationsbank and Valmont, do not contend that their compensation committees consist exclusively of outsiders. After all, Nationsbank's chief executive, Hugh L. McColl Jr., serves on his company's compensation committee and Valmont's chairman and biggest shareholder, Robert B. Daugherty, sits on his company's committee.
Spokesmen for both companies point out that neither man is chairman of his respective committee and that they abstain whenever their own pay is discussed. "If they were the sole members of the compensation committee, you'd have a point," said Brian Stanley, the treasurer of Valmont, a metal fabricator outside Omaha. "But when we have six people, it's just not an issue."
Most companies are free to put anyone they please on their compensation committee -- since there is no Federal requirement to even form a committee. "If you do your compensation by throwing darts against the wall, as long as you disclose it, you've fulfilled your duties," said John D. Heine, a spokesman for the Securities and Exchange Commission.
That regulatory attitude may be one reason why 75, or 9.5 percent, of the 788 companies in the Directorship study report that their chairmen serve on the panels that decide their pay. Even people who are very much part of the business establishment say that such committee configurations create unfortunate appearance problems. Indeed, the Business Roundtable, a group of the leaders of several major companies, recommended as much as two years ago that compensation committees should "limit membership to nonmanagement directors only."
Not doing that "opens you up for a lot of difficult scrutiny," said Thomas F. Madison, the president of markets for U S West Communications and a director who serves on several compensation committees, including Valmont's. Though he said he ordinarily would not tolerate having the chief executive on the compensation committee, he said Valmont was a special case since Mr. Daugherty dropped the chief executive's title in 1988 and drew relatively little compensation from the company.
Since chief executives have exactly the sort of experience that other bosses value, many shareholders say they would tolerate having a few chief executives in the mix.
But how tough might a watchdog be when the object of surveillance can always retaliate? "It would just be very difficult for the type of independence that is required of a board member to exist in that kind of environment," said Ralph V. Whitworth, president of the United Shareholders Association.
Further skewing how much chief executives take home on average is the tendency of many companies to deliberately set pay above their industry average to prevent defections. "That process of peer adustment is a problem to me as an economist because I see what it does to the average," said M. Kathryn Eickhoff, an economist who serves on the boards of five large public companies, including Upjohn.
The other culprit, in her view, is not interlocking directorships like the one that exists between Upjohn and Kellogg but simply the sheer number of chief executives who serve on compensation committees.
"I wonder whether it is too easy for them to rationalize the salaries being suggested," she said. "It seems to me it's easier to find such salaries acceptable if you've previously received one." Regional Patterns Seen
Another common pattern is that interlocking directors tend to be part of tight regional clusters, such as Conagra and Valmont, both Nebraska companies. "We're a fairly small town and we don't have many public companies that would be called industrials, so there's not a great variety of locals to draw from," said Charles M. Harper, chief executive of Conagra and a member of the compensation committee of Valmont.
Personally, he does not see anything wrong with looking close to home for directorial talent. "If I trusted somebody, I don't care if they were a second cousin to the c.e.o.," said Mr. Harper, who predicts that his own fiscal year 1992 compensation will be down significantly, as he believes it should, given this year's performance. "The way to test that from a shareholder's point of view is what are the results, and how does compensation track with results?"

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION (92%); BOARDS OF DIRECTORS (90%); EXECUTIVES (90%); WAGES & SALARIES (90%); CORPORATE GOVERNANCE (90%); CONFLICTS OF INTEREST (77%); HISTORY (73%); SOCIOLOGY (70%); COMPUTER EQUIPMENT (68%); EMPLOYMENT SERVICES (64%)

HEADLINE: PENTAGON ANALYST QUESTIONS TIMING FOR MISSILE SHIELD

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
The Pentagon's top program analyst says a $35 billion plan to protect the nation from nuclear attack with land-based interceptors calls for a hasty deployment that could create costly and crippling problems.
The criticism of the "Star Wars" plan, the sharpest to date by a senior Defense Department official, might fray or break a coalition on Capitol Hill that last year endorsed the building of limited missile defenses after the antimissile battles of the Persian Gulf war. 
 The official, Dr. David S. C. Chu, Assistant Secretary of Defense for program analysis and evaluation, says in an internal Pentagon document that the plan risks failure by rushing the development of rocket-powered interceptors and skipping important performance tests. That, he wrote, could hide defects that would cripple the system or lead to costly repairs.
 
Six-Year Delay Possible
 In his analysis Dr. Chu said the plan should be overhauled to delay the system's debut by as much as six years, from 1997 to the year 2003, so that prototype arms and other antimissile apparatus could be thoroughly tested, and modified if necessary, before being put into mass production.
Rejecting such criticism, the plan's architects say they remain confident that an initial system can be fielded by 1997. But they concede that the goal of speedy deployment with abbreviated testing carries many risks.
"The issue is whether you can manage that risk in a responsible way," Dr. Henry F. Cooper, director of the antimissile effort, said in an interview on Friday. "I think that's achievable," with the result that a missile defense system could be put in place without significant cost overruns, schedule slips or technical flaws.
But John E. Pike, director of space policy at the Federation of American Scientists, a private group in Washington, said Dr. Chu's analysis suggested that no credible defense against nuclear attack could be built in less than a decade.
"It's saying that any system deployed in this century isn't going to work, that the current plan is a procurement disaster in the making," Mr. Pike said. Leaders of the antimissile effort, he added, "basically want to decide what to build before they test it, and hope they guessed right."
Dr. Chu's analysis was made available to a reporter by an analyst who views the antimissile plan as flawed and who wanted to call attention to high-level Pentagon doubts about it.
The disputed plan is the main legacy of the "Star Wars" program, begun nearly a decade ago by President Ronald Reagan to build a space- and land-based defense against a missile attack. With the end of the cold war, the general goal of the "Star Wars" program has shifted, from one that would have created an impenetrable shield against thousands of Soviet warheads to forging a defense against accidental launchings and attacks by rogue commanders and renegade nations.
 
$4.15 Billion This Year
 The program's cost this year is $4.15 billion, a record high. Annual costs are expected to double as research gives way to production of batteries of interceptors. The plan for land-based interceptors is the only part of the initiative to be endorsed by Congress, which is bitterly divided over the merits of arms based in space.
The current deployment plan was proposed last year by Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Senate Armed Services Committee. Inspired by the Patriot interceptor in the Persian Gulf war, he successfully pushed Congress to approve the building of similar but larger land-based interceptors to defend the nation, if possible by 1996.
The Missile Defense Act was signed into law by President Bush in December. Dr. Cooper of the Strategic Defense Initiative Organization, which runs the antimissile research program, recently testified before Congress about how the agency would meet the act's requirements.
Its plan would delay the launching of space arms but would have one land-based battery of interceptors ready in 1997. The battery site would have 100 interceptors housed in underground silos, ready to blast into space.
More complete protection of the United States from a variety of threats would require seven sites across the country with some 700 interceptors in all, agency officials say. They put the cost at $35 billion.
The rocket-powered interceptors would have non-nuclear warheads that use advanced sensors to pinpoint a target, which would then be destroyed on impact with the warhead.
The challenge in developing such a system was illustrated on March 13 when an experimental interceptor called Eris blasted off from Kwajalein atoll in the Western Pacific but, because of technical errors, failed to hit a mock warhead in space. Eris is the general prototype for the proposed system of land-based interceptors.
The deployment plan recently came under the scrutiny of Dr. Chu, who in essence is the Pentagon's technical conscience, studying arms programs to make them more efficient as they move from research to production. He reports to the Secretary of Defense, and draws on a force of about 100 analysts.
Dr. Chu, a Yale-educated economist, has directed program analysis and evaluation since 1981 and has a reputation for rigor. In the early 1980's he insisted that the Army subject its division air defense gun, or Divad, to strenuous field tests that it ultimately failed; in 1985 the $1.8 billion program was canceled.
 
Plan Called Too Risky
 Writing on May 15 to Donald J. Yockey, Under Secretary of Defense for acquisition, Dr. Chu warned that the $35 billion plan for interceptor deployment was too risky and "almost certain to suffer early, significant cost growth and schedule slippage" because little of the initial apparatus would be tested thoroughly before manufacturing. The emerging system, he wrote, thus might have to undergo extensive repairs and revisions.
Worse, Dr. Chu wrote, the plan could produce interceptors and other antimissile hardware that were "technologically inferior" and unable to adequately defend the nation.
In addition, he wrote, speeding the program to achieve the 1997 deployment date would require exemption from more than a dozen laws and directives that govern the purchase of military equipment.
Dr. Chu recommended an alternative plan in which prototype hardware would be subjected to "a rigorous test program" and its experimental data used to forge final designs, pushing back the date of initial antimissile deployments to the years 2002 or 2003.
While private experts and some members of Congress have recently expressed alarm over possible technical risks and cost overruns in the proposed land-based system, this is believed to be the first time such criticisms have been leveled by a senior Pentagon official.
 
Both Cautious and Confident
 Five days after Dr. Chu's analysis was sent to Under Secretary Yockey, Dr. Cooper, the head of the antimissile program, summarized the plan before Congress in testimony that was alternately cautious and confident.
"Meeting the 1997 date represents a major challenge," Dr. Cooper said May 20 in a statement to a subcommittee of the Senate Armed Services Committee. But he added, "I believe the risk, although high, is acceptable given the urgency related to our uncertainty in predicting when we might actually be threatened with ballistic missile attack."
He said he would press for "an acceleration of the normal acquisition processes and procedures in light of the very high priority assigned by the Congress to meeting the goals" of the Missile Defense Act.
In the interview on Friday, Dr. Cooper said past arms programs had succeeded even though their testing and production had been accelerated, pointing to the Pershing II missile as an example.
But Mr. Pike of the Federation of American Scientists said a successful quickening of the antimissile program was highly unlikely, given its past difficulties. "Most tests," he said, "have been behind schedule and failed or had major shortcomings."

HEADLINE: Bush, Trying to Counter Criticism, Offers Plan to Save Earth's Forests

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GREENBELT, Md., June 1

 BODY:
Seeking to counter foreign and domestic criticism of his environmental record, President Bush presented a new program today to conserve the world's dwindling forests, a crucial issue at this month's Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro.
Standing at a NASA research center before a huge blue photograph of the earth taken from space, Mr. Bush said the White House would increase its aid to other nations' forestry programs by $150 million, to $270 million, starting in the fiscal year that begins in October. 
 He also challenged other nations to double spending on forest conservation to $2.7 billion annually, to halt the worldwide loss of trees.
Today's actions, details of which had been circulated over the weekend, were described by Mr. Bush as part of a commitment to improve the quality of the environment without affecting economic growth.
But they were also clearly aimed at critics who have charged the White House with trying to weaken domestic environmental laws and sabotaging the goals of the Earth Summit by withholding support for forceful language in proposed treaties.
As delegates to the summit meeting began to gather in Rio de Janeiro today, the Brazilian press painted the Bush Administration as an environmental villain. [Page A10.]
As recently as Sunday, Mr. Bush was calling such critics "extremists" and saying he would not rely on "unsound science" to make basic decisions about global warming and other environmental issues.
"I came to this office committed to extend America's record of environmental leadership and I've worked to do so in a way that is compatible with economic growth," Mr. Bush said today, "because this balance is absolutely essential, and because these are twin goals, not mutually exclusive objectives."
Mr. Bush's words reflected a continuing struggle at the top of his Administration over environmental politics. On one side are his most conservative advisers, who view most environmental rules as a drag on the economy and want to appeal to business and industry executives. On the other side are some senior political advisers who are wary of alienating a large environmentalist constituency in the middle of Mr. Bush's re-election campaign.
In his speech today, Mr. Bush also announced three other measures to combat the warming of the earth's atmosphere:
*He pledged to establish a Technology Cooperation Corps of United States business experts to survey the environmental needs of developing nations and to find ways to introduce new pollution-control technologies.
*He offered to help pay for studies of developing nations to determine what policy changes would make it easier to cut emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases.
*He promised to distribute thousands of computer discs at Rio with scientific data from United States studies of global warming. Data from satellite studies by NASA of the Earth's climate will be offered soon to scientists and governments worldwide to support new research into changes in climate, he said.
 
Urged Less Strict Controls
 Last month, Mr. Bush successfully wielded a threat to boycott the Earth Summit to win concessions from most of the world's nations on a global warming treaty, eliminating language that would have required the United States to cap its emissions of carbon dioxide by 2000 at 1990 levels. The treaty now calls for "action plans" to reduce emissions of gases that are thought to promote global warming, but does not mandate reductions.
The Administration's plan leaves open the prospect of capping all the greenhouse gases at 1990 levels, but suggests that United States emissions of carbon dioxide, by far the most threatening of the gases, will rise by about 6 percent.
Only last week, the Administration announced that it would not sign the other major treaty at the Rio meeting, which calls for new measures to slow the extinction of plants and animals. The State Department said the Administration objected to language decreeing how preservation would be financed and to other measures that were said to injure industry in the United States and impinge on patent rights.
 
Focus on Forests
 Administration officials today depicted the new forest-conservation program as an alternative to the strictures of both treaties. New forests, they said, would reduce global levels of carbon dioxide faster than mandated pollution controls. And they argued that the program would save more threatened species because forests already are home to half the world's plants and animals.
The reaction from many environmental leaders and political critics was harsh. The Sierra Club and the Wilderness Society called Mr. Bush's announcements hypocrisy, and several groups noted that the United States had opposed an international agreement on forest preservation that was to have been offered at Rio.
Some also noted that the Administration had recently moved to allow clear-cutting of old-growth forests in the Pacific Northwest and to allow limited logging in Oregon forests that are home to the endangered northern spotted owl. Both actions have come under strong attack from environmentalists.
 
Losing 1.5 Acres Each Second
 Still, the President won some guarded praise for focusing on the loss of forests, one of the most serious and stubborn problems.
The Earth loses an average of 1.5 acres of forest each second to lumbering and land-clearing operations, or a space roughly equal to the State of Washington each year. Forests prevent erosion, stem drought, store carbon dioxide and purify rain water.
Mr. Bush has sent letters outlining his program to leaders in major industrial nations and hopes to have a good sense of the world's response by the time he leaves Brazil in mid-June, Administration sources said.
"The forest plan is the basis for a good program," Gustave Speth, president of the World Resources Institute in Washington, said of the proposal. "It has the germ of a good idea. But there are some significant flaws in the plan. It's much too narrowly focused on the forest sector and on the funding issue."
Beyond increasing spending on existing efforts to preserve forests, Mr. Speth said, the Administration should try to change development policies that encourage tree-cutting in developing nations. And it should work harder to ease the debt problems that drag down those economies, forcing the poor to subsist by clearing forest land.
Senator Albert Gore Jr., Democrat of Tennessee, derided the plan as "a diversion."
"I'm not sure I'd put the trees in my backyard in his care, because I'm not convinced he wouldn't have a chain saw in his trunk," Mr. Gore said.

He spoke earlier with William K. Reilly, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times) (pg. A10)
