HEADLINE: New York's Teen-Agers Face Worst Job Market in Decades

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
The job market for New York City teen-agers is the worst in memory and shows few signs of immediate improvement, government labor experts and business executives say.
Across the nation, the percentage of young people who have jobs has fallen sharply during the recession. But the problem is most acute, the experts say, in New York, where only slightly more than 1 in 10 youths is working. 
 The city's employment rate for 16- to 19-year-olds for the first three months of this year was 12.6 percent, compared with a 37 percent average for the United States.
 
Fewer Entry-Level Jobs
 No comparable figures are available yet for other major cities for the same period. But for all of 1991, New York's employment rate for teen-agers was 16.9 percent, lower than the rates in Chicago, Detroit and Los Angeles.
Analysts say some of the reasons for the problem include fewer entry-level jobs for workers of all ages and tougher competition for those jobs because of the increasing number of immigrants. "This economy has been bad for everyone, and teen-agers are at the bottom," said Eli Ginzberg, a labor economist at Columbia University.
Chris Lewis, 18, of the Bronx, said he has searched in vain in the last month for maintenance work in Manhattan, where he believes the pay is better. Not having a high school diploma, he said, has been his biggest liability.
"Before, I didn't run into that problem so much," he said. "But now I see they are looking for older people with more training. I'm a little bit worried."
New York's job market has always been a tough one for teen-agers, particularly as manufacturing jobs declined sharply over the last 40 years. The percentage of 16- to 19-year-olds with jobs in New York City was more than 30 percent in the late 1960's, but it has fallen almost steadily since then, statistics from the United States Department of Labor show. The 12.6 percent employment rate for New York for the first quarter of this year, the department said, was the worst ever recorded for the age category.
"Our parents just don't understand," said Robert Hargrove, a 21-year-old who lives in Long Island City, Queens, and who said he spent three years searching for a job before finding one for this summer as a camp counselor in Westchester County. "It is a lot harder these days."
John Ottulich, vice president of York Ladder Inc., a distributor of construction supplies in Queens, said that "with so many adults out of work, it is difficult to rationalize hiring as many young people as we used to." He said his company has been hiring teen-agers to load trucks in the summer for more than 20 years. In 1988, he said, the company hired five. This year, it plans to hire two.
 
Scrambling for Jobs
 A combination of geographic and economic factors have wracked the city's job market for teen-agers, labor experts say.
In addition to the decline in manufacturing jobs in the last few decades, other industries that provided many of the city's entry-level jobs have fallen off precipitiously since the onset of the recession in 1988. Chief among them is retail sales, where young people have always been sought for weekend and after-school work but where a raft of department-store closings has left experienced sales clerks scrambling for jobs.
Jamoda Fuller, a 20-year-old freshman at York College in Queens, said she has spent a year applying to clothing shops and jewelry stores for part-time or full-time work. But so far she has come up empty.
Computers and telecommunications have also taken a toll, making thousands of entry-level jobs obsolete. Where teen-agers once found work as clerks, telephone operators and messengers, now the fax machines, phone mail systems and computerized data processing are abuzz.
And because most of the city's jobs are concentrated in the office towers of Manhattan while most of its young people are concentrated in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx, after-school and part-time jobs are harder to get to than in many other cities.
The problem of geography has been underlined by the shift of retailing, data processing and corporate services to suburban malls and offices over the last decade.
Business executives say part of the blame for low levels of youth employment lies with the schools, which they maintain do not provide even the minimal level of literacy and job skills. Faced with that, employers in some cases are relying on more experienced workers, who are paid higher wages, to do menial tasks in addition to their regular duties. In other cases, with no shortage of job-seekers, the employers are simply hiring older, more qualified workers.
 
Reflection of Problem
 "The irony is that the jobs are there, but 16- to 19-year-olds are not qualified," said Ronald Shelp, president of New York City Partnership, a business group that sponsors the city's largest program to match teen-agers with summer jobs.
In a reflection of the problem, a survey of 300 businesses in the city in September by Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm, found that a large majority of them considered the quality of mid- and upper-level workers in the city as good as or better than elsewhere. But when asked to assess entry-level employees' performance, 42 percent found them as good as or better than elsewhere, and 37 percent said they were worse.
Another reason that few New York teen-agers are working may be because not that many bother to look, believing that entry-level jobs pay too little when some movies cost $7 and a shearling coat may cost several hundred.
 
Influx of Immigrants
 "New York kids aren't stupid," said Vernon M. Briggs, a labor economist at Cornell University. He said the influx of immigrants willing to work long hours for low wages has kept entry-level wages low, just as it has also reduced the number of openings available to teen-agers.
"To an immigrant willing to work two or three jobs at once, $5 an hour may not look bad," he said. "But to a kid from Brooklyn or the Bronx, it is a turnoff."
Federal labor statistics show that employment of youths 16 to 19 years old has traditionally been lower in New York City than across the nation. Beginning in the late 1960's, the New York City rate fell from slightly over 30 percent to 16.9 percent last year and 12.6 percent for the first quarter of this year.
Other cities fared better. The employment rate for teen-agers last year was 23.6 percent in Detroit, 29.5 percent in Los Angeles and 32.2 percent in Houston.
Even the summer jobs program sponsored by the New York City Partnership, now in its 11th year, has felt the employment pinch. More than 100 New York companies, from large corporations and small businesses, participate in the program by offering teen-agers summer jobs.
The program provided rising numbers of jobs for teen-agers from 1981 to 1990, when 52,913 jobs were filled. Jobs offered through the program began to wane last year, to 45,852. Now, Mr. Shelp said, the group hopes to find 45,000 jobs for teen-agers this summer, slightly fewer than last year.
"We think we will make it, but it is tough going," he said. "This is the worst market we've seen."

HEADLINE: High Court Gives Airline Industry Victory Over States on Fare Ads

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
In a victory for the airline industry, the Supreme Court ruled today that states may not regulate the way airlines advertise their fares.
The 5-to-3 decision, upholding a ruling last year by a Federal appeals court, came in a long-running battle between the airlines and a national organization representing the attorneys general of all 50 states. 
 The state officials, who in most states are responsible for enforcing consumer protection laws, sought the right to prohibit airline advertising that they consider misleading and to require prominent disclosure of the restrictions and surcharges that are often attached to the advertised offers of low air fares.
 
U.S. Rules Called Lax
 Airline advertising is already regulated by a Federal agency, the Department of Transportation, which prohibits airlines from making deceptive claims about their fares. The state attorneys general, however, have regarded the Federal standards as lax and Federal enforcement as lacking, and they wanted a specific code of disclosures.
The dispute between the airlines and the attorneys general dates to 1987, when the National Association of Attorneys General adopted a set of guidelines for applying general consumer protection laws to the particular problems of airline passengers.
For example, the guidelines called for requiring that disclosures of restrictions and conditions on the availability of low-fare seats be made in a particular size of type. The guidelines also provided that if seats at an advertised fare were not actually going to be available in quantities sufficient to "meet reasonably foreseeable demand" on every flight, the advertisement had to disclose that in a "clear and conspicuous" way.
The decision today, written by Justice Antonin Scalia, was based on an interpretation of the 1978 Federal law that deregulated the airline industry. Congress, wanting to make sure that the states did not take up the regulatory role that the Government was abandoning, put into the law a clause prohibiting the states from enacting any rules "relating to rates, routes or services of any air carrier."
The question for the Court was whether the phrase "relating to rates" simply barred the states from regulating fares, as the states argued, or whether its meaning was broad enough to keep the states from regulating the advertising of air fares as well.
Justice Scalia wrote that "we note that our decision does not give the airlines carte blanche to lie to and deceive consumers." He added that the Transportation Department had the authority to prohibit advertisements, "which in its opinion do not further competitive pricing."
A brief filed in the case by the Bush Administration, which supported the airlines, said that in nine enforcement actions since 1985, the department had imposed $265,000 in penalties against airlines for unfair or deceptive advertising.
 
Economic Analysis Accepted
 Justice Scalia accepted the airlines' analysis of the economic impact of such regulations. The airlines argued that the restrictions and disclosures would interfere with their ability to adjust the mix of fares in response to demand and market conditions.
Justice Scalia noted that the airlines' marketing strategy was to sell as many high-priced seats as possible to business travelers who are not particularly sensitive to price, and then to use advertising to sell the rest of the seats at low prices with conditions attached. The attorneys generals' guidelines "may make it impossible to use this marketing process at all," he said.
On the issue of the phrasing of the 1978 law, Justice Scalia cited a legal dictionary for the definition of the phrase "relating to." He concluded that "the ordinary meaning of these words is a broad one," meaning to pertain or refer to, and that "the words thus express a broad pre-emptive purpose."
He noted that the Court, in interpreting the identical phrase in the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, had found extensive Federal pre-emption of state laws on the subject of pensions and employee benefit plans. "We think it appropriate to adopt the same standard here," he said.
The majority opinion was joined by Justices Byron R. White, Sandra Day O'Connor, Anthony M. Kennedy and Clarence Thomas. Justice John Paul Stevens filed a dissenting opinion that Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justice Harry A. Blackmun joined.
 
Souter Isn't a Participant
 Justice David H. Souter did not participate in the case. He gave no reason, but as a former Attorney General of New Hampshire, he may have considered himself too closely tied to one side in the case.
The decision, Morales v. Trans World Airlines, No. 90-1604, came in a lawsuit brought by T.W.A., Continental Airlines and British Airways against the State of Texas, which in 1988 had threatened the airlines with a lawsuit for failing to comply with the state's laws governing deceptive advertising and trade practices.
A Federal District Court in Texas issued an injunction barring Texas and 33 other states from taking action against the airlines. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans, upheld the injunction last year.
The Supreme Court today limited its ruling to the fare-advertising question, setting aside other aspects of the injunction on the ground that the state had not threatened to bring any other legal action against the airlines.
The dissenters to today's decision said the majority had interpreted the pre-emption provision of the Federal law in a way "that is neither compelled by its text nor supported by its legislative history."
There were these other developments at the Court today:
 
Interstate Waste
 The Court ruled, 8 to 1, that states may not discriminate against other states in providing for waste disposal.
With only Chief Justice Rehnquist dissenting, the opinion by Justice White invalidated a special fee of $72 a ton that Alabama had imposed on all hazardous waste shipped from other states to a commercial hazardous-waste landfill at Emelle, Ala., the biggest such landfill in the country.
The decision, Chemical Waste Management v. Hunt, No. 91-471, was based on the constitutional prohibition of state barriers to interstate commerce. "No state may attempt to isolate itself from a problem common to the several states by raising barriers to the free flow of interstate trade," Justice White said.
The decision overturned a ruling by the Alabama Supreme Court. The appeal was brought by Chemical Waste Management Inc., an Illinois company that owns the Emelle landfill and had sued the state over the out-of-state fee.
 
Redistricting
 The Court agreed to decide a potentially important Ohio redistricting case that could set new rules on whether black voters and members of other minorities can or should be concentrated into districts in which they make up a large majority. In the current round of redistrictings, Republicans in many states have advocated this as a way of making suburban districts more white and presumably more reliably Republican.
The Ohio case, Voinovich v. Quilter, No. 91-1618, typifies this trend. A Republican-dominated reapportionment board drew new state legislative districts with heavy concentrations of black voters, eliminating a dozen racially integrated districts in which blacks, while not a majority, were in a position to influence the outcome of elections. A three-judge Federal District Court ruled earlier this year that by "packing" minority voters into a small number of districts without adequate justification, the plan violated the Voting Rights Act.
Gov. George V. Voinovich, a Republican, appealed to the Supreme Court. The Court earlier issued a stay of the District Court decision, and is not likely to decide the case until after the November election.
In a second redistricting case, the Court today upheld, without a written opinion, the new district lines for the four Congressional districts in Arkansas. The districts were challenged by a group of black voters on the ground that no district had a substantial enough black population to influence the outcome of elections. The case was Turner v. Arkansas, No. 91-1615.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
CLINTON IS FACING A DIFFICULT HURDLE IN CALIFORNIA VOTE

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., June 1

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, who has had more than his share of discouraging news in the last five months, could get some more from the California Presidential primary on Tuesday.
The experts still expect him to win. Indeed, he seems sure to pick up, here and in the five other primaries on the schedule, far more than the 167 delegates that he needs, according to the latest New York Times tally, to assure him a first-ballot majority at the Democratic convention in New York City next month. More than 700 delegates are at stake in the six tests. 
 But he had hoped to sprint, not limp, across the finish line, and he may be hard pressed to do it. A disappointing showing by Mr. Clinton here in the nation's largest state, whose big block of electoral votes are considered essential to a Democratic victory in November, would constitute a psychological downer for his party.
 
Clinton Has Narrow Lead
 The final California Poll of the primary campaign, made public today, showed Mr. Clinton with a relatively narrow lead over his sole remaining party rival, former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, who was written off as a major force in the race after the New York primary two months ago. Among likely voters, the survey found, the Arkansas Governor led by only 35 percent to 28.
In an apparent reflection of the surging popularity of Ross Perot, the presumed independent candidate, the poll showed former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, long since withdrawn from the race, at 17 percent, other candidates at 9 percent, and undecided voters at 11 percent. The margin of sampling error in the statewide survey, conducted Wednesday through Saturday, was 5 percentage points in either direction.
Mr. Perot's name is not on the ballot, but those of Mr. Tsongas and others still are.
 
California's Distinctive Vision
 In the past Democratic nominees have run weak primary races in this state, which has always had a distinctive political vision. Several, including Jimmy Carter on two occasions, have actually lost the primary and gone on to easy nominations.
But Mr. Clinton arrived in California in poorer political health than his predecessors, looking for a cure. Mr. Brown is also a weaker foe than Gary Hart or Edward M. Kennedy or others who have scored upsets here.
Until a month or so ago, Mr. Brown was considered by some to be the favorite in California, his home state, although he was the subject of controversy during his time as Governor. But the rules of the expectations game changed when Mr. Brown lost much of his national following after he took a drubbing in New York, then failed to recover in the primary in Pennsylvania.
So if Mr. Clinton loses this time, or only narrowly edges Mr. Brown, or sees his own vote fall below 40 percent, he may stir some fresh speculation within his party about an alternative candidate. That will be especially true if surveys of voters leaving the polls show a large write-in, officially uncounted, for Mr. Perot, and show Mr. Clinton running third in a three-way trial heat for the fall against Mr. Perot and President Bush.
In theory, the superdelegates could turn against Mr. Clinton and deny him the nomination. Of the 1,978 votes credited to him in a tally by The Times, 433 are those of superdelegates; if a significant portion of those deserted him and joined with the uncommitted delegates and superdelegates, who number more than 650, Mr. Clinton's momentum might be stopped. But that would require an alternative candidate and a strategist willing to organize such a move. Neither is in sight.
A weak showing by Mr. Clinton is far more likely to slow his preparation for the convention and the general election, and to give further scope to Mr. Perot's insurgency, than it is to cost him the nomination.
The Arkansas Governor has gone all out in the final week of the campaign to achieve an impressive victory here. He had planned to spend some time over the weekend in Ohio and New Jersey, but changed his schedule to concentrate on California.
Today, Mr. Clinton campaigned in Fresno, in the agriculturally rich Central Valley; in Los Angeles, and in this economically troubled city across the bay from San Francisco.
At a lunchtime rally here, he was welcomed by local officials and a raucous crowd. Portraying himself as a Washington outsider, he appealed to voters to "take our political system back" and accused the Bush Administration of not being aggressive enough to help the environment.
But it has not been easy for him, even with a heavy schedule of television commercials, to catch the attention of the state's electorate.
Despite a pair of closely fought Senate races, and dozens of Congressional and state legislative primaries brought on by reapportionment, political participation is declining in California, which will chose 52 representatives in November, the largest delegation in American history.
As recently as 1976, the primary attracted a turnout of 72.6 percent of registered voters. Eight years later, in 1984, the turnout was 48.6 percent. On Tuesday, a turnout under 40 percent has been predicted, or not much more than half of the 1976 figure, and apparently a record low.
For all the efforts by Mr. Clinton and Mr. Brown, it has been Mr. Perot who has attracted the attention of the politically alienated voters in this state. Many of the tens of thousands of Californians who have signed his nominating petitions and put his bumper stickers on their cars describe themselves as people who have never voted or who gave up on the established parties several years ago.
Nationally, a new poll conducted by CBS News showed that in a three-way race Mr. Bush was favored by 35 percent of registered voters, while Mr. Clinton and Mr. Perot were tied for second with 27 and 26 percent support, respectively.
A previous poll, by The New York Times and CBS News in early May, showed Mr. Bush at 36 percent, Mr. Clinton at 30 percent and Mr. Perot at 25 percent.
 
People Want to Hear More
 In the new telephone poll of 1,347 adults, taken Wednesday to Saturday, voters said none of the three Presidential contenders have been clear on issues. Sixty-one percent of registered voters said Mr. Perot was not telling enough for them to judge what he would do if elected, 58 percent said that about Mr. Clinton and 62 percent even said that about the incumbent President. The survey had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points. Another new national poll today also showed Mr. Perot in a strong position. The survey by ABC News and The Washington Post that tested a three-man contest put Mr. Perot's backing at 36 percent, to 31 percent for Mr. Bush and 27 percent for Mr. Clinton. The differences between Mr. Perot and Mr. Bush, and between Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton, were within the poll's four-percentage-point margin of sampling error.

HEADLINE: India Is Facing Quandary in Plan to Dam a River

BYLINE: By SANJOY HAZARIKA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, June 1

 BODY:
When it was conceived in the 1940's and redesigned in the 1970's, the huge Narmada River hydroelectric dam project in central India was intended to supply a vast impoverished area with drinking and irrigation water.
Now the World Bank and the Indian Government have been forced to review their support of the $20 billion project because of pressure from Indian politicians, newspapers, environmentalists and hundreds of thousands of villagers whose homes would be wiped away if the Narmada River were dammed. 
 In addition, the World Bank and rich nations as well as the Indian Government are under pressure to develop cheaper and more environmentally sound energy alternatives. If it goes through, the Narmada project will be built over the next several decades, Indian officials said.
The Narmada River project is not simply a symbol of India's struggle to reconcile its growing demands for energy and development with concerns over protecting the environment.
 
India Seeks Leading Role
 With the approach of the world environmental summit meeting, which begins on Wednesday in Rio de Janeiro, India has tried to become a spokesman for developing countries that are demanding financial help from rich countries to help sustain their natural resources.
India's goals have not been made any easier by its critics at home, with environmentalists saying the Government's difficulty in balancing environmental issues shows a lack of development and conservation strategy.
"India is screaming its head off about the North's exploitation, but there is no commitment to set its own house in order," said Ashish Kothari, who has organized central Indian opposition to the Narmada project.
Indian officials defend their record, saying that they are prepared to turn the Rio conference into a forum for demands that the United States and other industrialized countries stop lecturing poor countries about the environment and start setting a better example themselves.
"At meeting after meeting, we have told the developed world, especially the United States, that the North has far greater responsibility to clean up its act," said Kamal Nath, India's State Environment Minister. "They have polluted the most, per capita and in gross national terms, and they should carry the burden of cleaning up."
Negotiators said it was difficult to explain to Western delegations that economic development and environmental protection cannot be separated.
"The developed world just cannot say, 'O.K., chaps, you freeze at the current state of development,' " said Chandrashekhar Dasgupta, a senior Indian diplomat and negotiator on the issue of global warming. "You cannot freeze people into permanent poverty while the West continues to sustain unsustainable life styles."
On the issue of global warming, India and other developing nations have asserted that Western nations must reduce their emissions of carbon dioxide instead of placing future limitations on emissions for poor countries.
Indian negotiators take credit for the fact that the draft treaty on climate issues, which sets goals for reducing emissions, states that nations that produce more pollution have a greater responsibility for cleaning up. But differences persist on financing, and the best that either side could muster in the draft climate convention was a bland declaration that financing would be voluntary. Mr. Nath, the Environment Minister, said that such an approach is unacceptable.
"If their reactions are voluntary, so will mine be," he said, insisting that the West first cut back on what he described as its wasteful life style. Mr. Nath said he would support moves by rich nations to subsidize programs to expand or protect forest areas in the third world as a means of reducing and combating carbon dioxide emissions by both sides.
The question of damage to the ozone layer from the use of chlorofluorocarbons -- gases used in refrigerators, air conditioners and aerosol sprays -- also rouses strong passions here. At current levels, India and China, with nearly two-fifths of the global population, produce only two percent of the world's chlorofluorocarbons. But their share is predicted to rise sharply in the next decades with their growing affluence and populations.
"India and China today account for more than one-third of the world's population," said Anil Aggarwal of the Center for Science and Environment, an Indian environmental group. "The question is whether we are consuming one-third of the world's resources or contributing one-third of the muck and dirt in the atmosphere or the oceans."

HEADLINE: Unions Ease Overhead At Javits Center Shows

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB

 BODY:
When Lloyd R. Reeder arrived to exhibit his company's lighting fixtures at a recent trade show in the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, he braced himself for clashes with workers over union rules, high costs and bribe demands.
Mr. Reeder recalled that at two previous shows in the hall, on the West Side, he was forced to pay carpenters $200 to install a prefabricated booth that he could quickly assemble by himself without a tool. An electrician charged him $70 to plug in a lamp and when it came time to leave, teamsters and other workers demanded payments of $50 to retrieve his packing crates. 
 "All of us used to dread coming to the Javits Center," said Mr. Reeder, who works for the Greenlee Lighting Company of Carrollton, Tex. "It was a nightmare."
 
A 'Stunning Surprise'
 But at the Lightfare trade show last month, Mr. Reeder found that the work rules had suddenly been relaxed, labor expenses had been sharply cut and no one even hinted at a bribe for routine services.
"It sure was a stunning surprise," he says now.
In the last several years, even as national trade-show business has remained steady despite the recession, the Javits Center has been losing business amid complaints like Mr. Reeder's: exorbitant costs, labor racketeering and bribery. Now, however, the center's management is campaigning to convince the trade-show industry that Mr. Reeder's stunning surprise was no aberration, that new labor agreements and a law-enforcement crackdown on racketeers will combine to make the hall a more affordable and hospitable place for exhibitors to bring their business.
 
Some Exhibitors Skeptical
 Still, trade organizations and show arrangers caution that it could take several years before business picks up at the center. The experts say that major trade shows and conventions are scheduled years in advance and that bookers will wait to see if costs drop significantly and abuses end.
One skeptic is Michael R. Hough, the president of A/E/C Systems in Newington, Conn., which organizes trade shows for the computer industry. Despite the changes, Mr. Hough noted that the center's rental fees and labor costs generally remain the highest in the country and that New York is one of the nation's most expensive cities to visit.
"The changes at Javits sound good," said Mr. Hough. "But I want to see if they're implemented before making any commitments."
The new work rules came after a yearlong campaign by Fabian G. Palomino, the center's chief executive, to obtain concessions from four unions that represent employees at the center. The revisions, announced last month, will reduce some daily wages by 25 percent and limit the number of employees exhibitors are required to hire for simple tasks.
Companies that arrange trade shows estimated that the new contracts would shave between $100 and $1,000 from costs that range from $3,000 to over $25,000, depending on the size and complexity of an exhibit at the crystalline hall, which extends from West 35th to West 39th Street and from 11th to 12th Avenue.
Under the revised contract exhibitors for the first time can screw in a light bulb without paying an electrician $70, assemble a small booth, known as a pop-up, without paying two carpenters $120 and carry small packages to and from their display booths rather than paying $50 to a teamster or an exposition worker.
 
Hourly Wage Rates to Fall
 Previously, according to a survey by Tradeshow Week, an industry newspaper, electricians at the Javits Center were paid $72.50 an hour compared with costs averaging $43.07 at other convention halls; carpenters, $60.13 an hour compared with $40.24, and teamsters and laborers about $55 an hour compared with $38.41.
From the day the center opened in April 1986, bookers and exhibitors have complained about excessive costs, featherbedding and bribery demands. Mr. Palomino, in an interview, said that he had warned union leaders that the center was becoming increasingly uncompetitive.
 
Fewer Visitors and Shows
 Indeed, in the fiscal year that ended on March 31 about 3.3 million visitors attended 129 trade shows and events at the center compared with 3.9 million people at 155 shows and events the previous year.
The $486 million construction cost for the center was financed through bonds authorized by the state in the mid-1980's. The center's operating budget comes from rental fees charged to exhibitors.
Before seeking the revisions, Mr. Palomino said he had reduced the center's annual operating budget to $31 million from $36 million, discharged 36 executives, some with salaries of more than $90,000 a year, and frozen the salaries of 317 remaining white-collar employees.
"I had to have credibility with the unions," Mr. Palomino explained. "I pointed out that I had cut expenses as much as I could."
John G. Hohmann, a teamsters' official at the center, acknowledged that "business is dropping, our members are hurting and we had to give the exhibitors a break."
"Palomino said he wanted changes and we knew we had to make them," added Mr. Hohmann, the secretary-treasurer of Local 807 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
Steven Hacker, executive director of the National Association of Exposition Managers in Indianapolis, said he believed that the Javits Center was the only major convention hall with fewer events the last two years.
Even so, Mr. Palomino said the center generated more than $5 billion for the city's economy last year by drawing visitors to hotels, restaurants, theaters and shops.
Mr. Palomino was appointed the center's chief executive at a salary of $125,000 in January 1991 by the 13-member state corporation that sets policies for the center. He is the unsalaried Special Counselor to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and a close friend of the Governor's. Those ties to Mr. Cuomo may have helped persuade the unions to go along with Mr. Palomino's proposals.
An investigation by the Manhattan District Attorney's office produced indictments in February against 26 officials and members of Teamsters Local 807, the New York District Council of Carpenters and Joiners, the Exhibition Employees local 829 and Stage Employees Local No. 1. The charges included extortion, fraud, theft and assault.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
U.S. Environment Negotiator in Rio Walks a Tightrope in Administration

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
William K. Reilly, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, was in Europe last month explaining a proposal to preserve the world's forests that President Bush plans to introduce at the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro.
Only four days earlier, the Bush Administration introduced legislation that called for cutting four million acres of ancient forests in the Pacific Northwest. 
 "This must be a very hard Administration to read on the outside," Mr. Reilly said in an interview. "It's hard for me to read sometimes from the inside."
Few issues, domestic or foreign, produce quite as much conflict in the White House as the environment. Like a red float on a fishing line, Mr. Reilly's life in the Administration has been up one week and down the next. Lately, Administration fish stronger than he are trying to tug him completely out of sight.
 
Battles Over Environment
 As the Bush Cabinet's lonely professional environmentalist, Mr. Reilly has led fights in the last 10 months to protect the nation's wetlands, prevent companies from secretly increasing toxic air pollution and strengthen the Administration's position on global warming. In each case, he has lost.
But despite these setbacks, Mr. Bush seems determined to extend important gestures that satisfy a Cabinet officer's expectations about his value.
To wit: three times in the last month Mr. Reilly joined Mr. Bush for lunch to discuss environmental issues. And last week Mr. Bush appointed Mr. Reilly as head of the United States delegation to the conference in Rio, a position that will make the E.P.A. Administrator among the most visible and influential negotiators. Mr. Reilly won the position over Clayton K. Yeutter, the domestic policy chief, who had been favored by Administration conservatives.
The Rio assignment will likely test Mr. Reilly's skills even more than usual, since he will have to defend many of the policies that he is on the record as disliking.
It's been a long three years since Mr. Reilly almost single-handedly put distance between Mr. Bush and the environmental record of Ronald Reagan by proposing a more comprehensive clean-air law and arguing successfully for steep increases in the budget and the number of employees at the E.P.A.
Now the gathering momentum of what appears to be a sharp attack by the Bush Administration on environmental laws worries Mr. Reilly. It is poking holes in the green sash the President has draped across his chest since 1988 when he promised to be the "environmental president."
 
Bloodied but Unbowed
 Mr. Reilly insists, however, that the string of losses has produced neither profound gloom nor unbearable embarrassment. Against a cadre of Administration officials who think ecological protection equals economic stagnation, Mr. Reilly said he is willing to battle against policies he considers irresponsible.
"I have been treated by this President, I think, pretty well," he said in an interview. "I feel I make a difference."
His position as the guardian of nature has led to open fights with Vice President Dan Quayle, made him the focus of wisecracks in Cabinet-level meetings from Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, and Michael J. Boskin, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. It has also strained his relations with Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr.
 
How Long in Office?
 In recent weeks, Mr. Reilly's setbacks have prompted repeated questions from outside the Administration about whether Mr. Bush is setting the stage for his resignation. Environmental leaders in Washington say that might not be such a bad idea because if he stays, Mr. Reilly still affords the President a measure of respectability on environmental issues that they now contend Mr. Bush does not deserve.
"What Reilly should do is ask himself how many more can he lose," said Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate. "He's not losing shades of gray. He's not losing innings. He's losing the whole ball game."
To his critics in and out of the White House, Mr. Reilly is emphatic about his intention to remain.
"The answer is, I have no plans to leave. Loyalty is a must at this level," he said. "I've won big in this Administration. The Clean Air Act was a big victory. I've lost, too."
 
Defender of the Panda
 Mr. Reilly's career -- as a conservative environmentalist with links to the Nixon Administration and as the leader of a wildlife organization devoted to saving pandas -- hardly marks him as an ecological radical. But the idea of strict protection for the environment has become a red cape to the fighting bulls in the Administration, and their view of him seems to be colored more by their contempt for the environmental movement than by particular positions Mr. Reilly holds dear.
Mr. Reilly's isolation in the Administration is matched by his estrangement from former allies in the environmental movement. He often complains that despite his warnings, national environmental leaders arrived much too late last summer to help him defend wetlands from a proposal by Vice President Quayle that would open half the nation's marshes, swamps, and bottom lands to development.
In the White House, the President's closest advisers say Mr. Reilly enjoys as much support as he always has. "Reilly does as well as anybody," said C. Boyden Gray, the President's counsel. "He's a good Cabinet officer. That doesn't mean he doesn't lose."
The strains on Mr. Reilly and in the White House reflect growing pressure from the lingering recession, an approaching election and an environmental backlash stirred up across the country by conservative business and political groups.
 
Is Calamity Near?
 Mr. Darman, Mr. Boskin, the Vice President and Mr. Lujan have pressed with increasing success to loosen environmental regulations, arguing that the benefit will be lower costs to business and preserving jobs.
"The mood is different than it was," Mr. Reilly said in the interview. "The country is preoccupied with jobs, and so is the Administration."
Born in Decatur, Ill., Mr. Reilly spent his childhood following his father, a small businessman, to several states until the family ended up in Fall River, Mass., where he went to high school. Mr. Reilly attended Yale College and Harvard Law School and received a masters in land planning from Columbia University. Tall and slim, with sandy hair and green eyes, the 52-year-old Administrator looks like a young Bob Barker, the host of the daytime television program "The Price is Right."
 
A Seeker of Compromise
 Before joining the Administration, Mr. Reilly was president of the World Wildlife Fund. He convened groups of government officials, business leaders, technical experts and environmentalists to develop compromise solutions to ecological problems. One such group, led by former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, Republican of New Jersey, produced a report in 1988 calling for a policy of "no net loss" for the nation's wetlands.
The "no net loss" idea was adopted by Mr. Bush during the campaign in 1988. Mr. Bush's choice of Mr. Reilly as the E.P.A. Administrator was widely viewed as a clear signal that the President meant what he said about protecting the environment.
Thus, his top aides say, Mr. Reilly has watched with dismay as the Administration busily works to reduce environmental restrictions, rewrite some environmental laws and block new regulations.
The Administration's attack began last summer when Mr. Quayle unveiled a proposal that would open 50 million acres of wetlands to development, which Mr. Reilly argued would violate the "no net loss" promise.
 
Tensions With Quayle
 Though the E.P.A. Administrator has managed to prevent the proposal from going into effect, the rivalry produced a confrontation last December when Mr. Reilly accused Mr. Quayle of "corrupting the process," according to a participant. Mr. Quayle replied, "You've got your job and I've got mine."
The Vice President has proved a formidable foe for Mr. Reilly. Mr. Quayle and his staff helped to develop the moratorium and review of Federal regulations that Mr. Bush announced in January. Mr. Quayle also prevailed last month in the debate over allowing companies to increase, without public intervention, the air pollution they emit above the level allowed on their operating permits.
But Mr. Reilly also has his problems with environmentalists' tactics.
"There is a reflexive interventionism among environmentalists which is associated with classic liberal left politics. Unless the Government is involved managing the problem, nobody else can be trusted to do the job," said Mr. Reilly. "That attitude drives conservatives crazy. And it should. But it's also an increasingly outmoded stereotype. I've never been a polarizer and polarizing the environmental issue is bad politics."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week;
Being Party's Nominee Is Not a Blessing in '92

BYLINE: By Robin Toner, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 1

 BODY:
The primaries are ending, the conventions are looming on the horizon, and George Bush and Bill Clinton will soon step forward to claim their parties' nominations. They are supposed to look happy. But in their darker moments, as they survey the parties they now inherit, they may wonder whether it was worth it.
Entire academic careers have been spent predicting the decline of American political parties, but the institutions look particularly troubled these days. The likely independent candidacy of Ross Perot, now tied with Mr. Clinton in some polls and ahead of him in others, is a graphic demonstration of the waning influence of party loyalty. "Because of that lack of anchoring, voters are just sort of out there, floating," says Martin P. Wattenberg, an expert in parties at the University of California at Irvine. A billionaire wise to the ways of Larry King and Phil Donahue, with telecommunications savvy and the resources to use it, can obviously catch his share. 
 It is known as "dealignment," and it is not what the Republicans expected a decade ago. Ronald Reagan's allies were convinced that he was ushering in an era of Republican loyalty as profound and lasting as the Democratic era begun by Franklin D. Roosevelt -- a classic realignment of American politics. But voters kept blithely splitting their tickets, producing a Democratic Congress and a Republican White House, and the "gridlock" that Mr. Perot so merrily campaigns against today.
The parties' problems are fed by the anti-politician mood among the voters this year. What better symbol of politicians than parties, particularly parties that seemed stalled in endless partisan warfare, or parties that seem enmeshed in internal struggles, or parties that seem to be creatures of constituent groups? Both Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton face the possibility of conventions that highlight the tensions within their parties -- while Mr. Perot can stage his own, uncomplicated, harmonious "counter-events."
There are, of course, long-term forces behind the weakening of the parties; the country is fundamentally different from the days when party leaders basically organized politics and much of the neighborhood as well. While many Democrats secretly yearn for the days of brokered conventions and smoke-filled rooms, Ann F. Lewis, a Democratic strategist, argued, "Do you really think these educated, suburban voters sitting around watching CNN would cheerfully allow their Presidential votes to be cast by people they don't know?"
Mr. Wattenberg, who wrote "The Decline of American Political Parties, 1952-1988," said that parties have declined "because people don't see them as relevant to today's world; they've become like the British monarchy."
But the parties are also struggling with a host of internal problems, many of their own making. Mr. Bush has yet to figure out a way to re-energize a Republican coalition that was already strained in 1988. The waning of the Communist threat, the slowing of the economy and the rise of the abortion issue have all undermined the Reagan majority. In the weeks to come Mr. Bush faces the probability of a platform fight over the abortion issue that will highlight many of these divisions. Mr. Perot, with his appeal to the Sunbelt, to the entrepreneurial-minded and to the moderate-on-social-issues suburbanites, seems eager to chip away at the cracks.
For their part, the Democrats have struggled unsuccessfully to redefine themselves as a Presidential party for a generation. Mr. Clinton began this election cycle with a carefully-calibrated message intended to recreate his party, and reach out to the middle class, but it was largely lost during the onslaught of character issues. He will have to tread carefully among the party's constituent groups as he chooses a running mate, a process now going on quietly but which will not stay quiet much longer. And he will have to manage, looking triumphant, a convention that he could enter in third place in the polls.
The nomination of a major political party, in short, is hardly an unalloyed blessing in the summer of 1992. For all of that, there is still a base for each party. And given that Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton seem destined to face a three-way race, even a base that is not a majority is important.
The latest CBS Poll showed 28 percent called themselves Republicans, 31 percent called themselves Democrats and 35 percent said they were independents. It also showed Mr. Perot essentially tied with Mr. Clinton in second place. Numbers like these, six months before the election, probably have little to do with what will happen this fall. But they are sure to take the edge off the victory celebrations as the long primary season finally ends.

HEADLINE: U.S. Has a Starring Role At Rio Summit as Villain

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 1

 BODY:
The Earth Summit officially opens here on Wednesday, but already "villain," "party pooper" and "Uncle Grubby" are being used to describe the Bush Administration, reviving anti-American sentiment rarely seen in international forums since the Vietnam War.
"The mood in Brazil is that the United States will be the biggest villain of the conference," Fabio Feldman, a Social Democratic congressman in Brazil, said today. "U.S. intransigence is recreating the polarized atmosphere of the 1960's: all civil society and the press against the U.S." 
 Traditionally centrist Brazilian magazines and newspapers are taking an increasingly harsh tone, accusing the Bush Administration of draining content from what Brazilians proudly predict to be the largest gathering of heads of state in history.
Calling President Bush "Uncle Grubby" and "Mr. Smoke," Veja, a Brazilian newsweekly, told its million readers on Sunday, "Bush comes to Rio as Earth Summit enemy."
In contrast, Japan was hailed as the world's "first environmental superpower."
 
Bush Won't Sign Treaty
 The hostility boiled over on Saturday with the news that Mr. Bush would not sign a bio-diversity treaty when he comes here June 11 to 13. Mr. Bush only agreed to appear briefly after timetables and targets were withdrawn from the text of a second treaty to be signed here, on climate change.
"Our feeling is that the world is doing what it should to organize these vast areas, and that the U.S. is not prepared to join, that the U.S. is isolated," said Marco Azamabuja, Brazil's chief negotiator. "What's the point of a major treaty if the U.S. is not on board?"
American efforts to turn the tide in public opinion have been fruitless.
On Thursday, William Reilly, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, gave a long interview by satellite to journalists in Latin America and Europe.
Jornal do Brasil, an influential daily here, printed the interview with an explanation that Mr. Reilly "will have one of the less desirable jobs of the Earth Summit, that of party-pooper."
Reflecting the anti-American mood here, Carlos Minc, a left-wing Rio state deputy, posed on Friday with his new "lie-o-meter." The device, featuring a caricature of Pinocchio, was designed to reflect mendacity levels emanating from televised speeches from the official conference hall. For demonstration purposes, Mr. Minc placed a "U.S.A." plaque on the device and pulled Pinocchio's nose off the chart.
Today, the news that Mr. Bush had offered $150 million in new forest protection aid mollified few environmentalists in a nation that has the largest expanse of tropical forest in the world.
"We feel that the United States is trying to pay to clean their name before the conference," said Joao Paulo Capobianco, executive director, of Brazil's largest environmental group, SOS Mata Atlantica.
Mr. Bush's proposal includes doubling international aid to protect world forests to $2.7 billion in 1992.
The isolation of the United States seemed to take on a physical dimension today as reporters explored the new exhibition and office hall of the Riocentro conference center. In this miniature world's fair, the United States has rented the smallest office space of the eight industrialized nations.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
A Plea for Progress
PARIS, June 1 (Special to The New York Times) -- Scientists, writers and other figures from 29 nations today warned Government leaders gathering at the Earth Summit in Rio not to forsake scientific and industrial progress in the name of the environment.
The statement, signed by 264 scientists including 53 Nobel Prize winners, appears to be a defense against what scientists describe as the "anti-science movement."
"Some scientists wanted to stress their ideas amid the growth of environmentalism," said Emanuel Beaurepaire who distributed the text. "They feel scientists do not get enough of a voice and they are afraid governments will take decisions under pressure."
The group includes biologists, physicists, chemists, economists, writers and politicians. Among the writers are Umberto Eco of Italy and Eugene Ionesco of France.

The Economy
States may not regulate the way airlines advertise their fares, the Supreme Court ruled. State attorneys general wanted to make airlines adhere to guidelines that they said were more extensive than the Federal regulation they regarded as lax. [Page A1.]
Manufacturing expanded robustly in May, the nation's purchasing managers said, because of sharp increases in industrial production and exports. The rise to an index level of 56.3 percent in May -- the highest level in nearly four years -- indicated that the economy is emerging from recession. [D1.] 
 The country's trade performance was the second best in nearly a decade in the first quarter, the Government said. Lower oil prices helped shrink the merchandise trade deficit by 5.8 percent, to $17.5 billion. [D20.] A revival in the manufacturing sector led to a slight rise, of 0.1 percent, in consumer incomes during April. [D20.] Construction spending slipped slightly in April. [D20.]

HEADLINE: Post Office Tries Battling Deficit with Stamp Sales

BYLINE: By BARTH HEALEY

 BODY:
Struggling to meet the legal requirement that it break even, the post office is vigorously trying to sell stamps to people who won't put them on letters.
The breadth of this effort is not immediately apparent amid the public-relations furor surrounding the planned Elvis Presley stamp. The design chosen -- a young Elvis or a more mature one -- after a nationwide mail-in vote is to be announced Thursday with appropriate fanfare at Graceland, the Presley house in Memphis. 
 Nevertheless, by aggressively promoting stamps as collectibles to more buyers, the United States Postal Service says, it reaped $175 million in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, almost double the figure from the year before. That made a substantial dent in the deficit that the post office, the nation's eighth-largest corporation in terms of revenue, had built up since 1987.
"We are trying to get adults, married perhaps, with children, to reconsider stamp collecting" for its educational value, said the senior Assistant Postmaster General for marketing, Richard J. Strasser Jr.
 
A String of Losses
 The stamp-buying promotion comes as the Postal Service is struggling with losses and a growing deficit. The service was set up as a Government-sponsored corporation in 1971 with the idea of making enough money to end taxpayer subsidies of regular mail service, a goal it met in 1982.
But the service is also required to break even during any three-year period, and in the last few years its losses have been substantial enough to defeat efforts to balance the books.
The service's losses last year were particularly troubling because they came after an increase in postal rates. The money from that increase, however, was largely offset by a 2 percent decline in third-class mail, mostly advertising circulars, which accounted for 20 percent of the agency's total revenue of $42.51 billion last year. Mr. Strasser ascribed the decline in third-class mail to the recession as well as to the rate adjustments.
The situation has prompted postal officials to seek out the revenue to be derived from promotions like the Elvis stamp, the beginning of a planned series of stamps on popular music stars.
 
Sponsoring Olympic Games
 In seeking more revenue from collectors, the Postal Service is also sponsoring the Olympic Games. This sponsorship, the service's biggest single marketing campaign, brought the agency a substantial share of the special-delivery mail and parcel post generated by the Games that might have gone to private delivery companies, and yielded a profit of $20 million on an investment of $122 million in 1991, the post office calculates.
Most of the profit came from the sale of stamps with an Olympic theme, and this year, the agency expects to make $35 million on the program.
The Postal Service is also working with Hollywood in promoting stamps. When a booklet of five 29-cent stamps showing Al Hirschfeld caricatures of famous comedians was issued last August, MCA/Universal Home Video also released two videotapes of Abbott and Costello that included a promotion of Postal Service products. A similar MCA video of "An American Tale: Fievel Goes West," went on sale on April 10 together with the 29-cent Western Americana envelope.
The marketing effort is clear in the redesign of the post office's catalogue of stamps, prints and albums for sale by mail. Once a drab booklet, it has been transformed into a slick brochure emblazoned with the slogan "Stamps Worth Saving."
Whether that slogan is true is questionable: Ordinary first-class stamps are printed by the billions and never rise in value; indeed, dealers routinely sell older stamps, like those purple 3-cent issues from the 1940's, at 80 percent of their original value. They are still valid as postage, and collectors like to dress up their mail with them.
Higher-value stamps do better because many fewer are printed. The $1 Airlift stamp issued in 1968 now sells for about $2.50, and the $5 Railroad Lantern stamp of 1979 goes for about $9.
The post office seems to be aiming at this market for higher-value stamps with the reprints of the 16 stamps that were issued in 1893 (a year late) to commemorate the 400th anniversary of the first voyage of Columbus.
The 1992 issue, released May 22, uses the original engraved plates to create the reprints. Only two million sets will be printed, a relatively small number for modern United States stamps, and they will not be sold in post offices, only at philatelic centers in large cities and by mail. At $16.34 each, the two million sets, if unused, could yield the post office a profit of more than $32 million.
The market for stamps has risen steadily over the past year after tumbling from speculative highs in 1980-81. A value index of United States stamps compiled by Linn's Stamp News, a weekly newspaper, rose to 436.60 in May (1970 equals 100), the sixth consecutive monthly increase, to a level 8.3 percent higher than a year earlier. But most of the rise came in 19th-century stamps, and the most recent stamp in the index is from 1955.
There is some annoyance among traditional collectors at the flood of new stamps that the Postal Service hopes will never be used. The post office plans about 130 different stamps and envelopes this year.
But Mr. Strasser of the Postal Service said the philatelic push would continue. And, indeed, whether the agency can reverse its four-year decline in equity may depend on new business like that from the philatelic program.
The deficit reached a cumulative $848 million in the year ended Sept. 30, even before allowing for a special charge: a decision by Congress that made the Postal Service responsible for $1.9 billion in retroactive health benefits and cost-of-living pay raises. This put the total deficit in its equity at $2.75 billion.

HEADLINE: Bronx School, Tired of Low Expectations, Has Everyone Taking Japanese

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
When President Jimmy Carter made his famous journey to the South Bronx and looked out over a desolate wasteland, one of the few buildings standing around him was Herman Ridder Junior High School. Its academic prospects were just as bleak as the neighborhood's.
Today, the neighborhood is showing sure signs of life, with suburban-style ranch homes sprouting in the rubble. And so is Ridder, where students who might once have been destined for average or slow classes are studying the formidable language of Japanese. 
 Chie Mochizuki's sixth graders are translating Eric Carle's popular children's book, "The Very Hungry Caterpillar," adorning the text with their own drawings. From lists that Miss Mochizuki has provided, they are copying Japanese characters that make up sentences like "On Saturday, he ate through one piece of chocolate cake, one ice cream cone, one pickle, one slice of Swiss cheese . . ."
Keith Levin, a soft-spoken 11-year-old, and Venus Ramos, a 12-year-old with a large purple bow in her ponytail, have practical reasons for studying this language.
 
A Gift of Challenge
 "If you know Japanese you can read directions on a Japanese VCR," said Keith.
"They need more Japanese speakers to sell U.S. products over there," said Venus.
Japanese is generally confined to gifted classes. But many educators believe that one reason many other children -- especially black and Hispanic youngsters -- do not do well is they are not sufficiently challenged. By learning Japanese, says Diana Castro Caracciolo, the acting principal, and Angel Villareal, the assistant principal, the students will learn more keenly how a language works and apply those lessons to English.
"You are here because you're special," Mrs. Caracciolo says her school is announcing. "And we are going to prove you are special because who else is studying Japanese?"
There are other difficult languages, but Mrs. Caracciolo says she chose Japanese believing that it would one day give students from a neighborhood with high unemployment a competitive edge. All students take it, along with regular subjects.
 
Like Seeing King Kong
 Ridder, at Boston Road and 173d Street near Crotona Park, is a gray Art Deco landmark. Its squat tower has long dominated the scarred landscape and residents like to joke that it would form a perfect second perch for King Kong.
But for more than two decades it was afflicted with academic failure and spurts of violence. The idea of students studying Japanese would have been more incongruous than seeing King Kong on the tower.
Alfredo Mathew, the District 12 superintendent, and the local school board decided to scatter Ridder's children to other schools and reopen it with a smaller, more selective population. Borrowing an idea from District 4 in East Harlem, where students can choose from a roster of theme schools, Mr. Mathew called his school the Foreign Language and Global Studies school, or Flags.
 
Students' Reading Problems
 The school, which can hold 1,000 students, opened in September with only 250 students, mostly sixth graders, chosen from teacher recommendations and reading and math tests. The student population is not gifted, but above average for the district.
Mrs. Caracciolo says there were "glitches" in the screening that admitted "youngsters who do not have their own first language in hand." A third of the students read below the desired grade level, she said.
Still, she says that students, including many slower ones, seem to be reading better and thinking more logically. She and Mr. Villareal are planning to introduce Russian, Arabic, or Chinese next year. They are also hunting for a martial arts instructor.
Learning Japanese is a high expectation. The language uses over 8,000 ideograms, pictorial characters, in addition to two syllabic alphabets. It usually omits personal pronouns and articles and puts verbs at the end of sentences. It has scores of shadings for politeness and social status.
Still, Miss Moshizuki, a 31-year-old native of Tokyo, says she has found that children prefer the Japanese symbols to a mere alphabet. "They are very visually oriented," she said. "To them it's almost like a drawing, not writing a text."
 
Student Likes Ringo
 Keith Levin savors the Japanese word for apple -- ringo. Venus Ramos treasures the word for caterpillar, imomushi, and moon, tsuki. She can sign her name in Japanese.
To simplify lessons, Miss Moshizuki has students tackle sentences together as they work in groups around large tables. The tables are identified by colors: red, blue, yellow, green and orange, or aka, ao, kiiro, midori and orenji.
"It's a Copernican revolution in their psyche," she said. "That is why it is difficult for young children. They're very egocentric. But sixth graders can try to understand another perspective. This is my alphabet. This is your alphabet."

HEADLINE: Danes Vote Today on European Union Treaty

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COPENHAGEN, June 1

 BODY:
After months of debate over whether to ratify the far-reaching treaty on European union that the 12 European Community countries signed in December, Danish voters appear to be moving toward a "yes" vote in a referendum on Tuesday.
A "no" vote in the referendum, the first in any European country, could force a renegotiation or even scrapping of the treaty, since all 12 member nations must ratify it before it can go into effect at the start of next year. 
 Public opinion polls over the last months have sometimes shown more people against it than in favor, but the latest Gallup telephone survey for Berlingske Tidende newspaper and the Danish radio last week showed 44 percent for and 35 percent against, with 13 percent undecided and the others saying they would not vote or were unsure whether they would.
The debate has raged for months, with television talk shows, poster battles and a huge rally against the treaty in a park all day Sunday. Every family in the country has received a copy of the treaty's impenetrable prose, courtesy of the Government.
"Even in the darkest days of the polls, I was convinced that we'd win," Foreign Minister Uffe Ellemann-Jensen said in an interview today. "How could there ever have been any doubt? Well, Danes are doubters. You just have to read your Hamlet to understand that."
Opponents of the treaty on European union, which was signed by the leaders of the 12 countries at Maastricht, the Netherlands, continued the battle for public opinion all day today, hoping to reach as many as they can of the country's 3.9 million voters.
"I think we still have a chance to win," said Birgit Bjornvig, a leading opponent of the treaty.
"I think it's important to realize that what is good for France or Germany, on one side, or Greece and Portugal, on the other, isn't necessarily good for Denmark," she said. "If Europe becomes a federal state, it will be more centralized than the United States, and I don't think our democracy can survive."
At the heart of the argument, both for and against, are the treaty's requirements for European countries to pool sovereignty in vital areas that up to now have always been jealously guarded national prerogatives. The treaty provides for a European Central Bank to make monetary policy for a common currency for countries that want it and qualify, as early as 1997, and it pledges all 12 to try to make more of their foreign policy and security decisions together.
Most of the nations plan to ratify the treaty by parliamentary vote, but France and Germany also need to make changes to their constitutions, and Ireland has a referendum on June 18. With the ineffectiveness of European Community security policy already embarrassingly apparent through its impotent attempts to stop the fighting in Yugoslavia, supporters of greater unity fear that Denmark could scuttle the whole process by voting against it Tuesday.
But in Denmark, fear of being overwhelmed by a newly united Germany, after the last barriers to internal European trade and immigration are removed in January, is also not far below the surface. The minority coalition Government of Prime Minister Poul Schluter negotiated a protocol in the treaty that gives Danes the right to keep prohibiting Germans from buying summer houses in Denmark.
It is German economic clout, not tanks and troops, that some Danes are afraid of this time. With nearly 80 million mostly landlocked Germans looking longingly at their beaches, the 5.1 million Danes felt they needed the protocol to retain rights to their shores.
Denmark's economy -- with an inflation rate of below 3 percent and a trade surplus even with Japan -- is now intimately bound up with its European neighbors. And, Mr. Ellemann-Jensen argued, with Sweden, Finland and possibly Norway all about to become community members within the next several years, it would make little sense now for Denmark to opt out of provisions designed to bring everybody closer together.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Cuzco Journal;
In Peru, Pizarro Won a Battle; the War Goes On

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CUZCO, Peru

 BODY:
High in the thin air of the Andes, sculptors here are raising what will be the largest statue in Peru: a 114-foot-high bronze rendering of Inca Pachakuteq, a 15th-century ruler of the Inca empire.
Far away in the capital, Lima, the nation's Government center is adorned by a statue of a triumphant Spaniard: Francisco Pizarro, conqueror of the Inca empire. 
 The two statues symbolize the hidden regional and racial divisions of modern Peru. And people who have studied this country's Shining Path rebel movement say that now, 500 years after Columbus's voyage foreshadowed the fall of this city as capital of the Inca empire, Peru's legacy of racism and regional isolation helps explain the xenophobia, the rage and the violence of the leftist rebellion.
"It is impossible to understand Peru's political violence if you only look at poverty or political oppression," said Nelson Manrique, a leading researcher of the rebel movement. "Racial discrimination is a very important factor."
 
60 Percent Are Mestizos
 Of Peru's 22 million people, about 60 percent are mestizos, or people of mixed Spanish and Indian heritage, 30 percent are Andean Indians and 10 percent are whites. With ethnicity blurring racial labels, an Indian who moves to the city, cuts his braids, puts on Western clothes and learns Spanish, generally considers himself mestizo or "cholo."
Officially, both Shining Path guerrillas and the Government deny that Peru has a race problem. The Government, headed by Alberto K. Fujimori, a son of Japanese immigrants, maintains an official policy that "we are all cholos."
But one Shining Path supporter, a mechanic from Cuzco interviewed in a Lima shantytown, asked a pointed question: "How can we have a statue of Pizarro, a man who betrayed our forefathers, who stole our gold?"
Coastal Peruvians, when scanning newspapers, rarely fail to note that arrested Shining Path supporters often come from cities of Peru's Andean heartland: Cuzco, Ayacucho, Huancavelica and Huancayo.
Shining Path "seems to attract Andean migrants," said Guido Delran Cousy, director here of the Bartolome de las Casas Center for Andean Regent Studies. "People have made an enormous effort to leave the cultural roots, but haven't found space in the cities."
The split is echoed by a controversy today over how to commemorate the 500th anniversary of Columbus's arrival in the Americas.
Peru's Association of Economists recently delivered to Spain's Ambassador a bill for $647 billion in colonial reparations and a request for an apology over the colonists' genocide. The largest item on the bill was for a ransom of seven tons of gold and 13 tons of silver that a captive Inca, Atahuallpa, paid Pizarro for his release. After the ransom was paid, Pizarro put Atahuallpa to death.
Defending the cause of Western culture, Mario Vargas Llosa, Peru's most prominent novelist, wrote in reply that Atahuallpa's modern-day defenders "never shed a tear for the thousands, or hundreds of thousands, of Indians sacrificed to gods in barbarian ceremonies by Incas, Mayas, Aztecs, Chibchas or Toltecs."
Offering a middle road, other Peruvian intellectuals propose "unhorsing" Pizarro by placing the conqueror's statue in a museum.
After Pizarro founded Lima, the Spanish adopted racial controls to maintain power: Indians were barred from owning horses, from bearing arms, from wearing Spanish dress, and from entering the sumptuous gold-leafed churches.
Hundreds of thousands of Indians died working as slaves in Spanish mines. In the mid-19th century, British companies impressed Indians, Chinese and Polynesians to mine guano, allowing hundreds to be blinded by ammonia fumes. In the 1920's, workers died from fumes from an unregulated copper smelter run by an American company.
This history undoubtedly contributes to the extreme xenophobia of Shining Path. "In sectors of the masses, there is resentment of centuries," said a Lima professor who sympathizes with the Shining Path.
But the rebels say they are motivated by class struggle. A Shining Path ideologist said in a March interview in a Lima jail: "The central problem is not race. It's economics. It's class. Class society appeared long before 1492."
While rigidly Marxist, Shining Path's murals and portraits show a Maoist iconography blurred with Indian images. The group's leader, Abimael Guzman Reynoso, presents himself as a sun figure, a reference to ancient religious beliefs that the Inca descended directly from the sun.
Although Shining Path does not make direct racial appeals, deep racial alienation undoubtedly contributes to bitterness speeding the movement. Signs of this alienation are everywhere.
Every year, judges in the Miss Peru contest invariably choose a contestant who looks as if she arrived yesterday from Barcelona. "You will never find a Miss Peru called Quispe or Mamani," Mr. Manrique said, citing Indian names from the Quechua and Aymara groups. "Indians feel like foreigners in their own country." Mixed-race children typically play with dolls with European features.
Gonzalo Porto Carrero, a Catholic University sociologist, said: "Many poor people see whites as foreigners, and they have revenge fantasies. In some factories where Sendero has killed white managers, the workers approved."
