HEADLINE: Milk the Cows. Do the Arithmetic. Sell the Farm.

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COLEBROOK, Conn.

 BODY:
Cows are George and Gloria Wilber's life. From dawn to midnight, much of their daily routine is crowded with the care and feeding of their 60 Brown Swiss cows. There are cows all over their house, too, painted on the flour canisters and dangling in stained glass from window frames. "You should see our Christmas tree," said their 16-year-old daughter, Katie.
The Wilbers are the last dairy farmers in this northwestern Connecticut town, where a generation ago there were more than a dozen. Soon the Wilbers will be gone, too; after five money-losing years, they are trying to sell their herd. 
 They are part of a trend in the metropolitan area, where the number of dairy farms has fallen by half in the last 10 years in Connecticut and New Jersey, and by one-third in New York.
 
Farms to Shopping Malls
 A combination of local conditions and national policy brought the Wilbers to this point. Federal regulation of the price they get for milk does little to take into account the region's relatively high fuel and labor costs, not to mention taxes, Mr. Wilber said. As those costs have risen, the price of milk has stayed about the same, forcing farmers to absorb the higher expenses.
And as suburbs spread farther from America's cities, farmland has become more valuable as a potential subdivision or shopping mall. The landscape around the Wilber farm, once dotted with grazing cows, is now speckled with weekend homes for New Yorkers.
"The economics are forcing them out," said Richard A. Meinert, a cooperative extension educator with the University of Connecticut in Litchfield. "To an extent, it's happening to everybody, but the dairy farmers are in it worse. They don't have the option of a roadside stand. They have a product they have to market through federally regulated channels."
To keep earning a living in agriculture, some dairy farmers have merged their operations, while others have abandoned cows for corn, hay or flowerbed plants, and still others have sold their land for development.
Farms in the region continue to produce about 70 percent of the milk sold here. But more and more, that milk is coming from large operations with hundreds of cows, which benefit from the economies of scale.
To consumers, this makes little difference, because milk prices are largely determined by Federal policies, not by producers' costs.
 
Farmers in Suburbia
 Still, the trend toward such large farms runs counter to the traditional approach to dairy farming. Across the nation, about 90 percent of all dairy farms are small and family-run, like the Wilbers', with fewer than 100 cows each, according to U.S. Department of Agriculture statistics.
The Wilbers' decision to get out came in part from the loneliness of being the only dairy farmers in town, Mrs. Wilber said.
"What's very hard for me is that there's no support group for farmers," she said. "We have become farmers living in a suburban area. Take us and put us in Ohio or Vermont, and it might be different."
But even there they would not be free of problems they ascribe to the Federal pricing policy for milk, a policy described as complicated and out-of-date even by its supporters. Based on prices paid to dairy farmers in Wisconsin and Minnesota, considered the center of dairy country, the Department of Agriculture computes a minimum price every month for milk in three grades.
The policy makes some allowances for higher costs in different regions. But since prices in a given area are inflexible, the policy encourages the creation of larger farms that can balance costs against higher volume. In densely populated states like Connecticut, however, it is difficult for dairy farmers to buy additional land and expand.
 
State Intervention
 For George Wilber, the discouraging economics of a small dairy farm are best illustrated in a recent monthly statement from Agri-Mark, the marketing cooperative to which he belongs. Of about $4,539 he was paid for his milk, all but $1,115 went to taxes, promotional fees, co-op dues, a $105 "stop charge" to pick up his milk, transportation charges and a $2,000 mortgage payment on the farm; a $1,000 advance he had taken the previous month from the cooperative was deducted as well. His net pay does not cover half of his $3,000-a-month feed bill, he said.
"At one point, we stopped paying for health insurance," Mrs. Wilber said. "And that was when I went back to school. It was just too risky, with farms having such high accident rates." Now she works as a teacher and Mr. Wilber earns a salary as First Selectman of Colebrook.
From time to time, state try to ease the predicament of dairy farmers with land-preservation programs and tax breaks and even by adding to the price they get for their milk. But in general these steps fail to prevent many small farms from going under. In April, a Federal judge in Manhattan struck down a 1991 New York law requiring dealers who sold their milk in New York to pay a premium if they bought from out-of-state farmers. The money collected was to be redistributed to the farmers.
"It tried to keep the playing field level, if you will," said Patrick M. Hooker, a dairy specialist with the Farm Bureau of New York, a lobbying organization near Albany, noting that New York costs could be higher than in Connecticut or Pennsylvania.
 
'A Fluid Commodity'
 The judge disagreed, saying that the policy violated rules of interstate commerce. But many officials in the Northeast say the Federal system does little to consider higher labor and fuel costs in the region that shrink a farmer's profit margin.
"I don't think there's a whole lot that any state can do," said John R. H. Blum, Connecticut's Commissioner of Agriculture. "The difficulty with individual state action is that milk is literally such a fluid commodity, with the interstate system and the big tanker trucks, that if prices are lower in a neighboring state, the dealers just go to that state."
Efforts have begun to change the pricing policy in small ways, said Willard H. Blanchard, director of the dairy division of the United States Department of Agriculture, but there are no plans to sharply revise or replace it.
Barring a major change in pricing policy, farmers could be helped by attracting milk-oriented industry to their states.
"If we were able to locate a large baby-formula plant in Connecticut, that would open up an export market that we haven't got now," Mr. Blum said. "And as the European markets open up, the export of breeding stock is a possibility."
 
Fate of Open Space
 The plight of dairy farmers is also cause for concern among advocates for open space.
"There's a whole generation of disgruntled, underpaid, overworked farmers controlling most of the open land left in Connecticut," said Robert C. Wagner, northeast regional director of the American Farmland Trust, which has its headquarters in Washington. "We've got to be concerned about where dairying goes. Land prices will come back long before milk prices come back."
Mr. Meinert of the University of Connecticut echoes that point. "If you lose the dairy farmers, you lose the open land," he said, "and God knows what comes in to take its place."
For the time being, the Wilbers are trapped by the recession into staying right where they are, unable to get a good price for their land or their cows, which they say are worth about $2,000 apiece.
And Mr. Wilber, who was the state's Commissioner of Agriculture during the late 1970's, said switching to other products is easier said than done. "In the town of Colebrook, our soil is very stony," he said. "You're not going to be able to set strawberry beds or plant sweet corn."
 
A Way of Life
 His concern is echoed by Ray Vail, whose dairy farm in Lagrangeville, N.Y., has been in the family for 197 years. "Vegetables really don't turn me on too much," Mr. Vail said. "And if everybody went into vegetables, there'd be no money in that, either."
The Wilbers may not be as desperate as farmers who have never known any other profession. But it is clear that they will miss their cows, whose twice-daily milkings govern their lives. "They're like members of the family," Mr. Wilber said, calling to Tessie and Carly and Glenda and Tabitha by name.
The couple gave their children calves on special occasions and encouraged them to care for them. Several of the cows have won grand prizes at state and county fairs.
"They say agriculture is the principal industry of Colebrook," Mr. Wilber said, quoting the state manual known as the Blue Book. "Well, it's gone now."

HEADLINE: Brady Warns That Fed Could Delay Recovery

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, June 1

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said here today that the United States economy was starting to show "good solid growth," but he warned that the recovery could be aborted, as it was last summer, by inadequate money supply from the central bank.
Mr. Brady, here for the International Monetary Conference of the American Bankers Association, demonstrated the increasing sensitivity of the Bush Administration this election year to the policies of the independent Federal Reserve Board. The Administration is counting on strong growth later this year to help re-elect the President. 
 "I think it is clear that if the Fed pulls down the lever of money supply in 1992, as was the case in 1991 when the first appearance of growth started in midsummer, then we are taking a chance with this economic recovery that I don't think is wise for this country," Mr. Brady told reporters after an address to the main conference.
 
Personal Assessment
 His comments followed last week's upward revision by the Commerce Department, to 2.4 from 2 percent, in the annual rate of economic growth in the first quarter. The Treasury chief said his own assessment of recovery was based on indicators like a 30 percent rise in shipments of truck motors, "very good" increases in leading department store sales and increased orders for heavy manufacturing equipment.
"What I see are the foundations for growth, not meteoric growth, but if we can get to a 2 1/2 to 3 percent growth mode in the U.S. economy, that will provide for substantial job creation," he stressed.
The Treasury and the banking industry are working out details on legislative proposals to allow banks to set up nationwide branch systems, but Mr. Brady declined to predict what Congress would do about it this year. A similar effort collapsed last year.
"After watching what's gone on in Congress the last three or four months, I can't tell you what is going to get done, but it's quite clearly needed," Mr. Brady said.
He disclosed that the Senate minority leader, Robert J. Dole of Kansas, would shortly introduce legislation that seeks to undo some of the regulations imposed on small banks by last year's Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation Improvement Act, which recapitalized the bank insurance fund with $30 billion.
New reporting requirements on loans to small businesses and farmers would be eliminated under the Dole bill for banks with less than $100 million in assets.
Diane Casey, executive director of the Independent Bankers Association of America, said in a telephone interview from Washington that the relief was "vital" for small banks but noted, "It will be an uphill battle this year."
 
Problems of Japan
 The meeting also focused on financial problems in Japan and the current difficulties of banks of many nations in commercial real estate lending.
In Japan, both the stock and property markets have fallen dramatically, and corporations and individuals as well as banks are financially squeezed.
Toyoo Gyohten, an adviser to the Bank of Tokyo and a former vice minister of finance for international affairs, said the majority view in Japan was that the market declines had "passed the bottom" and that overall economic activity should start picking up in the latter half of this year.
Mr. Brady said he welcomed recent cuts in official Japanese interest rates and hoped they would be matched with fiscal actions to strengthen domestic growth, which would help reduce Japan's trade surplus, the No. 1 source of the United States trade deficit.
 
Multiply Banking Difficulties
 The frmer chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker, now an investment adviser in New York, said the difficulties being felt by banks in the United States and elsewhere in real estate lending have come on top of problems with loans to the Soviet Union and the third world.
"How could banks have made so many lending mistakes so repeatedly in such a limited period of time?" he asked.
Yet he pointed out that unlike earlier periods in history, the strains of the banking system had had "little effect" on the real economy because of government safety nets in all the major countries.

HEADLINE: Losses Force Japan's Banks To Halt Expansion Overseas

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 1

 BODY:
After a decade of growth that left them towering over the world financial system, Japan's big commercial banks have been forced to hit the brakes on their global expansion. They have been hobbled by a problem many Japanese thought afflicted only the West: billions of dollars of bad loans.
The pullback from what had seemed an unstoppable march to dominance amounts to a significant shift in the balance of financial power and is likely to be felt from Wall Street to America's industrial centers, as well as in Japan, bankers and analysts say. 
 As the flood of Japanese money dries up, borrowers are already having to give their banks slightly higher profit margins to obtain certain kinds of loans and guarantees than they did a year ago, even though interest rates are broadly lower. Some riskier ventures, like takeovers that rely on borrowed money, are finding it far more difficult to borrow funds.
The result, many analysts say, is likely to be a market in which banks win business based on ideas and efficiency rather than just with financial muscle.
 
'It Should Be Scaled Back'
 "The Japanese banking system has outlived its purpose in its current form, and it should be scaled back," said Akio Mikuni, the president of Mikuni & Company, Japan's only independent credit rating agency. "When this was a closed system banks could just consider size and not worry about profitability. But the system is opened now, and the banks are going to have to pay for having been slow to realize the effects of that fact."
During the Japanese banks' global lending spree in the 1980's, they pushed aside their foreign rivals as they grabbed a growing share of the international banking market. Financing the acquisition of everything from Impressionist paintings to golf courses in California and office towers in New York, the big Japanese banks claimed 7 of 10 places among the world's largest.
"By following the trail of dollars and yen, we can see the accelerating pace at which the Japanese empire is gaining momentum and the American empire is losing ground," warned Daniel Burstein in his 1988 book, "Yen! Japan's New Financial Empire and Its Threat to America."
But the speculative bubble burst two years ago, when the Japanese Government raised interest rates sharply to cool inflationary pressures. Japan has now suffered a record level of corporate bankruptcies, and mounting loan losses for the banks that are likely to take at least five years to clean up.
A series of scandals also created turmoil, forcing the heads of five of the largest banks to resign in the last year and a half because of questionable financial activities. Many analysts say this is Japan's worst banking crisis since World War II.
 
Bad-Loan Losses to Rise
 But with the Japanese economy in a slowdown and bankruptcies still rising, the analysts say they still expect the losses from sour loans to rise. That is forcing Japanese banks to reassess their strategies in a fundamental way.
"Maybe our bank has grown too big," said Hisao Kobayashi, a managing director in charge of international operations at the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, the world's largest commercial bank. "It's time perhaps for us to think about what the appropriate size is. We may need to concentrate more on profits than expansion."
Japanese banks controlled just 4 percent of the international lending market in 1980, with the assets of their overseas branches at just $189 billion. By 1989, aggressive expansion gave them a 40 percent share, with overseas assets of $1.4 trillion. Today, the share is edging down near 30 percent, with assets of $1.26 trillion, the first such decline in overseas assets in years. Although Japanese banks remain among the world's largest, their overall assets declined last year, the first such drop in years.
The banking problems reflect a deeper financial shift taking place. Japan invested so much abroad during the 1980's that it emerged as the world's largest creditor nation -- at the same time that the United States fell to become the world's largest debtor nation. The collapse of stock and real estate prices in Japan has undermined confidence and forced the Japanese to marshal more of their capital at home, and last year Japan suddenly shifted course and slowed its flow of investments abroad, including new bank loans.
 
Focusing on Japanese Business
 Many Japanese banks are cutting back on some overseas operations, refocusing their business on their core Japanese customers rather than the American municipialities and other foreign customers they chased during the 1980's.
During the years of aggressive expansion, Japanese banks issued letters of credit for American authorities planning bond offerings, often charging only a few hundredths of a percentage point. United States banks said the fee was too low, and business flowed to the Japanese. Now, with the Japanese pulling back, municipalities have to pay more for such services.
Adding to the anxiety about the extent of the banks' problems is a striking lack of information on just how many loans at the Japanese banks have become uncollectible.
American banks are required to make detailed disclosures on their problem loans, and they must set aside reserves promptly to offset those losses. As a result, most big American banks reported heavy losses in the last few years because of tumbling real estate prices, failed leveraged buyouts and other loan problems.
But in Japan, the Government does not require that such information be made public in great detail, and the disclosure rules are riddled with loopholes, analysts say, leaving the public in the dark.
"Absolutely nobody knows," said Alicia Ogawa, the banking analyst here for S. G. Warburg Securities. "The Bank of Japan has no idea. The Ministry of Finance has no idea. It's clear, though, that the banks will be working their way through these problems three years from now, and probably more like five."
The Finance Ministry has sought to allay the fears by abandoning its usual reticence and offering a few vague figures. It asserted that the 11 biggest Japanese banks had less than 2 trillion yen in bad loans, about $15.5 billion at current exchange rates. Many analysts and even some Government regulators say the number could easily top $150 billion, and some estimates run to well over $200 billion.
"Whatever the amount is, it will increase substantially during the course of this year, without doubt," said David Atkinson, an analyst here for Salomon Brothers. The banks' profits are likely to be hurt for several years, he added, and that will continue to crimp their ability to expand overseas.
Seeking to end the months of damaging speculation, Government officials have been forced to state openly that they will stand behind every major bank no matter what.
"Our financial system is not so fragile," Tadao Chino, the Vice Minister for International Affairs at the Finance Ministry, insisted recently. But, he felt compelled to add, "We don't think the bankruptcy of a financial institution can be justified."
Yoshihiro Watanabe, deputy general manager of the Bank of Tokyo's planning division, noted that even Japan's ballooning trade surplus, which is headed for a record this year, is not enough to fuel the banking growth it did during the 1980's.
"In the past when the surplus grew, the position of Japanese banks abroad grew," he said. "That is not happening this time. The years of big growth are over."
 
How the Boom Began
 The Japanese boom began in the 1980's, after the Japanese agreed to almost double the value of the yen against the dollar in an effort to shrink their yawning trade surpluses. To avoid a recession, the Government lowered interest rates.
That began a remarkable surge in the growth of the money supply. The financial system was awash in funds, which translated into soaring stock and property prices, strong economic growth and a surplus of funds for Japanese bankers to lend.
Looking for ways to use this cheap money to grab market share overseas, Japanese banks became major lenders for leveraged buyouts on Wall Street and for foreign property companies, like Olympia & York Developments Ltd., whose empire is now tottering. They also made a major business of issuing letter of credit to American municipalities that were financing municipal bonds, at rates that American banks said were absurdly low.
The number of Japanese bank branches overseas grew to 327 at the end of last year, from 139 in 1980. The Japanese banks also acquired banks in California and elsewhere to channel their loans around the world.
Mr. Kobayashi of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank spent four and a half years in Los Angeles trying to expand his bank's influence. "I had a mission there," he said. "It was to look for an acquisition."
As it happens, he failed, which in hindsight is proving to be a kind of success. Dai-Ichi Kangyo did end up acquiring 60 percent of CIT Financial from Manufacturers Hanover Trust in 1989, but otherwise it is scaling back.
"Our market share is declining in the United States, but this is still our most important foreign market," Mr. Kobayashi said. "It's just not necessary for us to grow overseas with the speed we did in the past."
Within Japan, the banks' loan problems have been worse. Among the prominent casualties here are these:
*Itoman & Company, once a textile trading house, lost hundreds of millions of dollars on purchases of art and property and is now suffocating under nearly $11 billion of debts, owed mostly to Sumitomo Bank.
*Dai-Ichi Real Estate, which owns the Tiffany Building in New York, is struggling under about $10 billion of borrowings, owed to a group headed by Mitsui Trust and Banking Corporation.
*The Shuwa Corporation, whose properties include Arco Plaza in Los Angeles, has been swamped by $10 billion in debt and is being rehabilitated by a group that includes Sumitomo Bank.
*E.I.E., a little-known electronics concern that suddenly began acquiring hotels around the world, is now suffering under about $7.7 billion of debt, owed mostly to the Long-Term Credit Bank.
"The banks overexpanded," said Mr. Mikuni of Mikuni & Company. "We cannot muddle through without changing the system in some fundamental ways."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

METRO DIGEST
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
FEW JOBS FOR TEEN-AGERS
The job market for New York City teen-agers is the worst in memory and the worst among major cities in the United States, government labor experts and business executives say. Analysts attribute the erosion in youth employment to cutbacks in entry-level jobs and new competition from immigrant workers. "This economy has been bad for everyone, and teen-agers are at the bottom," said Eli Ginzberg, a labor economist at Columbia University. A1.
 
TEACHERS PROTEST A BEATING
Outraged over the beating of a social studies teacher in his classroom, teachers at Adlai E. Stevenson High School in the east Bronx rallied against what they called dangerous conditions at the school. The teachers have asked their union to authorize a strike if safety does not improve. Shortly after the protest, a student was charged in the assault. B3.
 
CRIME FALLS IN MIDTOWN
Major crime in midtown Manhattan fell sharply in the first four months of this year, continuing a major decline in the area over the last several years, a ranking police official told business leaders. The drop was attributed to the presence of more police officers on patrol, augmented by an increase in private security guards hired by business groups. B3.
 
REGION
 
PRIMARY SEASON ENDS QUIETLY
New Jersey's Presidential primary season ended fittingly -- with a rally on the State House steps for Paul Tsongas, who retired from the campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination several weeks ago. President Bush did not visit New Jersey during his campaign. The Democratic front-runner, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, visited two New Jersey schools but avoided reporters over the last two weeks. A19.
 
Many new voters won't vote. A19.
 
A TAX PROPOSAL IN NASSAU
After treading lightly for months out of fear of an anti-tax backlash, Nassau County legislators are coming together on a financial bailout plan that includes a $40 million annual tax increase. "The time has come to put political posturing aside," said Joseph N. Mondello, the Republican county chairman, as he announced his support for a county mortgage-recording tax that would be one of the highest in the state. B4.
 
FIGHTING DRUNKEN DRIVING
Suffolk County's District Attorney declared war on drunken drivers, imposing what he called the toughest regulations in the state to deal with the state's highest rate of alcohol-related highway fatalities. Starting Aug. 1 repeat offenders and drivers who are severely drunk would have operators' licenses and registration tags seized upon arrest "as evidence in their cases," barring further legal driving until their cases are cleared. And under a proposed law, their cars, too, could be seized. B4.

Forget the hot dogs, rolls and charcoal. The new state park proposed by the Town of East Hampton, L.I., is going to be 20 feet below the surface of Fort Pond Bay. It would be New York's first underwater state park, and the main attraction would a sunken British frigate. B6.

HEADLINE: Diving for Diversion;
Albany Considers a Shipwreck Park

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 1

 BODY:
Forget the hot dogs, rolls and charcoal. The new state park proposed by the Town of East Hampton is going to be 20 feet below the surface of Fort Pond Bay.
If approved, the park would be New York's first underwater state park, and the main attraction would be the H.M.S. Culloden, a 74-gun frigate that sank more than 200 years ago and is one of the oldest known shipwrecks in the vicinity of Montauk Point. 
 "It would be an interpretive underwater trail for divers, monitored and guided, and an on-land museum," said Larry Penny, director of the Town of East Hampton's Department of Natural Resources.
The 161-foot Culloden sank off the eastern highland of Fort Pond Bay on Jan. 22, 1781, while in pursuit of French vessels sent to assist the American colonists. All 600 crewmen escaped with their lives. The wreck was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1979.
 
Looted by Hurricane
 Town officials believe that turning the site into a state park would help protect the Culloden from treasure hunters. There are still several triangular stacks of cannonballs and a few cannon on the wreck, local divers say. But once there were a few thousand cannonballs, and local lore has it that every East End resident with a boat and a wet suit has one.
Some security is offered by employees of the State Department of Environmental Conservation and the town, who randomly check boats and divers for stolen artifacts.
Last summer, Hurricane Bob washed artifacts from the Culloden ashore, and dive boats congregated like a flock of seagulls. Cannonballs weighing 25 to 30 pounds, bits of brass fastenings, silverware and pottery were taken away, Mr. Penny said.
Much of the Culloden's hull is buried in the sand, and local officials have drafted plans to excavate it under the sponsorship of the Montauk Historical Society. A $1.5 million state grant under the 1988 Environmental Quality Bond Act is pending for the project, Mr. Penny said. Additionally, Suffolk County has promised $3.5 million, and the state Heritage Fund has pledged $1.5 million. No additional state financing would be required to turn the site into a state park, officials said.
Three agencies -- the Education Department, the Office of General Services and Department of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation -- must review the state park proposal.
"We're looking for a site that has an interesting experience for diving and is not historically or environmentally sensitive," said Philip Lord, a senior scientist at the Department of Education and a member of the review panel.
Mr. Lord warned that the Culloden site might not fill the bill and said that, given the state's fiscal problems, "it's hard to imagine any expansion of the park system."
Still, Henry Moeller, a Long Island marine archeologist who spent a decade mapping the Culloden's remains, is hopeful. Mr. Moeller, who has been named the project's official marine archeologist, found the blueprints used by the shipwrights who built the Culloden at Deptford, England, in 1747.
"If Montauk would focus on drawing tourists into the economy by having a museum or an underwater park," he said, "that's the way to help the economy of eastern Long Island, with tourism. There's a lot of material there."

GRAPHIC: Photo: On the bluff above the beach near Montauk Point, Walter Galcik, left, and Larry Penny studied charts that map what would be the state's first underwater park, the place where H.M.S. Culloden sank more than 200 years ago. The two area residents have pushed the proposal. (Rameshwar Das for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Nassau Sees Mortgage-Recording Tax as Solution to Its Money Problem

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., June 1

 BODY:
After treading softly for months out of a fear of an anti-tax backlash, county legislators from both parties are coming together on a Nassau County financial bailout plan that includes as its centerpiece a $40 million annual tax increase.
"The time has come to put political posturing aside," said Joseph N. Mondello, the presiding supervisor from the Town of Hempstead and the Republican county chairman, as he announced his support for a county mortgage-recording tax that would be one of the highest in the state. 
 Within hours, several Democrats signaled that they, too, could support at least some portion of the tax if it was part of a package that also cut into county spending on consultants and managers, which Democrats consider patronage, and the outlines of deal began to take shape.
But the shift in priorities appeared to reflect less the ebbing of anti-tax fervor than bipartisan frustration over a budget-cutting exercise that for a time almost halted the delivery of some services in the county without solving its financial problems.
Now both Democrats and Republicans are betting that the new tax will be more palatable to voters, especially those who do not have to pay it, than allowing the county's political stalemate and fiscal disarray to continue.
They are also betting that County Clerk Harold W. McConnell, who would be responsible for collecting the tax, will have cleared up continuing problems in his office by the time the new tax takes effect. Earlier this year, it was reported that the office was months behind in recording deeds and mortgages and that millions of dollars in taxes and fees collected by the office were stashed in envelopes awaiting processing.
After the disclosure, Mr. McConnell, an elected Republican, said he would speed up the automation of his office.
The new tax plan avoids raising the unpopular property tax, which affects most residents, in favor of raising the mortgage-recording tax -- imposed on real estate developers, home buyers and homeowners who refinance their mortgages. Currently, the state imposes a 1 percent tax in Nassau County; the county plan would add another 1 percent county tax. The increase requires the approval of the State Legislature.
The new tax would raise the tax on most mortgages to the highest level in the state. Only New York City has higher rates, and those apply only to mortgages of $500,000 or more.
"The situation is so desperate that I am willing to go along with that," said Benjamin Zwirn, a Democratic supervisor from North Hempstead, "because the tax doesn't affect everyone in the county."
But real-estate agents and developers worry that it would increase the cost of many mortgage refinancings, at a time when low interest rates encourage refinancing, and dampen a real estate industry already in the throes of bankruptcies and faltering property values.
"This is an unbelievably callous disregard of economic realities," said Stephen Hess, president of the Association for a Better Long Island. "They are not only going to kill the golden goose, they are going to render it."
After watching several incumbents swept from office last November by voters enraged over soaring property taxes, Republicans on the Board of Supervisors rewrote the budget prepared by the Republican County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, to reduce the county work force by one-fourth.
But after more than 2,600 full-time workers were pared from the payroll, many through layoffs, the layoff program was called to a halt as officials began to fear that services in one of the wealthiest and most heavily taxed counties in the country would crumble. The county was left with a $129 million deficit this year.
Under a plan put forward by Republican supervisors, the gap would be closed over the next 18 months by a series of steps: $53 million through the mortgage-recording tax, a $15 million cut in consulting contracts, $8 million through attrition. The balance would be made up by up to $75 million in general obligation bonds.
 
County Executive's Role
 Republican supervisors put the plan together, after months of stalled talks with Democrats, in a legislative body with a complicated weighted voting system in which neither party has a working majority.
Last week, Mr. Gulotta, the County Executive, held separate meetings with Democratic and Republican supervisors, but to the frustration of supervisors was unwilling to put forward any plan of his own to solve the county's fiscal mess.
Members of both parties said they believed that Mr. Gulotta wanted to ask the Legislature for the authority to borrow up to $125 million in bonds to close the county deficit, produce a surplus and cut county taxes next year, before he faces re-election.
In the end the Republican plan included many ideas originally proposed by Democrats, including deeper cuts in consultants, and the establishment of a bipartisan spending review panel.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chevron Set To Combine Five Units

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
The Chevron Corporation said yesterday that it would combine its five oil and gas research and technology organizations into one unit, which the company said would save more than $60 million a year in operating costs.
The consolidation, which will trim the units' current staff by 450, to 1,100, adds to several cost-cutting moves by San Francisco-based Chevron since last fall that are part of a restructuring started two years ago by Kenneth T. Derr, chairman and chief executive. It also reflects the push to streamline operations at many American oil companies that are trying to cope with depressed margins in their refinery operations. Many oil companies, Chevron included, are also increasingly focusing their exploration and production efforts overseas. 
 Analysts said yesterday that the move had been anticipated, and the announcement had little impact on Chevron's stock, which closed yesterday at $71.50, up 12.5 cents, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. "It's just another step in the process," said Michael L. Mayer, an oil industry analyst with Wertheim Schroder.
Chevron, the largest producer of oil products in the United States, has established a new company, the Chevron Petroleum Technology Company, to be responsible for technical services and research in oil and gas exploration and production. "We must focus our technology efforts more clearly to improve the long-term competitiveness of the company," said Bill Crain, corporate vice president of exploration and production.
The president of the new Houston-based subsidariy is Donald L. Paul, 46 years old, the vice president of exploration research for the Chevron Oil Field Research Company.
Chevron said in April that it would slash its exploration and production subsidiary by 2,300 workers, or 28 percent of its staff. The company also announced in April that it planned to lay off 700 workers at its refinery in Port Arthur, Tex.
Chevron's earnings have suffered lately along with those of other oil companies because of lower prices for crude oil and natural gas, and weak demand for chemicals and refined products. In the first quarter, its net income was $304 million on revenues of $9.7 billion, compared with $557 million on revenues of $10.8 billion in the period a year earlier.
Because of its focus on the United States market, Ron Londe, an analyst with A. G. Edwards, said the company's fortunes should improve with the nation's economy. "I think they're doing the right things to improve the company, and when things turn around, you'll see benefits to the bottom line," he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Banks Are Urged to Discuss Study on Low-Income Loans

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
A community group that has often criticized banks for lending too little in low-income areas sent letters last week to the chief executives of more than 350 banks across the country, asking them to participate in a conference on July 12 in New York City to discuss new lending programs.
The community group -- the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now, known as Acorn -- is expected to publish a study on Thursday of bank lending and deposit-taking showing that residents of low-income areas provide far more in deposits to banks than the banks use to make loans in those areas. 
 Acorn officials describe the study as proof that banks are denying credit to businesses and consumers in low-income areas, and thus contributing to the areas' economic problems.
 
 
An 'Eye-Opening' Difference
 "The discrepancy between what banks take in deposits in low-income areas and what they issue in loans is not surprising,' said John L. Kest, Acorn's chief organizer in New York City. "But the magnitude of the gap is eye-opening."
Acorn officials had not yet compiled all the data for the study, which covers 20 cities and does not focus on the practices of individual banks. Other studies, however, have shown that some banks have issued loans equal to only 25 percent of the deposits they collect in low-income neighborhoods, or half the lending rate in higher-income neighborhoods.
Deepak Bhargava, a legislative representative at Acorn's Washington office, said the low level of lending in poor neighborhoods was one reason some banks cited when contending that branches in poor areas were not profitable and should be closed. He noted that the new study was limited to mortgage lending because data on other kinds of bank loans were not readily available with the ZIP codes of the borrowers.
 Although people do not always do their banking where they live, Mr. Bhargava said the gap between deposits and mortgage loans was great enough to justify more efforts by bankers to issue loans in poor areas.
Chemical Bank of New York is the largest bank so far to agree to attend the conference. "We are interested in economic development of the low-income areas where we do business, and Acorn's agenda is also our agenda," said Carol Parry, managing director at Chemical for community development.
Acorn is seeking to help banks develop lending programs that would reduce the high rejection rate for low-income mortgage applicants and would make more money available for small businesses.

HEADLINE: Purchasing Index Has A Big Gain

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Spurred by sharp increases in industrial production and exports, the nation's manufacturing economy expanded robustly in May, according to a monthly survey of the nation's purchasing managers. Economists interpreted the rise as a strong sign that the economy was strengthening.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of economic activity rose to 56.3 percent in May from 51.3 percent in April. It was the index's highest reading in nearly four years; the figure stood at 58.2 percent in July 1988. The group says a reading below 50 percent indicates that the economy is contracting, while a reading above 50 is a sign of expansion. 
 "It's a solid sign that this recovery is shaping up as a manufacturing-led recovery," said Stephen H. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "We've got manufacturing companies benefiting from a competitive dollar, from restructurings and lean inventories. And as demand picks up, they are really building momentum. And all the signs suggest that this manufacturing revival is for real and has staying power."
 
 
First Monthly Indicator
 The monthly index is compiled from a survey of more than 300 purchasing managers at a wide range of industrial companies. It is considered important because it is the first significant indicator of economic activity in the previous month.
Last week, the Commerce Department said that the economy grew 2.4 percent in the first quarter, the largest quarterly gain in three years. The department also said corporate profits increased at an annual rate of 8 percent, the highest gain in four years.
But the purchasing managers report came amid other, mixed economic news today. The Commerce Department said that income from wages, salaries, rents and other sources inched up a tenth of a percent in April, and that consumer spending rose three-tenths of a percent. In a more bullish report, the department said the country's trade performance in the first quarter of 1992 was its second best in nearly a decade, largely because of lower oil prices. The merchandise trade deficit shrank by 5.8 percent, to $17.5 billion. But construction spending slipped slightly in April. [Page D20.]
 
 
Bad News for Bonds
 The sharp increase in the purchasing managers' report was taken as an unfavorable development in the bond market, where it apparently curbed hopes for additional cuts in interest rates by the Federal Reserve to stimulate the economy.
"After slowing in April, the economy resumed the steady growth trend, which began in February, with a sharp increase in May," said Robert J. Bretz, director of corporate purchasing at Pitney Bowes Inc. and the chairman of the purchasing managers' survey committee. He added that "the lofty level of new orders should be more than enough to assure that growth in the second quarter" will be respectably better than in the first.
New orders, which have generally remained strong for several months, rose sharply in May, the report said. The association's index of new orders rose to 61 percent, from 56.7 percent in April. The increase in new orders is widely expected to carry over into growth in industrial production.
Orders for export, which had slipped in recent months, also showed a strong increase, despite the generally higher value of the dollar and a slowdown in many foreign economies. The association's index of new orders for export rose to 56.9 percent, from 52.3 percent in April.
 As a result of the increases in orders, production soared in May to the highest level in more than four years. The production index rose to 62.9 percent in May from 56.6 percent in April. The association said that the production improvement was widespread and affected virtually all industries.
The association's price index also rose sharply, to 56.3 in May from 49.6 in April. It was the highest level since December 1990, when the index stood at 58.4 percent. The association said that many manufacturers, who have been trying to raise prices for some time, were beginning to have some success, largely because of increased demand for some products.
Inventories rose sharply in May, with the index of inventories increasing to 49.2 percent, from 42.4 percent in April.
Employment levels increased in May, with the association's employment index rising to 49.1 percent, from 43.9 percent in April. The May figure was the highest since April 1989, when the index stood at 50 percent. Economists said the May increase was a signal that the economic recovery was beginning to have some impact on industrial companies' hiring patterns.

HEADLINE: Board Room Back-Scratching?

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
At first glance, the latest proxy statement from the B. F. Goodrich Company sounds all the right notes in the executive pay debate. It details for the first time how the company links pay and performance and boasts that executive pay is reviewed by a board committee that "consists entirely of outside directors."
What the proxy does not spotlight is that until a year ago one of the outside directors who helped set the pay for Goodrich's chief executive, John D. Ong, was Joseph A. Pichler, the chief executive of the Kroger Company -- whose compensation committee included Mr. Ong as an outside director. Thus, Mr. Pichler's $890,370 pay for 1991 was partly determined by a man whose own $905,113 pay Mr. Pichler helped set. 
 Such interlocking arrangements, which are difficult to detect from public documents, do not in themselves constitute impropriety. Indeed, Mr. Ong's 1991 pay dropped by about a million dollars from 1990.
Yet in a year when politicians, investors and even the Japanese are pointing to executive pay as a symbol of corporate America's ills, the potential for conflicts is being singled out by some shareholder activists and others as evidence that some board rooms are closed societies where friends often decide sensitive issues among themselves.
"That's the worst sort of potential conflict of interest, when you're serving on each other's jury to determine compensation," said Thomas J. Neff. president of Spencer Stuart, an executive search firm that conducts about 50 director searches a year in the United States. "There's the temptation and the risk of not being objective."
A recent computer search of the proxy statements of the 788 largest public companies by Directorship, a Westport, Conn., consulting firm, disclosed 39 instances, or nearly 5 percent, where heads of companies sit on each other's boards. Five of those couplings have unusual influence over each other's pay since they also sit on each other's compensation committees.
Besides Goodrich and Kroger, they are Conagra Inc. and Valmont Industries; the Kellogg Company and the Upjohn Company; the Sonoco Products Company and the Nationsbank Corporation, and Allergan Inc. and Beckman Instruments Inc.
It is only in the last few years that computers have been enlisted to help analyze the minutiae contained in corporate documents that disclose executive pay. But sociologists, business historians and others who have studied the issue believe that the incidence of interlocking directorships has remained fairly constant since the early part of the century, when the fear was collusion.
Catapulting the issue back into the spotlight today is the public's concern over the spectacle of an already well-paid corporate elite more preoccupied with their pay packages than corporate performance. Now, there is growing apprehension that those charged with policing pay are not always independent.
The mere presence of interlocking directors does not automatically raise improprieties. Indeed senior executives at 3 of the 10 companies in question including Goodrich saw their total compensation tumble in 1991, while the others for the most part took home pay packages that were roughly clustered around the $2 million or so that the average chief executive earned in those years. But the abundance of interlocking directorships may be symptomatic of some of the deeper problems in the board room.
Not surprisingly, 5 of the 10 companies with interlocking compensation committee members include other members whose independence could be questioned.
For instance, 4 of the 10 companies have executives on their compensation committees whose business dealings with the company are extensive enough that they have to be disclosed in the proxy statements.
 
Relatives on Committee
 Sonoco Products, a packaging concern based in Hartsville, S.C., describes the members of its compensation committees as nonemployees of the company. Nonetheless, it has one executive on its compensation committee who once worked for the company and another whose objectivity could very well be tested: He is F .L. H. Coker, brother of the chief executive, C. W. Coker.
The company does show some restraint. Also on its board, though not on its compensation committee, is a third Coker, J. L., the chief executive's cousin, and a fourth director, J. C. Fort, whom a company spokesman described as a distant relative of Mr. Coker, though that fact is omitted from the proxy. A Coker family ancestor founded the company, although none of the four descendants on the board individually own more than 2 percent of the company's stock.
And indeed, the precise makeup of the committee may be moot. According to the proxy, the committee annually "reviews the salaries of executive officers and recommends increases as deemed appropriate." The possibility of salary decreases is never broached.
"Last year was just about the second time in over 20 years when our earnings from continuing operations didn't better the previous year," said Richard Puffer, Sonoco's spokesman. "So, we normally do have increases."
Asked about the propriety of these symbiotic relationships, the 10 companies insisted that such people should be counted as outside directors so long as they were not currently on the payroll.
Even Goodrich and Kroger, which took Mr. Ong and Mr. Pichler off each other's compensation committees last year, defended the arrangement while it lasted and explained the moves as nothing more than the normal rotation of committee assignments. "The important thing to focus on is whether the company's compensation program is performance-based, and ours is," said Gary Habegger, Goodrich's vice president for human resources. "If it is, you have much less chance for that type of situation to be a real issue."
Two companies, Nationsbank and Valmont, do not contend that their compensation committees consist exclusively of outsiders. After all, Nationsbank's chief executive, Hugh L. McColl Jr., serves on his company's compensation committee and Valmont's chairman and biggest shareholder, Robert B. Daugherty, sits on his company's committee.
Spokesmen for both companies point out that neither man is chairman of his respective committee and that they abstain whenever their own pay is discussed. "If they were the sole members of the compensation committee, you'd have a point," said Brian Stanley, the treasurer of Valmont, a metal fabricator outside Omaha. "But when we have six people, it's just not an issue."
Most companies are free to put anyone they please on their compensation committee -- since there is no Federal requirement to even form a committee. "If you do your compensation by throwing darts against the wall, as long as you disclose it, you've fulfilled your duties," said John D. Heine, a spokesman for the Securities and Exchange Commission.
That regulatory attitude may be one reason why 75, or 9.5 percent, of the 788 companies in the Directorship study report that their chairmen serve on the panels that decide their pay. Even people who are very much part of the business establishment say that such committee configurations create unfortunate appearance problems. Indeed, the Business Roundtable, a group of the leaders of several major companies, recommended as much as two years ago that compensation committees should "limit membership to nonmanagement directors only."
Not doing that "opens you up for a lot of difficult scrutiny," said Thomas F. Madison, the president of markets for U S West Communications and a director who serves on several compensation committees, including Valmont's. Though he said he ordinarily would not tolerate having the chief executive on the compensation committee, he said Valmont was a special case since Mr. Daugherty dropped the chief executive's title in 1988 and drew relatively little compensation from the company.
Since chief executives have exactly the sort of experience that other bosses value, many shareholders say they would tolerate having a few chief executives in the mix.
But how tough might a watchdog be when the object of surveillance can always retaliate? "It would just be very difficult for the type of independence that is required of a board member to exist in that kind of environment," said Ralph V. Whitworth, president of the United Shareholders Association.
Further skewing how much chief executives take home on average is the tendency of many companies to deliberately set pay above their industry average to prevent defections. "That process of peer adustment is a problem to me as an economist because I see what it does to the average," said M. Kathryn Eickhoff, an economist who serves on the boards of five large public companies, including Upjohn.
The other culprit, in her view, is not interlocking directorships like the one that exists between Upjohn and Kellogg but simply the sheer number of chief executives who serve on compensation committees.
"I wonder whether it is too easy for them to rationalize the salaries being suggested," she said. "It seems to me it's easier to find such salaries acceptable if you've previously received one."
 
Regional Patterns Seen
 Another common pattern is that interlocking directors tend to be part of tight regional clusters, such as Conagra and Valmont, both Nebraska companies. "We're a fairly small town and we don't have many public companies that would be called industrials, so there's not a great variety of locals to draw from," said Charles M. Harper, chief executive of Conagra and a member of the compensation committee of Valmont.
Personally, he does not see anything wrong with looking close to home for directorial talent. "If I trusted somebody, I don't care if they were a second cousin to the c.e.o.," said Mr. Harper, who predicts that his own fiscal year 1992 compensation will be down significantly, as he believes it should, given this year's performance. "The way to test that from a shareholder's point of view is what are the results, and how does compensation track with results?"

HEADLINE: Report Benefits Big 3's Shares

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 1

 BODY:
Shares of Detroit's Big Three auto makers jumped today on a report that the companies planned to raise third-quarter production sharply.
The General Motors Corporation topped the New York Stock Exchange's list of most-active stocks, gaining $2.125, to $41.50. The second-most-active issue was Chrysler, which jumped $1.625, to $19.75. Ford Motor's shares were the third most heavily traded, rising $2, to $46.375. 
 Analysts said investors rushed to buy the shares based on a report in Ward's Automotive Reports, a trade publication. Ward's said the American car makers and the seven Japanese "transplant" companies planned to build 17.4 percent more cars and 19.5 percent more trucks in the third quarter than they did a year earlier.
The production goals were stronger than expected, said David Garrity, an analyst at McDonald & Company. "That's indicating stronger demand," he said.
Mr. Garrity said the third-quarter production schedules added to growing evidence, including stronger sales and rising consumer confidence, that the American industry was recovering from its worst year ever. The Big Three auto makers lost a combined $4.5 billion last year.
Many analysts had predicted a third-quarter loss for the nation's car makers. But analysts have recently revised their figures upward.

HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Performance Much Better in Quarter

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
The country's trade performance in the first three months of 1992 was its second best in nearly a decade, the Government said today.
The Commerce Department said that the country's merchandise trade deficit shrank by 5.8 percent, to $17.5 billion in the first quarter from $18.5 billion in the fourth quarter of 1991, as a big decline in oil prices helped offset a slowdown in export demand. 
 Since the spring of 1983, only a $16.4 billion deficit in the spring of last year was lower.
Exports totaled $107.83 billion in the quarter, essentially unchanged from the last three months of 1991, while imports fell nine-tenths of 1 percent, to $125.29 billion. The trade deficit is the difference between imports and exports. American demand for manufactured goods and farm products climbed by $743 million, but was offset by a 15 percent drop in the bill for imported oil, by $1.8 billion, to $10.4 billion, reflecting a price decline to $15.28 a barrel, down from $18.04 in the fourth quarter. The volume was essentially unchanged at 7.42 million barrels a day.
United States exports were off by $26 million, leaving them essentially unchanged from their fourth-quarter level, which had been a record high.
Economists said the lack of further growth in this area showed that the export boom, one of the few bright spots over the last three years, was ending. Last year's recession, which saw the economy shrink by seven-tenths of 1 percent, would have been three times as bad if it had not been for strength in overseas sales, Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch, said.
"But this year the shoe is on the other foot," Mr. Steinberg said. "The U.S. economy is beginning to recover, but the rest of the world economy is either in or near recession."
Mr. Steinberg forecast that this year's trade deficit was likely to worsen by around $10 billion, reflecting sluggish demand in Europe, Japan and Canada. Paul Lally, an economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, said he believed the country's trade deficit would gradually deteriorate for the rest of the year "as our economy perks up, and there is sluggishness overseas." Such forecasts are not welcome news to Bush Administration officials, who are counting on further export gains to help keep the recovery alive in an election year.
The Administration has been pressing Germany and Japan in particular to stimulate their domestic economies to lift demand for American products.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said that while the Administration was happy with recent interest rate cuts by the Bank of Japan, he still hoped to see the Japanese Government increase spending even more to stimulate domestic demand and lower the country's growing trade surplus.

HEADLINE: Consumer Income Rose 0.1% in April, U.S. Says

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
A revival in the manufacturing sector led to a slight rise in consumer incomes during April, the Government said today, raising hopes that the recovery is gathering momentum.
The Commerce Department said income from wages, salaries, rents and other sources inched up one-tenth of 1 percent in April. It was the third increase in a row but was well below gains of four-tenths of 1 percent in March and 1 percent in February. 
 But the department said manufacturing payrolls jumped by $4.4 billion in April, four times the $1.1 billion increase registered in March.
 
Consumer Spending Rose 0.3%
Consumer spending, the engine of recovery that fuels two-thirds of national economic activity, rose three-tenths of 1 percent in April after a flat performance in March.
Jack Albertine, an economist who heads Albertine Enterprises Inc. in Washington, said the figures showed "a recovery that is on track, with slow but steady gains being made in most sectors."
Lynn Reaser, an economist with First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles, referring to stronger hiring by manufacturing companies, said, "That will support increased consumer spending in May after the slowdowns we've seen in March and April."
Figures on May employment are scheduled for publication by the Labor Department on Friday.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Has Mixed Results Despite U.S. Economic Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mixed on world currency markets yesterday, losing ground in domestic trading despite good news about the health of the American economy.
Gold prices rose after losing ground overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $337.80 an ounce, up $1.40 from Friday. The Republic National Bank said gold was up $1.35, to a late bid of $337.60. 
 The dollar settled higher in overseas trading, aided by a report showing that American manufacturing strengthened in May for the fourth straight month and grew at the fastest clip in almost four years, according to the National Association of Purchasing Management.
But the report was balanced somewhat by fresh Government data showing that Americans' incomes and spending rose anemically in April while construction spending fell three-tenths of 1 percent. The data seemed to underscore the fitful nature of the economic recovery.
 
'Down Trend' Seen for Dollar
 Unconfirmed reports that the Bank of Japan had entered the market to sell dollars and buy yen in a move to support the Japanese currency pulled the dollar from its highs.
"It's perceived that the dollar has slipped into a down trend," said Kevin Lawrie, director of foreign exchange at the Bank of Boston. "If a string of good economic data is not enough to bring the dollar higher, I don't know what is."
In Tokyo the dollar closed at 126.78 yen, down 1.55 yen from last Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 127.55 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 126.95 yen, down from 127.60 yen on Friday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.8220, from $1.8295 late Friday. In New York it cost $1.8275 to buy one pound, less expensive than Friday's $1.8282.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.6045 German marks, down from 1.6080; 1.4550 Swiss francs, down from 1.4560; 5.3910 French francs, down from 5.3990; 1,209.00 Italian lire, down from 1,210.00, and 1.2031 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2048.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
The Trend In Dividend Payments

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
The revival in dividend payments may be running out of gas.
The Standard & Poor's Corporation reported yesterday that 106 companies announced dividend increases in May. That figure was up from 89 in May 1991, but was below the 110 that reported increases in May 1990, on the eve of the recession. 
 The S.& P. figures also showed that 13 companies reduced their dividends in May, one more than in May 1991. It was the first time this year that that figure showed an increase, providing another indication that the revival of dividends might be slowing.
Changes in dividends are often lagging indicators of corporate performance, because companies hesitate to raise dividends until managements are certain that profits have risen and will not soon decline, and because companies often try to avoid cutting dividends until bad news on the profit front is unmistakable. Thus the dip in good news on dividends need not be a sign that the economy is again weakening.
Nonetheless, the news on May dividends did remove some of the excitement -- and the hopes for a rapid revival in corporate profits -- that was generated when S.& P. reported a month ago that dividend payouts had risen to 136 in April, exceeding not only 1991's recession figure of 106 but also the April 1990 level of 129.
The S.& P. figures count only the number of companies that change their dividends, not the amount of the changes. As such, the figures provide a view of actions by both large and small companies.
But another indicator of dividend payments, reflecting the large companies that dominate the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index, moved higher in May. That could be a sign that larger companies are doing better than the rest, which would be consistent with the stock market's movement since early this year, in which large stocks generally outperformed smaller ones.
Arnold Kaufman, the editor of Standard & Poor's Outlook newsletter, said that the indicated annual payout rate of the S.& P. 500 index, assuming all companies pay their current dividends for the foreseeable future, without increases or decreases, was now $12.42, up from a rate of $12.28 at the end of April.
That rise came as companies from Home Depot to McDonald's, and from Waste Management to American International, all members of the S.& P. 500, announced higher dividends.
Last year, the S.& P. 500 paid $12.20 in dividends. But early this year, with many companies cutting payouts, the annual rate was down to $12.13. Mr. Kaufman estimated that the total for this year would rise by 5 percent.
Although profits were surprisingly strong in the first quarter of this year, dividend increases may still be held back by the fact that dividends now make up an unusually large percentage of profits. For that proportion to decline to more normal levels, profits will have to rise faster than dividend payouts.
The figures on the numbers of companies raising dividends are highly seasonal, because many companies make dividend decisions in the same month each year. Mr. Kaufman said that May was one of the less active months and that it was too early to conclude that this year's mild surge in the number of companies increasing dividends was slowing.
He said he expected the number of companies raising payouts this year to be up about 18 percent, to around the same level as in 1990. That year, he noted, "was not a good year, but it was not a disaster like 1991," when a total of 1,086 dividend increases was announced, down from 1,263 in 1990.
The 1991 figure was the lowest for any full year since 1962, with the exception of 1970 and 1971, when Federal wage and price controls restrained dividend increases.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Owners Take Leash And Make It Longer

BYLINE: By Murray Chass

 BODY:
Rosa Wilson was filled with pride yesterday when the Wilson family of Bamberg, S.C., learned that son Preston was a first-round choice of the Mets in the baseball draft of high school and college players. She was even prouder that "my baby," an outfielder and pitcher and the president of the Ehrhardt High School student body, will graduate Thursday with a 4.0 grade average.
But there was one aspect of this week's major developments in the life of her son and Mookie Wilson's adopted son that did not please Rosa Wilson: the new rule that extends a club's rights to a drafted player from one year to as long as five years. 
 "We are aware of the rule," she said by telephone. "I hate it. I don't think it's fair. I really don't think it's fair for a club to tie up a player that long. It's not fair to any player."
When the club owners changed the rule earlier this year, they were not trying to be fair to the high school and college students. They said the rule would actually encourage high school students to go to college because they could still sign with the drafting team when they finished. But they didn't fool anyone.
This is the Brien Taylor rule, named for the No. 1 pick a year ago, who used the threat of going to college -- a place he previously had made clear he had no desire to be -- to extract $1.55 million from the Yankees. The rule is intended to eliminate such a threat as a negotiating weapon and reduce the cost of signing the player.
"There's been so much controversy about this rule that I don't really know everything about it," said Derek Jeter, the high school shortstop the Yankees made their first-round pick this year. "My goal is just to play professionally. I guess there's nothing I can do about it."
Neither Jeter nor any other drafted player has any desire to fight the rule in court, but next Monday, George Nicolau, baseball's arbitrator, will begin a hearing on the Players Association's challenge to the rule. The owners' labor lawyers will argue that Nicolau doesn't have jurisdiction because amateur players aren't covered by the collective bargaining agreement. Union lawyers will counter that Nicolau does have jurisdiction and, anyway, the fairness issue overrides the jurisdictional question.
Allocation without representation is bad enough; drafts in all sports always have impinged on the rights of the players drafted because they don't have a say in where they will be working. But restricting the drafted player to negotiating with one club until one year after he leaves college makes the procedure even more onerous for the player, if economical for the club.
Economics dictated this year's draft. Scott Boras, the devil incarnate in the clubs' view, called it "the Wall Street draft."
"It's not a talent draft," said Boras, the agent who "advised" Taylor and other wealthy young men before him. "It's determined by what a team can assure itself it can sign a player for. On Wall Street, the value of the stock on the market is not necessarily the true value of the piece of paper. That's what you have here now. Economics are playing more a part of this."
When Houston selected third baseman Phil Nevin, Cleveland chose relief pitcher Paul Shuey and Montreal picked pitcher B. J. Wallace in the first three selections yesterday, they did not draft the player they felt was the most talented available. They drafted the player they felt they could sign for what they were willing to spend.
The Baltimore Orioles, awash in money from the gold mine they have discovered at Camden Yards, were the first team to pick they player considered the best available, money notwithstanding. Drafting fourth, they took Jeffrey Hammonds, a Stanford outfielder scouts generally felt was the best player in the draft.
Charles Johnson, a catcher with the University of Miami in the College World Series, was considered one of the best in the draft, but he lasted until the very last pick in the first round. The expansion Florida Marlins, Johnson's hometown team, finally uttered his name.
Unlike other clubs, the Yankees, for one, the Marlins were not uttering Boras's name in vain. Boras will advise Johnson and his family -- N.C.A.A. rules, absurd in their own right, prohibit college players from having agents.
So many clubs have expressed their distaste for Boras that the father of one prospective first-rounder felt compelled to correct an erroneous newsaper report that Boras would advise his son.
On May 22, Calvin Tucker of Chase City, Va., wrote the following to the Players Association: "USA Today printed incorrect information about my son Michael Tucker. Mr. Scott Boras is not and will not be our family adviser, agent or anything else. Please let the teams know this for us."
The association passed on the information to the clubs, and yesterday the Kansas City Royals made shortstop Michael Tucker the 10th pick in the draft.
"The clubs are putting themselves in a questionable legal position because that's a restraint of trade," Boras, a lawyer, said.
Boras said that Brien Taylor's mother was told last year by "something like 15 clubs" that if Boras were advising the family they would not draft the flame-throwing pitcher. Boras said Charles Johnson's family was contacted by 13 or 14 clubs asking if he would sign for a certain amount, numbers, he added, "far below his true-market value."
At least Johnson won't be subjected to the new rule. He and 14 other first-round selections had been chosen in prior drafts and thus come under the old rule that gives the drafting club rights to the player until the next draft. Preston Wilson and a dozen other first-rounders face the fallout from the Brien Taylor signing.
"We're going to leave it totally in the hands of his father," Rosa Wilson said of the former Mets' outfielder. "He definitely had his share of dealings with the business aspect. We'll be watching it very closely."
