HEADLINE: Architects Rediscover the Best City Planners: Citizens

BYLINE: By DANIEL GOLEMAN

 BODY:
BORROWING the methods of social science, a school of architects and urban planners is going beyond bricks and mortar to incorporate the often-ignored needs and preferences of those who will use public projects in their design.
That common-sense approach is taken for granted when people build for themselves, and it enjoyed a short-lived prominence in the urban planning of the 1960's and 1970's. But social scientists say it is rare in the inner city. 
 The results, they say, are parks and playgrounds that go unused, public housing that rapidly decays because people living there do not care for it and neighborhoods that are destroyed by projects meant to preserve them.
"It remains a radical idea to most architects in public projects to talk to the people who will use what they build, instead of just to those agencies who hire them," said Troy West, an architect at the School of Architecture of the New Jersey Institute of Technology in Newark. "We have several sociologists on our architecture faculty. We believe in integrating design with how people actually live, rather than forcing their lives to fit our designs."
The resurgence of this type of planning, known as "participatory design" or "advocacy planning," is being led by groups of social scientists, architects and urban planners who see themselves as being at the service of residents for whom they are building, rather than simply seeking to please the agencies that finance projects.
"Advocacy planning means speaking for those who will actually use the building, instead of doing research about them for those who hold the power," said Dr. Roger Hart, a psychologist who directs the Children's Environments Research Group at the City University of New York Graduate School. "It means helping people in a community do their own planning."
Mr. West cited very recently built low-income housing in Newark as an example of what happens when architects never meet the people who will use their buildings. "The houses are concrete blocks with tiny windows that make them look like prisons, no porches, and, instead of having yards, the houses front on a parking lot," he said, even though there was no need for the parking.
By contrast, a "sweat-equity" project of low-income housing near New Haven on which Mr. West worked with the occupants in the redesign has very different features: large, sunny windows, wood siding that can be freshly painted every few years, yards where gardens can be grown or children can play and porches where people can gather with neighbors in warm weather.
Like many others, the Newark project seems to have been designed to protect the buildings against the people who live there, rather than the effort in New Haven to give people buildings they will like and care for.
Mr. West first employed the new planning approach in successfully rebuilding an Pittsburgh neighborhood after riots there in the mid-1960's, and it is coming to center stage again.
Perhaps the most methodical example of advocacy planning is an international movement called "Healthy Cities." The movement, involving researchers in public health, social science and urban studies, measures the "health" of cities or neighborhoods using 30 or more variables, including rates of violent crimes, unemployment, poverty, homelessness, loneliness, air pollution, death and even an "annoyance index" linked to levels of noise and dirt.
 
'Multiplicity of Life'
 Such measures, most based on data already collected, are used to point to the areas of most urgent need in a city. Then these social scientists apply the participatory approach, "something akin to family therapy for a city," said Dr. Leonard Duhl, a psychiatrist and professor of public health and city planning at the University of California at Berkeley who is a founder of the Healthy Cities program.
The program convenes meetings of residents, business people, community groups and city agencies, where all are on an equal footing. Those most affected by a problem are asked to help from the start in designing a solution.
"You've got to deal with the multiplicity of life in the city rather than just one dimension," said Dr. Duhl, who is convening a meeting of those involved in Healthy City programs around the world, sponsored by the World Health Organization, in San Francisco in December 1993.
In Quebec, for example, a Healthy City project consulted with nearly 6,000 citizens of Rouyn-Noranda, a mining town of 27,000 northwest of Montreal. The result was six plans of action, including reducing sulfur emissions from a local smelter, and building a botanical garden and a recreational park for year-round use. In another Quebec city, the projects were very different, with prevention of vandalism near the top of the list.
 
Difference in Practice
 But the Healthy Cities approach is the exception rather than the rule. While many city planners and architects invoke the words of involving those for whom they plan, few actually do so in any meaningful way, proponents of advocacy planning say. For example, even when government guidelines require consulting those who will use buildings about the design, planners typically nod in that direction by simply offering two different designs and using public meetings to ask community leaders to choose one.
By contrast, full involvement means that people who will use a project are among those generating the basic specifications for it.
"It's the detailed knowledge that residents have that will make a design work or not," said Dr. Hart. "What will work is unique to each site. You have to adapt your design based on what residents tell you."
A case in point is the design of a playground to be built in the West Farms neighborhood, a poor, drug-ridden district of the South Bronx, peppered with glass-strewn vacant lots and bordered by two expressways and the Bronx Zoo.
In research with Selim Iltus, an architect and environmental psychologist, Dr. Hart held long discussions with groups of parents, teen-agers and children. It emerged that neighborhood residents avoided several city-built playgrounds in favor of impromptu basketball courts improvised using traffic signs as backboards and a vacant lot several blocks out of the neighborhood that is also used for basketball.
 
Dangers at Playgrounds
 To live in a topography of peril, parents, children and teen-agers avoid zones of drug dealers, crack users, prostitutes and homeless people. The city-built basketball court was popular 10 years ago, for instance, but since then it has become the most heavily used corner for drug deals.
Parents would not let their children play after school in two large, open schoolyards because they said the schoolyards were too isolated. The Bronx River Park playground was similarly off limits because it is home to drug dealers and prostitutes.
With neighborhood residents as co-researchers, Dr. Hart and his students conducted a series of surveys to find a site and design for a playground that would be used. Part of that planning involved asking the 900 students of the local public school what they would like in the playground.
What people think of as well-equipped playgrounds typically take care of only 10 percent of what children like to do when they play, Dr. Hart found in his research.
The standard features, like jungle gyms, are irrelevant to imaginary play like "house," to efforts like dam and road-building in dirt or sand and to socializing. "Getting together and talking in pairs or small groups is the single most popular playground activity," Dr. Hart said.
In addition, he found that standard playgrounds with basketball courts and baseball diamonds ignored the needs of girls. "Conventional wisdom in playground design holds that what teen-age girls mainly want is seats so they can watch boys play basketball and other sports, Dr. Hart said. "If you ask girls, that's just not so. But that's what they've been left with."
He found that teen-age girls in West Farms wanted a volleyball court, a small stage to practice dancing and out-of-the-way places where they could sit and talk.
The city has budgeted more than $2 million for the new playground in West Farms. Dr. Hart and his students have acted as consultants to help the neighborhood tell the Park Department just where in the neighborhood the playground will work best and what should be in it. The place chosen is an empty lot next to a strip of stores.
"The residents chose that site because between police on foot, shoppers, and association patrols, there will be enough eyes to protect the children there," Dr. Hart said. But rather than wait the five or so years it will take the city to begin building, a residents' association will hold its own unofficial opening of the lot, with a baseball diamond and other equipment residents are making themselves, on the Fourth of July.
"One of the goals of participation in planning is to develop a sense of symbolic ownership and control -- that it's your neighborhood, your community," said Mark Francis, a landscape architect at the University of California at Davis, a leader of the advocacy planning movement.
"I got a call from a colleague who has been helping people in South-Central Los Angeles take vacant land and turn it into gardens or little parks," Mr. Francis said. "During the riots not one of these was touched, even though some were right next to burned stores. The gardens and parks were seen as community space, while the stores were seen as invaders."

HEADLINE: New York Rediscovers the U.N.

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany has come up with an offer that three United Nations agencies in New York City may find hard to refuse. Come to Bonn, says Mr. Kohl, and we'll pay the moving expenses, give you rent-free offices and toss in German lessons for your staff. Another agency, the United Nations Children's Fund, is being tempted by suburban New Rochelle, which offers an annual rent of $531,156, compared with the $10 million Unicef now pays.
The right response for New York City is an effective counter-campaign. This means providing short-term inducements and a long-term plan for a growing world organization. It also means nudging Washington to behave responsibly by paying its U.N. dues, on time and in full. 
 For New York, more is at stake than losing 2,300 jobs, which generate $200 million in salaries, rents and other expenses. The U.N. also generates news and tourism, global conferences and state visits; it gives New York its cachet as an international capital. If four agencies depart, other suitors will soon appear to grab what remains.
The U.N. agencies that Bonn covets -- the Development Program, the Population Fund and the Development Fund for Women -- now occupy rented offices in two buildings facing U.N. Plaza and in the Daily News building. Total annual rent is around $14 million. Shaving that figure by finding new space or renegotiating leases is a task ideally suited to Barry Sullivan, the city's new Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development.
More ambitious proposals are also essential. With new members and larger tasks, the U.N. has outgrown its glass shell. It thus makes eminent sense to begin searching now for space elsewhere. One possibility is Hunters Point in Queens, already scheduled for commercial and residential development. According to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns some of the land, waterborne transport could provide a direct link to U.N. headquarters.
The precondition for any such effort, however, is ending Washington's shameful financial delinquency; the U.S. owes the U.N. $555 million in general dues and $112 million for peacekeeping. Not only is Germany paid up, but Mr. Kohl promises a substantial increase in voluntary contributions. The Bush Administration can hardly fault Mr. Kohl's generous effort to fill empty buildings in Bonn as Germany's capital moves to Berlin.
In any case, the U.N. stands to benefit from this competition. New York's concern marks a wholesome change from the days when former Mayor Edward Koch groused about troublesome foreigners and a Reagan Administration official said he would gladly bid adieu at dockside to the U.N. Nowadays the U.N. is viewed as a jewel in the city's crown; keeping it there will take energy and diligence, in New York and in Washington.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: When Perot Says 'Goofy,' Voters Say Amen

BYLINE: By Cokie Roberts; Cokie Roberts is a correspondent for ABC News and an analyst for National Public Radio.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Whatever pathetically small percentage of eligible voters casts ballots in the final round of primaries today, on their way out of the booth a good number will almost certainly tell pollsters that other candidates should have been on the ballot, that the choice leaves them cold. That's been true throughout this nomination season. The difference this time: a lot of voters now know the name of their ideal contender, Ross Perot.
If any one incident explains the Texas billionaire's appeal, it's the flap over the television character Murphy Brown. While Vice President Dan Quayle attacked her and Gov. Bill Clinton solemnly stated that the unwed anchor was less than an ideal role model, and while White House and Republican campaign operatives debated the wisdom of taking on a popular situation comedy, and while columnists and commentators entered the fray weightily on all sides, Ross Perot had only one word for the spectacle of grownups debating the decisions of a fictional character -- "goofy." 
 The voters have shouted that message for months. They started the primary season by elevating someone the media had virtually ignored, Paul Tsongas, and removing the men from Washington, two senators, from the contest. They kept the born-again outsider candidacy of Jerry Brown alive until the end and defied the pundits who early on declared Bill Clinton dead, even as voters told exit pollsters they questioned whether he had the honesty and integrity to be President.
Despite the continued presence of Pat Buchanan on the ballot, most Republicans who bothered to vote went for President Bush but gave him high disapproval ratings. Democrats nominated little-known women to carry their banner into the Senate races in Pennsylvania and Illinois, and in both parties exit polls showed huge percentages expressing dissatisfaction with or anger at the Government.
And why not? Why would people who feel strapped by a stagnant economy and burdened by taxes that don't seem to buy anything be satisfied? In interviews all over the country, voters recite the same refrain. More and and more money comes out of paychecks for Social Security and Medicare, they say, but we worry about the long-term care for our parents and rising health insurance premiums for ourselves and our children.
They say that despite increasing state taxes, budget cutbacks have caused overcrowded classes in public schools, reduced hours in public libraries and eliminated recreation department programs, so we have to send our kids to private schools.
They say they hate seeing homeless people and knowing children go to bed hungry right here in the U.S., but no one seems to be doing anything about it. "I grew up in this neighborhood, when nobody locked their doors, and now I'm afraid to go outside alone at night," they say.
Nobody trusts the politicians of either party, or the Government, to fix the problems. They think George Bush is out of touch, playing golf with his rich friends. They think the Democrats are out of control, ready to give their hard-earned money to the bureaucrats who administer programs -- the people who make it an all-day event to renew a driver's license, an ordeal to get a copy of a birth certificate. But voters also don't buy Democratic plans to soak the rich or Republican attempts to eliminate Government programs.
What the voters tell us most is that they are tired of politicians saying its someone else's fault. Jimmy Carter ran to clean up the mess in Washington, to be the President who would never lie. Ronald Reagan ran to clean up the mess in Washington -- even in his second term. George Bush ran to carry on the Reagan legacy. Members of Congress run against their own institution. And the public screams: "Stop fixing the blame. Fix the problems."
Enter Ross Perot. A man who seems to be able to fix things. A man not tied to either party. Americans always proclaim that they vote for the man, not the party, anyway. What better way to prove the point? As for President, most vote the way their gut tells them to, not on the issues. So it doesn't much matter -- it could even be a plus -- that Mr. Perot's programs and plans remain a mystery.
Bill Clinton complains that he hasn't been able to get his message across. The people respond that they don't want to hear it. They don't think campaign speeches mean anything when it comes to governing, and they think politicians treat them as fools with statements like "I didn't inhale" or "race played no role in my choice of Clarence Thomas."
During the gulf war, the public responded positively to George Bush because he didn't just talk, he acted and led. That's why Californians expressed such disappointment after the Los Angeles riots. They looked for leadership; they got vacillation.
Right after Mr. Bush visited the riot area, I interviewed conservative Republicans in Orange County. They seemed genuinely distressed by life in the ghetto. They talked of the hopelessness, the need for education and jobs, and they showed an interest in imaginative Government programs and a desire to do something to help. "Give those people opportunities," said one rock-ribbed Republican, "and the crime will take care of itself."
Rather than reaching out to those suburbanites at that moment, uniting the communities in a time of tragedy, their leaders chose to divide, to talk of the lack of personal responsibility in the inner city, rather than the personal responsibility to help one's neighbor. The moment for action, for the involvement of individuals, was lost.
Ross Perot offers his supporters the opportunity of involvement. Instead of surrounding himself with political consultants, he recruits armies of volunteers to circulate petitions, answer phones, collect contributions -- to act. Obviously, he can afford it. He doesn't have to pay someone to calculate which TV spots will work because he can buy whatever time he needs to get his face into the family room.
For those who have dedicated their lives to public service, men like George Bush and Bill Clinton, the appeal of the cowboy riding in out of nowhere with no responsibilities or record must be maddening. Politicians find their frustration so great they are opting for private life in record numbers, and those who choose again to run grumble that colleagues and columnists lionize the quitters.
But the politicians bring grief on themselves, choosing repeatedly to do what they think will sell, not what they think is right. Rather than do something real to bring down the deficit, for instance, they've decided that a constitutional amendment to balance the budget -- something many have ridiculed for years -- is the better part of wisdom. And rather than fight the amendment on its merits, opponents put forward what they believe is a less damaging amendment of their own. The battle of the amendments will convince voters Washington is producing more wishy-washy words -- and the political amateur will look better and better.
The novelty of the noncandidate could soon wear off. Voters could grow as tired of Mr. Perot as they are of the professionals. He's already in danger of overexposure. But what he represents should not be lost. It's not just change, it's action.
Mr. Perot's followers look for someone who says what he thinks and seems ready to act on it without worrying about whom it offends. That's what voters mean when they talk about leadership. That's what they insist is lacking among politicians. And, in times like these, they find that lack goofy.

HEADLINE: As Forests Fall, Environmental Movement Rises in Brazil

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH HEILMAN BROOKE

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO

 BODY:
A TELEVISION announcement here features a lithe, bikinied beauty sunning herself on a crowded beach. She carelessly throws a piece of trash on the sand and suddenly transforms into a bikinied pig.
The message, which is the work of a private group, the Blue Wave Foundation, is one sign of the growing concern about the environment in Brazil. As in many third world countries, conservation and environmental awareness have little history here. But in recent years, an impressive domestic environmental movement has taken root. 
 The nation's environmental record is coming under scrutiny as thousands of people from all corners of the earth arrive in Rio de Janeiro for the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development that opens tomorrow. In addition to governmental representatives and environmental specialists, there will be private groups composed of or representing women, children, Indians, trade unionists, business people, economists and scientists. Nearly 100 Brazilian environmental groups plan to debate the host nation's ecological problems and progress.
 
Natural Resources
 Rio sits in the middle of an Atlantic coastal forest that has shrunk to 3 percent of its original size. The world's fifth largest country in area and the sixth largest in population, Brazil is first in biological diversity, but also high in habitat destruction. One-third of the world's forests lie in Brazil. More than a fifth of the world's freshwater supply is in Brazil's rivers. Brazil holds claim not only to the world's largest river, the Amazon, but to the world's largest tropical forest, the Amazon forest.
More than 1,000 local groups are working to save Brazil's threatened forests, coastline and animal species. Last year, in a reflection of the new interest, Globo Television, Brazil's largest network, started showing a weekly environmental program, and Jornal do Brasil, a Rio newspaper, started publishing a weekly environment section.
"In terms of environmental action, Brazil has as sophisticated groups as the United States," said Lou Ann Dietz, the World Wildlife Fund's senior program officer for Brazil. "Many of them are very capable, but most have difficulty in trying to sustain themselves financially, and that's a result of the economic situation in Brazil and the fact that there is not a culture of philanthropy in Brazil."
On a grass-roots level, middle-class Brazilians have raised money to administer state parks and to raise the consciousness of a people who have often destroyed their forests and polluted their waterways in pursuit of short-term economic gain.
 
Wave of Awareness
 Brazilian composers have been celebrating their lush natural surroundings for decades, but it has been the political pull of Gilberto Gil, a Bahian singer, that brought the televised message about the thoughtless sunbather into the nation's living rooms. In an effort to protect Brazil's waters, Mr. Gil founded Ondazul, or the Blue Wave Foundation, in 1989.
Based in Salvador, the capital of the state of Bahia, the foundation has received support from advertising agencies as well as the three major television networks for its national educational campaign aimed at cleaning Brazil's beaches. Thousands of garbage bags have been distributed to encourage citizens to keep the coast clean.
One group considered a pillar of Brazilian environmentalism, Funatura, has a wildlife sanctuary program in the Atlantic coastal forest and other programs in the Grande Sertao Veredas National Park in Bahia and Minas Gerais states. The Brasilia-based group was founded in 1986 by Maria Tereza Jorge Padua, an agricultural engineer, former director of Brazil's national parks and current president of Ibama, the Brazilian Institute of Environment and Renewable Resources.
Frequently sought out by foreign groups for partnerships, this highly professional group received $582,000 from the World Bank to complete and administer a 1,300-acre wildlife sanctuary in Brasilia. Conservation International and the Nature Conservancy are helping Funatura with foreign-debt conversion projects, in which foreign lenders forgive portions of Brazil's debt in exchange for environmental protection projects.
 
Setting Aside Land
 Another group, the Pro-Nature Institute, is a private environmental organization founded by Dr. Marcelo Carvalho de Andrade, an orthopedist, in 1986. With sponsorship from international corporations like Esso, Shell and Imperial Chemical Industries, as well as the MacArthur Foundation of the United States, the institute has begun programs in both the Amazon rain forest and the Atlantic coastal forest. Two state parks and a biological reserve have been established and are being maintained in Rio de Janeiro state. Research has been started for a sustainable development program in Juruena, a frontier between farmed land and virgin rain forest in Mato Grosso state.
In an attempt to verify deforestation and to identify areas for conservation, S.O.S. Mata Atlantica, officially called the Brazilian Foundation for the Conservation of the Atlantic Rain Forest, is organizing the first comparative analysis of satellite images of the Atlantic forest in eight Brazilian states in 1985 and 1990.
For five years the group has worked "to protect the biological diversity and ecological processes of Atlantic rain forest ecosystems, to promote sustainable use of the region's natural resources and establish a strong environmental ethic in the area." In a pioneering television and radio campaign, "The Green of Our Earth is Being Destroyed," S.O.S. made a mass audience aware that many of the plant and animal species of Brazil's Atlantic forest were threatened with extinction.
Thomas E. Lovejoy, assistant secretary for external affairs at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, said: "These environmental groups are a relatively new phenomenon in a country that is still getting used to democracy. What is impressive is that there has been an explosion of new environmental groups and it keeps going. There are 100 groups alone in the Brazilian Amazon. Obviously, some of those groups are small and very specialized, but the mere fact that they exist says something about the change in Brazilian society."

HEADLINE: Poor vs. Rich in Rio;
If Development in Southern Hemisphere Is to Be 'Green,' North May Have to Pay

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 2

 BODY:
The Earth Summit, a vast environmental jamboree bringing together thousands of delegates from more than 170 countries, countless ecological watchdogs and the world press, gets under way tomorrow in Rio de Janeiro and it has already become mired in discord and suspicion between rich and poor nations.
The central issues are: Who will pay the bill for the first comprehensive attempt to repair the environmental damage caused by industrialization? And who will insure that the poor nations of the southern hemisphere industrialize at a lower cost to the environment than the richer nations of the North did? 
 The largely northern-inspired drive to make the South's development environmentally sustainable has opened a new chapter in a battle between the have and the have-not nations that dates from the 1960's and 70's.
 
The Goals of the South
 If nothing else, the arguments prove that the end of the cold war has not ended recriminations by the developing world directed at the major industrial democracies.
At a news conference today, Maurice Strong, the Earth Summit's normally ebullient Secretary General, put the best face he could on the difficulties confronting him, saying: "Success will not come easily. I predict this conference will look as though it is going to collapse before it is over."
The atmosphere is one of poor and rich countries playing on each other's anxieties.
Poor countries want to exploit northern worries about climate change, the destruction of forests and polluted seas to extract more aid. They say that the rich countries must pay the extra cost of "clean" development, just as 20 years ago they demanded a new world economic order to shift the North's riches southward.
Richer northern countries want to hold the poor to their pledge to pursue sustainable economic development by setting up a commission to monitor the South's strategies. But the developing world is resisting any obligation to abide by outsiders' recommendations.
The Earth Summit's success is also being jeopardized by the Bush Administration's refusal to sign a convention protecting the diversity of nature because of disagreements over patent rights and the way they are paid for.
Britain, Japan and France may withhold support too. But if so powerful a quartet of industrialized countries refuses to sign a convention widely perceived as favorable to the developing world, southern countries warn, they may not sign a convention backed by the North on stabilizing the climate.
Such a deadlock could deal a crippling blow to the meeting here, for the two conventions have been billed as its greatest triumph and their signature is a major reason why nearly 100 heads of state and government will be here for the finale on June 14.
Another looming difficulty is Israel's expected bid on Wednesday to remove references to the environmental rights of "people under occupation" that Arab nations have inserted into several documents even though this threatens to unravel existing agreements.
Austria, the Netherlands and Switzerland are also planning to isolate the United States further by inviting countries that favor stricter control of gas emissions than President Bush will accept to sign a "like-minded countries declaration," pledging to do more to combat global warming.
 
Smaller Nations Weigh In
 The Earth Summit is officially the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development, and as that name suggests, its overarching goal is to find a way for rich and poor to raise living standards while insuring that growth is tailored to what the Earth can stand.
But after two years of preparatory talks, poor southern countries are fearful the North wants to keep them that way. The poor countries say they will only match their development to environmental goals if the rich pay the bill.
The industrialized world is afraid of new financial commitments at a time of slow growth and widespread recession. The electoral paralysis that seems to be seeping through the United States only adds to the indecision.
Conference officials are still given to extravagant statements about the meeting's significance. "We have a clear mandate to take new steps towards a new order in the interests of mankind," Brazil's Foreign Minister Celso Lafer said today.
But most delegates' expectations range from low to modest.
"The real test is whether governments carry out their commitments," said Mr. Strong, the Canadian who is leading the conference. "We have to hold them to account."
The last time the developing South sought access to the coffers of the rich on such a scale came 20 years ago when -- encouraged by the oil exporters' success in raising prices tenfold -- they tried to jack up the price of other raw materials.
 
Some Convergence
 That attempt failed. But this time the developing world senses that the North may be more vulnerable.
Already industrialized countries have agreed that nothing less than the "eradication of poverty" must be the cornerstone of ecological survival. And they also know that if China and India industrialize, as Britain did in the 19th century, by burning their coal reserves, all the North's efforts to curb pollution will come to nothing.
In preparatory negotiations stretching back over two years, the North and the South have already reached a measure of agreement on some steps.
They include conventions to curb the emission of gases that may warm the atmosphere and to preserve flora and fauna, as well as an ambitiously detailed plan, called Agenda 21, to clean up virtually every aspect of the environment during the next century.
These will be complemented by a declaration setting out the basic principles that should guide this quest.
 
$125 Billion a Year
 Final negotiations begin in earnest after the ceremonial opening on Wednesday by President Fernando Collor de Mello of Brazil and Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali of the United Nations at the immense, shabby concrete-and-steel conference center almost an hour's drive from the center of town.
The estimated cost of cleaning up the globe are astronomical: some $125 billion a year just for the goals in Agenda 21. But the North so far has only pledged to provide "new and additional resources," without saying how much.
The developing world receives about $55 billion in aid each year; if all this were used for environmentally sound projects, it would take another $70 billion to meet the bill for Agenda 21.
Most of the new money could be found if the industrial world increased aid to the target they have already set: seven-tenths of 1 percent of total economic output.
Developing countries have asked for a commitment to reach this level by 2000. But Britain, Germany and Belgium oppose setting a binding date, and the United States has never accepted the higher target.

HEADLINE: Byrd Predicts Senate Will Defeat Amendment for Balanced Budget

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
Prospects for a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget, which seemed likely to sail through Congress only a few weeks ago, dimmed dramatically today when Senator Robert C. Byrd, a veteran vote-counter and master of Senate procedure, predicted that the Senate would kill it.
As chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, Mr. Byrd has decisive power over the pet projects of every senator, although he said he was not applying this influence in his meetings with one senator after another to argue against the amendment. 
 Today Senator Byrd, a West Virginia Democrat, told reporters, "In the final analysis, Congress will not approve the amendment."
 
'Mischief' and 'Damage' Seen
 "Once members are really informed as to the mischief this amendment could do, and the damage it could do to the country and to the Constitution," he said, "I just have faith that enough members will take a courageous stand against the amendment."
The amendment's sponsor, Senator Paul Simon, said of Mr. Byrd's remarks, "It is possible he is correct" about the amendment's prospects.
Mr. Simon, an Illinois Democrat, added: "I don't need to tell you that when the chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee talks, senators pay attention. We all have things we want to get through appropriations."
The amendment has been under steadily increasing attack in recent days, and its prospects now appear uncertain at best.
Senator Byrd and other opponents call the amendment a smokescreen that will allow lawmakers to claim action against the deficit while still postponing hard budgetary decisions. Supporters argue that all other efforts to cut the deficit have failed and it is time for the ultimate discipline of a constitutional amendment.
Passage by the House is still considered probable when the amendment comes up there next week. But in the Senate, which will act after the House does, Mr. Byrd may be able to rally either the 34 votes required to deny the amendment the two-thirds majority required under the Constitution, or to filibuster successfully against it.
Two weeks ago he warned the Senate of a possible filibuster, saying, "Unlimited debate is one of the cornerstones on which this institution, the U.S. Senate, rests."
While it takes 41 votes to sustain a filibuster, some senators might find it easier to cast a procedural vote for unlimited debate than to vote against the popular amendment directly.
 
Effective Lobbying Cited
 Senator Simon said in an interview, "As of two weeks ago, we had the votes." But he added that Mr. Byrd's lobbying had had its effect.
Mr. Simon said Mr. Byrd would never threaten senators that their pet projects would be the first to go if the budget had to be balanced, but some senators might draw that conclusion anyhow.
An aide to Mr. Byrd insisted that when he met with other senators he assured them that his position as chairman of the Appropriations Committee was not a consideration and that they should consider his arguments strictly on their own merits.
Another measure of opposition was sounded at a news conference here by the Economic Policy Institute. The institute made public a statement of opposition signed by 447 economists, including seven who won the Nobel Prize in Economics.
 
Making Recessions Worse
 "When the private economy is in recession," they said, "a constitutional requirement that would force cuts in public or tax increases could worsen the economic downturn, causing greater loss of jobs, production and income."
The Nobel laureates signing the statement were Kenneth J. Arrow of Stanford University, Lawrence R. Klein of the University of Pennsylvania, Herbert A. Simon of Carnegie Mellon University, James Tobin of Yale University and Franco Modigliani, Paul A. Samuelson and Robert M. Solow of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
There are different House and Senate versions of the amendment pending, but they are similar. Senator Simon's proposal requires the President to submit a balanced budget to Congress. It compels Congress to enact and abide by annual budgets in which spending does not exceed receipts. That requirement could be suspended, a year at a time, by votes of 60 percent of both houses.
The basic argument for the amendment is that all other narrower measures to cut deficit spending have failed, and that only the compulsion of a constitutional amendment will work.
Mr. Simon said at a news conference today that the amendment "sets up a process of fiscal discipline that will mean painful choices sooner, rather than later."
The amendment, an idea that has been around for years, has gathered steam this year as Congress' own standing declined and deficits continue to increase, with the recession and the savings and loan bailout overcoming the hopes of a 1990 budget agreement between Congress and President Bush that was supposed to curb the deficit.
Senator Byrd, at the Economic Policy Institute meeting, called the proposal an "easy way out."
He and other critics have argued that the amendment itself would accomplish nothing except to give lawmakers political cover; Congress would still have to make the same difficult decisions it has so far been unable to make about what spending to cut or what taxes to increase.
Besides warning that a balanced budget requirement would make recessions worse, the economists said that it would lead to new budgetary gimmicks, invite the courts to meddle with the details of taxes, spending and the economy, and generally discourage constructive budget policies.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: On the Trail

 BODY:

CONGRESSWOMAN LINKED TO SCANDALS WINS NOMINATION
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 2 (AP) -- Representative Mary Rose Oakar won renomination today despite being linked to the House bank and post office scandals.
Ms. Oakar defeated Tim Hagan, a Cuyahoga County commissioner.
Seeking her ninth term, Ms. Oakar was considered vulnerable because of her 213 overdrafts at the House bank and for her role as chairwoman of the committee overseeing the scandal-ridden House post office. In April, she resigned as co-chairwoman of the Democratic Platform Committee, but denied she was pressured.
 
ALABAMA SENATOR WINS DEMOCRATIC NOMINATION
MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 2 (AP) -- Senator Richard C. Shelby won the Democratic nomination for a second term today. He easily dispatched three opponents, including Chris McNair, a county commissioner whose daughter was one of four black girls killed in the 1963 Birmingham church bombing.
Mr. Shelby led Mr. McNair by nearly 4 to 1. Mr. McNair had sought support from black voters and from women angry over Mr. Shelby's vote to confirm Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court despite accusations of sexual harassment by Prof. Anita F. Hill.
 
BLACK CANDIDATES WIN RUNOFFS IN NORTH CAROLINA
RALEIGH, N.C., June 2 (AP) -- Black candidates won runoffs today in two newly drawn Congressional districts, heightening the possibility that North Carolina could send two blacks to Congress in November. In the First District Democratic primary, Eva Clayton, a black businesswoman, defeated Walter Jones Jr., who is white and the son of the district's incumbent, who is retiring. Ms. Clayton will face a white Republican in November.
Black representation in the 12th District had already been guaranteed, with two black Republicans vying today for the right to face a black Democrat in the fall. In that runoff, Barbara Gore Washington defeated George Jones.
 
PEROT UNVEILS PLANS FOR SOLVING U.S. PROBLEMS
 By Reuters -- Ross Perot, who stole the political limelight yesterday with a strong showing in surveys of voters on the day that President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton won the last round of primaries, said last night that he would treat the United States economy as if it were failed business.
In an interview with CBS News broadcast last night, Mr. Perot called himself "just an ordinary citizen" who wanted to cure American problems by getting the budget deficit under control, reforming the tax system and making education work, especially for poor children. He said he would only raise taxes as a last resort and only after much discussion with the American people, and that he would "bury" himself in meetings from his first day in the White House, to solve the budget deficit. The Texas billionaire also said he would concentrate on problems at home rather than international affairs.
 
MARGOT PEROT BACKS ABORTION RIGHTS
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Margot Perot, wife of the undeclared Presidential candidate, says the right to choose an abortion is "probably the most important issue to me."
"I think there are extenuating circumstances where an abortion might be the best choice, and certainly the choice that should be made by that individual," Mrs. Perot said Monday on the NBC News program "Today."
 
 GERALD FORD SEES TROUBLE FOR BUSH
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Former President Gerald R. Ford says that the Presidential election would be thrown into the House if it were held now, but that President Bush would win in November if the economy continued to improve.
In a speech on Monday at the National Press Club, Mr. Ford said that in traveling around the country he had concluded that "all incumbents, including the White House in my opinion, are in trouble."
"If the election were held today," he said, "we would have a three-man race, and I don't think any of the three would get the 270 electoral votes" needed to win.
 
MARILYN QUAYLE JOINS ATTACK ON HOLLYWOOD
 HOUSTON, June 2 (Reuters) -- - Marilyn Quayle climbed into the political fray today by joining her husband in attacking Hollywood's values, deadbeat dads and Ross Perot. Mrs. Quayle, who as wife of Vice President Dan Quayle normally avoids political sparring, criticized what she characterized Mr. Ross Perot's effort to buy the White House.
Mrs. Quayle, in Houston to make a speech about breast cancer, defended her husband, who was criticized two weeks ago after attacking the TV show "Murphy Brown" because of its main character's having a child out of wedlock. "The entertainment industry continually knocks the values that we need to have if we are going to have a civilized society," she said. "Men need to be responsible for their actions and they need to be held accountable."

HEADLINE: Bush Seeks Trade Benefits for China

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
The White House announced today that it planned to extend preferential trade benefits to China for another year, arguing that it was the best way to support economic and political reform in the world's most populous country.
The announcement immediately drew protests from Democrats on Capitol Hill, who argued that the President's policy of "constructive engagement" with China had produced no tangible results. In fact, they said, China has engaged in increasingly provocative acts -- including the underground testing of a large nuclear bomb, harassment of American reporters, denial of visas to the Chairmen of the Senate Intelligence and Foreign Relations Committees and a failure to make any significant improvement in human rights. 
 Ever since the Tiananmen Square massacre in June 1989 the annual extension of trade benefits to China has produced a fight between the President and Congress, which Mr. Bush has won each time, and this year will probably be no exception.
"The President informed the Congress today that he plans to extend China's most-favored-nation, MFN, status for another year," said the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater. "In making this important decision, the President stressed that it is wrong to isolate China if we hope to influence China. Maintaining a constructive policy of engagement with China has served U.S. interests."
 
Few Improvements in China
 Last year China exported $19 billion of products to the United States and imported $6.3 billion in American goods. The United States is China's largest overseas market, importing more than a fourth of Chinese exports, while China absorbs only 1.5 percent of American exports.
Administration officials acknowledged that the Chinese have made few improvements in human rights during the past year, and in recent months have taken actions that almost seemed designed to "to rub our nose in it," as one official put it.
A senior Bush Administration Asia policymaker argued, however, that this behavior was the result of a "world-class power struggle" now under way in Beijing in advance of the 14th Communist Party Congress, which will take place at the end of the year.
"The hardliners are deliberately trying to embarrass the reformers," the official said, "The hardliners are arguing that engagement with the outside world only brings internal infection on human rights, endless pressures for trade concessions and the denial of China's right to sell arms where it pleases. The reformers are arguing that China has to get along with the world and that China benefits enormously from trade. The President thinks we are doing the right thing by getting on the side of the reformers."
This argument has not impressed opponents of the China policy.
"It's deja vu all over again," said Rep. Stephen J. Solarz, the Brooklyn Democrat who chairs the House Asia subcommittee, "Nothing has changed in China or in Washington. The President sticks to his view that the best way to facilitate change in China is a policy of constructive engagement. He apparently agrees with the philosopher Hegel that if theory and fact disagree, so much for the facts -- because the facts simply don't sustain Mr. Bush's views."
Senate Majority Leader George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, and House Majority Leader Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, along with a bipartisan coalition of Congressmen, plan to unveil their own bill on Wednesday that will make extending China's trade privileges for another year contingent on specific improvements in human rights policies. The chances of gaining a veto-proof two-thirds majority of both houses appear slim at best.
"The President's decision is wrong, inconsistent with American values and contrary to American interests," said Senator Mitchell. "The longer the President's policy remains in effect, the greater and more obvious is its failure. It is a classic example of continuing a failed policy."
Representative Nancy Pelosi, who has led the House fight against most-favored-nation status for China, said that opponents may choose a narrower approach this year. They may, for example, seek selective tariff increases on specific Chinese products so they could not be exported to the United States at a profit. Lifting of these selective tariffs might be contingent on China's agreeing to release specific numbers of political prisoners, respect religious freedoms and open prisons and labor camps to international inspection.
The bill's sponsors hope that such an approach might overcome the Administration's concerns about damaging China's nascent free-market sector, which it argues is the best long-term hope for political change there. Administration officials say the proposed bill is unworkable and would elicit a veto.
By law, Mr. Bush had to decide by Wednesday whether to notify Congress of his intention to extend trade benefits for another year. Congress then has three months to try to prevent the move. In an election year, though, it will be very difficult to muster enough Republican votes in Congress to override the President.
Opponents of renewing the benefits argue that Beijing has not followed through on many of the promises it made to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d last November. It promised to allow a group of some 20 dissidents to leave the country and have only let two go so far. It promised to halt exports of products made by prison inmates to the United States, and were recently caught exporting tools and diesel engines made by prisoners.
The Beijing authorities did come through with a promised accounting of the status of about 800 political prisoners jailed after Tiananmen Square, but provided just the barest of information on each one, some of which has been proven incorrect, according to Congressional officials.

HEADLINE: Army Unrest Stirs Bolivia, the Land of Coups

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LA PAZ, Bolivia

 BODY:
In this country, which has had 77 governments in 167 years, the military coup has often been the engine for political change. Historians note that since independence in 1825, Bolivia has experienced more than 150 coups or attempted coups. And despite 10 years of civilian rule, any rumors of discontent in its armed forces are watched closely.
Encouraged perhaps by recent displays of military assertiveness in Venezuela and Peru, four factions in the Bolivian Army and Navy have been rattling their swords. 
 They are complaining that there is corruption in the armed forces and civilian Government and that the country has become a pawn of the United States. At times there have been calls for a military takeover, once again raising the specter that this fragile democracy could be disrupted at any time.
Military analysts and Government officials say a coup at this point is very unlikely, but they add that the rumblings reflect growing unrest over the diminishing role of the armed forces and severe reductions in their pay and budgets.
 
Diverse in Ideology
 The restive military factions in Bolivia are diverse in ideology. Vivo Rojo, the oldest of the clandestine groups, says its members are Trotskyites. The Group of Ten Stars is made up of naval officers. Its favorite theme is the supposed link between top naval commanders and Bolivian drug traffickers. The Army of Bolivar rails against the economic programs of the International Monetary Fund. And the Movement for Dignity and Renovation makes corruption within the Government of President Jaime Paz Zamora its target.
"No one really knows who are members of these groups," said a retired senior army officer who maintains close ties with the military. "There are many theories, among them that the top commanders let them exist so they can express the frustrations of the high command. But they have remarkably accurate information."
The disquiet is not confined to Bolivia. A group of 50 current and former military officers in Uruguay, apparently rightists, has set off a series of bombs around Montevideo, the capital. And a rebel officers' group in Argentina that has staged four uprisings still has adherents in the ranks of the country's military even though most of its leaders are in prison.
While partaking of Latin America's penchant for military solutions to civilian problems, these groups tend to pursue a different political strategy than military rulers in the past. Instead of forming close relations with business groups and the controlling oligarchies, they seek to appeal to the masses, pointing a finger at government corruption, poverty and drug trafficking.
 
A Loss of Esteem
 Analysts note that these groups generally do not represent the top military hierarchies, who are mostly well paid. Rather they are made up of officers from the lower classes of society who have had their pay and benefits slashed by as much as 50 percent in recent years and now see their once bright hopes for a military future waning.
In addition, border tensions have quieted with the emergence of democracies in Latin America, reducing the military's role and sense of self-esteem and giving time to focus on scandals within the armed forces themselves.
Corruption has been the focus of recent letters written by the four Bolivian groups. Of greatest concern are two scandals involving the sale of large farms north of La Paz that were owned by the army. Not only were much of the proceeds illegally pocketed by army officers, but one farm was sold to a former officer with links to drug dealers. .
The Movement for Dignity and Renovation said in a letter circulated in the last week that "because of the fault of some bad military officers, the entire institution is losing credibility and respect among the Bolivian public."
Jorge Lazarte, a member of Bolivia's National Court of Elections, said: "Right now the military are going to watch and see what happens in the presidential elections next year. If they think the wrong person gets into office, then it could be dangerous."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Finding Plays In Toy Stocks

BYLINE: By Adam Bryant

 BODY:
TOYLAND is busy these days. In the last month, Tyco Toys Inc. and Hasbro Inc. announced plans to acquire Japanese toy companies; Child World Inc., the huge retailer, filed for bankruptcy, and a rash of investor concerns pushed the stock of Mattel Inc. down roughly 20 percent from April to May.
To some investors, the turmoil reinforces a belief that toy stocks are best avoided, a theory born from ill-fated investments in the 1980's in companies like Coleco, whose sales of Cabbage Patch dolls tumbled from more than $500 million in 1985 to $125 million in 1987. 
 But many analysts say the industry is growing increasingly stable, and some feel the recent commotion has created buying opportunities.
Gary M. Jacobson, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company, noted that demographics were driving growth in the toy business. He said more children -- 4.1 million -- were born in the United States last year than in any year since 1964. He added that 40 percent of those babies were first-borns, "who generally get spoiled rotten."
Other analysts noted that a consolidation under way in the industry -- including Tyco's acquisition of the Universal Matchbox Group of Hong Kong and Hasbro's plan to buy the Nomura Toy Company of Japan -- reflected a trend toward internationalization. They also said that the rapid expansion in Japan of Toys "R" Us Inc., the largest American retailer, was creating opportunities for American toy makers in the world's second-largest toy market.
"That's where the biggest opportunities for growth lie," said Greg Simpson, an analyst at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis.
Mattel is seen by some as the most attractive among the four market leaders: Hasbro, Mattel, Tyco and Fisher-Price Inc.
Mattel's stock was battered recently, dropping from $36.75 in mid-April to its recent low of $30.12. Some of the decline came on concerns raised on May 5 when Warburg Pincus, an investment bank and Mattel's largest shareholder, announced it would distribute more than 10 million Mattel shares to its limited partners.
Also, some investors worried about Mattel's relatively large exposure in the May 7 bankruptcy filing by Child World. Tyco's planned acquisition of Matchbox, a maker of miniature cars, also worried investors, who saw competition for Mattel's Hot Wheels.
But some analysts waved off the Tyco threat. That, combined with continued strong sales of Barbie dolls, appears to have helped Mattel's stock rebound sharply in the last week. It closed yesterday at $36, down 62.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Jacobson said that while the stock was no longer a table-pounding bargain, it remained an attractive long-term investment.
Sean McGowan, an analyst with Gerard, Klauer, Mattison, recommends all the toy stocks. In particular, he applauded Tyco's Matchbox deal, which he said would give Tyco improved distribution networks in Germany and Britain. He said Tyco's sales would probably exceed $1 billion next year -- up from just $87.7 million in 1986 -- moving it past Fisher-Price as the third-largest toy company. "Tyco is in the best position to put up very good growth rates," Mr. McGowan said.
Tyco shares added 37.5 cents each on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, closing at $45.625.
Mr. McGowan also likes Hasbro, the industry leader. The company recently offered analysts a glimpse of cost reductions achieved from its acquisition of the Tonka Corporation in May 1991 for $486 million, and most think sales of its Batman toys will probably be buoyed by the release this year of a sequel to the movie.
Hasbro shares closed at $28.625 on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, down 25 cents.
Mr. McGowan also recommends Fisher-Price, in part because of its rapid sales increases in the United States. But Mr. Jacobson is more skeptical, arguing that long-term growth will be difficult because of the company's narrow focus on infant and pre-school toys. "Four-year-olds want to play with Barbie and Sega," he said.
Fisher-Price shares gained 25 cents each on the Big Board yesterday, closing at $18.875.
Despite the heady growth that is anticipated abroad, some analysts feel that toy stocks are already overpriced. "There are some fantastic numbers there, and these companies didn't suffer in the recession," a neutral Mr. Simpson said. "It's more a matter of where do we feel comfortable getting into these things."

HEADLINE: New Data Show Continued Slow Recovery

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
In reports suggesting a continued ragged and lackluster economic recovery, the Government said today that sales of new homes edged up 1.3 percent in April while its chief economic-forecasting index rose four-tenths of 1 percent.
The results, analysts say, mean that the economy is likely to keep forging ahead but without the long-awaited acceleration some thought they detected in Monday's report by purchasing managers of stepped-up activity in the industrial sector. 
 "The recovery is in place," said Stuart G. Hoffman of the PNC Financial Corporation in Pittsburgh. "But this also reminds us that it's not going to be robust, not going to surprise us on the upside."
The skimpy gain in new-home sales, virtually all of it in the West, followed a plunge of 15.9 percent in March and left the sector that Mr. Hoffman called the epicenter of the recovery running only 5 percent above the level a year earlier.
The April annual selling rate was 530,000 units, compared with 523,000 in March and an average of 644,500 for the first two months of the year, when falling interest rates and warm weather helped spur demand.
Sales actually fell in the South and Midwest and gained only insignificantly, to a 53,000 rate from 52,000, in the Northeast. The West posted a 22.5 percent gain, to 169,000, but still a slower pace than in December, January or February.
At the end of April, there were 274,000 unsold new homes, representing a 6.4-month supply at that month's rate of sales, a figure unchanged from March, according to the report, issued jointly by the Departments of Commerce and Housing and Urban Development.
The index of leading indicators for April climbed for the fourth straight month and by slightly more than had been expected. Yet analysts found no particular comfort in the rise of four-tenths of 1 percent, which was almost entirely accounted for by higher prices for materials sensitive to the business cycle. These prices have since flattened.
And the increases of four-tenths of 1 percent for both April and March were only half those chalked up in January and February.
"These numbers are giving us pause," said Laurence H. Meyer, who heads a consultancy by that name in St. Louis. He cited the lack of a gain in April in a companion index of indicators that reflect current conditions.. That index, the index of coincident indicators, was also revised to show a one-tenth of 1 percent rise in March after having initially been reported to have been unchanged.
 
Reversal of a Pattern
 The economy is not building momentum, Mr. Meyer said, noting that in the first quarter, the consumer sector was strong while production lagged, a pattern reversed in the current quarter.
"There's no indication that this economy is going to fall back into recession," Mr. Meyer said, but he added that the lack of momentum was "a source of concern."
Only 4 of 11 components of the leading indicators index contributed to the advance, with higher materials prices far outweighing a decline in first-time claims for unemployment insurance, higher factory orders for consumer goods and a rise in consumer expectations.
Holding the index back were a drop in the M-2 money supply, lower building permits, a decline in the proportion of companies reporting slower deliveries from suppliers, lower contracts and orders for new plant and equipment and lower manufacturers' backlogs of unfilled orders.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: New Jersey;
Perot Not on Ballot but on Many Minds

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 2

 BODY:
As expected, New Jersey voters endorsed the nominations of George Bush and Bill Clinton today to head the tickets of their respective parties, but more than a quarter of the voters on both sides would have defected to Ross Perot if the Texas billionaire had been on the ballot, according to a survey of those leaving the polls.
Among voters in the Democratic primary who were questioned as they left the polls around the state, about half said they had voted for Governor Clinton of Arkansas as the party's nominee for President, 1 in 5 said they had voted for former Gov. Edmund G. Brown of California, 1 in 10 said they had supported former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, who ended his active campaign in March but was still on the ballot here, and another 1 in 10 voted for an uncommitted slate that appeared on ballots in some counties. 
 Among voters in the Republican primary, almost three-quarters said they had voted for Mr. Bush, while about 1 in 8 voted for Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative newspaper columnist, with fewer than five percent supporting uncommitted delegates.
Mr. Perot was not on the ballot, but about 3 in 10 the Democrats and more a third of the Republicans said they would have voted for him if they had been given the option.
Commenting on those results, Thomas V. O'Neil, a former executive director of the state Democratic Party who is now a consultant to businesses on governmental affairs, said: "And that is among committed party voters in partisan primaries. I would guess these are party regulars, and if you included independents" the percentages would probably be higher.
 
Suggestion of Anger
 The poll results, the random voices of voters as they left the voting booths and the analysis of political professionals of both parties all point in the same direction: New Jersey's voters are angry, disappointed to the point of disgust with the candidates, and ready to turn to almost any alternative.
Marilyn Greenberg, 58 years old, of Cherry Hill, said she wrote in Mr. Perot's name "because I didn't like any of the others" and "he's the lesser of all evils."
And Jim Welch, a Republican leaving the polls in Red Bank, voted for candidates for other offices, but not for a Presidential candidate. "I don't like Bush," he said. "I don't like either one of them." His wife, Toni Welch, said she had voted for Mr. Bush, but "it wasn't an enthusiastic choice."
Similarly, Robert M. Fugazzi, who voted in the Democratic primary in Red Bank, said he voted for Mr. Clinton but would have voted for Mr. Perot had he been on the ballot. "I just think, from what I hear, he'd do a much better job," he said.
 
Voices of Despair
 To Jay Severin, a New York political consultant who works in New Jersey for Republican candidates and the party, those are voices of despair. "It's not the corruption, the bad checks and the post office scandal," he said. "It's the impotence, the feeling it's not working, government in gridlock.
"No one should draw any joy from this, Democrats or Republicans or anyone else," he said, adding that many voters are so alienated that they no longer seem to care very much how they vote.
"They used to look at the candidates and say, 'We can do better than this,' but now it's a step further. Now they say, 'How can we do any worse?' They vote for somebody they don't even know."
Mr. O'Neil agreed. "The problems are so significant that people believe they can no longer be entrusted to the politicians or to the parties. They prefer anyone else," he said.
Former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, now the president of Drew University and the chairman of the Bush campaign in New Jersey, said Mr. Perot should not take comfort in the numbers. "I think voters are confused and disillusioned," he said, "and Perot is the only way they can find to say that. They are unhappy with the process. It's not an affirmation of Perot.
"If the voters don't pull out of it, you'll have third-party candidates all over the country" in state and local elections, he added.
Steven A. Salmore of the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University said that the disaffection in both parties results more from distaste for recent candidates than from anger with the process itself. "The voter is saying, 'I don't really like Bush or Clinton, so I'll send a message and vote for Perot,' " he said. "When they actually have to vote for a President in November, will Perot's numbers come down?"
 
Frustrated Voters
 Whatever the cause, the voters are frustrated, angry and cynical.
Bruce Pfeffer, 28, of Maple Shade, an unemployed industrial engineer, voted for Mr. Clinton but would have preferred to support Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey or Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York. "I don't particularly believe in Brown," he said. "He flip-flops."
Carole Szcykalski, 48, a child care worker from Maple Shade, said she voted for Mr. Brown, albeit reluctantly. "I'm Catholic, and he was in the seminary," she said. "But to tell the truth, it was hard to vote for anybody. Clinton, I don't trust him because of what came out about him running around. I'm waiting to see about Perot. I do not see myself voting for Bush because he really hasn't helped the middle-income-type people."
The disappointment clearly cut across party lines. Fran Kupko of Edison, a teacher, said she would vote for President Bush "reluctantly."
"I'm not really happy with any of the candidates," she explained, echoing what seemed a universally dispirited attitude in this primary. "I was considering Perot, but he's not on the ballot."

HEADLINE: Poll Shows New Yorkers Prefer To Put State in Private Hands

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Most New Yorkers are so angry with state government that they believe a private commission would do a better job than their elected officials, a public-opinion survey commissioned by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan has found.
The results suggest further evidence of a frustration with incumbents and may not bode well for those seeking re-election in state legislative races this year. Mr. Regan said he planned to run for Comptroller again in 1994 and had commissioned the poll, which was released last week, to determine whether his warnings and proposed remedies regarding fiscal stability were being heard. 
 The survey seems to indicate that many were not, which Mr. Regan attributed to what he described as the news media's inattention to the underlying problems behind recurring deficits. Only one in five respondents said that Mr. Regan had offered long-term plans to deal with deficits -- evidence, he indicated, of a gap between his efforts to call attention to budgetary irresponsibility and the public's perception of his effectiveness.
The telephone survey of 800 registered voters statewide was conducted by Penn & Schoen Associates between April 26 and May 6. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points.
Almost 7 in 10 surveyed said that the state's problems were so big and steeped in politics that a private commission would do a better job of proposing nonpartisan legislative solutions than politicians.
 
Unexpected Answers
 The survey found dissatisfaction about high spending and support for reducing inefficiency in state programs. But some results were less predictable, particularly in a poll released by the ranking Republican in state government.
Nearly two in three respondents agreed that the state's budget problems were a direct result of "the failed economic policies of the Reagan and Bush Administrations."
Given a choice of raising taxes for state programs or cutting those programs, one in three people preferred the tax increase. Nearly as many blamed the Legislature (about one in five) as blamed Gov. Mario M. Cuomo (about one in three) for fiscal problems.
Asked which single expense they would cut, one in four respondents volunteered welfare, and one in six preferred to prune legislators' salaries.

HEADLINE: Hand Injuries In Workplace Ignite Battle

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH

 BODY:
In a decision that creates a forum for the legal battle over one of the nation's fastest growing workplace disabilities, a Federal judge in Brooklyn agreed yesterday to combine 44 hand-injury suits into one consolidated case.
Such hand injuries -- which are known as repetitive stress injuries and which medical experts say can be caused by the routine use of computers, supermarket checkout scanners and other mechanical and electrical devices -- have spawned hundreds of individual lawsuits across the country in recent years. 
 But legal experts said that yesterday's decision by Judge Jack B. Weinstein marked the first time that many repetitive stress cases had been consolidated, a technique that has previously produced legal precedents in such areas as asbestos.
 
Possible Precedent
 And while the decision could be revised or overturned at a later date, the experts say the outcome of these cases could also set a precedent for future litigation.
The consolidated cases were assigned to Judge Denis R. Hurley. But before they go to trial, Judge Hurley will have to rule on whether they have factual, legal and scientific issues in common. At the heart of the case will be whether repetitive stress injury can be considered a general syndrome, or even whether there is any such medically recognized injury. Only then will the question of responsibility be assessed.
The plaintiffs run the gamut from stenographers, postal workers, and data inputers to word processors and journalists, among others.
The workers are suing the manufacturers of the equipment they use -- multi-million dollar companies like Apple Computer, A.T.& T., I.B.M., and Atex and its parent company Eastman Kodak. Workers' compensation laws prohibit employees injured on the job from suing their company.
The injured workers include employees from Nynex, Blue Cross-Blue Shield, the New Jersey Department of Taxation, The New York Times, The Philadelphia Inquirer, The Philadelphia Daily News, and Newsday, said Steven Phillips, a lawyer in the New York firm of Levy, Phillips and Konigsberg, which is representing 37 of the plaintiffs.
Aside from the 44 consolidated lawsuits in Brooklyn Federal Court, there are 16 similar lawsuits pending in the Southern District of New York and 84 in the New York State courts. Judge Weinstein suggested that they, too, might be included in the suit at a later date.
"The message is that it's time to take litigation seriously," said Mr. Phillips, the lawyer who presented the original motion. "We want a single judge to decide it so we don't have to reinvent the wheel hundreds of times." Mr. Phillips said he had more than a hundred other such cases pending.
While some conceded that the judge's decision lent an appearance of greater credibility to the plaintiffs' claims, lawyers for the defendants said yesterday that there were no genuine links among the claims and that they should not have been joined.
"The types of machinery are different from one case to another, so without the commonality of product, of work history, of individual's background as well, there isn't a reason for all of the cases to be thrown into one hopper," said Arthur J. Liederman, a lawyer representing Matsushita Electronics and C. Itoh. "It's one thing if somebody is exposed to asbestos. That's one fiber, one product."
 
'Heard on the Merits'
 But Michael Cerussi, who represents International Business Machines, said, "I'm not necessarily displeased by the decision." The decision will speed up the legal process, he said. "What'll happen now is that I.B.M. is going to have the opportunity to get heard on the merits of this sooner rather than later."
And, like other defense lawyers, Mr. Cerussi argued that there were no merits. "One, there's nothing wrong with the product in the first instance, and, two, the nexus between the product and claimed injury doesn't exist," he said.
With the rise in theuse of personal computers, injuries caused by repeating the same motions thousands of times a day crept from assembly lines into the previously low-risk white-collar world during the last decade, according to physicians who treat people with repetitive stress injuries
By sitting in the same position for four or five hours to punch keys without pause or variation, telephone operators, data entry workers, reporters and other computer operators can overtax the muscles and tendons in their wrists and forearms. As the strain accumulates, it can lead to swelling and inflammation of those tissues, causing weakness, numbness, tingling and pain.
In extreme cases, the injuries can render a victim unemployable, turning motions as routine as gripping a doorknob or lifting a coffee cup into painful ordeals.
"It can be anywhere from three months to two years to recover, depending upon the severity of the injury," said Dr. Emil F. Pascarelli, who has treated hundreds of musicians and computer operators with repetitive stress injuries at the Miller Institute at St. Lukes Roosevelt Hospital Center.
Consolidation has benefits. A single or a series of larger lawsuits economize time and money. In fact, in the opinion document, Judge Weinstein stressed that consolidation of law suits "will provide for convenience and economy of effort." "A significant feature in these cases supporting consolidation is that the litigation is still in infancy," Judge Weinstein wrote.
Depending on the number of consolidated cases, there will be fewer juries and verdicts and depositions by experts would be limited.
Consolidated cases can also create a ripple effect, bringing it to the attention of other injured workers who have not filed suit. "It lets other plaintiffs know about that litigation," said Melvin Friedman, a senior partner at Kreindler & Kreindler a firm that has dealt with consolidated cases. "One of its goals is to wake up people to an injury whose source they may not know."
 
'Slip Through Cracks'
 Mr. Phillips said that individual repetitive stress suits might make it easier for manufacturers to "slip through cracks in a confused, serendipitous situation."
But there are downsides as well. Large numbers of cases lumped together make it very difficult for cases to be settled, said Stuart Speiser, senior partner at Speiser, Krause, Madole, & Nolan a firm that has dealt in large aviation cases. "Total consolidation of cases I don't think is good for anybody," Mr. Speiser said. "The preferable method is to have them pending before the same judge so that there is no duplication and then if appropriate have one trial on liability."
