HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGNBUSH WIDENS PLAN ON BUSINESS ZONES

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
As Congress and the White House continued to fight over the response to the recent rioting in Los Angeles, the Bush Administration today announced a plan to expand urban enterprise zones, one of its favorite antipoverty proposals.
Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp, the Administration's most ardent advocate of enterprise zones, said in a telephone interview that the new plan would increase both the number of zones as well as the tax breaks they offer. 
 To sell his proposals, President Bush brought Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles and other California leaders to the White House today to tell Democratic Congressional leaders that the initiative would help rebuild the nation's cities.
The meeting was part of a negotiating effort by the White House to back increased aid for urban summer-job programs in exchange for a pledge by Congressional leaders to move quickly on the President's proposal to grant tax advantages to businesses willing to invest in inner-city neighborhoods.
 
Plans for Passage
 The House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, said Mr. Bush had suggested at the meeting that his enterprise-zone proposal be broken out of his broader urban package to expedite passage before the Fourth of July Congressional recess. "We are going to discuss that and get back to the President," said Mr. Foley, a Washington Democrat.
Enterprise zones are intended to lure businesses into impoverished areas by means of tax cuts. The Administration contends that this approach will bring jobs to those who need them most, although Congress has viewed such claims with skepticism and has allowed previous proposals to languish for more than a decade.
While the previous Administration proposal would have created 50 enterprise zones, Mr. Kemp said the new one would create them in any community that meets criteria like endemic poverty, unemployment and a shrinking tax base.
In addition, Mr. Kemp said the new plan for expanded enterprise zones would eliminate all capital gains taxes in such areas, while the previous proposal did away with only some of those taxes. It would also eliminate the "alternative minimum tax" that investors pay, and would allow investors who buy stock in companies in enterprise zones to deduct that investment from their taxes immediately.
Despite today's maneuvering, officials close to the negotiations between the White House and Democratic leaders said they were inching closer to an agreement on a measure to help the nation's cities. The bill would include most of a $1.5 billion provision for summer jobs, Head Start and law enforcement for 75 big cities that was passed by the Senate but not by the House.
 
'Hope, Faith and Confidence'
 After the meeting at the White House, Mr. Bradley told reporters that urban enterprise zones would "add greatly to our desire to restore the hope, faith and confidence of the people in the cities of America."
Standing alongside Gov. Pete Wilson of California and Peter Ueberroth, the leader of the effort to rebuild parts of Los Angeles scarred by rioting last month, Mr. Bradley added, "We've got to demonstrate to the people of our cities that the Government means business."
Democratic Congressional leaders said they also support urban enterprise zones, but expressed dismay that Mr. Bush did not specify how he would pay for the program, which will involve an estimated $2.3 billion in tax breaks over five years.
The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, said he was concerned that if Congress considered the urban enterprise zone legislation apart from other initiatives, public interest could wane and momentum would be lost in legislating job and school relief.
"We think enterprise zones make sense," said Mr. Mitchell, a Democrat from Maine. But he added that "to achieve the full beneficial effect of enterprise zones, it's important to have education, job training and other initiatives at the same time."
The House Republican whip, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, said the Democrats were stalling. He and other conservatives contend that the Democrats are more interested in raising taxes and expanding urban bureaucracies than in promoting solutions based on private enterprise.

HEADLINE: Cynicism and Hope: Diverse Voices of Black Youth

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEMPHIS

 BODY:
This is a city of song and sorrow, a great fount of blues music and the place where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was murdered in 1968, touching off riots across the country.
This year, while the wounds from the recent rioting are still raw in Los Angeles, all seems calm here. On these late spring weekends the sweet, smoky aroma of barbecue floats over shabby patches of the inner city. Children play tag while the grownups set up folding chairs, stock ice coolers and slap grandma's secret sauce on the ribs. 
 But a visitor who asks will find that many of these Memphis residents, largely black and struggling, feel increasingly isolated from the American mainstream by poverty, unemployment and racism.
And the suspicion and cynicism have a hard edge especially among the young. They voice a sharp distrust and fear of the police, the courts and the government and its leaders.
"They don't really care about black people," Marissa Dicluson, 15 years old, said the other day. "It's hard to choose a political role model, black or white. They lie. 'No new taxes.' Right. They're so phony and fake. They say how they're going to fix up the projects around here, but they never do."
 
Are Whites to Blame
 In more than two dozen interviews, from public housing projects to street corners along blues-soaked Beale Street, inner-city teen-agers and young adults talked about their lives, their hopes and their heroes. Their voices sounded like echoes from the streets of Watts or the South Side of Chicago or Harlem, and they were just as diverse. Black America is not a monolith.
"It seems like white folks want to do away with us," said William Grant, 18. "During wars they always put us on the front lines so we'll die first."
Less than a block away, though, Mark Williams, 20, said: "You can't blame everything on the white man now. I think racism is over. Opportunity is out there, you just got to go out and get it."
But so far, Mr. Williams said, he has not been able to just go out and get a job.
"I need a job bad," he said with a sigh. "Any job. But nobody will hire me."
After the April 29 acquittal of four white Los Angeles police officers in the beating of Rodney G. King, the black motorist, some of the boys at the Dixie Boys Club, on the grounds of a public housing project here, were angry, said Joe Jones, the club's 28-year-old program director, but others just called the verdict business as usual.
"We try to convince the kids to work and strive within the system," Mr. Jones said. "It's hard to teach them that when they see things like the Rodney King incident."
 
Meeting at the Club
 The gym at the John Dustin Buckman Boys Club on the city's struggling north side is crowded when school lets out for the day.
"The Boys Club is really a lifesaver for a lot of these kids," said Bernal E. Smith, the club director. "On the streets it's a survival-of-the-fittest situation. Inner-city youth don't have summer jobs, and that's a big part of the problem."
Patrice Ray, 19, his brother Solomon, 17, and their friend Caesar Davis, 17, play basketball at the club on most afternoons because, in the words of Mr. Davis, "it's too violent out there."
When asked whom they look to for guidance, the three friends named their parents and then several rap stars, including Ice Cube and Ice T.
"Rappers, they educate through reality," Solomon Ray said. "They talk about how politicians be crooked, how TV and newspapers lie. They tell the truth about the world."
The rap stars also tell the truth "about how wrong the police be treating us," Patrice Ray said.
His brother interjected: "Their job is to serve and protect us. Who's going to protect us from them?"
"Being broke all the time is how selling dope gets started," Solomon Ray continued. "We need some jobs in the ghetto, and they need to raise the minimum wage. Slavery days is over."
 
A Principal's Lament
 Not far away is Booker T. Washington High School, the city's oldest predominantly black high school. The principal, Elsie Lewis Bailey, spends much of her time nurturing the aspirations of her students.
"Our children can learn just like anybody else," Mrs. Bailey said. "But the children lack a lot of experiences. Many of our kids don't get out of this community for anything.
"We're in an area that is terribly economically depressed. Our kids aspire to the same things that other students aspire to. But some of them don't know how to get there."
Late one recent afternoon, six students sat around a table in the school. Although they said they generally did not trust politicians or others who are usually called "leaders," there were exceptions like the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Memphis's first black mayor, W. W. Herenton, who was elected last November by 172 votes.
"But it's hard to succeed when you only see good examples every 10 years or so," said Freddrick Dupree, who hopes to become a doctor. "All we have now is the Mayor."
The students said it was also hard to succeed when they were confronted and held back by stereotypes. Mr. Dupree said the police harassed young black people in his neighborhood regardless of whether they were selling dope or jumping rope.
"It seems like society wants us to fall flat on our faces," Ms. Dicluson added. "Other schools call us a 'project school.' They say stuff like we can't go anywhere without a police escort. They call us 'at risk.' When they stick these tags on us, we end up doing exactly what they want us to do: fail."
"But I'm not at risk," she said. "I'm not going to fail."
 
Legacy of the King Era
 Dr. King came to Memphis in 1968 to support a strike by public works employees. Willie Cooper, then and now, worked for that department, and he marched with Dr. King.
"I carried a sign for 65 days saying, 'I am a man,' " Mr. Cooper said. "I thought things would change, would get better, but it looks like they're slipping back. These youngsters today aren't going to take what we took or half of what we took."
There is a generation gap in the Cooper family -- more than one, in fact. Willie Cooper's 35-year-old son, Arthur, is more hopeful about race relations, at least when he begins to talk.
"It was the happiest day of my life when we elected a black Mayor," Arthur Cooper said. "It was like some big chains fell off my back."
The younger Mr. Cooper then said that he had an 18-year-old daughter and that she and her friends were restless and angry about their lives. A black Mayor does not mean as much to them, he said.
"I'm not prejudiced," he went on. "But when black people earn anything, it's always a struggle. It gets on your nerves. We always have to struggle. Something is going to have to give. These kids are too mad."
 
A Budding Family
 Hurt Village, a troubled public housing project, is a series of red two-story buildings in the style of row houses not far from the fun, music and tourists of Beale Street. The Police Department has recently begun an aggressive foot patrol in the project to curtail the frequent shootings and drug dealing there.
Tanya Minor, 19, has lived in Hurt Village for much of her life. She and her 19-year-old boyfriend, Rico Monet, have a baby girl. "We aren't on welfare," Ms. Minor said. "We're going to raise this baby ourselves."
The other day Ms. Minor sat in front of the home she shares with her family and said race relations "are going back to the way they used to be."
Mr. Monet ground out a cigarette butt in the dirt yard and said, "It don't make a difference what we say or do, white folks is going to treat us like dogs."
"White people the ones bringing the drugs into the country, but we the only ones going to jail for it," he said.
Nearby, Judy Price, 19, said she was happy to see so many police officers walking through the project, chasing away the drug dealers. "Now the kids can go out and play," she said.
Around the corner, William Grant stood talking with his family. He said that he had two role models -- his grandmother and Marcus Garvey, the black back-to-Africa advocate of the 1920's -- but that it was the words of a stranger who helped persuade him to stop selling drugs.
Mr. Grant said he had attended a meeting for teen-agers conducted by 100 Black Men, a group of professionals who also do neighborhood work. One speaker told the group that one measure of a man was what the women of his life thought about him.
"That made me think," Mr. Grant said. "If I ever have a family, I want my kids to look up to me. I don't want them saying I was a dope dealer, destroying our own people.
"You know, Coretta Scott King can tell her kids that Dr. King died fighting for his people. His kids are proud of that and want to follow in his footsteps. I want my kids to be proud of me like that, too."

He was joined by his friends Patrice Ray, 19, left, and his brother Solomon, 17 at a Boys Club on the city's struggling north side. (David Smart for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Papers Merge In Alaska

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ANCHORAGE, June 2

 BODY:
The Anchorage Times was sold today to its rival's owner and was to publish its last edition on Wednesday.
The closing makes Alaska's largest city a one-newspaper town and lowers to 60 the number of American cities with more than one daily. 
 The Times was sold to McClatchy Newspapers Inc., based in Sacramento, Calif. McClatchy owns The Anchorage Daily News.
"It's real hard for two newspapers to make it economically, so we elected to sell," said Bill Allen, The Time's owner and publisher. "It's a sad day and a good day."
No purchase price was disclosed. A severance package equivalent to two months' wages was offered to Times employees, Mr. Allen said. The Times employed 471 people and The Daily News 476 people last year.
McClatchy bought The Daily News in 1979 when its daily circulation was 11,500 to The Times' 45,600.The Daily News overtook The Times in circulation 10 years ago.

HEADLINE: MILITARY IN HAITI NAMES A PREMIER

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, June 2

 BODY:
The military-backed Government named a conservative politician today to become the country's new leader, the state-run National Radio said.
The politician, Marc Bazin, a former World Bank official and businessman, would become Prime Minister and run a consensus Government under a plan backed by the army and many politicians. Parliament is expected to ratify his selection in about a week. 
 Mr. Bazin's appointment has been opposed by the international community and supporters of the ousted President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
Haiti has been shaken by growing violence and an exodus of thousands of Haitians by boat over the last several weeks as hemisphere-wide sanctions have squeezed the economy.
A radio report broadcast from Parliament quoted an "official and authorized source" as saying Mr. Bazin had been designated by the interim President, Joseph Nerette. Under the plan, Mr. Nerette and Prime Minister Jean-Jacques Honorat would step down once Mr. Bazin's appointment was approved. The presidency would remain vacant.
Mr. Nerette and Mr. Honorat were appointed by parliament, under heavy pressure from the army, shortly after Father Aristide's ouster on Sept. 30 in a bloody coup.
Mr. Bazin, 60 years old, holds a law degree from the University of Paris and spent more than 20 years as a development expert for the World Bank in West Africa and Haiti.
In 1982, he was economy minister for the dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier, but he was ousted after just four months for attacking corruption. The brief stint earned him the nickname "Mr. Clean."
In the elections in December 1990, Mr. Bazin, who speaks fluent English, was said to be favored by the United States (some have called him "Mr. America"), but he ran a distant second to Father Aristide. Mr. Bazin's relationship with the American embassy soured after Father Aristide's ouster.
Mr. Bazin is despised by many supporters of Father Aristide. The ousted President remains highly popular and a leftist coalition that has sought his reinstatement, the National Front for Change and Democracy, has vowed to boycott the ratification proceedings for Mr. Bazin. A co-leader of the Front, Victor Benoit, has said the coalition, which holds almost half the votes in the House of Deputies, would refuse to recognize Mr. Bazin.

HEADLINE: Rumors Fly On Meeting At Salomon

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON Jr.

 BODY:
Wall Street eats rumors for breakfast, and its plate was heaped high yesterday. The topic was who will be named today to replace Warren E. Buffett at Salomon Inc., where he has served as interim chairman since last year.
Salomon's directors are scheduled to gather for a monthly meeting in New York this morning, and executives close to the firm said Mr. Buffett had said he would name a successor. No one could be sure, however, just who it would be. 
 John J. Byrne is the name that jumped off many a tongue yesterday. As chief executive of the Fund American Companies, Mr. Byrne is a big investor who is familiar with Wall Street's peculiar ways and, perhaps more important, is a longtime acquaintance of Mr. Buffett.
 
'In the Buffett Mold'
 "Byrne is a man in the Buffett mold," said one Wall Street executive who asked not to be named. "He can be a strong leader without meddling, which is apparently what Warren wants."
Other candidates mentioned by Wall Street executives included John C. Whitehead, the former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company; Thomas S. Murphy, the chairman of Capital Cities/ABC Inc., and Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve.
"Warren's been looking for a Volckeresque character, since Volcker himself apparently isn't interested in the job," said another executive, who also asked not to be named. "Someone of stature, who understands the Street."
Mr. Byrne, 60 years old, may not have Mr. Volcker's stature, but he earned a reputation for able management by leading the Government Employee Insurance Company from insolvency in 1976 to a solidly profitable enterprise in the mid-1980's.
One of the insurer's leading investors was Berkshire Hathaway Inc., Mr. Buffett's Omaha-based investment company, which also assisted Mr. Byrne when he led the Fireman's Fund Corporation, with well-known results.
"Jack Byrne is a very logical choice," said John Keefe, the president of Keefe Worldwide Information Services. "He's not only an eminence grise, he's one with substance."
 
Competitor's Ties Cited
 But another executive pointed out Mr. Byrne's position as a director at the American Express Company, which owns Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., a Salomon competitor, and said he thought it unlikely that Mr. Byrne would be Mr. Buffett's choice.
When Mr. Buffett detailed the requirements for the job in Salomon's annual report in March, he said the chairman should be "an owner-oriented and business-wise man or woman" who can supervise and counsel the heads of Salomon's two subsidiaries, Salomon Brothers Inc. and Phibro Energy Inc.
"Essentially, the holder of the job will act as a strong, nonoperating chairman of two companies lodged under one corporate roof," he said in the report. "This position may not require the full time of its occupant but it will demand significant time."
Deryck C. Maughan was named chairman and chief executive of Salomon Brothers last week, and Andrew J. Hall is Phibro's chairman and chief executive.
 
Byrne Unavailable for Comment
 Mr. Byrne's office in Norwich, Vt., said yesterday that he was traveling and could not be reached for comment. A Salomon spokesman, Robert F. Baker Jr., said the board meeting had been scheduled long in advance, and he declined to discuss the agenda.
Mr. Buffett told reporters last autumn, when Salomon was still under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission for its role in a Treasury scandal, that his successor would need to have experience running a business, and he expressly ruled out Mr. Volcker, who was the Fed chairman from 1979 to 1987.
On May 20, Salomon agreed to pay $290 million to settle charges that it had systematically submitted phony bids in Treasury auctions, freeing Mr. Buffett to pursue his often-stated goal of retreating from Salomon once its legal problems related to the scandal were resolved.
 
A Noted Dictum
 Mr. Keefe of Keefe Worldwide Information Services noted that one of Mr. Buffett's well-known dictums was that when management with a reputation for brilliance tackles a business with a reputation for bad economics, it is invariably the reputation of the business that survives.
"Byrne is one of the few cases," Mr. Keefe said, "where good management has collided with crummy industry, and everybody still thinks they're good managers."
Another executive recalled that Mr. Byrne was mentioned as a possible successor in the current issue of Business Week magazine and said that he wondered how much of yesterday's talk was, like so much gossip, a blanket of speculation wrapped around a germ of information.

HEADLINE: Afro-American Studies Get New Life at Harvard

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 29

 BODY:
Since it was founded amid the political protests of the late 1960's, the Afro-American studies department at Harvard has struggled. Professors elsewhere in the university criticized the new department's scholarly work as mediocre. Some said the department was run by radical black students. And students and professors in Afro-American studies felt Harvard neglected them.
By the 1990-1991 academic year, the department seemed on the verge of collapse. Only one tenured professor remained, and Harvard students majoring in Afro-American studies found themselves in the unfamiliar position of having to go to Tufts University or Boston University to take required courses. 
 But now the Afro-American studies department has handsome new offices overlooking Harvard Square, four new professors have joined the faculty, and the department's new chairman, Henry Louis Gates Jr., a prominent black literary critic, has reorganized and re-energized the program.
In one year, the number of undergraduates majoring in Afro-American studies at Harvard has almost doubled, going to 37 from 19. "Gates has done miracles; the department is as different as night and day," said Mecca Nelson, a 21-year-old senior from Flint, Mich., who is majoring in Afro-American studies.
 
National Implications
 Perhaps even more important, the transformation of the department at Harvard has national implications, at a time when Afro-American studies as a discipline has been under assault.
"Because of Harvard's national pre-eminence, what happens there gives Afro-American studies an intellectual legitimacy for other places," said Cornel West, the director of the Afro-American studies program at Princeton, considered by many to be the best in the country. "What's happening at Harvard makes it more difficult to trash Afro-American studies."
John Blassingame, a tenured professor of history and African-American studies at Yale University, concurred. "I've always said that until Harvard has a strong program, the enterprise called African-American studies won't arrive," he said.
At the center of the changes at Harvard is Professor Gates, known as "Skip" to his friends and colleagues, a 41-year-old academic entrepreneur who has been one of the most sought-after scholars in the country in the last decade. Cornell University made him a full professor at the age of 33 to lure him away from Yale, his alma mater; Duke University then gave him an endowed chair.
But he stayed at Duke only a year before accepting an offer from Harvard that made him simultaneously chairman of the Afro-American studies department, the W. E. B. Du Bois professor of the humanities and the director of the W. E. B. Du Bois Institute, a research institute.
 
Fear of Closing
 When he was first offered the job at Harvard, Professor Gates said in an interview in his office: "I thought the department had been cursed. Afro-American studies here were about to be shut down."
But Henry Rosovsky, the longtime dean of the faculty of arts and sciences, assured him that Harvard was now serious about building the best Afro-American studies program in the world.
"Harvard was the ideal situation," Professor Gates said. "I had always wanted to build an institution, and there was no dead wood to clear out."
In 1990, Mr. Rosovksy said, when both he and Derek Bok, who had been president of Harvard for two decades, were about to retire from administrative work, they decided to "make one last very determined effort" to build a good Afro-American studies department.
"We didn't want to leave that one last item in poor condition," said Mr. Rosovsky, who is still a professor of economics. "So we went out to look for the person who could do it, and we got Skip."
 
Time of Protest
 It may have helped that a number of black students at Harvard were protesting the lack of a first-rate Afro-American studies program.
Professor Gates has moved quickly, securing the new offices and helping to bring in three new professors, including his closest intellectual friend, K. Anthony Appiah, a Ghanian-born philosopher who was also hired away from Duke. Professor Gates hopes to bring in several more new professors in the next few years, conserving his resources by making the appointments jointly with other departments like the Divinity School, and the music, fine arts and history departments.
In the past, making such joint appointments at Harvard proved difficult because many professors were skeptical of the academic quality of the work being done in Afro-American studies. Harvard's history department does not have a single professor working on Afro-American topics, and it recently cut short a search for a new professor in that field, concluding that none of sufficient stature was available, several professors said.
Mr. Gates has also made several high-profile moves to fill in the gaps in the department's course offerings and to give Afro-American studies more excitement. Last winter he invited a friend, Spike Lee, the film director, to teach a seminar at Harvard. The course was oversubscribed and so successful that Mr. Lee has agreed to come back again in the fall.
The Afro-American Studies Department has not offered graduate degrees, reflecting its diminished status at Harvard. But Professor Gates is optimistic that there will be a master's degree program soon, and after that a Ph.D. program.
Politically, Mr. Gates has disappointed some of the more radical students because he does not share their black nationalist or Afrocentric views. The Afrocentrists believe that the ancient Egyptians were black and that therefore Western civilization is derived from black Africans.
Mr. Gates said that some of the work being done in the more than 200 Afro-American studies programs around the country is intellectually "bogus" because, he contends, they are essentially inventing an African past that never was.
"You would think that the most urgent issue in Afro-American studies departments today would be the causes of poverty and how they can be remedied," he said. "But this is not the most urgent issue.
"The most urgent issue is whether Cleopatra was black. This is classic escapism and romanticism."
Professor Gates would like to see more rigorous scholarship, rather than what he calls "ethnic cheerleading," to separate truth from fiction.
In a conciliatory gesture this spring, Professor Gates invited the more radical students to send him their comments, and he has agreed to lead an informal reading course next fall examining some of the Afrocentric writings, Professor Appiah said.
"We told them we're grateful that they made a fuss, because that's why we're here," Professor Appiah said, referring to the student protests in 1990.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Afro-American studies department at Harvard University has been re-energized by its new chairman, Henry Louis Gates Jr. (Sarah Putnam for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Move Higher

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday after the Federal Reserve Board surprised credit market participants when it aggressively purchased notes and bonds for its own account.
Market prices were down from Monday's late levels at the time the Fed made its so-called coupon pass. 
 "Of the coupon passes I have seen, this was on the aggressive side," said one government bond trader.
Analysts estimated the Fed bought about $3 billion worth of securities, and said the move had no policy implications. The Fed routinely declines to comment on its open market operations. Purchases of Treasury securities by the Fed add reserves to the banking system.
The Fed's action "was a pleasant surprise for those who had some coupon-bearing securities they wanted to unload," said Dana Johnson, chief money market economist at the First National Bank of Chicago, "but there is no reason to think that this pass was anything other than technical."
Economic data released yesterday continued to support those who argue for a mild recovery.
The four-tenths of a percent rise in the Government's index of leading economic indicators was bigger than expected, but the 1.3 percent increase in new-home sales during April was an extremely mild rebound from the nearly 16 percent decline registered in March.
"New-home sales were running at an unsustainably rapid rate in the first quarter," said Samuel D. Kahan, chief financial economist at Fuji Securities Inc. "From here on I expect they will work their way higher, but slowly and irregularly."
Despite the price gains recorded during the session, traders said they remain cautious in advance of May employment data to be released on Friday.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 101 19/32 , up 1/4 point, to yield 7.86 percent, compared with 7.88 percent late Monday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 6/32 in late trading, up 1/4 point, to yield 7.32 percent. The 6 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 5/8, up 1/4 point, to yield 6.60 percent. And the 5 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 7/8, up 1/8 point, to yield 5.19 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates inched lower.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.72 percent late yesterday, down one basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by two basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.85 percent.
In the corporate bond market, Cinemark USA, a movie theater operator, offered $125 million worth of high-yield 10-year senior notes through an underwriting group led by Bear, Stearns & Company.
The 12 percent notes, which are callable in five years at a price of 106, were priced at $100, or par.
The securities are rated B-1 by Moody's Investors Service and B+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company offered $500 million worth of one-year notes through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

HEADLINE: Dow Back Under 3,400 With 17.11 Decline

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Stock prices fell in active trading yesterday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average below 3,400 as investors took profits.
Drug issues slipped on worries about earnings as fickle investor attitudes about the economy turned pessimistic. 
 The Dow, which closed past the 3,400 threshold for the first time on Monday, fell 17.11 points yesterday to end at 3,396.10.
 
Stock Hangover
 "The market had a little bit of a hangover from breaking into record territory," said Philip Orlando, a trader at Unity Management.
Declining issues led advancers, 917 to 815, on a New York Stock Exchange volume of 203.1 million shares, compared with 190.6 million on Monday. The Big Board's composite index fell 1.70 to close at 228.20.
Broader market gauges were mostly lower. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 issues fell 3.80 points, to 413.50, as the American Stock Exchange's composite index finished 0.89 point lower at 393.95. In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index rose 0.81 point, to 589.18.
"The market made a couple attempts to best its closing level of yesterday and failed, and that created a little bit of concern," said Eugene Peroni, a trader at Janney Montgomery Scott Inc.
 
Selling Programs a Factor
 Traders said some selling programs late in the session knocked the Dow to its low for the day of about 3,393. A sharp selloff in drug stocks kept many investors hesitant, analysts said.
Drug issues fell after a warning from Bristol-Myers Squibb on profits and after Miriam Cutler, an analyst at Lehman Brothers Inc., downgraded Johnson & Johnson.
Mr. Orlando of Unity Management said disappointing earnings from Syntex last week were also a factor. "The Street said that if three drug companies are having problems, maybe the rest of the group is, too," he said.
Bristol-Myers tumbled 6 7/8, to 66 7/8; Johnson & Johnson dropped 5 5/8, to 92 3/8, and Merck lost 1 1/2, to 49 5/8. Syntex was off 2 3/4, to 35 3/8.
 
Sun Microsystems Off 2
 Sun Microsystems fell 2, to 26, in over-the-counter trading. Alex. Brown & Sons removed the computer maker from its "emphasis" list and cut forecasts. Harley Davidson, the Milwaukee-based motorcycle maker, fell 2 7/8, to 55 7/8. The company said it had fallen behind on its production schedule. Salomon Brothers was among the brokerages trimming its estimates as a result.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Broad Gains As Denmark Rejects Treaty

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly higher on world currency markets yesterday after early returns from a referendum in Denmark showed voters rejected a treaty on European political and economic union.
Gold also rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $339.30 an ounce, up $1.50 from Monday. The Republic National Bank said gold was up $1.35 an ounce, to $337.60. 
 The dollar settled higher in overseas trading, aided by buying from traders seeking to offset previous bets that the dollar would fall. But the overseas gains faded in New York on disappointing economic data.
The Government reported that sales of new homes rose just 1.3 percent in April; many analysts had expected a gain of about 7 percent.
In addition, the sharp March decline in home sales was revised even further downward, to 15.9 percent from 14.8 percent. That was the largest drop in a decade. But another report, on the Government's main economic forecasting tool, showed the index of leading indicators rose more than expected in April.
The data seemed to underscore the fitful nature of the economic recovery.
"The market is more reactive to bad news than good," said Kevin Lawrie, director of foreign exchange at the Bank of Boston.
However, as initial results of the Danish voting began to filter out just before the market's close, "the dollar took off," Mr. Lawrie said.
After currency trading ceased in New York, it was reported that in the final count, Danish voters, by a slim margin, had rejected having Denmark adhere to the European treaty.
European officials had said Danish rejection of the treaty would mean the other 11 nations in the community would have to produce a new accord.
"In times of confusion, people tend to buy dollars," Mr. Lawrie said.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 127.48 yen, up 0.70 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 127.55 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 127.45 yen, up from 126.95 Monday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Platinum's Price Up Sharply On Strong Europe Demand

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Strong European demand and some hints of an improving American economy sent platinum futures sharply higher yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Platinum for delivery in July settled $8.90 higher at $377.20 an ounce. 
 "The key to platinum's advance seems to be a surge in commercial demand, mainly out of Europe," said William O'Neill, senior futures strategist in New York with Merrill Lynch Futures. "We started to hear last week of tight supplies in Europe, and some of this may be related to the emission standards that go into effect there later this year."
A primary use for platinum is in automobile catalytic converters.
 
No Long-Term Shortage Seen
 In addition to the increased demand, the Commonwealth of Independent States, created from parts of the old Soviet Union, is expected to sell less of the metal this year.
While there are no signs of long-term shortages of platinum, there could be short-term tightness, Mr. O'Neill said.
In addition to the overseas influence on platinum futures, domestic news also played a part.
"The data continue to show an economic rebound," said Peter Cardillo, research director in New York for Westfalia Investments Inc. "That is a major plus for the metals."
The Commerce Department said Tuesday that its index of leading indicators increased four-tenths of 1 percent in April -- better than expected but still less than robust.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, forecasts for some rain in the Midwest this week were brushed aside, and soybean and corn futures prices rose.
Dry conditions are posing a particular threat to the heart of the corn region.
"The indications now are that some of the drier areas of Iowa, Illinois and Indiana probably will get no rain until at least a week from this Thursday," said Joel Karlin, an analyst in Chicago with K & S Research.
Wheat was also higher because of continuing rains in the southern Plains that have delayed the harvest of the winter wheat crop.
"The rain just can't get past a high-pressure area," Mr. Karlin said.
Cattle futures slumped in late trading at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. While the cash cattle and wholesale beef prices are supportive now, traders say they are not convinced that these markets will not turn weaker in the coming weeks.
Energy futures were mixed on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Light crude oil for July delivery was 8 cents higher at $22.11 a barrel; July heating oil was 0.13 cent higher at 60.38 cents a gallon; July unleaded gasoline was 0.13 cent lower at 65.79 cents a gallon, and July natural gas was 0.8 cent lower at $1.652 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Another Recovery Forecast, This One a Quarter Delayed

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
LIKE the station master who keeps reassuring impatient passengers that yes, indeed, the train is coming, a leading advertising industry forecaster said yesterday that domestic ad spending was beginning its much-anticipated recovery, albeit at a slower pace than had been hoped.
"I am convinced the economic recovery is on its way," Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and director of forecasting at McCann-Erickson U.S.A., said during a presentation in Manhattan. "Unfortunately, its arrival is about a quarter delayed." 
 "We're on our way back, finally," he added, "but there could be a little lag before everyone gets into the act."
For 1992, Mr. Coen expects ad spending in the United States to total $132.7 billion, which would represent a 5 percent increase from what he called the "terrible" results of last year. In 1991, ad spending actually fell for the first time since 1961, suffering its largest annual decline since 1942. It was a sobering event, perhaps even a watershed, for the advertising, marketing and media industries, for which optimism over ever-rising expenditures has become second nature.
Though a 5 percent gain for ad spending this year would stand in sharp contrast to a decline last year of 1.7 percent, to $126.4 billion, the rebound would not be as robust as Mr. Coen predicted in December. He forecast then that ad spending would rise 6.2 percent in 1992. And it is far from the 8.5 percent increase Mr. Coen forecast in a preliminary estimate a year ago.
Offsetting that, Mr. Coen offered the "good news" that a "recovery will occur in 1993." In his first look at ad spending for next year, he predicted it would total $143 billion, representing a healthier gain of 7.5 percent.
Underscoring Mr. Coen's ambivalence over the course of the economy, he used the word "mixed" almost a dozen times in his remarks. And he noted at several points he had been chided for "being far too optimistic" in the two forecasts he made last year about 1992.
"We're starting to see some improvement in the marketplace," he said. "But it sure isn't booming yet."
If ad spending does rise 5 percent this year, that would match its increase in 1989; the following year, it rose just 3.8 percent. Mr. Coen's forecast assumes an increase in gross domestic product, including inflation, of 4.8 percent, and an increase of 2.1 percent in real gross domestic product.
Mr. Coen, perhaps the most widely followed forecaster of ad spending, has been tracking those trends since 1948. He issues his predictions twice a year, in June and December, updating and revising his figures at subsequent presentations.
J. Kendrick Noble, a longtime advertising and media analyst who attended the presentation yesterday, said he had "been tracking Bob for decades, and he's about as good a forecaster as there is -- his midyear forecast last year notwithstanding."
"He was pretty far off," he added, "but so was I."
 Mr. Noble said he agreed with Mr. Coen's current forecast of slowly improving results for 1992, followed by a 1993 that is "even better."
Alan J. Gottesman, an analyst for Paine Webber Inc. in New York who also attended the presentation, described himself as perhaps more sanguine than Mr. Coen.
Mr. Gottesman said that given the low expectations of most industry executives, there are "odds of a feeding frenzy," that is, even a slight improvement in sentiment could produce "an incredible amount of leverage" to raise advertising demand.
Mr. Coen forecast that national advertising would increase 5.2 percent this year, to $76.4 billion, while local ad spending would increase 4.6 percent, to $56.3 billion.
Among the media categories that he expects to fuel growth are local newspapers, particularly in help-wanted classified ads, which are "going against such bad past results," and local television, which in the first quarter registered solid gains from advertisers like department stores and fast-food restaurants.
Those increases would offset continued weaknesses, Mr. Coen said, in areas like local and national Yellow Pages advertising and national mailings by direct marketers.
Outside the United States, Mr. Coen said that total ad spending should reach $161.8 billion, up 5.4 percent from 1991. That is a slight rise from his forecast in December of $161.5 billion.
And in his preliminary forecast for overseas ad spending next year, Mr. Coen predicted a total of $172 billion, up 6.3 percent from his revised 1992 estimate. Adding that to his prediction for domestic ad spending in 1993 would produce a total of $315 billion -- and it would be the first time ad spending worldwide had ever topped $300 billion.

HEADLINE: Yields Down on C.D.'s and Bank Funds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
In what has become an almost familiar pattern in the last few months, yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit were down in the week that ended yesterday, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's most recent survey.
The average decline was a little sharper for New York area banks than for those outside the market, reversing last week's trend. 
 If the auction of new three- and six-month Treasury bills on Monday is a harbinger of things to come, the bottom of the current rate decline may be near. The auction is considered by many interest-rate watchers as a good barometer of what banks might be paying their depositors in the weeks ahead.
 
3-Month Rate at 3.75%
 The average rate on a three-month bill was unchanged at 3.75 percent and the six-month bill rate also remained at the previous week's level of 3.90 percent.
Robert K. Heady, the publisher of the interest-rate publication, also noted some easing in the recent modest declines, but he does not see an upturn yet.
"If we begin to receive more bullish news about the economy like this week's leading indicators, then banks' interest rates will turn up," Mr. Heady said. "But one rosy indicator does not a trend make. If the economic news is mixed as it has been over the last couple of months, then rates will remain depressed longer."
 
Money Market Yield at 3.41%
 Yields at New York area banks were down, but the decline was a little less than the previous week, as the average money market account dropped by 3 basis points, to 3.41 percent. The yield on three- and six-month certificates declined by 2 basis points and 1 basis point, respectively, to 3.52 percent and 3.69 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Commercial banks, which make up half of the New York area's composite index, slightly lowered the yield of an average money market account to 3.19 percent, down by 2 basis points, and cut those on the average three-month and six-month certificate, by a basis point each, to 3.38 percent and 3.46 percent, respectively.
Savings banks, which make up the other half of the composite index, made more significant cuts, lowering the average money market account yield by 5 basis points, to 3.62 percent; a three-month C.D. yield by 4 basis points, to 3.67 percent, and a six-month C.D. yield by 3 basis points, to 3.92 percent.
 
Big Cuts in New York
 The sharpest yield changes were among the New York savings banks. First Nationwide dropped 20 basis points from its money matket account yield, to 3.80 percent, and the Anchor Savings Bank trimmed its three-month C.D. yield by 11 basis points, to 3.64 percent. Crossland Savings, for the second time in as many weeks, chopped a quarter of a percentage point off its six-month C.D. yield, to 4 percent.
For 20 large banks outside the New York market, yields were also down, but less so, with a money market account off by 2 basis points, to 3.27 percent, and a six-month C.D. off a basis point, to 3.63 percent.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Producer-Friendly Oil Conservation

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
NOW that Saddam Hussein has been shoved back within his own borders and the pragmatists in Teheran are oozing moderation, is Saudi Arabia once again summoning the courage to flex its formidable energy muscles?
That was certainly the spin the kingdom's leaders wished to put on their decision last week to side with the price hawks in OPEC. And while there is widespread feeling that the Saudis are bluffing, it raises anew the question of how far oil-importing nations should go along to get along. 
 To Morris Adelman, professor emeritus of economics at M.I.T., the Saudis' reported motive, pique at the prospect of an anti-greenhouse tax on carbon fuels, is just a frustrating reminder that OPEC's efforts to raise oil prices have always been vulnerable to strategic countermeasures. Philip Verleger, an oil specialist at the Institute of International Economics in Washington, is more cautious: The Saudi tilt, he suggests, is a warning that the West would be well advised to curb carbon in ways less likely to provoke confrontation.
According to news reports last week, Saudi Arabia had planned to raise output this summer in order to keep oil prices near the current $18-$21 a barrel benchmark at a time of rising demand. But the Saudis changed their mind, serving notice that they would no longer champion price moderation if the industrialized nations went along with a European Community proposal to tax carbon emissions.
Mr. Verleger doubts the Saudis are showing all their cards. The carbon-tax proposal, he notes, was already dead on arrival at the Rio environmental summit since the Bush Administration is not buying it, and the Europeans will not go it alone.
The real story, Mr. Verleger speculates, goes something like this. Oil prices spiked a bit before the OPEC meeting, perhaps on rumors of an assassination attempt on the King of Saudi Arabia. The Saudis then quietly decided to allow prices to stay up for a few months as a gift to the financially pressed (and politically unstable) governments of Venezuela and Nigeria -- but chose to use the occasion to register their protest over carbon taxes.
This fits with the near-consensus view that Saudi Arabia's strategy for long-term survival -- an image of moderation built around stable oil prices -- has not really changed. It also meshes with the view that the Saudis no longer believe they could keep prices much above the current level without racheting down the flow of oil below the rate that keeps them in Rolexes and Range Rovers.
Mr. Adelman, who has long believed that the importers were foolish to concede any price-setting power to OPEC, says the Saudis have done us a favor. The right course, he argues, is full speed ahead on conservation.
He says the Saudis are right to worry about carbon taxes. For while the money would initially come out of the pockets of consumers, the ultimate incidence of carbon tax, like any other excise tax, would turn on how buyers and sellers responded. And since energy consumers have substantial capacity to shift to energy-conserving technologies, the tax would almost certainly reduce the price of oil at the wellhead.
While other energy analysts do not disagree with the thrust of Mr. Adelman's analysis, many still fear there is risk to playing hardball. Jack Riggs, the staff director of the House Subcommittee on Energy and Power, guesses that the Saudis do perceive some flexibility in long-term pricing -- surely not the $10 or $15 a barrel assumed by OPEC hawks in the 1970's, but perhaps a few dollars. And it hardly seems wise to provoke them to try for a higher price if importing countries can find producer-friendlier ways to meet policy objectives.
That, of course, leaves open the question of how to put meat on these worthy bones. One way, suggests Mr. Verleger, would be to use free markets -- but not taxes -- to limit carbon emissions.
The model is the trading system now in place for sulfur. An overall national limit on sulfur emissions was set in the 1990 Clean Air Act, with each polluting electric utility assigned a quota according to past rates of emissions. The utilities are now free to clean up their own mess, or to buy emissions rights from others who can trap sulfur at lower cost.
The design and enforcement of a trading system for carbon would be far more problematic because there are so many sources of emissions. But economists at the Environmental Defense Fund say it could be done. And the ends, least-cost adjustment to fossil fuel conservation, would be identical to that achievable through a carbon tax.
The one big difference is that the Government would not collect a giant pot of money. That might be seen as a big disadvantage by people who would use the tax to fund the budget. But it could prove a big advantage in dealing with Saudi Arabia, which apparently sees itself in competition with governments for the oil consumer's dollar.

HEADLINE: The Pop Life

BYLINE: By Peter Watrous

 BODY:

Los Lobos
Los Lobos, one of the few Mexican-American bands working in pop, will come to town tomorrow for three nights at the Bottom Line to support its new album, "Kiko" (Warner Brothers). In 1987, the Los Angeles-based band had a hit with the track "La Bamba," but since then things haven't gone well commercially. The group released "La Pistola y el Corazon," a record of Mexican folk music, and followed that with "The Neighborhood," a decent enough rock album that vanished like snow in the Mojave. "Kiko," instead of returning the band to form, finds it in an experimental mode.
"This strange thing happened with 'La Bamba': it twisted things, and it took us a little bit to get back on the path again," said Louie Perez, one of Los Lobos' songwriters. "The first reaction was to dig into the roots, so we made 'La Pistola,' which gave us the opportunity to perform more in Spanish using traditional forms. When we did "The Neighborhood," we found ourselves looking into the rock-and-roll base, part of that was going back and redefining things for ourselves." 
 Where the band had often been working in rhythm-and-blues, blues and rock-and-roll, "Kiko" gives less of a nod to specific styles. Rather, songs are spare and the arrangements use odd instrumental configurations; all sorts of sounds percolate in the background.
"At the end of the session for 'Neighborhood,' we started working up some songs that were really different," Mr. Perez said. "They were taking shape like flashes and impressions. We were looking for more of an atmosphere than something conventional, and sonically we were trying to create a climate instead of saying 'Here's where the guitar solo goes.' This is a record where there's a sense of freedom to explore different things."
Los Lobos' songs often have references to Mexican culture, whether they're in the lyrics or in the music itself. In an era where borrowing and eclecticism are standard practices, the record fits right into mainstream pop, something it might not have done 10 years ago.
"It's a balancing act for us," said Mr. Perez. "We live in a different, separate world, and it's not the world that we found ourselves in when we turned on TV when we were kids. This is part of living as an ethnic person in America, I guess. Those differences made us draw chalk lines around ourselves, limiting ourselves, but through music we found a way to go beyond those boundaries. Music connected us with something outside social and economic factors that defined us and led us to a life in larger American culture."
 
Charlie Rich's Way
 When Charlie Rich canceled his appearance at the Bottom Line last week, groans could be heard through the critical world. Mr. Rich, who had been a huge country star in the 1960's, has just released a record, "Pictures and Paintings" (Sire/Warner Brothers), and it had excited people. Mixing jazz and country and blues, it is a particularly American album, moving easily between black and white music, making the connections between styles more important than the differences.
"American music is a good way of putting it," said Mr. Rich, who said he had canceled because of a tooth infection and would reschedule his appearance in New York. "I always have to be careful about what I say, that I did feel confined, because country was a big part of my musical career.
"But I grew up listening to all sorts of music in Arkansas, because black and white people lived very close by. So I heard gospel and blues and country and just about everything. A lot of country people are interested in all sorts of music -- Chet Atkins can play great jazz -- but people cut loose behind closed doors. I don't hate to be a country singer, but this was my fun record."
Mr. Rich has basically been retired since 1981. He'd tired of the road and he and his wife have been writing songs, which is what they say they prefer to do musically. Three years ago, he recorded an album for sale on television, but beyond that, Mr. Rich has lived quietly out of the limelight in Memphis.
"I just settled back in and figured out what to do," he said. "A couple things I kind of wanted to do, like raising my family, I'd been putting off. I just decided that it might be the best thing to do. Now we play around the house quite a bit. We just write songs, we love to do that first of all."

GRAPHIC: Photo: David Hidalgo, lead singer of Los Lobos, is to be at the Bottom Line with the Mexican-American band for three nights, starting tomorrow. (Matt Anderson)

HEADLINE: Some Top Urban Chefs Find New Life Outside the City Limits

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
WHEN Brendan Walsh packed up his sacks of blue cornmeal and strings of dried chilies to head for Island Park, L.I., in 1990, the acclaim he had earned at Arizona 206 in Manhattan immediately put his new Southwestern-style restaurant, the Coyote Grill, on the map. His venture out of the city to Long Island was so satisfying that last fall, he and his partner, John Vitale, opened another restaurant, the North Street Grill, in Great Neck.
With innovative chefs like Mr. Walsh choosing to do their cooking outside urban centers like Manhattan, the limelight they are used to is spreading beyond the city limits. 
 "I think somebody like Brendan, with that kind of New York reputation, in a restaurant on Long Island has made people notice what's going on," said Michael Meehan, the chef at the Mill River Inn in Oyster Bay, on the North Shore of Long Island. Mr. Meehan, 35 years old, grew up on the Island and cooked in restaurants there before working in Manhattan. He returned to Long Island three years ago, and his cooking now depends heavily on local ingredients.
"It's a great time to be cooking on Long Island," he said. "The public here now appreciates contemporary new American cuisine, and there's a growing network of chefs with lots of imagination and spirit."
In outlying areas all over the New York region, restaurants are adding a measure of urban style in their cooking, service and wine lists, as well as in their sometimes noisy settings. The recession, which hurt restaurants in cities all over the country, made the communities surrounding urban areas more attractive to chefs looking for work or seeking to open their own places.
Chefs and restaurateurs find that it is easier and less expensive to do business outside urban centers. And some chefs in their 30's are now married with young children, so, like many other young parents, they have chosen a life outside the city.
Some chefs, like Barry Squier of Girafe in Basking Ridge, N.J., cultivate their own tomatoes, herbs, berries and lettuces. At the same time, suppliers of the best ingredients, who might have delivered only to the city five years ago, have expanded their routes, making it even easier for the chefs to maintain high standards.
Take Jimmy Burke. He is filling his rustic new Tuscan Grill in Waltham, Mass., outside Boston, with people eager for garlicky wood-grilled shrimp, pappardelle with rabbit and spit-roasted chicken. The Tuscan Grill represents his return to Waltham, where in 1981 he opened a restaurant named Allegro. Encouraged by critical acclaim and a full reservation book, he left Waltham to open another Allegro, in Boston.
But the Boston fling fizzled, and Mr. Burke is now contentedly cooking in Waltham. "We are now seeing more business and from a more varied clientele than we ever had at either Allegro," he said.
In July 1991, Jeff Farnham, formerly a chef on the Queen Elizabeth 2, opened Amadeus in Stamford, Conn., with George Welser and Rudolph Sodamin, who also worked for Cunard, the line that owns the QE2.
"The economics in this area were right," he said. "and we thought it might be more forgiving and less cutthroat than in Manhattan. Manhattan is every chef's aspiration. But when people tell us they're coming here instead of driving to the city, that's very satisfying."
With a nucleus of energetic chefs and restaurateurs in the areas outside cities, not just in luxury restaurants but in new, more casual places, differences in style between those areas and the cities have narrowed.
Mr. Walsh's restaurants -- he is also a consulting chef for Mr. Vitale's seafood restaurant, Paddy McGee's, in Island Park, L.I. -- are all stylish but informal, with a good measure of noise. At the North Street Grill the food departs from Mr. Walsh's Southwestern mode to explore the shores of the Mediterranean. But dishes like wood-oven pizza with artichokes and roasted peppers, and Long Island duck salad with grilled eggplant and dried fruit, still bear his exuberant, well-seasoned stamp.
Christian Bertrand, whose reputation as sous-chef at Lutece in Manhattan preceded him when he opened Bertrand in Greenwich, Conn., nearly five years ago, said he was serving essentially the same kind of haute cuisine. "My customers are very demanding," he added. "They want perfection for their money."
Maxime Ribera, one of the first New York City chefs to open restaurants in Westchester, said: "Suburban customers are more sophisticated today. They want good value, and they understand that you don't need truffles or fancy ingredients for food to have quality."
Mr. Ribera has just converted his formal French restaurant, Maxime's, in Granite Springs in northern Westchester, to a more casual place called Maxime's Brasserie. But before he shifted the emphasis and lowered his prices, he tested the waters with a country bistro, Bistrot Maxime, in nearby Chappaqua. That was just two years ago, and the water's still fine.
Still, some characteristics will always separate city restaurants from those in outlying regions, especially around New York. People outside cities tend to dine out more on the weekends, for example, making for a crush of reservations and a need for larger staffs at those times. As a result, the restaurants must rely on a pool of part-time help. Lately, theme dinners with wine makers and famous chefs have become popular promotions to fill seats during the week.
In the past, it might have taken half a decade or more for a cutting-edge trend to seep outside a city. Today, chefs everywhere are keeping in step.
At Maxime's Brasserie the food is the lusty, classic French bourgeois fare that delights customers and critics at places like Park Bistro and Quatorze in Manhattan. Coq au vin in earthenware casseroles and a Rabelaisian braised lamb shank, at less than $15, have replaced the $25 Dover sole and rack of lamb.
Two years ago Peter Kelly, a young self-taught chef whose restaurants have all achieved high marks from the critics, opened the Freelance Cafe, a casual dining spot next to his elegant Xaviar's in Piermont, in Rockland County, New York, near the Tappan Zee Bridge.
"We considered expanding Xaviar's," Mr. Kelly said, "but we saw that people also wanted quality in a more relaxed, less expensive context, so we created the Freelance Cafe."
At Xaviar's the food is elaborate, befitting a $42 prix fixe. The cooking tends to be richer than at some trend-setting French-style places in Manhattan, with dishes like lobster ravioli in a saffron butter sauce and black bass sheathed in potatoes in chive beurre blanc, but it is generally well conceived, carefully wrought and impeccably served. The restaurant's 32 seats can sometimes be as difficult to obtain as tables at JoJo, a hot restaurant in Manhattan.
The menu at the Freelance Cafe offers small plates like spinach and shrimp fritters and pasta dishes averaging $7 each, and large plates like grilled duck breast with fettuccine or steak pommes frites for around $15.
"Not long ago, people found it hard to believe there could be a good restaurant in Rockland County," Mr. Kelly said. "There is plenty of competition now, and I think it will be easier for suburban chefs to get the recognition and respect they deserve."
Some chefs like Jean-Louis Gerin of Restaurant Jean-Louis in Greenwich regularly participate in charitable events, finding that they help to build loyalty among customers and to reach a wider audience. And when several regional chefs cook together at such events, they find a welcome camaraderie and capitalize on the reputations of all their restaurants.
Even the hotels built near sprawling industrial parks have attracted well-known chefs. Yannick Cam, who owned Le Pavillon, a superb Washington restaurant that could not weather the economic storm and closed in December 1990, now cooks at the Radisson Plaza Hotel in Alexandria, Va. He has not altered his lavishly elegant cooking style at Yannick's, the restaurant there.
A few years ago, it probably would have been unthinkable to encounter fine dining in a chain hotel like the Radisson Plaza or the Hilton in Short Hills, N.J., with its opulent Dining Room, where the quality of food, wine and service attracts guest chefs like Jean-Louis Palladin of Jean-Louis at the Watergate in Washington.
Inevitably, as the status of chefs outside urban centers is enhanced, culinary Broadway beckons some chefs starring out of town. Joseph Verde, who worked at Lafayette and Le Cirque in Manhattan before becoming the chef at the Hilton in Short Hills, has just been hired by the Sea Grill in Rockefeller Center.
But the Hilton found a qualified young chef from Manhattan who recognized opportunity across the Hudson. Anthony Demes, 27, who has been working at Maxim's in Manhattan, started there this week.
"Even though it's not New York City, there's plenty of opportunity for creativity," Mr. Demes said. "They have a clientele that knows and appreciates good food and wine."
 
Tastes of New York, but no Commute
 HERE is a selection of notable restaurants on Long Island, in Westchester and Rockland counties, in Connecticut and in New Jersey:
 
Connecticut

HEADLINE: The No-Party System

 BODY:
If Ross Perot, candidate of no political party, had been on the California ballot yesterday, he might conceivably have defeated an incumbent President in the Republican primary and the front-runner in the Democratic primary.
Likewise, in New Jersey and Ohio, surprisingly large numbers of voters told exit-poll takers that they too would have voted Perot had his name been before them; he would have won the Ohio Democratic primary in a walk. 
 These findings warrant contemplation now that the 1992 Presidential primary campaign has ended. All this Perot support comes from primary voters, the people most likely to come to the aid of their party. And it comes for a man who has never held public office.
The scrappy Texas businessman has yet to spell out his positions. Under the microscope that goes with being taken seriously, he may come to be seen as harsh or hypocritical. But Ross Perot has already triumphantly demonstrated something recently unimaginable: It is now possible to mount a plausible campaign for President without backing from any political party at all.
That fact may portend a scary future, leading away from the certitudes of two-party politics to a system open to manipulation by the super-rich. But to judge by the present campaign, this evolution also could produce highly welcome results -- involving more citizens in politics, bringing politics closer to questions that affect their lives and giving them more say in how those questions are answered.
Ross Perot's showing represents a convergence of two tidal trends, of media and message. The media in question are the parties, whose role in Presidential politics has been degenerating for years. Before telephones, let alone television, they served as organs of communication, conveying information, buttons and enthusiasm to the faithful.
John Kennedy pushed the diminution of parties past one milestone when he used a handful of 1960 primaries to prove himself to Democratic elders. George McGovern in 1972 and Jimmy Carter in 1976 seized on multiple primaries to win nomination in spite of party elders. Richard Nixon and later Ronald Reagan perfected the selling of the Presidency not by party but by television.
Parties are not dead, but as a medium in Presidential politics they can be superseded by electronic means. Ross Perot rides the new medium to connect with the other tide, of voters dissatisfied with the two-party system and its candidates. He has already demonstrated how to use back-channel television -- interview and talk shows -- to denounce politics as usual.
Why do Americans so hate politics? The recession explains much sourness. So does the strong dissatisfaction at the choice of George Bush or Bill Clinton. Voters also think Washington has performed miserably in dealing with, for instance, the savings and loan debacle.
Worse, Washington has failed to respond to urgent problems that bedevil people in real life. The Los Angeles rioting ended five weeks ago. The Administration and Congress are still dickering over emergency aid.
In this climate, it's easy for Ross Perot, personification of None of the Above, to sound good. It will get harder. Even he is not so well liked. From a third to half of voters interviewed yesterday hold an unfavorable opinion of him. Judging by the experience of third-party candidates George Wallace in 1968 and John Anderson in 1980, chances are his support will diminish as November nears.
But if yesterday's exit poll results proved anything, it is that dissatisfied voters need no longer wish for another path, for None of the Above. At the moment, at least, they can look to a Someone.

HEADLINE: University Presidents Less Secure in Jobs and Stature

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
By the end of a tough year of handling screaming students, angry professors, jealous alumni and hawk-eyed Federal auditors, the presidents of many elite American universities admit they have given serious thought to quitting.
Still, Benno C. Schmidt Jr.'s resignation last week as president of Yale University -- the fourth departure by a leading college president this year -- surprised nearly everyone and is widely seen as another sign that America's top universities are losing a whole class of leaders without a clear sense of who will replace them. 
 Mr. Schmidt was the lastest prominent president to call it quits. Hanna H. Gray announced that she would resign from the University of Chicago, where she has been president for 14 years. H. Keith H. Brodie is leaving Duke University after seven years. And Donald Kennedy resigned after 12 years as president of Stanford University, the last two years in a dispute over government research reimbursements.
 
Is Prestige Undermined?
 Their sudden departures have raised concerns about the strength of higher education's leadership. But more than that, since the presidents of these elite universities have often become de facto leaders off campus as well, the rash of resignations raises questions about the ability of future presidents to play that role.
"University presidents have gotten bashed a bit over the last couple of years," said Frank Newman, president of the Education Commission of the States and a former president of the University of Rhode Island. He said events had "gradually eroded the sense we have of the president of a university as being a moral and civic leader for our society."
The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, who retired in 1987 after 35 years as president of the University of Notre Dame and was active in many social causes, fit the role of "moral leader," Mr. Newman said, but many current presidents are so immersed in the problems of their own campuses that they cannot undertake a larger role. And new appointees are likely to face even more pressure.
For many presidents of America's most important universities, the demands of running the campus have become close to unbearable. The average tenure for all university presidents is less than seven years. The public image of presidents may be at its least flattering since the campus protest days of the 1960's, when some presidents were being splashed with red paint and escorted from their offices by armed students.
 
Trouble on All Fronts
 Today, they must deal with Federal and state governments that have cut their financial support. University curriculums have been criticized. Parents, students and alumni have been shocked by intercollegiate sports scandals, tuition bills and racial and ethnic conflicts, real or perceived, on campus.
Traditionally, the president of Harvard University has by dint of the prestige of that position been one of the most influential education leaders in the nation. The new president there, Neil L. Rudenstine, is completing his first year, a year in which his voice has not been heard much.
"Pulpits are earned, they're not conferred or made," Mr. Rudenstine said. "It will take a bit of time, but on the whole, people are speaking out so much more than they are thinking these days that a little more time, patience and thought wouldn't hurt at all."
Mr. Rudenstine will begin to earn his pulpit tomorrow with his first commencement speech address, in which he will tackle some of the most complicated issues on campus today: diversity, free speech and the values that make a good education.
 
Puzzling Over Schmidt
 Those issues have been addressed on occasion by Mr. Schmidt in his six years heading Yale. Six years would not seem to be much time, relatively, and so Mr. Schmidt's resignation still puzzles many. Even with its budget problems, Yale is one of America's most influential institutions.
In explaining why he was leaving to join a for-profit venture to establish a national system of private schools, the 50-year-old Mr. Schmidt said that while his tenure may have been short, it was intense, and that his goal was to improve the nation's schools.
But then, describing his proudest achievement, he made an unusual observation: "There's never been a blemish or even a suspicion about Yale's integrity or my own." The statement seemed to reflect the degree to which presidents today are suspect, rather than revered.
Most of Mr. Schmidt's colleagues were reluctant to criticize his decision, but some were concerned about the perception his leaving would present.
"His move, however laudable the motive may be, adds yet another dimension to the perception that in this country, the public sector and excellence do not go hand in hand," said Vartan Gregorian, the president of Brown University. "It suggests that excellence belongs in the private domain only."
 
Ivy League Survivors
 In the Ivy League, the two longest-serving presidents are Frank H. Rhodes, at Cornell for 15 years, and Michael I. Sovern, the president of Columbia since 1980. Both say the job has changed fundamentally during their time in office. The demands of dealing with more pressing economic conditions, more onerous government regulation and increasingly complex social issues on campus leave far less time to be "presidential," in the sense of speaking out on issues of importance beyond their own campuses.
Mr. Sovern said that it is still possible for him to speak out on national issues, but that the opportunities are more limited. At Columbia's commencement, for example, he spoke about the plight of the author Salman Rushdie and called for freedom of speech to be defended everywhere.
"It is a national issue," he said, "but it's a national issue of special importance to universities."
Mr. Sovern said it is increasingly difficult, given the burdens of office, for presidents to get involved in off-campus issues, as he did a few years ago when he headed a state commission on integrity in government. "I could not have said yes to that invitation this year, and I don't think I could say yes next year," said Mr. Sovern.
Mr. Rhodes was asked recently by the university's board of trustees to stay on indefinitely; he agreed, although he said, "The pressures increase each year," and, "The physical demands are enormous."
 
Essential Skills Change
 The skills considered essential to run a university shift with the times. Lawyers, like Mr. Sovern and Mr. Schmidt, with their skills at mediation and analysis, have been in demand for a while. The ability to raise money is taking on more importance. But with that comes some traps.
Mr. Gregorian is considered one of the more outspoken presidents, a trait he honed as head of the New York Public Library before going to Brown. But even he said that with so much emphasis today placed on a university president's ability to raise money and solicit support from alumni, speaking out on public issues becomes more delicate.
"You're frightened to take a stand as an educator because you are afraid that the Federal or state authorities, or your private benefactors, may retaliate against your institution by not giving money," Mr. Gregorian said.
With their different schools and deans, universities on many levels run themselves. But if something goes wrong, it is often the president who takes the blame.
 
How They See Themselves
 In the recent investigations into research costs at Stanford, the president, Mr. Kennedy, became a visible target, especially after it was learned that the Government had been charged a portion of the costs for improvements and even flowers at Mr. Kennedy's university-owned home. His rough treatment on network television and in the local newspapers was so scathing that it has changed the way university presidents are perceived -- and the way many university presidents see their jobs.
"That hurt, all right," Mr. Kennedy said, "but I certainly hope that no one will be discouraged by the fact that I went though such a tough passage."
Other presidents have said that Mr. Kennedy's experience was likely to make recruiting leaders more difficult, though by no means impossible. Mr. Kennedy's replacement at Stanford, Gerhard Casper, the former provost at the University of Chicago, said that at first he had been reluctant to give up teaching and take on the administrative responsibilities of heading Stanford.
"Wally Sterling, a former president of Stanford, said after he was selected that the trustees had been looking for a person who is sufficiently intelligent to do the job and sufficiently foolish to take it," Mr. Casper said soon after his own selection was announced.
"My intelligence, I wouldn't dare comment on, but I certainly am displaying a sense of foolishness, no doubt about it."
