HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: California;
2 Women Win Nomination In California Senate Races

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 2

 BODY:
Democratic voters in California nominated two women in separate Senate contests today, setting the stage for a first in American political history: an election with two women running for the United States Senate from the same state.
The two women, Dianne Feinstein, a former mayor of San Francisco, and Representative Barbara Boxer, easily defeated their male opponents in races that many political experts called a historic watershed in a year of female political outrage and growing public demand for candidates who represent a break from the establishment politics of government in Washington. 
 Both Ms. Feinstein and Ms. Boxer received concessions from their opponents in three-way races and claimed victory less than three hours after the polls had closed.
"It's historic," said Katherine Spillar, national coordinator of the Fund for the Feminist Majority, "It shows the power of what's happening this year, with women winning elections that, just a few months ago, the political pundits were saying were impossible."
Ms. Feinstein and Ms. Boxer joined a growing number of women seeking Senate seats. Including them, six serious contenders have won major party nominations. If they all win election to the Senate, it would be major change for a body that has never had more than two female members at once.
A dozen women are also contesting primaries in seven other states, including two New York Democrats, Geraldine A. Ferraro and Elizabeth Holtzman.
At her headquarters in San Francisco, Ms. Feinstein accepted congratulationss from her opponents, State Controller Gray Davis and Joseph M. Alioto, a San Francisco lawyer.
 
2 California Contests
 "I think the message of this primary campaign is that once again Californians have spoken loudly and clearly and sent the whole country a message: the status quo must go," Ms. Feinstein said. "We Californians want fundamental change and we won't settle for anything less.
"We must put America's domestic needs first: jobs, health care, educations, crimes, drugs, gangs, environmental cleanup, the right to choice. That change begins tonight. They don't get it yet in Washington, but they will once we get there."
In Los Angeles, Ms. Boxer received concessions from Lieut. Gov. Leo T. McCarthy and Representative Mel Levine.
In a victory speech to supporters, Ms. Boxer said: "I promised to take this campaign to the people and the people have responded. They want a fighter in the Senate, don't they? They want someone who will shake up the Senate, don't they? I will be a fighter in the Senate."
In one Republican contest, the incumbent Senator, John Seymour, far outdistanced the field for one seat. The other race appeared to be a toss-up between Representative Tom Campbell and Bruce Herschensohn, a conservative television commentator.
The two women benefited both from being women in a year of female political outrage and from the growing public demand for candidates who represent a break from the norm in a year of near revolution against the establishment in Washington.
"I think it's a very exciting result," said Kathleen Brown, the Democratic State Treasurer who was not on the ballot this year but is widely believed to be contemplating a run for Governor in 1994. "It means that people are really anxious for change, and women symbolize change because they have not been part of the old way of doing things. They have not been insiders, they have not been present when the rules were being made that got us into the mess we're in."
Tony Podesta, a Democratic political consultant who ran the Presidential campaign in California for former Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts in 1988, called the results "a revolution in American politics."
 
Role of Women's Vote
 A survey of voters leaving the polls showed that female voters solidly backed the two women and that they were heavily influenced by the abortion issue and the furor surrounding the nomination of Clarence Thomas to the United States Supreme Court. Both also did well among male voters, especially Ms. Feinstein.
The voting also represented a rebuke for the kind of manipulative television campaigns now common in this, the largest state. Despite spending about $4 million for a campaign that was almost entirely limited to television commercials that in the end turned to denouncing "mob rule" in the Los Angeles riots, Representative Mel Levine was trailing badly, running last in a field of three led by Ms. Boxer.
On the Republican side, Senator Seymour, a moderate Republican appointed to the seat until the November election, was well ahead of Representativ William E. Dannemeyer, a conservative from Orange County. He will face Ms. Feinstein in the general election. In the close race for the other Senate seat, Mr. Campbell, a moderate from of Palo Alto, was running neck-and-neck with Mr. Herschensohn of Los Angeles. A third candidate, Mayor Sonny Bono, the former Mayor of Palm Springs, was well behind.
Californians have a rare opportunity to vote for two Senators this year because Pete Wilson vacated his Senate seat after being elected Governor in 1990. By law, his appointed successor, Mr. Seymour, a former State Senator, had to run again in the next general election.
 
Year of the Woman
 Most of the attention was focused on the two women. They have much in common: both are from the San Francisco Bay area, both are Jewish, both are forceful and pugnacious and they dislike each other. But they are likely to share a Democratic ticket in what is shaping up as the year of the woman in California and nationally.
Previous primaries in other states have put three other women who are serious contenders into Senate races: Carol Moseley Braun in Illinois, Lynn H. Yeakel in Pennsylvania, and Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, the incumbent running for re-election in Maryland, all Democrats. The other female incumbent in the Senate, Nancy Landon Kassebaum of Kansas, a Republican, is not up for re-election.
In addition, two other women have won major party nominations for the Senate, but both are running against entrenched incumbents and are considered underdogs. They are Charlene Haar, a Republican who is running against Senator Tom Daschle, a South Dakota Democrat, and Jean Lloyd-Jones, a Democrat who is challenging Senator Charles E. Grassley, an Iowa Republican.
The female factor was striking in California contests, the voter survey, conducted by Voter Research Surveys, showed. The male candidates seemed to do particularly well only among those voters who considered crime a top issue.
The two women appeared to share the same voters. More than 80 percent of the votes of those who said they voted for Ms. Boxer said they also voted for Ms. Feinstein, while two-thirds of those who said they voted for Ms. Boxer said they also voted for Ms. Feinstein.
Ms. Boxer, a former Marin County housewife who won national attention when she and six other women in the House of Representatives paid an angry visit to the Senate during the confirmation hearings for Judge Thomas after accusations of sexual harassment were leveled against him, won more than half of the women's votes and almost half of the men's votes, according to the surveys. The runner-up, Mr. McCarthy, won less than a quarter of the female vote.
Ms. Feinstein received nearly two-thirds of both the male and female votes.
More than half the Democratic primary voters said Justice Thomas should not have been confirmed, and almost two-thirds of them voted for Ms. Boxer. Mr. McCarthy did very well among those who thought the Justice should have been confirmed, but that was only one-fifth of the voters.
 
Role of Abortion Issue
 Similarly, on the abortion issue, nearly two-thirds of the Democrats said they thought the Democrat national platform should support keeping abortion legal. Ms. Boxer received one-half of the that vote from that heavily female group, while her two male opponents, who also support abortion rights, lagged with the group.
In the Feinstein-Davis race, three- quarters of those who opposed Justice Thomas voted for Ms. Feinstein. Similarly, those favoring strong abortion rights voted went for her by more than 3 to 1.
 In the Republican primary, Senator Seymour, as expected, was comfortably ahead of Representative Dannemeyer. He overwhelmed the staunchly conservative Congressman among nearly all demographic groups except fundamentalist Christians and those who want the Republican platform to oppose abortion rights. The polling found that half of California Republicans supported an abortion-rights plank, one-quarter wanted an anti-abortion plank and one-fifth believed that the party should take no stand on abortion. Like Governor Wilson, Senator Seymour supports abortion rights.
The extremely close race between Mr. Campbell and Mr. Herschensohn race was more complex, and underscoring the battle between moderates and conservatives for California Republicans.
The 39-year-old Mr. Campbell is a former economics professor at Stanford University who takes an internationalist position on free and open trade and markets and is a something of a liberal on most social issues like abortion and the environment. Mr. Herschensohn, 59, who ran a close second for a Republican Senate nomination in 1986, appeals to a more traditional Republicans, who opposed to higher taxes and to excessive environmental protection.

2 PATHS TO NOMINATION
Barbara Boxer, Member of Congress, 51
Five-term Representative from Marin County. . . . Led a delegation of Congressional women up the Capitol steps last fall to demand that the all-male Senate Judiciary Committee hear sexual harassment charges against Judge Clarence Thomas as it considered his nomination to the Supreme Court. . . . Blunt, with a talent for generating publicity. . . . Longtime advocate of women's and environmental issues, a must in her trendy district. Entered politics as a community activist, district aide, then local supervisor. . . . Relentless campaigner in a year when most candidates chose the television studio over the stump. . . . Brooklyn native and graduate of Brooklyn College. . . . Married to a lawyer, Stewart Boxer, with two grown children.

Dianne Feinstein, Former Mayor, 58
Took over as Mayor of San Francisco in 1978 after the assassination of Mayor George Moscone. . . . Served nine years and earned a reputation as a hands-on manager. . . . Lost 1990 governor's race to Pete Wilson. . . . Was previously snubbed by some women's groups and other female officeholders, including Representative Boxer, who saw her as inattentive to their issues, but won support as feminist candidate this time, with television commercials about breast cancer, rape and family leave. . . . Was regarded as a breakthrough woman in politics when she was a contender for the Democratic Vice Presidential nomination in 1984. . . . Married to an investment banker, Richard Blum, who has helped finance her campaigns, and mother of one grown daughter. Graduate of Stanford University.

An article on Wednesday about the California elections referred to Sonny Bono, a candidate for the United States Senate nomination, incorrectly in some copies. He is a former Mayor of Palm Springs, not the current one.

HEADLINE: Exiled Haiti Leader Chides U.S. on Response to Coup

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
The exiled President of Haiti asked the United States and other countries in the hemisphere today to stop talking about democracy and start taking direct action to restore it, beginning with the interception of oil tankers bound for Port-au-Prince.
The exile, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, said that sooner or later a naval blockade of Haiti might be necessary to bring down the military Government that ousted him eight months ago. 
 While avoiding direct criticism of the Bush Administration, Father Aristide, who was elected President of Haiti in 1990 with more than two-thirds of the popular vote, delivered a bitter and sarcastic indictment against "friends of democracy" who he said seem unable to act to support it.
"They say: 'We will give democracy to them, we are with them. We will tighten the embargo,' " he said in an interview. "But when we saw more tankers arriving in Haiti only four days ago with oil, we thought, 'is this the best way to tighten an embargo?' "
 
Questions on Sincerity
 "It is not difficult to do what we have to do," he said. "It is a question of knowing whether or not they believe in what they are saying."
Father Aristide also said the level of anger was rising among Haitians, who are running out of patience after eight months of military rule. He agreed with comments by Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, who said after returning from a recent visit to Haiti that "a head of steam is building up there."
"It is true, it is like a volcano," Father Aristide said. "At this moment, it is very explosive."
He added that as a "responsible" head of government he had to urge nonviolence to head off an explosion like that in Los Angeles -- a parallel he has been drawing in speeches around the United States as he meets business leaders, human rights groups and, on this trip, Jewish organizations.
But he also said that nonviolent people expect justice to be done. He said his job was not to teach Haitians patience but to bring back their elected government.
Father Aristide, a charismatic priest whose strong language has at times disconcerted officials in the Bush Administration, spoke with low-key, sharply focused determination in an interview at his hotel here. He dismissed the naming Tuesday of the conservative economist Marc Bazin as a new Haitian prime minister, saying that this was another time-wasting ploy by the military under Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, which overthrew him on Sept. 30.
The Secretary General of the Organization of American States, Joao Clemente Baena Soares, also rejected the Bazin nomination today, saying that "no government that may result from this illegal situation will be accepted."
Father Aristide insisted that developments in Haiti had created a propitious moment for a real tightening of the embargo on Haiti. He said some original financial and political backers of the coup are now breaking ranks and coming here to tell him that they are exhausted, fearful of spreading violence and ready to discuss his return.
"Some of them are really tired," he said. "They are really afraid. They know, day after day, the anger of people is increasing. They realize that the only way to avoid violence, vengeance, retaliation is to have democracy back."
 
Tensions in Military
 Father Aristide said that the emergence of rival "gangs" within the military has created disaffection, and that he was receiving letters from soldiers complaining about the level of killing.
He restated his belief that many refugees are "politically oppressed." Last week, President Bush said in Atlanta that he was convinced that Haitians fleeing in boats were not "physically oppressed" or deserving of political safe haven in the United States.
"They say they want to stop refugees," Father Aristide said of the Administration. "I want to stop refugees. So we have the same goal. They say, we want democracy. We say, we want democracy. We have the same goal. So I say, let's do it."
He said that some steps taken by the United States to punish the leaders and supporters of the coup, including the cancellation of American visas, had been partial measures at best.
 
Coup Leaders 'Still Flying'
 "They don't see any kind of real sign of action against them," he said of the coup leaders. "Visas? Just some were seized. What about the others? The people involved in the de facto regime are still flying."
Father Aristide said that only an effective oil embargo, stopping ships from all over the world, would make an impression on the Haitian military.
"Once Cedras realizes there is no petrol coming to Haiti, that will be the first sign to show him he has no allies," the exiled President said.
"I cannot stop remembering how in 1986 Jean-Claude Duvalier left Haiti after a phone call," he said, referring to the intervention of the United States. "Why after eight months is that criminal Cedras still there? Is he strong enough to say no to the world?
"No," Father Aristide laughed softly. "No. No."

HEADLINE: Denmark's Signal;
Rejection of European Union Treaty Points Up Anxieties on Sovereignty

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OSLO, June 2

 BODY:
By its rejection on Tuesday of the treaty on European union, Denmark exposed the idea of European political unity for the fragile cold-war creature that it really was.
The message sent by Denmark, one of the smallest and proudest nations in Europe, was that it feared being swallowed up in a federal state dominated by larger and more powerful neighbors. But the concern of the supporters of union was that the Danes were not alone in their anxieties. Some officials in 10 Downing Street expressed relief that finally it was not just Britain that had doubts about how far national interests and ancient symbols of national sovereignty should be submerged in a European federal state.
 
2 Different Views
 Nationalism nearly destroyed Europe in two world wars, and it lies at the heart of the unresolved contradiction between two different views of what the European Community should be today: a confederation of freely cooperating sovereign states, or a federation with a single currency, a single economic policy and a single foreign and security policy. 
 On the idea of building a prosperous and powerful trading bloc together and never going to war again with one another, there has been a true unity of views in Europe, a remarkable achievement in itself. But it has not been enough to make the European Community a powerful and cohesive political force in the world, or even to enable it to defend itself. For that, as long as the Soviet Union existed, Europe needed the United States, through the NATO alliance.
NATO's conventional forces were designed to deter Soviet attack, and thus, in a sense, never to be used. Now they are impractical for use in dealing with new kinds of threats, resulting in the European Community's difficulties in coping with the violence in the Balkans, where ethnic brush fires threaten to become conflagrations.
The treaty that Denmark rejected was to try to create a common European foreign and security policy as well as a common currency. But the crisis in the Balkans has already made clear the difficulties in achieving a common foreign policy.
Last week the European community imposed economic sanctions on the rump Yugoslav state dominated by Serbia, but it finally imposed an oil embargo only after the United Nations Security Council did so. France went along reluctantly after arguing earlier that the sanctions would not be effective.
The nightly television shots of Serbs killing ethnic Muslims in Bosnia and Herzegovina and mortar bombs falling on the ancient Croatian port of Dubrovnik are a shame and a scandal, western Europeans agree, and the violence has already confronted them with hundreds of thousands of refugees huddling on their doorsteps.
 
Rapid Reaction Force
 Yet neither NATO nor the European Community has any realistic plan or policy, yet, to quell the fighting or prevent it from spilling over into other countries.
NATO agreed last year to create a rapid reaction corps that will consist of 70,000 to 100,000 troops from European countries and be supported by American helicopters and airplanes. If it existed today, it might conceivably be sent in to enforce peace in the Balkans.
But the corps will not even be ready until 1995. And there is no consensus among European members of NATO for using those troops or any others in such a peacekeeping role anyway. The 51-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which unites all European countries, could theoretically ask NATO to undertake such a role, according to the alliance's secretary general, Manfred Worner, but there is no European consensus as yet on whether NATO should entertain such requests.
Denmark's rejection of a treaty on unity, unsurprisingly, came as a discouraging sign to Mr. Worner. "Looking at the picture in Europe at this very moment, confronted with very serious crises, I think what Europe needs is the opposite of such a vote," he said.
France and Germany, saying they both want to strengthen Europe's ability to provide for its own defense, have announced the formation of a joint corps of 35,000 troops, but that has aroused British and American fears that it could undermine NATO.
But the French-German corps, too, does not yet exist in reality, and even if it did, the Bonn Government has insisted that the German soldiers in it could not go anywhere to do anything until the German Constitution is changed.
"We Europeans have to admit openly: Europe has not yet gone so far as to be able to deal with this new kind of challenge," the German Foreign Minister, Klaus Kinkel, said in Paris on Tuesday.
Mr. Kinkel and his counterparts in NATO and the European Community are to meet here on Thursday, and they plan to issue a statement deploring the continuing violence in Yugoslavia. But, a NATO diplomat said today, "It's clear to everyone that Yugoslavia is not the right place to start with a peacekeeping force."
 
Consensus and Inaction
 In Denmark, supporters of a yes vote in the referendum this week echoed concerns of the referendum's critics that European unity might require participating countries to accept steps they did not like. Interviewed on Monday, the Danish Foreign Minister, Uffe Ellemann-Jensen, who led the failed campaign for a yes vote, said that Denmark, too, did not want European foreign policy decisions made over its head, and that consensus was better.
But some diplomats in Europe, particularly those from America, observe that consensus often leads mostly to inaction, and that inaction in security affairs is really what most of the Europeans, led by small countries like Denmark, really want.
These American officials believe that Europe still needs the United States to help it solve its most acute security problems, and that it may yet need the United States to lead it to effective action in Yugoslavia. That may be a little clearer after Thursday's meetings here in Oslo, but not much.

HEADLINE: Chinese Police Halt Tiananmen Square Memorial

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, June 3

 BODY:
The police arrested several Chinese today as they tried to mark the third anniversary of the army's attack on democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square, and detained and roughed up foreign journalists covering the incident.
The police detained seven foreign journalists for about three hours, and beat up a Tokyo Broadcasting System television cameraman who had been trying to film plainclothes policemen on the square. The cameraman, Atsushi Yamagiwa, was reportedly knocked to the ground and kicked before being taken away bleeding. 
 An hour earlier, a Chinese man named Wang Wanxin was dragged away after he tried to unfurl a banner calling on Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, to apologize for the 1989 army crackdown in which hundreds were killed and thousands wounded. It is unclear what happened to Mr. Wang, who is said to be in his 40's.
Foreign reporters who were present at the detention of Mr. Wang and the beating of Mr. Yamagiwa were detained and their film was exposed. Among those detained were jounalists from the United States, Canada, Germany and Japan. The police punched and kicked several of the reporters before taking them away.
In 1989, the army attack on the student protesters began late at night on June 3 and continued for most of June 4. The attack is widely known in Chinese as the June 4 incident.
A new sign in the center of Tiananmen Square warns visitors not to lay mourning wreaths, unless the authorities have given approval five days in advance. The sign also forbids laughing and joking in the vicinity.
The authorities have warned dissidents and others not to cause trouble on the anniversary, and security has been stepped up throughout the capital.
One unusual precautionary measure was taken at Beijing University, which in the years since the crackdown has seen some unrest on the June 4 anniversary. In an effort to reduce the availability of glass to smash, a common gesture of protest for some students, bottle-collectors were sent around the dormitories, offering to pay about four cents per glass bottle.
The Foreign Ministry expressed appreciation of President Bush's announcement on Tuesday that he was recommending unconditional renewal of low-tariff trade benefits for China.
"The Chinese Government appreciates this realistic and wise decision of President Bush," a Foreign Ministry spokesman said. A spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations and Trade also expressed appreciation of Mr. Bush's recommendation to extend most-favored-nation trade benefits, but said the annual debate over the issue in Congress made the Chinese authorities "uncomfortable." The spokesman called on Washington to come up with a "more efficient" way of providing low-tariff trade.
The Government also said that it would now allow Dai Qing, a journalist who this year is holding a fellowship at Harvard University, to return to visit her family in Beijing. On Saturday, Ms. Dai, who is 50 years old and is often critical of the Government, was refused permission to board a plane in Hong Kong for Beijing. She now has a ticket to fly to Beijing on Sunday.
Another Chinese living in the United States, Gong Xiaoxia, was also recently refused entry to China because of her political views. It is unclear if she will now be allowed to return.

HEADLINE: Ibrahimpur Journal;
A Single-Minded Man Fights to Free India's Slaves

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: IBRAHIMPUR, India

 BODY:
The spare 15-year-old in a tattered shirt stood stiffly, shaking his head. "No," he said. "I don't know Bharat."
Gently, Kailash Satyarthi placed his hand on the young man's shoulder and said: "Bharat is this country, where you live. Bharat is India." 
 Around Mr. Satyarthi and the 15-year-old, Bushan Lal, hovered a dozen other young men, some nodding in understanding, others wrestling with a new idea, the idea of India.
Mr. Satyarthi explained: "These men have never seen a white person. They have never seen a newspaper. They have never heard of America. They don't know what money is. Some don't even know the name of their country. They were bonded laborers, people who have been in complete servitude."
Throughout India, bonded laborers toil, unpaid and ill treated, in what amounts to slavery in stone quarries, in brick kilns and yards, and in the rice paddies of central and southern India.
 
40,000 Are Liberated
 Bonded labor -- the practice of engaging laborers without wages to pay off real or imagined debts -- is against the law. But it persists despite court rulings, occasional police intervention and the work of people like Mr. Satyarthi, who works here at his center for bonded laborers 20 miles northeast of New Delhi.
"We estimate," he said, "a very conservative estimate, that there are 5 million adults and 10 million children in bonded labor in India," which has a population of 844 million.
For more than a decade, Mr. Satyarthi, a former engineer, has devoted his energies to freeing India's bonded laborers from servitude.
"Since 1980 we have liberated more than 40,000 bonded laborers from around the country," Mr. Satyarthi said. "I have lost two friends while trying to liberate laborers, both in 1985. One was beaten to death with iron rods. One was shot dead. Both were in the quarries. Some people were arrested, but all were released later on."
Virtually all of India's bonded laborers are untouchables, who are at the bottom of the caste hierarchy. Some were born into their condition because their parents or grandparents were sold long before they were born. Others were lured into servitude by agents for quarry owners or brick kiln managers with promises of higher paying jobs than those they had. Still others fell into their position from the need to repay loans that were readily given, but that can never be fully repaid. Once indentured, it is almost impossible to escape.
Only through repeated court orders from the Indian Supreme Court has Mr. Satyarthi been able to free any bonded laborers. And even then, he said, local police and government officials often ignored the court's ruling. "There is so much corruption," he said.
Hari Krishna Kandoi said: "I'm a harijan. My family has been bonded labor for generations. My father was bonded labor and also my grandfather. I worked on a rice field in Chaunaurdiha Village," in Madhya Pradesh in central India. "I was never paid any wages. I was just given some food. I was released three months ago by the Supreme Court."
But freedom alone, Mr. Satyarthi said, is not enough for men like Mr. Kandoi. "We realized that here was a problem of looking after these people, otherwise they would go back to being bonded laborers," Mr. Satyarthi said.
So last year he formed what he calls Mukti Ashram, or Liberation Retreat, where he works with former bonded laborers.
 
'Afraid of Everyone'
 "People who are bonded laborers are mental slaves," he said. "It is hard for them to mix in society. They feel themselves very inferior. They feel the burden of being casteless. They have no way of earning a living. They have no idea what to do with money. And they are afraid of everyone."
With money from private donors, he bought an acre of land on the outskirts of this village. He hired a tailor, carpenter, weaver, iron worker and mason to teach trades to the bonded laborers, a counselor to help with their adjustment problems and a cook to feed them.
From his decade of work with bonded labor, he has 100 people around India working full time to free laborers from servitude, mostly by trying to get court orders enforced. And every three months, his colleagues send 50 to 60 bonded laborers to Mukti Ashram for training.
"Caste, religion, the political system, the economic system -- all are helping the bonded labor owners," Mr. Satyarthi said. "I believe in Gandhi's philosophy of the last man, that is, the bonded laborer is the last man in Indian society, that we are here to liberate the last man."
 
Ranks Still Grow
 Despite the efforts of his ashram, and the injunctions of the law, the ranks of bonded laborers continue to grow, Mr. Satyarthi said. "We have liberated about 5,000 children in the last 10 years. But in the last 10 years, about 100,000 children have come into the industry."
Mr. Satyarthi walked across the ashram compound toward the communal hall where a new group of bonded laborers were gathering. They sat cross-legged in precise rows on coir mats, expectant, unsure of what the next three months would hold. Then Mr. Satyarthi turned to Bushan Lal, the 15-year-old, and said quietly, "Show us a dance."
And the young man, to the beat of a drum from another laborer, began a slow folk dance and song from his native village. Bushan Lal, Mr. Satyarthi said later, was beginning to learn to be himself.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Recently released bonded laborers who have been in complete servitude for their entire lives receive lessons in self-confidence and self-worth at the Mukti Ashram, or Liberation Retreat, in Ibrahimpur, India. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: To Recapture an Uptown Elegance

BYLINE: By SUZANNE SLESIN

 BODY:
SINCE 1976, Josephine E. Jones has been the proud owner of a house with an unglazed terra-cotta front on West 122d Street, one of seven houses dating from 1887. Mrs. Jones has always had two goals: to be sure her daughter, Wendy, got an education -- "I've been a single mother since Wendy was 6 months old," she said -- and to own her own house.
Now that her daughter has been educated (Dalton class of '71, Yale '75, Columbia graduate school '81, now a playwright and English professor), Mrs. Jones is a bit freer to concentrate on the house. It is an ambitious project, but having held three jobs at a time, Mrs. Jones said, "Don't tell me what I can't do." 
 All seven houses on the street, in the Mount Morris Park section of Harlem, were designed by Francis H. Kimball, said Michael H. Adams, the president of the Upper Manhattan Society for Progress Through Preservation, a nonprofit group. Kimball also designed the Montauk Club in Brooklyn and the Waldo mansion that is now the Ralph Lauren store at Madison Avenue and 72d Street.
"These houses are extraordinarily exuberant examples of the Queen Anne style, which Kimball knew firsthand from working in England for the famous architect William Burgess," Mr. Adams said.
For five years, Mr. Adams has been an enthusiastic leader of what he calls "a celebration of Harlem." He leads walking tours through historic neighborhoods there, including Hamilton Heights, Jumel Terrace and Striver's and Astor rows, as well as Marcus Garvey Park.
The Mount Morris Park area, loosely bounded by West 119th and West 126th streets and Seventh and Madison avenues, will be the site of a June 14 house tour. It will include five landmark churches, a carillon recital at St. Martin's Episcopal Church, a walk led by Urban Park Rangers to the historic fire watchtower and bell tower in Marcus Garvey Park, an architectural tour and visits to 12 private homes.
Until last year, ailanthus trees were growing inside the upper part of Mrs. Jones's house and climbing through the terra-cotta roof tiles, as others still do in adjoining buildings. The removal of the trees was her first step in restoring the house.
After meeting Susan Henshaw Jones, the executive director of the New York Landmarks Conservancy, at a conservation conference, Mrs. Jones got a 3 percent loan from the conservancy to continue her renovation.
"We feel preservation is the key to community renewal," Susan Jones said. "Although hard as it is to believe that these houses are not designated landmarks, because they were eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, we were able to make the loan."
Two doors down, a house covered with a latticework of scaffolding is under renovation by the Harlem Urban Development Corporation, a state-sponsored development group. The house, which is being converted into apartments, is also on the tour.
The interior of Josephine Jones's house is amazingly intact, considering that until she bought it in 1976 it had been a warren of one-room apartments. The years the tenants had spent in the house, which was built for a single family, had taken a toll. But the Minton tile fireplace surrounds, embossed firebacks, leaded-glass sliding doors and stained-glass transom windows are still there. Mrs. Jones seems determined to persevere in tasks that might seem impossible to others.
There is more than a little of her in her daughter, who has written a one-character play about the crusading 19th-century journalist Ida B. Wells.
"She was a woman of the 1990's who happened to live in the 1880's," Wendy Jones said of her subject.
One of the most impressive homes on the tour is the majestic four-story 1890 brownstone where 21-year-old Lynai Williams lives with her 8-year-old sister, Leah Williams; her 16-year-old cousin, Imani Walker; her aunt Paula Walker, and Ms. Walker's husband, Roosevelt Madison.
"On June 14, about 500 people will be coming to your house," Mr. Adams said last week to Lynai Williams, who seemed surprised and maybe not overjoyed. He added quickly: "Don't worry. They won't all be here at the same time."
"It took at least seven years to get it in this condition," Ms. Williams said as she showed visitors the dining room, with its high ceiling, gas fireplace, beveled glass panels and pristinely stripped woodwork. Charcoal and sepia artworks by John Biggers hang above the stripped oak paneling, and an imposing African carving leans against the wall.
"I'm a native of Harlem and always vowed that if I lived in New York, I would live in my hometown, and that's Harlem," said Paula Walker, the assistant news director at WNBC television. The century-old house, on West 119th Street, has been in her family since 1980.
The architectural firm of Neville & Bagge designed the house. The wrought-iron gates on the front door incorporate an H, for the house's original owner, Daniel Huber Jr., a real estate developer of the time.
Ms. Williams remembers moving to the house when she was in the sixth grade. After graduating recently from Vassar College, she thought of moving elsewhere. "But I looked around," she said, "then decided it would be better to stay here."
"Our goal was to raise these girls and still like each other," Paula Walker said. "And in a house of this size all the people who make noise can have their own floors."
"Taking into account the kind of job I have and the income level, I feel that people like me should also live in Harlem," she continued. "Neighborhoods can then remain neighborhoods, and people who live there are in the position to demand services and demand that Harlem gets its fair share."
At first, Mr. Madison, a television and film makeup artist, balked at letting people walk through their home. His wife persevered. "If you were trying to get people of different income levels back to Harlem," she asked, "how could you convince them it's a good place to be if you don't let them see it?" Mr. Madison agreed.
Their house is a rare example not only of Harlem's past but also of its potential future. Hundreds of single-family houses were built by some of the most successful architectural firms at the end of the 19th century, though most were turned into rooming houses during the Depression.
"There are all kinds of great places up here," said Ruth-Miriam Garnett, a poet who lives in a renovated apartment on the top floor of an 1890 brownstone on West 121st Street that was designed by the New York architectural firm of Cleverdon & Putzel.
In the 1890's, when the neighborhood was prosperous, the house belonged to Lippman Tannenbaum, a diamond merchant on Nassau Street. His neighbors included Thomas F. Gilroy, a Mayor of New York. The fancifully carved brownstone was recently converted from a rooming house into small apartments.
"I'm a tenant, so I'm not striving for perfection," said Ms. Garnett, who comes from St. Louis and is living in her third Harlem apartment. "I've always lived in a brownstone. When I'm ready to move, I look in black communities to see what's up." Ms. Garnett has only a few reservations about living in Harlem. "There are not a lot of services uptown," she continued. "Eventually you have to go to Fairway," which is almost 50 downtown blocks away.
Ms. Garnett's two-bedroom floor-through apartment, for which she pays $900 a month, has a view of the neo-classical dome of the Mount Morris Park Ascension Presbyterian Church and offers a quiet place to work.
She likes to tell a story about her cats, Latifah and Olivia, that illustrates the wariness some people have about her neighborhood.
After discovering a mouse on another floor, she called an animal rights group and asked for two cats. A man offered to deliver them. "He was very nervous coming up here," Ms. Garnett recalled. "Then he told me that the day before his car had gotten broken into near Lincoln Center.
"I told him to relax."
 
A Journey to the 1800's, in Walking Shoes
 The Mount Morris Park Open House Tour sponsored by the Mount Morris Park Community Improvement Association will take place on June 14 from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. The meeting place is the Harlem branch of the New York Public Library, 9 West 124th Street. Tickets are $15 each ($10 in advance; $8 each for groups of 10 or more). Information: (212) 234-8206.
The subway stop closest to the library is the 125th Street station on the No. 2 and No. 3 lines. Or you can take the M7, M100, M101, or M102 bus to 125th Street and Malcolm X Boulevard (Lenox Avenue).

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Politics' Cutting Edge;
Californians Making Political Waves That May Wash Over Nation by Fall

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 3

 BODY:
Once again, Californians are at the cutting edge of national trends, pushing non-interest in politics to the outer limits. The turnout for Tuesday's primary was the lowest for a Presidential primary in more than half a century.
But those who did vote made waves, with Democrats nominating two women for United States Senate seats and an extraordinary number of women for Congress and the state Legislature. In what one official portrayed as a gesture to the ultimate outsider, 18 women, Democratic and Republican, were nominated for the state's 52 seats in Congress, 15 of which are open. 
 The stage is now set for a crucial November election, with control of the largest state at stake. With the Legislature running under newly re-drawn districts, and with seven new seats in Congress, California will see the most sweeping turnover of elected officials in recent memory.
Apart from the nomination of the two women, Dianne Feinstein and Representative Barbara Boxer, for Senate, perhaps the most stunning result of the election was the setback suffered by the Waxman-Berman political machine of Los Angeles. The machine, dominated by Representatives Henry A. Waxman and Howard L. Berman, has long held sway over California liberal Democratic politics.
Representative Mel Levine, the machine's candidate for Senate, ran a poor third behind Ms. Boxer in a race in which he spent $4 million in television advertising but made almost no public appearances. Ms. Boxer won 44 percent of the vote, while Lieut. Gov. Leo T. McCarthy gained 31 percent, and Mr. Levine trailed with 22 percent.
One of the Waxman-Berman stalwarts, State Senator Herschl Rosenthal of Los Angeles, appears to have narrowly lost his seat to, of all people, the former radical, Assemblyman Tom Hayden, in a re-drawn district that includes Beverly Hills. The political consulting firm associated with the machine, BAD Campaigns, saw many of its clients go down to defeat, including State Controller Gray Davis in the Senate race. Ms. Feinstein won with 58 percent of the vote to 33 percent for Mr. Davis. In the Republican race for the same seat, Senator John Seymour won with 51 percent of the vote to 27 percent for Representative Bill Dannemeyer.
"The Waxman-Berman grip has been broken," said Joe Scott, editor of The California Eye, a political newsletter. "This opens a whole new chapter in Democratic politics in the state, a rejection of the hubris we've seen here for so long.
The implications for Republicans were less clear. It was mostly conservative politics as usual, with a Senate nomination going to Bruce Herschensohn, a conservative television commentator who has never held office before and who wants to abolish the Environmental Protection Agency, the Department of Energy and the Federal Reserve Bank. Mr. Herschensohn squeezed out a victory over Representative Tom Campbell, with 38 percent of the vote to Mr. Campbell's 36 percent. Sonny Bono collected 17 percent.
 
Mixed Results for Governor
 For Gov. Pete Wilson, the results were mixed. He had endorsed a number of middle-of-the road Republicans for the Assembly in the hope of reducing the number of far-right-wing Republicans who have opposed his programs. Some of his candidates won, including B. T. Collins in Sacramento, Tricia R. Hunter in Riverside and Imperial Counties, Jeffrey I. Marston in San Diego and Jan Goldsmith in San Diego.
But others lost, including Veronica A. Delaney and Gregory R. Cox in San Diego, and Barbara G. Pieper, who is for the right to abortion, in Pasadena.
"Moderate Republicans are so disaffected from the Bush-Quayle Republican Party that they stayed home," said Eileen Padberg, a political consultant who ran the campaign of Judith M. Ryan, a backer of abortion rights who unsuccessfully tried to take the Republican nomination away from the conservative Congressman, Robert K. Dornan, in Orange County. Only 20,000 voters turned out.
On the Democratic side, the clout of women was stunning. Mark DiCamillo of The California Poll called it "a major defining" force in the Democratic primary.
Calling women "the ultimate outsiders," William Schneider of the American Enterprise Institute said that having two well-known women on the California ballot could well serve as the spark that galvanizes the women's vote this year.
Among the women who won Congressional races were Anna Eshoo, a Democrat in the southern suburbs of San Francisco; Lynn Woolsey, a Democrat in Marin and Sonoma counties, north of San Francisco, now represented by Ms. Boxer, and Lucille Roybal-Allard, running in a heavily Hispanic district carved from one that had long been represented by her father, Edward R. Roybal.
In the new 49th Congressional District in San Diego, two women will face each other in November: Judy Jarvis, a Republican, and Lynn Schenk, a Democrat.
The dynamics of the general election in November are likely to be vastly different from the underpopulated primary Tuesday. The two Democratic women in United States Senate races have substantially different political philosophies and styles, share little affection for each other and face vastly different opponents.
The gap between the liberal Ms. Boxer, who represents the Marin County area north of San Francisco in Congress, and Mr. Herschensohn is of Grand Canyon proportions.
 
Middle-of-Road Race
 But the decision is tougher in the race between Ms. Feinstein, a former Mayor of San Francisco, and Mr. Seymour, the incumbent Republican who was appointed by Governor Wilson. Both are middle-of-the-roaders, and they share certain stands, like opposing off-shore oil drilling and favoring abortion rights.
But they are likely to clash on economic issues, like cutting military spending and about whether the Free Trade Agreement with Mexico will be good for California. (No, says Ms. Feinstein; yes, says Mr. Seymour.)
In the final days of the campaign, and again today as they flew around the state for victory rallies together, Ms. Feinstein and Ms. Boxer put aside differences and linked their campaigns under the banner of feminine unity. But two years ago, when Ms. Feinstein was running in the primary for governor, Ms. Boxer endorsed her male opponent, although she supported Ms. Feinstein in the general election.
"Feinstein is not as liberal as Boxer," said Herbert Alexander, a political scientist at the University of Southern California. "So it will be interesting to see if they run in tandem, saying it is a major breakthrough for women. There is some danger in that for Feinstein, who is not as much a feminist as Boxer."

GRAPHIC: Photo: California's Democratic nominees for the Senate, Dianne Feinstein, left, and Barbara Boxer, at a news conference in San Francisco. Despite the lowest voter turnout in history, California has nominated an extraordinary number of women for Congressional and state legislative positions. (Susan Spann for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN
Woman in the News: Barbara Boxer;
2 Senate Nominees Who Have Paid Political Dues

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 3

 BODY:
As newlyweds in 1962, Barbara and Stewart Boxer chose a Brooklyn apartment that seemed the perfect place to start their marriage, but for the musty carpet in the lobby, which the landlord promised would be replaced any day.
Months passed with no action. 
 So Ms. Boxer, fresh out of Brooklyn College with an economics degree and a go-get-'em attitude, organized the tenants of 770 Ocean Parkway, began planning all manner of protest, got the landlord's attention and quickly won a new rug.
Mr. Boxer, a lawyer specializing in worker's compensation cases, told the emblematic story of his wife's first political victory last night as a victory celebration swirled around him at a Holywood recording studio. Ms. Boxer, a five-term Democratic member of Congress, was on the stage promising her supporters that she was ready to shake up the Senate and go head to head with the entrenched, male political establishment, if she beats Bruce Herschensohn, a conservative Republican television commentator, in the fall.
 
Step by Step Into Politics
 Her husband looked up at her, a tiny woman who needs a riser to see over most lecterns, and smiled a shy, proud smile. There was nothing she was saying, Mr. Boxer said, that he had not known for 30 years.
During those three decades, Ms. Boxer, born Nov. 11, 1940, in Brooklyn as Barbara Levy, moved step by step into politics, following the community-oriented track common to women entering public life.
After moving west to the wild beauty of Marin County, following a sister who had already settled there, Ms. Boxer worked part time as a stockbroker while raising two children.
Aroused by the Vietnam War, and casting about for a worthy local project while her husband pursued his legal career, Ms. Boxer invited some neighborhood women to her backyard in Greenbrae. "Are you feeling what I'm feeling," she remembers asking them. The group organized a program to counsel high school dropouts, which was so successful it was taken over by the county school system.
Soon, Ms. Boxer was dabbling in journalism, at the weekly newspaper Pacific Sun, and from 1974-76 she was a district aide to Representative John Burton, a Democrat. From 1976 to 1982, she served on the county Board of Supervisors and then won election to the House of Representatives.
Ms. Boxer's daughter, Nicole, now 25, remembers her childhood home as command central for a group of animated, busy women who were constantly hatching plans.
"I was always sneaking downstairs in my pajamas," Nicole Boxer said, "because it was too exciting to go to bed."
 
Attack on Pentagon
 Once Ms. Boxer reached Congress, where she started her career with a highly publicized attack on Pentagon coffee pots that cost $7,622, she did lots of "telephone parenting," her children said.
Unlike some politicians, Ms. Boxer rarely trots her family out in public. Using them as campaign surrogates does not work, Mr. Boxer said, "because the certain magic Barbara has with people doesn't transfer to the rest of us."
Ms. Boxer made the most of her personality in a primary race that began months before the candidacies of women were galvanized nationwide by the spectacle last fall of the all-male Senate Judiciary Committee hearing charges of sexual harrassment against a Supreme Court nominee. Back then, and through the final days of the race when she made a 27-hour, 7-city campaign tour, Ms. Boxer built her campaign around cozy gatherings of like-minded women, much like the ones years ago.
In her base of Northern California and in the unfamilar southern precincts where California elections are won and lost, Ms. Boxer attended backyard barbeques, lox and bagel brunches, reunions of former Brooklynites, gripe sessions at senior centers.
Her supporters and strategists argued on Tuesday night that the person-to-person style was a perfect complement to a female candidacy, touching the same nerve in voters searching for leaders who understand their daily lives.
"She touched people and she talked to them," said Gloria Molina, the first woman and the first Hispanic politician elected to the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors.

HEADLINE: New York City Begins Talks With Its Unions

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
A broad coalition of municipal labor unions, representing 200,000 New York City workers, began contract negotiations with the Dinkins administration yesterday by demanding a raise, job security and improved health and welfare benefits, despite an earlier warning by Mayor David N. Dinkins that the city had no money and would grant no raises without productivity gains.
The talks come while all the city's labor unions are working without contracts and have not had wage increases for more than a year, raising the possibility of a work slowdown or other job action by irate unions. They have already threatened to withhold their political support from Mayor Dinkins in next year's election. 
 "We have done a lot to help the city through these hard fiscal times, and we intend to bargain hard to get our fair share of the budget as the city's financial condition improves," said Stanley Hill, president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees District Council 37, a coalition member that represents 117,000 workers.
To help the city close huge budget deficits during the last two years, the unions have endured the loss of 20,000 jobs through layoffs and attrition and agreed to furloughs and other concessions. Union leaders said yesterday that their members had earned raises and that the city could finance them through expected improvement in city tax revenues from an expanding economy.
 
Finances to Precede Raises
 But the administration stood its ground, maintaining that any improvement in city revenues would be first used to balance the budget by eliminating the city's dependence on risky or uncertain financing sources, like new borrowing, new taxes or increased Federal aid.
Both the unions and the administration described the opening talks as cordial and respectful, but they predicted that negotiations would grow contentious before long, given the city's need to cut costs and growing pressure on union leaders by members to get raises.
Among the major demands of the unions are a two-year labor agreement, an unspecified wage increase effective each new year of the contract, and job security in the form of no layoffs and limitations on the amount of services that the city contracts out to private business.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Sales Gain Of 11.1% for U.S. Vehicles

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 3

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built vehicles closed out the month on a strong note, rising 11.1 percent from May 21 to 31 and reinforcing hopes that the automotive sector is finally joining in the overall economic recovery.
Sales of domestically built cars rose 2.1 percent, to 237,400, and sales of domestically built light trucks, a category that includes mini-vans and utility vehicles, rose 27.9 percent, to 158,025. Together, domestic light vehicle sales totaled 395,425. 
 The seasonally adjusted annual rate for car sales was 6.5 million, down slightly from 6.7 million in mid-May and 6.6 million during the comparable period last year.
Tom Webb, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association, said: "The surge in the final 20 days of May was no fluke. The industry has a lot of catching up to do. Until now, auto sales were a weak link in the recovery."
 
An Optimistic Sign
 Even analysts who have been cautious until now conceded that late May sales were an optimistic sign that the market was turning. "The numbers suggest that what we had in mid-May wasn't an aberration," said Harvey Heinbach, an analyst for Merrill Lynch. "I'm feeling better that we might be at the start of an upturn."
For the last few weeks auto makers, feeling more bullish because of the increased sales, have responded by sharply increasing the numbers of cars and trucks they plan to build in the coming months, according to reports in the trade press.
"Not only has manufacturing for export held steady, but manufacturing in general shows some expansion," said Yale Gieszl, executive vice president of the Toyota Motor Corporation's United States sales arm. "That means more overtime, and the next step is increased hiring."
Matt Chesonis, sales manager of Ricard Ford in Columbus, Ohio, said, "Showroom traffic last year was higher than this year, but we're seeing more serious buyers this year."
For the entire month of May, sales of all vehicles, imported and domestic, rose 3.8 percent, to 1,147,155. Car sales dropped 1.3 percent, to 736,758, while light trucks rose 14.3 percent, to 410,397. May's seasonally adjusted annual rate of sales for domestically produced cars was 6.3 million, the highest monthly rate since last July.
 
Business Won Back
 Sales of vehicles produced in North America, by the Big Three and transplants, were proportionately higher than last year; they captured 82.6 percent of the total, compared with 79.9 percent of the total last year.
The Big Three, with improved quality and generally lower prices than Japanese competitors, were able to win back some lost business, capturing 72.4 percent of all vehicle sales in May, up from 68.7 percent last year.
The General Motors Corporation sold 273,263 import and domestic cars in May, up 2.5 percent from a year ago. G. M.'s light-truck sales rose 5.4 percent, to 141,174. The Pontiac division lifted monthly sales by 20.7 percent. Only Saturn, which more than doubled sales, was a better performer among G. M. car divisions.
The Ford Motor Company sold 153,115 cars, up 7.6 percent from last year. Ford's light-truck sales rose 17 percent, to 125,331. Ford's Explorer light utility vehicle established a monthly sales record in May.
The Chrysler Corporation sold 58,482 cars, down 10.1 percent from last year. Chrysler's light-truck sales rose 39.1 percent, to 99,446, largely on the strength of the popularity of the Chrysler mini-van and the new Jeep Grand Cherokee.
 
Honda Sales Drop
 The Honda Motor Company sold 65,628 cars, down 14.9 percent from last year. A Honda spokesman said sales were lower because the American economy had not recovered as strongly as hoped. He also conceded that competition against the Honda Accord in the midsize market was especially fierce, particularly from new models like the Toyota Camry, Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable.
Toyota sold 65,562 cars, down 5.8 percent from last year. But Toyota's Lexus luxury division was up 38.1 percent. Toyota's light-truck sales rose 6.1 percent, to 15,570.
The Nissan Motor Company sold 35,911 cars, up eight-tenths of a percent from last year. Nissan's light- truck sales fell 17.2 percent, to 11,507.

HEADLINE: Executives Say Hiring Will Be Back in Vogue

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
After a steady stream of layoffs last fall and winter, a new optimism is taking hold in executive suites across the country. In contrast to last year, many businesses are turning confident enough to map new hiring and expansion plans.
Interviews with chief executives, along with the results of several recent polls, show a marked upturn in hiring plans and general agreement that outside a handful industries in the throes of reorganizing, including the military, computer and banking businesses, the worst of the layoffs are over. 
 "The jump in hiring plans for the third quarter is huge," said Dun & Bradstreet's chief economist, Joseph W. Duncan.
 
Higher Sales Expected
 Preliminary results from Dun & Bradstreet's latest quarterly survey of 3,000 companies found that nearly 60 percent of executives predicted higher sales this summer and fall and the number of firms that planned to add workers nearly doubled from last winter. At least three other comprehensive surveys also found a signficant upturn in hiring plans this summer comparable to increases early in the recovery of 1983.
"These are actual plans, not just hopes and dreams," added William Dunkelberg, chief economist of the National Federation of Small Businesses, who reports a upturn in optimism among small companies.
Companies in many industries are planning to hire at least a few more people.
In Miami, for example, M. Anthony Burns, chairman of Ryder System, one of the nation's largest truck-rental companies, is planning to hire several hundred truckers for his auto-hauling business and to add 5,000 to 10,000 trucks to its fleet of 160,000 trucks in the coming months.
In Minneapolis, Kenneth A. Macke, chairman of Dayton Hudson, the department store chain and discount retailer, is planning to expand his payroll by 3 or 4 percent in the coming year, mostly to staff the 50 or so stores it plans to open.
And in Hickman, Ark., Nucor plans to open a steel mill after Labor Day even as it increases production at its other plants to five-day workweeks from the four days that about half are now on.
Mr. Duncan estimates that the resumption in new hiring -- payrolls have already increased by about 200,000 since February -- could add more than one million jobs this year, jobs that will put people back to work.
That is still far below the two million to three million jobs created every year during the robust recovery that followed that deep 1981-82 recession. But even this modest job growth is critical if the economic recovery is to keep gaining momentum rather than stalling , as it did in the latter half of last year. Executives and economists expect economic growth of 3 percent, about half the normal pace in a recovery.
At that time, executives were not convinced that expansion would last and hesitated to replenish inventories or recall workers. That lack of faith helped to bring economic growth to a standstill last fall before it picked up again this winter.
Business executives' confidence in the economic recovery has been growing for several months. But what is changing, is that the executives say that they are willing to back their confidence with cold, hard cash -- to hire more hands, replenish inventories and even open a new store or two.
 
Willing to Take Risks
 "People have more confidence that this recovery will continue so they are more willing to take the risk of hiring," said Mitchell S. Fromstein, chairman and chief executive of Manpower Inc., the nation's biggest temporary help company. He said that there had been a substantial increase in his business, and that that was typically a forerunner of permanent hiring.
To be sure, not a single executive interviewed thought that the recovery would be anything but a slow, drawn-out affair. And all still see signficant risks -- from a sharp weakening of export markets to a run-up in interest rates to a surprise jump in oil prices -- that could, despite all the positive signs, still knock the slow recovery down.
"The recovery is still very, very fragile," said Ward Smith, chief executive of Nacco Industries, a Cleveland-based conglomerate that makes products from fork lifts to toasters. The biggest risk for highly leveraged companies like his, Mr. Smith said, is a spurt in interest rates.
 
There Are Still Threats
 For Mr. Macke of Dayton Hudson, more big layoffs in the auto, airline and military industries would also be a threat. "When California went from boom to one of worst in the country, it really hurt our business," he said.
Bad news could still lead many businesses to put their hiring plans on ice. Nonetheless, Kermit Baker, the chief economist at Cahners Economics, which surveys 300 manufacturers on a monthly basis, said, "The reason we ask about the next three months is that the plans, in theory, are already pretty much in place."
But barring any nasty surprises, the new optimism represents a real turning point.
That message comes through in many different ways. Most of the recent surveys, including those by Cahners and the National Federation of Small Businesses, found not only stronger hiring plans, but also plans by more companies to increase inventories, marketing outlays and spending on new plants and equipment. In most cases, businesses' plans are less stingy than at any time since last spring, when the halting and uneven recovery first got under way.
 
Lower Interest Rates Help
 Businesses' new-found willingness to spend augers well for the year's second half and reflects a host of happy developments from lower interest rates and easier credit conditions to a pickup in profits, fatter orders books and ringing cash registers.
Indeed, the nation's total output of goods and services has nudged higher in each of the past four quarters, even though payrolls have grown very little in the past year and the unemployment rate has barely budged since March, when it reached 7.3 percent.
"The big difference is that the Fed didn't really get serious until last October," said Dexter Baker, who just retired as chief executive and chairman of Air Products, a producer of industrial gases in Allentown, Pa.
By past standards, the spending plans and hiring plans are still conservative.
"We've always worked hard to redeploy the assets we have," said Scott G. McNealy, the chief executive at Sun Microsystems. "We don't plan any massive rehiring." Still, with nine million businesses in the United States, even very selective hiring adds up.
Finally, hiring plans vary greatly depending on industry, region and even size of company. It may be a long time, therefore, before the recovery spreads across the board.
Big companies, according to a second Dun & Bradstreet survey, are likely to keep trimming while small ones with a couple of dozen employees or fewer may account for most of the job growth. Hiring plans in the Northeast are showing signs of life, but remain dead in the water in the West.
The most compelling testimonials of businesses' intentions, however, come not from anonymous polls, but from the decision makers who hire and fire, and crank up assembly lines.
"Last summer people told us the economy was getting stronger, but we didn't see it in our business," said Mr. Burns, the chairman of Miami-based Ryder System. "Now we're seeing a good solid expansion."
 
Strong Faith in the Upturn
 It is his confidence in the upturn -- which he thinks will be far more gradual than past recoveries -- that makes him willing to expand his fleet. What makes him so sure? His customers, who number in the tens of thousands, are more upbeat.
But even the most cautious executives are going ahead with expansion plans, and not necessarily gingerly either. "We don't really believe the recession is over," said Mr. Macke of Dayton Hudson, noting that his stores have seen only modest sales increases.
Nonetheless, he is proceeding with plans to spend $1 billion to open more than 50 stores and increase payrolls by 3 or 4 percent.
What the surveys show, and many of the executives attest to, is that they plan to raise production further this summer, largely because orders are gradually improving and inventories are already extremely lean.
Indeed, just keeping inventories from shrinking further could give production a lift for a couple of quarters. "We've let inventories rise in anticipation of slightly more robust sales," said E. W. Deavenport, chief executive of the Eastman Chemical Corporation in Kingsport, Tenn.
Still, with lots of unused production capacity at hand and continued pressure to keep costs under control, managers will keep a far tighter rein on inventories than in the past.
"Nobody's producing any more inventory than they have to, " said Mr. Smith of Nacco.
At the moment, many businesses are filling the new orders by stretching out short workweeks, adding overtime and hiring temps -- and generally finding ways to wring more work out of the existing work force.
"Orders and production are up, but we haven't recalled workers in any substantial numbers," said Leonard Hadley, the chairman and chief executive of Maytag. "I will use productivity and overtime to meet my needs before I recall or add." He expects that time to arrive within a year.
But as slow as the process may be, executives are already beginning to see the current phase as the prelude of better times to come. "Nineteen ninety-two will probably turn out to be a fair year, " said Mr. Deavenport of Eastman Chemicals. "Nineteen ninety-three might be average. And by 1994, we might have a good year."

HEADLINE: U.S. Increases Figures Showing Loss of Jobs

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
The Labor Department disclosed today that 164,000 more payroll jobs were lost than had previously been thought during the 12 months through February. But it contended that these and a number of other mostly downward revisions in job data did not materially change the shape of the recession or the budding recovery.
"The recession was much milder than the average postwar recession under both the previously published and the revised time series," the department declared, calculating a 1.8 percent loss of nonfarm jobs from July 1990 to the new low point of January 1992. Previously, figures showed a recession-period job loss of 1.4 percent through a low point in April 1991. 
 But the chairman of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, focused on 2.2 million jobs now shown as lost since June 1990 to argue that "these figures much more accurately represent what American workers have known all along: that this was a severe recession and a disaster for workers."
Today's numbers resulted from the annual benchmark revision under which estimates of payrolls based on samples are "re-anchored" to actual unemployment insurance tax records filed with state agencies. Officials provided them today during a briefing that anticipated the publication on Friday of the monthly employment and unemployment figures for May.
Revisions of payrolls for March and April will be announced that day.
The department's survey of payrolls is one of the most intensely scrutinized of economic indicators. It involves polling more than 350,000 business establishments each month, capturing the activity of people holding more than one job. It is separate from the Government's survey of households, which counts the number of people holding one or more jobs and which produces the monthly unemployment rate.
This year's benchmark revision has been eagerly awaited since reports of a huge change, concentrated in California, circulated last fall. This prompted the department to announce in November that the March 1991 count was overstated by about 650,000.
Today, the final employment figure for March 1991 was chopped by 640,000 before adjustment for seasonal variation and 558,000 after adjustment. While the department called these results approximately equal to the original projection, it acknowledged that this year's benchmark revision was unusually large. The average revision over the last decade has been about 200,000.
After conducting what it called an exhaustive analysis of the error, much of it occurring in January 1991, officials cited several contributing factors. But they were at a loss to determine whether the economy had performed more poorly than had been thought or whether the revision reflected faulty data collection.
One factor was that most states introduced better reporting forms and instructions during the benchmark period, specifying to employers, for example, that they must report only those people working during the week that includes the 12th of the month rather than total employment for the month.
Another factor was improved data for areas of the economy not well covered by the data-gathering process, like day-care services provided at churches and other nonprofit institutions. That industry accounted for 10 percent of the revision.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 10.89, but Broader Market Lags

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks ended with moderate gains yesterday, but the broader market trailed as investors focused on cyclical shares at the expense of growth stocks.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed back over the 3,400 barrier, rising 10.89 points, to 3,406.99. 
 "The important thing today is that we closed again above 3,400," said Harry Laubscher, a market analyst at Tucker Anthony. "Based on that we should see some higher prices. Breadth may not be that great, but volume is O.K.," he added.
In the broad market, declines led advances, 848 to 843, on strong New York Stock Exchange volume of 215.8 million shares, up from Tuesday's 203.1 million.
The Dow traded just above and below the 3,400 level for much of the day, but a recovery in bond prices in the afternoon lifted sentiment enough to spur more buying, traders said.
"Greenspan's comments earlier today that he sees no indication of inflation for two years gave a little boost to bonds, and that helped us," said Tom Luker, head of the trading desk at Nikko Securities. Mr. Luker's reference was to Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Mr. Greenspan, speaking to the International Monetary Conference in Toronto, said he saw "no evidence that inflation will be an emerging factor in the next two to three years."
A Government report that factory orders rose 1 percent in April, bettering forecasts by one-tenth of 1 percent, had little influence on stocks. Analysts said many investors stayed on the sidelines to await the May jobs report due tomorrow.
Oil company shares were pushed up by higher oil prices. Light crude for July delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange was up 32 cents a barrel to close at $22.43.
Exxon gained 1 1/2, to 62 7/8, and Texaco added 7/8, to 64 3/8. The oilfield services specialist Schlumberger was up 2 3/8, to 67 1/2 and Mobil rose 3/8, to 65 1/8.
The Big Three auto makers were among the most active issues, with General MotorsChrysler rose 1/2, to 19 7/8 and Ford Motor was up 5/8, at 46 3/4.
Among decliners, the integrated circuit maker Altera Corporation slumped 4 1/8, to 15 1/2. Traders said Smith Barney had cut earnings estimates.
In other trading, the Nasdaq over-the-counter composite index gained 0.75, to 589.93, while the American Stock Exchange's Amex index rose 1.70, to 395.65.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 1.09, to 414.59.
The New York Stock Exchange Composite Index rose 0.45, to 228.65, and the average price per share rose 7 cents.

HEADLINE: Fed's Chief Says Inflation Is Under Control

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, June 3

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Alan Greenspan, said today that even as the economy expanded, he did not see inflation re-emerging as an economic threat in the United States in the next two or three years.
"Short of an extraordinary expansion, which does not seem to be embodied in the data, inflation seems to be well contained," Mr. Greenspan said here at the International Monetary Conference of the American Bankers Association. 
 Although he declined to discuss the prospects for short-term interest rates, his analysis suggested that if current economic growth, which he termed "gradual but persistent," should falter, the central bank could provide additional stimulus by lowering rates another notch.
 
Fears of a Long-Term Threat
 His comments are likely to be welcomed by the Bush Administration, which is counting on renewed growth to improve re-election prospects for the President.
Mr. Greenspan, who appeared here with central bank leaders from Europe and Japan, acknowledged that the financial markets still saw a long-term inflation threat in the United States and said these inflation expectations had generated higher long-term interest rates than were justified.
While inflation is running around 2 percent, 30-year Treasury bonds are yielding 7 3/4 to 8 percent.
"I hope that when it becomes evident as time goes on that indeed inflation will not be emerging in the United States, that these inflation premiums will indeed fall, and with them long-term interest rates," the Fed's chairman told reporters after his address to the closed meeting.
 
Dissent on the Board
 Stephen D. Slifer, managing director of Lehman Brothers, said in a telephone interview from New York that some other members of the Federal Reserve Board were not as pleased as Mr. Greenspan with the current rate of inflation and believe it should be cut to zero.
As a result, Mr. Slifer said he did not see the Fed cutting short-term rates again unless there was some "real economic weakening."
The meeting brought together central bank governors from most of the countries that will participate in next month's economic summit meeting in Munich -- Robin Leigh-Pemberton, governor of the Bank of England; Jacques de Larosiere, governor of the Banque de France; Helmut Schlesinger, president of the Bundesbank of Germany, and Yasushi Mieno, governor of the Bank of Japan. Each pointed to improved growth prospects in his economy.
Mr. Mieno also discussed conditions in the Japanese financial system after the "bursting of the bubble" in real estate and stock market values. He estimated that less than 1 percent of outstanding Japanese bank loans would have to be written off. "In view of the effective earnings of Japanese banks, this problem is not serious enough to cause any major friction in the Japanese financial system," he insisted.
The European central bank governors all said they intended to push ahead with European monetary union plans, despite a referendum in Denmark which narrowly opposed a European Community treaty on economic and political integration.
"The thrust is there" for a European currency, "which I consider absolutely to be the case," Mr. de Larosiere said.
