HEADLINE: Fare War Is Coming To an End

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
After a tumultuous 10-day run, the curtain rings down at midnight tonight on the airline industry's smash hit -- the crowd-pleasing half-price ticket sale. But those who have waited until now to book flights are likely to find a sold-out sign.
By yesterday morning American Airlines had sold its entire summer's allotment of sale seats, except on some flights that depart on Tuesdays or Wednesdays, and other carriers were equally overwhelmed by a demand that far exceeded industry expectations. 
 Delta Air Lines, for example, said it had sold more than five million half-priced seats by yesterday morning. And Richard P. Friese, the publisher of Travel Agent magazine, estimated that the carriers sold more than 25 million tickets in the 10 days, totaling about $2.6 billion -- much of it new business. "Despite the low fares," he said, "the carriers could even end up making a few bucks."
 
Boost for Economy
 Including consumer outlays for hotels, car rentals, attractions and restaurants, Mr. Friese estimated, the fare sale will bring an additional $15 billion into the nation's economy. And one airline official estimated that the low fares could generate 100,000 new jobs in related industries.
As if to support such optimism, Avis Inc. reported yesterday that the airlines' half-price sale had spurred rental-car reservations from Monday to Wednesday to almost 300,000 -- the highest three-day total in its 46-year history. Radisson Hotels said reservations were up 30 percent at its 200 domestic hotels compared with last year -- much of it because of the fares.
But future fare cuts will be hard to achieve because the tough tactics of airlines to gain huge cost savings from labor in the last decade will haunt the industry, according to a study of the industry's labor relations commissioned by the Transportation Department. [Page D5.]
 
Volume Could Offset Discounts
 The carriers said they would not know the full financial impact of the sale for several days, though earlier this week American Airlines said that with heavy volume the sale could prove to be revenue neutral -- that is, the high number of bookings could offset the effect of rock-bottom prices.
For example, the $200 round-trip fare between New York and San Francisco works out to less than 2.5 cents a mile -- 6 cents to 8 cents a mile below what airline officials calculate it costs to provide a seat. But while more than 50 percent of the carriers' seats were included in the sale, airline officials said they hoped the average price-per-mile would rise because of higher fares for first-class and unrestricted-coach tickets.
The demand for tickets continued so strong yesterday that several carriers, including United and Delta, extended until Sunday the period in which customers must pick up the tickets they had booked by telephone. Previously they were required to do so within 24 hours. But the other stipulations remain in effect: Tickets, good for flights within the 48 contiguous states, must be booked at least seven days in advance and must include a Saturday stayover; travel must be completed no later than Sept. 13.
 
New Northwest Plan
 On Wednesday, Northwest Airlines added what it said was a new fare level 25 percent lower than the carrier's normal lowest excursion fare. Northwest said the fare, effective until midnight tonight, was created to accommodate passengers in markets where most or all of the half-price seats were no longer available on particular routes. Under Northwest's new fare, for example, a New York-San Francisco ticket is $300, compared with $200 for a half-price ticket. Competitors, who would not speak for the record, categorized the new fare level as a thinly veiled price increase, which Northwest denied.
While some beleaguered airline employees said they could not wait for the end of the sale, with workweeks that have averaged at least 60 hours, they told of equally Herculean efforts by customers intent on booking half-price tickets.
In Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a group of elderly people camped out at the Delta ticket office with lawn chairs and coolers. After a Delta ticket office in an Atlanta shopping mall closed at 9 one recent night, 60 customers continued to wait patiently while agents waited on them. At midday yesterday, a long line of customers on the sidewalk outside American's ticket office in Rockefeller Center, apparently hoping to avail themselves of the carrier's limited remaining selection, wiled away the time reading newspapers and paperbacks.
Reservations agents even reported finding callers on hold who were fast asleep by the time a reservations agent became available. When an American reservations agent eventually answered one call, the caller was snoring so deeply that he failed to respond to the agent's efforts to wake him long distance. Thus, that passenger, in the words of an American spokesman, "slept through his vacation."
Several carriers said that the combination of low fares and guaranteed seats prompted even many of their employees, who are often eligible to fly free or for a nominal price on a space-available basis, to buy sale tickets.
The carriers vow "never again" when asked about the possibility of future half-price sales. They are likely to adhere to that vow for the summer, when many planes will be packed. But travel industry executives -- remembering what happened in the past with the best laid plans of the nation's airlines -- are taking a wait-and-see attitude.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Excerpts From President's News Conference at White House

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference tonight at the White House. 

 
OPENING STATEMENT
Well, I have a brief statement and then I'll be glad to take questions. Two months ago I asked the Congress to cut almost $8 billion in wasteful spending projects, and tonight I've just signed the cuts that Congress sent to me in response. It's not all that I asked for, but it's a good start. Eight billion dollars sounds like a lot of money, and it is. But the facts remain it isn't good enough, not by a long shot. The American people know budget deficits threaten the long-term economic health of our country, and over the years we've accumulated Federal debt totaling $65,000 for every family of four in America. This debt does not create more wealth; it merely helps pay for our current consumption.
And it reminds me of the old fellow who bragged to his family that he had finally borrowed enough money to pay off his debts.
Our political system, as it is now, has failed to meet its responsibility to address this problem. And in the face of a several hundred billion-dollar deficit, a piecemeal approach simply will not do the job. We need a constitutional amendment to balance the Federal budget, and we need it now.
Three years ago, in my first address to the Congress, I asked the Senate and the House to pass such an amendment, and every year since then I have repeated a call. Like President Reagan before me, I've tried to get Congress to act responsibly and to restrain the growth of Federal spending. We've tried compromise, we've tried confrontation, we've tried quiet diplomacy with the Congressional leaders. And none of this has been enough.
And tonight I am more convinced than ever that a balanced budget amendment is the only way to force the Federal Government, both the Congress and the executive branch, to live within its means.
 
'Affect Every Other Decision'
 This month both houses of Congress will vote on a balanced budget amendment. It is impossible to underestimate the importance of this one decision. It will affect every other decision that the Government makes from that moment on and it will bear directly on the quality of life that we leave the generations who follow us.
Victory will not come easily. The amendment requires a two-thirds majority from both the Senate and the House. And I'm pleased to say that many serious-minded members, Republicans and Democrats alike, support this measure. They understand that this is not a partisan fight. It goes far beyond election-year politics. It is a fight for the economic security of the American people.
I realize that some in Washington consider a balanced budget amendment a rather radical step. Well, I strongly doubt that the American people consider a balanced budget amendment as radical. It's common sense, pure and simple. Each month millions of American families sit down to balance their checkbooks. Forty-four states -- 44 states have their own constitutional balanced budget requirements. And the Federal Government must now do the same.
The moment is at hand. In the coming days we will face an extraordinary choice. We can choose either to accept the status quo, piling debt upon debt, or we can strike a bold new course, restoring fiscal sanity to the Federal Government. And if we choose wrong, if we choose wrongly, our grandchildren and their grandchildren are going to bear the burden.
I refuse to believe that we will make them pay the price for Washington's irresponsibility, and for their sake I urge every Congressman and every senator to join me in supporting the swift approval of a balanced budget amendment.
Now I will be glad to respond to questions.Terry, I think you have the first.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 Q. Mr. President, I'd like to ask you about Ross Perot. He complains that you're hiding and you're afraid to take him on directly. Will you commit yourself to debating Mr. Perot as well as Bill Clinton in the fall campaign?
A. I'm sure there will be debates and I will be ready to join the fray after the conventions, but as you know, I have not challenged directly either Perot or Clinton, Mr. Perot or Governor Clinton. I have no intention of changing that before the convention.
I am trying to get things done that will help this country. The balanced budget amendment is a good example of that. And if I get too caught up in the political wars at this time, it will be even more difficult to get things through the Congress that will help -- a crime bill, an education bill, balanced budget amendment -- things that we really need.
And so I'm going to keep on this course that I've been on. I've been faithful to it during the primary season and I will continue to be until I make a decision to change. . . . Q. But I mean in the fall campaign, I'm not talking about immediately, right now, but will you commit yourself to debating the two --
A. There will be debates.
 
On Ross Perot
 Q. Mr. President, granting the legality, is it proper for a man, for a candidate with vast personal wealth and no spending limits to use that to attain the Presidency? And since you've known Mr. Perot for so long, is he an insider, an outsider? Is he a man of principles --
A. Helen.
Q. -- or does he go for the (inaudible)?
A. I'd love to answer that question --
Q. Why won't you?
A. Because I've vowed to keep my sights set on these legislative goals and on leading this country, and if I get into characterizing one opponent or another, I diminish my effectiveness in doing that. We've got a good chance now, and some of it's brought about by the primaries, I think, to pass this balanced budget amendment, for example. I'm a little disappointed that our education reform bill is languishing up there. I'd like to see us get a good energy bill soon. But if I start concentrating on the politics, I'm afraid I will waste an opportunity.
I think we're in a real opportunity situation now.
Q. Well, do you think he's trying to buy the Presidency?
A. Well, so far not. We'll wait and see...
 
Message From Voters
 Q. Mr. President, you've often said that you've not done so terrific a job of getting your message across. Tonight, you changed the venue. But I wanted to ask you if, indeed, what you've seen in the polls of the constant one-third or more of the electorate that's going other ways isn't a rejection of that message in and of itself?
A. I don't think so because you ask in these deadly polls that you read all the time, you know, about -- relating to issues. And it's vague out there.
We've got a good program, and tonight maybe this is a more effective way to say we want a balanced budget amendment. We've got a good program on the Hill to achieve a balanced budget amendment -- or after the balanced budget amendment is passed, to achieve a balanced budget.
And so I -- I think we just gotta keep hammering away on the issues because I believe the American people are with me. If they understand our total reform of education, they'll support it. Most Americans want a tougher crime bill. I heard people out on the West Coast who don't vote for tougher crime legislation all advertising in those 90-second bites they paid for, ads, how tough they are on crime. Maybe we've got a better chance now to pass an Administration crime bill.
So I'm going to keep focusing on those issues. And hopefully the American people will say he has a sound program for domestic affairs, just as he does in foreign relations.
Q. If I could follow up, sir, hasn't the pattern through the primaries been such that the American people have been constantly looking for an alternative?
A. Yes.
 
Problems With Economy
 Q. You may have put Pat Buchanan behind, but now you've got Ross Perot. Is he the inheritor of that?
A. No. Well, I don't think so. Tell you what. I think most people would concede that my problems stem from this sluggish, anemic economy. I think you can trace those problems to getting bigger with that.
Now I think the economy is improving. We still have some big problems there. For a person that's out of work, for him that unemployment is 100 percent. For a woman that can't get a job that wants one, for her, unemployment is 100 percent. So we've got to pushing ahead. And I make the appeal right now for our growth incentives to further stimulate an economy that is beginning to move, and is beginning to move positively.
But, no, I think it's -- I think my fortunes have been related to that, and I think, if I'll take the blame -- some of which I'll take -- is the economy has been sick. I assume the people are fair to get credit when there's recovery. Yeah?
 
More on Perot
 Q. Mr. President, your spokesman today described Mr. Perot as a man whose entire history is to stomp into the group, demand to do things his way, and if he doesn't get it to pick up his football and go home. The Vice President the other day questioned his judgment, saying he had been wrong on your most important decision of the presidency, the Persian Gulf war. Do you share their assessments?
A. I'm glad that they are putting their focus on these problems, but I'm not going to do it myself. I have a difference clearly, as far as the Persian Gulf war goes, no question -- and I think the American people support the actions that I took. I believe it was correct. I believe we performed well. I believe we set back aggression. I believe there was a whole new pride in this country. The international community supported it overwhelmingly.
So as people point these things out, that's fair. And as his supporters point out what they think might be foibles in me, that's fair, too. But I'm going to stay on the path that I've outlined.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Conference in Rio
 Q. Mr. President, if the experience of your E.P.A. chief in Rio to date is any indication, there's quite a reception committee of harsh critics of this Administration and of you, sir, waiting for you down there. Under the circumstances, if that's what the reception is going to be in Rio, why go?
A. Well, because we've got a sound and sensible environmental record and we have a strong role of international leadership. I wonder if the American taxpayer knows that we have spent something like $800 billion in the last 10 years on cleaning up things -- the atmosphere, the environment, in many, many ways. It is estimated that it will be $1.2 trillion spent by the United States taxpayers and businesses over the next 10 years.
We have a superb record to take to that convention. I am not going to go down there and forget about people that need jobs in the United States of America...
 But because I will not sign a treaty that in my view throws too many Americans out of work, I refuse to accept that kind of criticism from what I consider some of the extremes in the environmental movement, internationally or domestically.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
As the Economy Improves
 Q. Mr. President, you say your problems in the primaries have been caused largely by the anemic economy. Yet the economy is improving and the voters seem to be walking away from you in droves, sir.
Don't you take it personally? And what are you going to do about it?
A. I don't -- I don't take it personally. And as a guy who never looks at polls, as you know, I would like to cite a poll figure for you.
Seventy percent of the people in the most recent poll I saw that was done for our campaign said that they thought the economy was getting worse. And the economy is moving. There are still some problems, as I say. When a person is hurting for a job, that worries me. But gross domestic product, G.N.P., is moving; industrial production is up; payroll employment is up. And another thing that's up and soon will be picked up in these broad polls is that Michigan survey on business confidence. So things are turning around, and yet at this juncture, the American people haven't felt it. When they do, I think you'll -- I expect to see some change.
But, no, I don't take it personally at all. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Yugoslavia
 Q. Sir, you say that you have a strong international leadership role, but the new world order that you are promoting is being challenged in Yugoslavia these days. It appears that the sanctions are not working against Serbia.
When are you going to take the lead of an international coalition to force Milosevic out of Bosnia the way you did with Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait?
A. I think the sanctions -- I'm not prepared to give up on the sanctions at all. They've only been in effect for a few days. And as you know, first on this question of Yugoslavia, out in front, was the United Nations. You had -- Cyrus Vance as a representative of the United Nations did a superb job trying to negotiate, ably implemented -- supplemented, I might say, by Peter Carrington. They tried to work that problem, had our full support.
The E.C., which is right there in the neighborhood, tried to have an effective role. It now appears that a U.S. role, catalytic role, is important, and thus we are moving forward. Secretary Baker made a very strong statement on this recently. He has worked closely with the leaders of Europe, and so we are united in this sanctions question, and let's see if it works.
But I'm not prepared to say these sanctions will not work.
Q. Is the fact that the elections are approaching in the U.S. preventing a military action?
A. I think prudence and caution prevents military actions. If I decide to change my mind on that, I will do it in an inclusive way, but at this juncture, I want to stay with these sanctions.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
On Patrick Buchanan
 Q. Mr. President, in the interest of party unity and since he has indicated that he is going to endorse you at the Houston convention, would you like Pat Buchanan to have the prime-time speech that he wants to have at the Republican convention in August?
A. Susan, I'll be honest with you. I haven't focused on that at all. I welcome the support of all Republicans. And let's see how he handles this and let the people handling the convention work it out. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
U.S. Policies on Iraq
 Q. Mr. President, critics of yours on Capitol Hill have said your policies toward Saddam Hussein before the Gulf war strengthened him and made him more likely to make an attack against one of his neighbors. How do you respond to that? I've got a follow-up.
A. I respond that that's not right. As I said at my last press conference, we tried, not through strengthening his nuclear or biological or chemical weapons, as has been alleged, not by giving him part of Kuwait, as has been alleged. But we tried to work with him on grain credits and things of this nature to avoid aggressive action. And it failed. It failed.
That approach, holding out a hand, trying to get him to renounce terrorism and join the family of nations, didn't work. And the minute he moved aggressively, we moved aggressively and set back aggression.
You got a lot of people that opposed what happened in the war, stood there and didn't want to move, that are now trying to revise history. And so I am not persuaded by the critics at all. I know what we did. There wasn't anything illegal. We tried hard and I've said so, and it didn't work. But we were not going to let aggression stand. And when he moved into Kuwait, I decided this will not stand and it didn't.
Yeah, what's the follow-up?
Q. To follow up, the House Judiciary Committee looks like they're going to recommend special prosecutors and counsel to investigate it, and ask the Attorney General --
A. I wonder whether they're going to use the same prosecutors that are trying out there to see whether I was in Paris in 1980 and flew home in an SR-71 Blackbird.
I mean, where are we going with the taxpayers' money in this political year?
So, let them look at it. It's no problem to me. But I think at some point somebody ought to say where is all this money going that goes to pay for these special prosecutors, rummaging through files and proving nothing. I was not in Paris, and we did nothing illegal or wrong here. We tried, and it didn't work, and we moved. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Two-Party System
 Q. Mr. President, you've spent much of your life as part of the two-party system. You've headed one of the major parties.
In this unusual political year, how do you assess the viability of the two-party system in the future, and why would any candidate submit himself to grueling primaries if he could just announce and run?
A. I think the two-party system has really given us the most stable political system in the world. And, yes, we're going through an unusual period. But the two-party system has provided us fantastic historical stability. And you look around the world and compare this system with any other democratic system, and I think that would avail.
I'm sure the Brits take great pride in their parliamentary system. But I think our two-party system has provided us with the stability that heretofore we've simply taken for granted.
So my view, as this campaign unfolds, as all of us spell out our position on the issues, people are going to recognize that, and the two parties will be strong when this election is over.
Q. And the question of why any candidate would expose himself to the primaries.
A. That's what Barbara was asking me a few minutes ago.
Q. What's your answer?
A. Say, hey, I want to continue this job to help this country; I want to help preserve world peace and strengthen it -- and we've done pretty well there. And I want to move forward on these issues that we're talking about here tonight -- the balanced budget amendment -- I won't repeat them all. But it's worth finishing the job. Nobody likes the primary process. I had a call from a senator kind of asking how I was holding up, because he said, hey, you've been criticized a little in the newspapers and on the television; and I said, hey, that goes with the job. I'll do my best and I think things are going to turn around in that regard.
But to get out of the arena, to suggest that you're going to run because it's not particularly pleasant -- that's not the way I operate. . . .
 
On Abortion
 Q. Mr. President, there are many polls that now show that -- in California and elsewhere -- that most Republicans favor a pro-choice position on abortion. And I wonder, in view of that, and in view of the clear feeling of pro-choice in the party, that you feel the platform needs to be changed, and what your own view is on the whole notion of whether the abortion debate is going to be prominent in the fall.
A. Well, no, I hope the platform committee, in their wisdom, adopts the same language as we had before. Having said that, there is room in our party for people that have different views on this issue. I'm not persuaded that people all across this country vote on only one issue -- abortion. I think they're interested in world peace. I think they're interested in education. I think they happen to be very supportive of a balanced budget amendment.
And so my position is well-known, and I'm going to stay with it. But, as I say, we've got many good Republicans who disagree with me on that issue, and they may disagree with me on the balanced budget amendment or some of these other things I feel very passionately about. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Clarence Thomas
 Q. Mr. President, you said that your problems stem from the economy.
In addition, are some of your problems also related to the Clarence Thomas-Anita Hill hearings?
A. None. We forget. Now we see a revision. We forget that the American people overwhelmingly supported Clarence Thomas. He is being a good Justice. And the fact that some candidates are out there trying to revise that part of history, I'm sorry -- I don't agree with that.
There may be some -- now I can't say some people don't agree -- that, you know, everyone agrees with what I said. I support Clarence Thomas. I think he'll be an outstanding Justice. He passed a Senate that is controlled by the opposition party. He conducted himself with honor in those hearings. And that's my position. And I'm proud to have stayed with him when the going got tough. . . .
 
Leadership
 Q.: Mr. President, you say that the leadership qualities that are going to come out later are not in focus right now. But it would seem that leadership is the focus, that Ross -- that's the only thing that Ross Perot has been running on, is leadership. He has not addressed the issues. You are addressing the issues.
How do you feel? What do you say to Republicans who are going over and supporting him about your personal leadership quality?
A. I say take a look at what happened in Desert Storm where I didn't have to get anybody else's action. I moved. I saw a threat. I did what was required, and I didn't have to get a Congress controlled by the opposition party to move. The people saw leadership and action there.
The people know that the House of Representatives and the Senate control all the legislation: my crime bill, my balanced budget quest, whatever it is -- they control it all. And so I think when this campaign gets really rolling -- and it hasn't started, from our standpoint -- when that happens, I think these things will be in focus. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
After the Election
 Q. Mr. President, aren't we into a no-win situation here, because even if you do win, even if you do defeat Ross Perot, there are going to be a lot of Republicans out there who supported him, and there is going to be a lot of reprisal and revenge?
A. There will no reprisals. Look, Helen says we're through here -- but let me tell you something: you're dealing in a little cocoon here. We're talking about something big: faith and confidence in the American people. And this isn't done because there's something on the horizon right now, and people are going to -- you know, let 'em decide, let 'em sort out this. And I can understand that appeal: I'm from outside, I'll solve all the problems.
And then some day you guys are going to start: How are you going to do it, how are you going to get this through the Congress, what do you believe -- do you think the President is right on a balanced budget amendment, are you with him or against him, do you think he's right as he tries to tighten down on crime legislation, how do you feel on the narcotic problem, how do you feel on world peace, were you with him when he had to make a very tough call on sending back aggression, a move that was saluted all over the entire world and put this country together like it's never been together in the past since World War II.
And, you see, I think we're dealing in a funny time here, time warp. And I think come fall, when we're out there taking our case to the people, with an improved economy behind us, I still feel confident about the outcome of the political election. And I feel confident about ability to heal any wounds that may have been opened along the way.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush and his wife, Barbara, were luncheon guests of Vice President Dan Quayle and his wife, Marilyn. They spoke with reporters outside the Vice President's residence. Later, the President held an evening news conference. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Charges of insider trading were filed by the S.E.C. against seven corporate executives and investors. Among those accused of using confidential corporate information for personal gain were a former Bear, Stearns director who is the husband of the automobile heiress Charlotte Ford, and the co-founder of Revlon cosmetics. [Page A1.]
The insider charges offer a possible explanation for what had previously been an inexplicable series of stock-price run-ups. [D1.] 
 Retail chain-store sales crept up last month, continuing the sluggish growth that began in January. [D2.]
The number of Americans seeking unemployment benefits edged up by 4,000 during the week ending May 23. [D3.]
The cost of modernizing an obsolete building, particularly one filled with asbestos, can be used to reduce its assessed value, according to a state court ruling. [A1.]
New Jersey's credit rating is being threatened by a dispute over Federal payment of state Medicaid expenses. [B4.]
 
Companies
The airline industry's half-price fare sale was a smash hit for both carriers and passengers. And the money that travelers will spend on hotels, car rentals, attractions and restaurants will bring an additional $15 billion into the nation's economy. [D1.]
The tough tactics that airline managements used to gain huge cost savings from labor under deregulation in the past decade will haunt the industry in the future, a new study shows. [D5.]
Orion Pictures announced details of its plan to reorganize and remain an independent film-production company. [D2.]
Thomas Cook, one of the world's largest travel agencies, will be sold to two German companies. [D4.]
Many lenders to Olympia & York would face heavy losses if their collateral were liquidated, court papers show. [D4.]
Xoma's flagship drug was denied approval by the F.D.A., sending the company's stock plummeting. [D4.]
The Revco drugstore chain, in its first action since emerging from bankruptcy, dismissed its chairman and chief executive. [D5.]
National Medical Enterprises settled a civil suit in Texas by agreeing to pay more than $9 million in fines. [D6.]
 
International
Japanese and American electronics companies reached an 11th-hour agreement on ways to increase the sale of American semiconductors in Japan this year. [D1.]
Japan's 10-year effort to seize the lead in computer technology is fizzling to a close, having failed to meet many of its goals. [D1.]
The World Bank, at the Earth Summit in Brazil, proposed a $5 billion fund to help poor nations protect their environments. [A6.]
 
Markets
Stocks posted moderate losses in slow trading. The Dow fell 7.26, closing at 3399.73. [D6.]
Prices of Treasury securities were unchanged in very light trading ahead of today's May unemployment data. [D12.]
Copper futures prices rose to their highest levels in seven months as two huge Chilean mines were closed. [D13.]
The dollar settled mixed on world currency markets. Gold prices fell 10 cents in New York, to $338.60 an ounce. [D13.]
 
Today's Columns
Wall Street appears to have big doubts that Pennzoil will be able to benefit from its 9.4 percent stake in Chevron. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D1.]
The ridicule once heaped on infomercials by mainstream agencies and advertisers is turning into murmurs of interest. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D9.]

HEADLINE: S.E.C.'s View On Big Salaries

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission urged Congress today to reject legislation that would restrict the corporate tax benefits of large executive salaries.
Amid shareholder outrage over multimillion-dollar payouts to many executives, both the House and Senate are considering proposals to limit the deductibility on corporate income taxes for large salaries and benefits. 
 But testifying before a Senate Finance subcommittee today, Richard C. Breeden, chairman of the S.E.C., said there was no need to change the tax code because excessive salaries would probably be curtailed once the commission adopted its own rules to require more detailed disclosure of top salaries and bonuses.
"Market forces, not governmental dictates, should decide what is best," he said.
The House bill extending unemployment insurance benefits includes a provision that would limit the deduction for executive compensation to $1 million per executive. A similar measure is expected to be considered by the Senate Finance Committee.
Democrats in the House and Senate who support the proposals say they want to limit a taxpayer subsidy of excessive paychecks.
The legislation is opposed by the Bush Administration.

HEADLINE: U.S. Suggests It Might Give Trenton Medicaid Funds, but Bond Raters Are Wary

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 4

 BODY:
New Jersey received some good fiscal news today with word that it still had a shot at obtaining most of the $450 million in Medicaid payments it thought it had been denied.
But any celebrations were tempered by the news that Standard & Poor's, the bond rating firm, had placed the state on its credit watch, a move that could jeopardize its AA+ bond rating, the firm's second-highest ranking, and cost the state millions in interest charges. 
 The Standard & Poor's announcement came near the end of a day of pandemonium over the state budget that involved Gov. Jim Florio, State Treasurer Samuel F. Crane, the Republican-controlled Legislature and the White House.
On Tuesday, Mr. Crane announced a new $450 million hole in the state budget caused by what he said was the Federal Government's denial of New Jersey's request for retroactive Medicaid payments for psychiatric hospitals dating to 1989. Together with a $608 million shortfall created two weeks ago when the Legislature rolled back the sales tax to 6 percent from 7 percent, that put the budget for the 1993 fiscal year, which begins in 27 days, $1 billion in the red.
 
G.O.P. Blames Democrats
 Republicans attributed the loss of the Medicaid funds to Democratic bumbling, and the Republicans in the White House today seemed to back them up. Democrats, however, called the Federal denial a technicality.
"There are regulatory requirements that the Florio administration did not meet that resulted in the recent decision by the Health Care Financing Administration to disallow part of the reimbursement claim," the White House Chief of Staff, Samuel K. Skinner, said in a letter to Assembly Speaker Garabed Haytaian. "This initial decision resulted in a final notice of disallowance for $74 million. There remains $412 million in disproportionate share claims that have yet to be resolved."
Mr. Skinner concluded by said he expected a "final resolution" on the remaining amount within a week.
Mr. Crane said that $450 million was at issue, while Mr. Skinner's letter put the total at $486 million.
 
Florio Is 'Flattered'
 "Both are estimates," said Richard McGrath, Mr. Crane's spokesman. "It's not unusual in this sort of Medicaid funding to have different numbers. It depends on the tabulations and cutoff dates you use."
Mr. Florio said he was "flattered by the personal attention of the White House during a time when it has so many important things to be concerned about."
But he said he stood by his administration's interpretation of events and distributed a letter from the regional administrator of the Health Care Financing Administration, the Federal agency that ruled on the Medicaid funds, that appeared to indicate that New Jersey would receive no money for any period before Dec. 28, 1991.
"The people of New Jersey are not concerned about semantics, but only about receiving from Washington that which we are due," Mr. Florio said.
"Hopefully, the next communication from the White House will be, 'The check's in the mail.' "
 
Income-Tax Shortfall, Too
 The state constitution requires that New Jersey begin and end its fiscal year with a balanced budget. That has been complicated not only by the sales-tax rollback and the confusion over Medicaid reimbursement, but also by a $652 million shortfall that Mr. Crane attributed to lower-than-expected income-tax revenue.
Mr. Crane submitted a plan to cover the $652 million gap, but he said the $1 billion shortfall in the 1993 budget was the responsibility of the Republicans, who control both houses of the Legislature. Weeks before the current problems, the Republicans promised to cut $1 billion from Mr. Florio's $15.7 billion budget for 1993, but they have yet to present their alternative budget.
Standard & Poor's cited the spate of bad news in announcing its decision to put New Jersey on its credit watch. The action affects $4.7 billion in bond debt.
"I am not surprised at the official expression of concern about the state's fiscal status by Standard & Poor's," said Mr. Crane. "It is obvious that Wall Street shares the same apprehension and uncertainty that the people of New Jersey have about the absence of a budget plan."
 
Shortfall Is Doubted
 Senator Robert Littell, Republican chairman of the Senate Budget and Appropriations Committee, urged Standard & Poor's to withhold any action on the bond rating until it could verify some of its information.
"It seems to me that Standard & Poor's based its decision on nothing more than a shortfall manufactured by the Florio administration," Mr. Littell said.
Amid the flurry of activity over the budget, the Senate unanimously approved a bill that would use $200 million as seed money for nearly $1 billion in building projects and to create nearly 100,000 jobs.
Under the so-called Economic Recovery Fund Act, New Jersey will use $200 million in revenues from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for projects like improvements to the Atlantic City airport and building a performing arts center in downtown Newark.
Senator William L. Gormley, the bill's Republican sponsor, said it would add $800 million to the state's economy and help create 20,000 construction jobs and 75,000 permanent jobs in the next three years.

HEADLINE: May Sales Up a Bit at Most Retailers

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Sales in most of the nation's retail chain stores crept up last month, continuing the sluggish growth that began with a bang in January but has wound down ever since.
J. C. Penney & Company and Wal-Mart Stores Inc. continued to confound the trend, posting strong sales increases. But apparel-specialty store companies, like the Limited Inc. and Ann Taylor Inc., lost sales because of unusually cold, rainy weather across most of the country. 
 Most other companies had improvements of one or two percentage points in their sales last month. Analysts said even though the month over all was disappointing, they still saw glimmers of a recovery lurking in the reported sales numbers.
 
Salomon Index Up 4.2%
 The Salomon Brothers retailing index, which tracks the sales of several leading retailers, rose 4.2 percent in May. "The underpinnings for an improved retail sales and earnings picture for the year are becoming more evident," said Jeffrey M. Feiner, a Salomon retail analyst.
The analysts are now looking toward the back-to-school selling season in August, when they expect a slight surge in sales that is expected to continue until Christmas.
"They have really got some momentum now," said Walter F. Loeb, the principal of Loeb Associates Inc., a retail consulting firm. "If you look at all the numbers, while a few are down, you still see spotty improvement in consumer spending."
 
A Warmer May 1991
 Mr. Loeb said bad weather dampened sales, which benefited in the previous year's period from unusually warm weather. In May 1991, temperatures on average were 2 degrees higher than normal, while last month they were 4 degrees colder.
The Kmart Corporation, based in Troy, Mich., said the weather had hurt sales of apparel and gardening implements in its discount stores. Sales in Kmart's discount stores open at least a year dropped by two-tenths of a percent in May, while the comparable-store sales at Kmart's specialty stores, like Payless Drug Stores and Waldenbooks, grew by 7.8 percent.
Over all, Kmart's May sales increased by 6.5 percent, to $2.92 billion, from $2.74 billion in the corresponding period last year.
 
Sears Also Cites Weather
 Cold weather was also blamed for lackluster sales of lawn and garden equipment, air-conditioners and some clothing at Sears, Roebuck & Company. Sears posted a 1.1 percent increase in overall sales, to $1.71 billion. Sales at the company's comparable stores, or those open at least a year, were up by three-tenths of a percent.
But Sears, which is based in Chicago, said it saw some strength in the economy based on strong sales of durable goods, like large appliances, home-office equipment and furniture.
Analysts and investors track a retailer's sales from the company's comparable- or same-store figures. Those figures provide a more accurate assessment of a retailer's performance than the company's statistics on overall sales. New stores typically have strong initial sales that can distort a company's results.
 
Woolworth's Decline
 The Woolworth Corporation, based in New York, also attributed the six-tenths of a percent decline in its same-store sales to poor weather. Over all, the retailer's May sales, dropped slightly, to $688 million from $692 million.
But the weather did not faze Wal-Mart, which sold $4.44 billion in goods during May, a 27.2 percent increase over last year. The sales in Wal-Mart stores open at least one year grew by 12 percent.
Retailers with a strong presence in California, where the recession started later and has lasted longer, said they saw evidence of a rebound in the economy there, as well as in their own May sales figures.
The Dayton Hudson Corporation, whose Target and Mervyn's divisions have large presences in California, said sales in its stores open at least a year grew by 5.5 percent, while overall sales increased by 14.1 percent. Even its Dayton's, Hudson's and Marshall Field's department stores, which like other luxury department store chains had a difficult time increasing sales during the recession, showed a 2 percent gain in comparable-store sales.
 
Penney's Streak Continues
 At Penney, its department stores reported a 8.8 percent increase in sales in stores open at least a year, the third straight month that Penney has outpaced the industry. William R. Howell, the retailer's chairman, attributed the growth to strong sales of children's apparel and women's sportswear and dresses.
The Gap Inc., which routinely posted double-digit comparable store sales figures last year, said its May same-store sales rose 3 percent. While Gap's overall sales increased nearly 16 percent, to $191 million, from $165 million in the corresponding period last year, the retailer said those sales came at the expense of its gross margins.
Sales of the Limited Inc. in Columbus, Ohio, which operates Limited stores, Express and Victoria's Secret among other specialty-store chains, climbed by 11 percent, to $489.2 million, in May. Its sales totaled $439.8 million in the 1991 period. The company's comparable-store sales grew by 1 percent.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Retailers' Sales Detailed
 By The Associated Press -- Following are the sales for May reported yesterday by some of the nation's largest retailers. The figures give the current year's sales and the percentage difference over those of the previous year.
Some top retailers do not report their sales on a monthly basis, and reporting periods vary slightly. Most retailers' fiscal years end in late January or early February. Sales include those from stores open at least a year, which are also known as same-store or comparable-store sales.
 
Wal-Mart Stores Inc.
 For May: same-store sales rose 12 percent; overall sales up 27.2 percent, to $4.44 billion.
 
 Kmart Corp.
 For four weeks ended May 27: same-store sales rose 1.8 percent; overall sales up 6.5 percent, to $2.92 billion.
 
 Sears, Roebuck & Co.
 For four weeks ended May 30: same-store sales rose three-tenths of a percent; overall sales down eight-tenths of a percent, to $2.47 billion.
 
 J. C. Penney Co.
 For four weeks ended May 30: same-store sales rose 8.8 percent at Penney stores only; overall sales up 9 percent, to $1.2 billion.
 
 Dayton Hudson Corp.
 For four weeks ended May 30: same-store sales rose 5.5 percent; overall sales up 14.1 percent, to $1.21 billion.
 
 May Department Stores Co.
 For four weeks ended May 30: same-store sales rose 1.5 percent; overall sales up 6.2 percent, to $805.8 million.
 
 Federated Department Stores Inc.
 For four weeks ended May 30: same-store sales rose three-tenths of a percent; overall sales down 4.1 percent, to $488.1 million.
 
 Woolworth Corp.
 For four weeks ended May 30: same-store domestic sales fell six-tenths of a percent; overall domestic sales down 4.9 percent, to $368 million. Total sales, including foreign, were down five-tenths of a percent, to $688 million.
 
 Melville Corp.
 For four weeks ended May 30: same-store sales rose 2.9 percent; overall sales up 4.8 percent, to $728.4 million.
 
 Limited Inc.
 For four weeks ended May 30: same-store sales fell 1 percent; overall sales up 11 percent, to $489.2 million.
 
 TJX Cos.
 For four weeks ended May 30: overall sales up 14.6 percent, to $250 million.
 
 Gap Inc.
 For four weeks ended May 30: same-store sales rose 3 percent; overall sales up 15.7 percent, to $191 million.
 
 United States Shoe Corp.
 For four weeks ended May 30: same-store sales fell 5.6 percent; overall sales down 8.9 percent, to $165.9 million.

HEADLINE: Dinkins's New Economic Chief Finding Life in the Spotlight a Bit Unsettling

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 4

 BODY:
Barry F. Sullivan, the former high-powered banker who was appointed New York City's top economic development official five weeks ago, gave a news photographer here an uncomfortable frozen smile today as he demonstrated a French-made public toilet that New York City is considering leasing.
"I can see the headlines you're writing now," Mr. Sullivan said under his breath to reporters. "Well, I've done my part." 
 Being photographed inside a public toilet is emblematic of the many changes in Mr. Sullivan's professional life since he retired last fall as the head of First Chicago Bank and accepted Mayor David N. Dinkins's offer to become his Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development.
In his first significant act in his new post, Mr. Sullivan has escorted Mr. Dinkins through business meetings in London and Paris in the last four days. The trip was organized by the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry. By persuading Mr. Dinkins to lead a delegation of business leaders, Mr. Sullivan has emerged as the administration's main connection to New York's business establishment.
 
Big Switch in Roles
 When he took office in March, Mr. Sullivan, 61 years old and a Bronx native, exchanged the powerful but largely private job of running the United States' 10th-largest bank for the intensely public role of selling New York to investors and persuading failing businesses to remain in a city reeling from the effects of the recession and Federal budget cuts.
Mr. Sullivan says he is trying to adjust to life in the spotlight. Because decisions usually require a political consensus, they take longer than they did in the private sector, he said, and for the first time in his life, how his actions play in the news media counts almost as much as their results.
"The press is far more important in the political arena than I would have thought it was," Mr. Sullivan said in an interview in his Paris hotel room today. "It's tough. It is something that doesn't come naturally to me as it does to the Mayor. I can watch the Mayor think in media terms. And that is not my first instinct. I'm learning to do that."
His appointment was widely interpreted as a sign that Mr. Dinkins wanted to patch up his relationship with the city's business leaders, who have complained bitterly that the administration has not done enough to help business.
His first move was to make peace between the Chamber of Commerce and Industry and Mr. Dinkins, who had to responded to an invitation to lead the delegation to Europe. Mr. Dinkins, bitter about criticism from some prominent Chamber members over his handling of the city's budget negotiations, was planning his own trade mission to Germany.
"I came in and said why don't we see if we can do these two things together, which is exactly what we did," Mr. Sullivan said.
Since Sunday, the Mayor and more than a dozen New York executives have held seminars and meetings with scores of European businesses here and in London. The Mayor has tried to sell New York as a comeback city with a soft commercial real-estate market and declining crime.
 
'Seriously Successful'
 Several delegation members said Mr. Sullivan had played a criticial role in arranging meetings with chief executive officers, especially bankers at National Westminister Bank and Credit Local de France interested in doing business with the city.
"Barry is a seriously successful capitalist," said one member of the Mayor's delegation who insisted on anonymity. "These executives know it when he walks in the door."
Daniel Gronich, a New York real-estate executive, said Mr. Sullivan's appointment had convinced him and other business leaders that Mr. Dinkins was finally serious about economic development.
"This guy was chairman of a money-center bank," Mr. Gronich said. "That broke the ice. The business community said to the Mayor, 'O.K., let's work together.' "
 
Foreign Investment Is Goal
 In the interview, Mr. Sullivan stressed that his general plans for revitalizing the city's economy depended upon attracting foreign investment from service industries already linked to New York's economy, like entertainment, financial services and fashion. But he said he also intended to develop programs to help subsidize biochemical and other high-tech companies and to encourage small businesses to expand.
He conceded that many of his plans were sketchy. "I'm comfortable," he said. "I'm only in the job for five months."
A major difficulty New York faces, he said, is the dearth of cheap labor.
Another significant obstacle to developing new businesses and retaining old ones, he said, is the city bureaucracy itself.
A large corporation that deals with New York, he said, "may deal with seven, eight or nine agencies." Many times, he said, none of the agencies are aware the company is dealing with the others.
In contrast, Mr. Sullivan thinks of the businesses as the city's customers and insists that the government must become "more customer friendly."
Most foreign executives Mr. Sullivan has met on the trip think the United States is coming out of its recession faster than Britain or France, he said, and are eager to invest in New York.
Still, he said, he and Mr. Dinkins have had to fight New York's image as a crime-ridden, deteriorating metropolis with high taxes.
"Where they have an issue, it tends to be the quality of life," Mr. Sullivan said. "They say, 'We want to hear you talk about safety.' "

HEADLINE: Judge Stays Rate Ruling For Hospitals

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, June 4

 BODY:
The Federal judge who struck down New Jersey's system of financing health care for indigent patients last week said today that he would suspend his action if the Governor and the Legislature agreed to deal with the issue at a special summer session.
Judge Alfred M. Wolin of Federal District Court said he recognized the "catalogue of horrors" that would result from his ruling last week, including immediate financial crises at 20 inner-city hospitals serving 900,000 people. He stayed its effect until June 12 to give Gov. Jim Florio and legislative leaders time to deliver to him a signed "statement of principles" agreeing to conduct the special session with a single focus: health care. 
 In his ruling, which was to take effect on Friday, Judge Wolin said self-insured health plans were exempt under Federal law from paying more than the actual cost of health services. The ruling absolved about 2.4 million people covered by union and company self-insurance plans from paying a 19 percent surcharge that has been added to hospital bills to finance services for the poor and to cover bad debts.
 
A Separate Appeal
 Judge Wolin issued the stay after hearing arguments by lawyers for the state, the unions that brought the suit that overturned the financing system and the New Jersey Hospital Association.
The hospital association, which represents 112 health-care institutions, had announced plans to appeal Judge Wolin's ruling to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia by Friday's deadline, and Mr. Florio reluctantly agreed to file a separate appeal to avoid a potential hospital crisis. The Democratic Governor has been urging the Republican-led Legislature to change the system, which has added about $1.4 billion annually to 1.3 million hospital bills.
Although it was a response to a challenge to New Jersey's system, Judge Wolin's decision also could affect the way many states set hospital rates and pay for care for those who lack health insurance, Mr. Florio said.
Judge Wolin's decision to give the state time to find an alternate means of paying hospital bills for the poor was greeted warmly by Louis P. Scibetta, the president of the hospital association. "This is precisely the type of action we hoped would take place," he said.
"The hospital association will work tirelessly with the Governor, the Legislature and other interested parties to avert a situation that would otherwise spell crisis for our hospitals and the public," Mr. Scibetta said.
Mr. Florio met for 30 minutes today with the State Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco; the Assembly Speaker, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, and other legislators to discuss the health-care crisis. They later released a statement saying they were committed to finding a financing plan that was fairer to state residents and would stabilize the hospital system.
Their staffs will meet on Friday "for a lengthy work session to move this effort forward," the statement said, and the Governor and legislative leaders are to meet again on Monday. But while they noted Judge Wolin's conditions for extending his stay beyond next week, there was no promise that Mr. Florio, Mr. DiFrancesco and Mr. Haytaian would sign the requested statement of principles.
 
Legal Options
 Instead, the statement said the Attorney General's office would brief the legislative leaders on Judge Wolin's decision "and what the legal options are in light of that decision."
Albert G. Kroll, a lawyer for the union health plans that filed the successful challenge to the financing system, called Judge Wolin's decision today "a well-crafted opinion."
"He did an excellent job in identifying the problem," he said. "It lies with the Legislature, which created the problem and which has the power to come up with a solution."
Under the disputed system, the 19 percent surcharge on hospital bills goes into the Uncompensated Care Trust Fund, then is disbursed to hospitals on the basis of their indigent-patient caseload. The trust fund expired in January but was extended for six months by the Legislature and Mr. Florio to allow time to find a substitute.
Nothing has happened since, and the Legislature has passed another extension. Mr. Florio, who has not signed the bill, has insisted on some changes in the health-insurance laws, among them a requirement that commercial insurance companies insure every applicant, regardless of age or health history.
Since they filed suit a year ago, the union health plans have been withholding the 19 percent surcharge and placing the money in an escrow account in the event they eventually lose their suit and have to pay, Mr. Kroll said. The escrow account holds about $5 million that the unions say they will be able to keep as the result of Judge Wolin's ruling.


GRAPHIC: A new judicial ruling in New Jersey would exempt federally regulated insurange funds from souldering the costs of health care for the uninsured. Here is how the system now works:
Chart: "Health Care: Redistributing the Hospital Costs of the Uninsured"
 A 19 percent surcharge is added to the hospital bills of people who have insurance except those covered by Medicare.
 The money from the surcharge, more than $900 million a year, goes to the state's Uncompensated Care Trust Fund.
 The fund distributes the money to hospitals that have treated patients who do not or cannot pay their bills; the bulk of the money goes to 20 inner-city hospitals. The money also provides discounts to patients covered by New Jersey Blue Cross and Blue Shield.
 On May 27, a judge ruled that the surcharge would not have to be paid by federally regulated insurance funds administered by unions and companies. If the ruling takes effect, all the money needed for the uncompensated care fund would have to come from surcharges on the bills paid by private insurers, raising them substantially. This means 20 percent of the patients in the state would be paying for 100 percent of the costs of uncompensated care. (pg. B5)

HEADLINE: 57 Suffolk Officers Retire Over Plan for 10% Pay Cut

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., June 4

 BODY:
A proposal to cut Suffolk County police salaries by 10 percent has led 57 officers to file for retirement this week to avoid a cut in pension benefits, the county's Police Commissioner said today.
At least 700 other officers in the 2,300-member department are eligible for retirement, having served 20 years, and could file for their pensions should the County Legislature adopt the pay cut as part of a plan to close a $90 million budget gap, the Commissioner, Robert Creighton said. 
 He said the pay cut, which would affect all county employees, could have a devastating effect on public safety if it prompts more officers to retire.
"It will certainly affect the response time of police officers," Mr. Creighton said. "People do not expect the police to take an hour or two or three to get to see them, especially if they have a serious problem."
 
$90 Million Budget Gap
 Union officials say the retiring officers are concerned that a pay cut will diminish their pension income. Retirement pay equals half the salary earned during the final year of active service, or half the average salary during the last three years on the job, whichever is higher.
Nassau County was faced with a similar problem earlier this year when scores of officers retired because they were working without a new contract and no pay increase. Since January, 180 have filed to retire in Nassau, compared with 190 for all of last year and 86 in 1990.
The base police salary of about $50,000 a year in Suffolk and Nassau is $10,000 more a year than in New York City, where union officials have historically used Nassau and Suffolk wage and benefit packages as a standard when negotiating labor contracts.
The 10 percent pay cut is one of several measures being considered by the Suffolk Legislature. The county's $1.3 billion budget has a $90 million gap because of sales-tax revenues that were lower than expected and higher costs for welfare programs primarily because of the recession.
 
Police Pledge to Fight
 The Legislature is also considering laying off 1,341 of the county's 10,000 employees, including 300 police officers, raising the sales tax half a percentage point, to 8.5 percent, and selling $90 million in deficit notes. The alternative would be additional layoffs and an increase in property taxes.
Thomas Tohill, president of the Suffolk County Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, said union leaders met today and reconfirmed their commitment to fight the layoffs and salary cuts in court, if necessary.
Since January, 140 officers have retired. Mr. Tohill said that over the last six years, an average of 150 officers retired each year.
He said the 57 additional officers who filed this week did so because they were uncertain about their future income and could not take the chance of awaiting the outcome of a court battle that could go against them.
"They feel there is a lack of direction in the county leadership," Mr. Tohill said. "And they can't trust the county when it comes to contractual benefits."
Arthur Cliff, president of the Superior Officers Association, which represents those with the rank of sergeant and above, said his members "felt betrayed by the country."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thomas Tohill, president of the Suffolk County Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, spoke to union members yesterday in Ronkonkoma, L.I., on the county's plan to trim police salaries. The cuts, which will diminish pension income, have been cited as the reason 57 officers have filed for retirement. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Are Becalmed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were essentially unchanged on nearly non-existent volume yesterday, as credit market participants curbed buying and selling until after May employment data are released this morning.
"The past two days have been hideous," one Government securities trader said. "For the most part, people are washed out and waiting for Friday." 
 A rise in weekly initial unemployment claims, the first in three weeks, and sluggish chain-store sales reported for May did not have much impact on prices yesterday. Nor did money supply data that were weaker than expected.
"The recovery continues to look slow and anemic," the trader said. "Until and unless that view changes, the market will pretty much sit where it is."
Analysts noted that the number of individuals receiving unemployment benefits fell during the week ended May 23. The decline raises the possibility that the unemployment rate, which stood at 7.2 percent in April, could show a decline when the data are released.
Most analysts are forecasting that nonfarm payroll employment rose by 100,000 or a bit more last month.
Although market participants chose not to register much reaction to the money supply figures, analysts said the data provided the market with some underlying support going in to today's employment report.
 
Money Supply Moves Down
 The Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply fell during the week ended May 25.
M-2, the monetary aggregate most closely followed by the Fed, declined by $10.4 billion. With the drop, M-2's growth rate for the year slipped to 1.6 percent, well under the 2.5 percent rate that represents the floor of the Fed's target growth range of 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 101 14/32 , down 2/32 , to yield 7.87 percent, compared with 7.86 percent late Wednesday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 1/8, down 1/32 , to yield 7.33 percent. And the 5 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 30/32 , up 1/32 , to yield 5.15 percent.
Rates on outstanding short-term Treasury bills moved a tad lower after the money supply figures were released.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.67 percent, down two basis points, or two one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by three basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.81 percent. And one-year bills were offered at a late rate of 4.04 percent, down two basis points.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, Proctor & Gamble offered $200 million worth of noncallable five-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The 6.85 percent notes were priced at $100, or par, 25 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 3/4 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated AA-2 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
A decision by Standard & Poor's to place the State of New Jersey on creditwatch with the possibility of downgrading its AA rating on outstanding New Jersey debt securities had no impact on prices of those issues yesterday, traders said.
In the broader secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, participants said that prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged to up 1/8 point.

HEADLINE: Stocks Slip As the Dow Drops 7.26

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Stocks posted moderate losses in slow trading yesterday as investors took a breather ahead of the release today of May employment report.
But the shares of Ford, G.M. and Chrysler continued to entice buyers after the report on Wednesday that late May car sales surged 11.2 percent. 
 "The market is cautious ahead of the unemployment numbers, but a positive has been strength in the autos," said Alan Ackerman at Reich & Company.
The Dow Jones industrial average lost 7.26 points to close at 3,399.73, just below the key 3,400 level.
Volume on New York Stock Exchange turnover was 204.5 million shares, off slightly from 215.8 million shares traded Wednesday. Declining stocks led advances, 942 to 762. The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.75, to 227.90.
The Nasdaq composite index closed at 588.26, down 1.67 points. The American Stock Exchange index was up 1.53 points at 397.18. The Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 1.31 points, to 413.26.
Traders and analysts expect the jobs numbers to show that nonfarm payrolls grew by 101,000 jobs and that the unemployment rate was unchanged from April, at 7.2 percent. Neither figure was considered reason to buy or sell.
"It's tough to make a Picasso out of a finger painting," said David Holt, director of research at Wedbush Morgan Securities.
The market flirted with the 3,400 level throughout the day, but with both buyers and sellers lacking strong conviction, it was unable to break to the upside.
General Motors topped the Big Board most-active list, adding, 1 7/8 to 43 5/8. Chrysler rose 3/4, to 20 5/8, and Ford Motor rose 1 3/8, to 48 1/8. Bear, Stearns repeated a buy rating on G.M.
Shares of the Xoma Corporation sank 4 3/4, to 15 1/4. The drug maker said regulators in the United States had asked for additional tests of its drug to treat septic shock.
U.S. Surgical rose 1 1/4, to 114 3/4. The company said it could achieve $250 million in revenues next year from the sale of instruments used in less-invasive procedures for hysterectomies.
Monsanto slumped 2 1/2 to 60 1/4. Kidder, Peabody downgraded its rating and estimates on the company.
 The Altera Corporation lost 2 1/4, to 13 1/4, after it said second-quarter net would be below analysts' estimates.
Lehman Brothers upgraded its rating on McDonnell Douglas, citing the stock's attractive price. Shares surged 4 3/8, to 43 1/2.

HEADLINE: Jobless-Benefit Claims Up

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits edged up by 4,000 during the week ending May 23, the Government said today.
Analysts, however, dismissed the small advance as insignificant and noted that the four-week average for new jobless claims continued to improve, falling to the second-lowest level in 18 months. 
 The Labor Department said the weekly gain had pushed initial claims for unemployment benefits to 407,000, up from 403,000 the previous week, which was the lowest weekly figures in seven months.
But even with the recent advance, the four-week average for claims declined to 410,750, the second-best showing since October 1990.
Because week-to-week changes in jobless claims can be volatile, economists prefer to focus on the four-week moving average.
They noted that the average claims level had now dropped significantly from the 450,000 mark, where it had been stuck for the first three months of the year.
Economists use the jobless claim data to gauge the economy's direction, figuring that lower claims indicate that companies are hiring and expanding output.
Robert Dederick, chief economist of the Northern Trust Company of Chicago, said the slow improvement in jobless claims was consistent with the view that the economy had begun a sustainable, but modest recovery.
On Friday, the Government will issue the unemployment rate for May and Mr. Dederick said he was looking for it to remain at 7.2 percent and stay above 7 percent for most of the rest of the year.
The state with the biggest increase in jobless claims in the week was Oregon. The increase of 3,156 was attributed to computer problems that delayed claims processing in the previous week.
Claims also rose by large amounts in Michigan, up 1,865, a gain attributed to further layoffs in the auto industry; Mississippi, up 1,783, and Texas, up 1,383.
The state with the biggest decline in claims was California, where claims dropped by 4,375, with the improvement attributed to fewer layoffs in the electronics and aerospace industries.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mixed as Traders Await May's Jobless Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mixed on world currency markets yesterday as traders awaited the release of May unemployment data today.
Gold prices fell. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $338.60 a troy ounce, off 10 cents from Wednesday. Later, the Republic National Bank quoted a bid of $338.40, also down 10 cents. 
 The dollar traded in quite narrow ranges in anticipation of the unemployment figure, expected by analysts to remain at 7.2 percent.
Dealers were trying to figure out the direction of the economy, said Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager with the Bank of New York.
Weekly data on unemployment insurance claims released yesterday had little impact on the dollar. The Labor Department said the number of Americans filing new claims edged up by 4,000 during the week ended May 23.
"Today's data are just one part of the puzzle," said Jeff Mondschein, a managing director with the Continental Bank in Chicago. "Tomorrow we'll get the whole picture,"
But the dollar's potential to rally significantly if the figures are solid is limited by mixed sentiment toward the economy, dealers said.
There was still uncertainty in the market surrounding Denmark's rejection of the treaty on closer European economic and political union, Mr. Mondschein said.
"Traders are waiting to see how the political dust settles after the Danish vote and where that leaves the currencies," he said.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 127.70 Japanese yen, from 126.90 yen at Wednesday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 127.50 yen. In New York the dollar near unchanged at 127.40 yen, from 127.45 Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday, were: 1.5980 German marks, down from 1.6040; 1.4625 Swiss francs, down from 1.4700; 5.3800 French francs, down from 5.4025; 1,208.00 Italian lire, down from 1,213.00, and 1.19605 Canadian dollars, down from 1.20065.

HEADLINE: New U.S.-Japan Accord on Semiconductors

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 4

 BODY:
In an 11th-hour attempt to head off a trade crisis, Japanese and American electronics companies agreed today on measures aimed at vastly increasing the sale of American semiconductors in Japan this year.
A key part of the plan is that Japan's 10 largest electronics companies, including giants like Hitachi, Toshiba and Sony, will take "emergency special measures" in which they will give American and other non-Japanese suppliers advance information on their need for semiconductor products in the third and fourth quarters. 
 "We have high confidence that these extraordinary measures that have been agreed on today will result in significant increases in market share," said James Norling, the president of the semiconductor group at Motorola Inc. and one of the negotiators for the American trade group, the Semiconductor Industry Association.
But there is still some reason to be skeptical. Giving advance information on the need for chip products does not guarantee that orders will be placed. That will depend on market conditions and other factors.
Tensions have been rising over what American semiconductor companies regard as Japan's failure to live up to a semiconductor trade agreement between the two nations.
A major goal of that agreement was that American and other non-Japanese suppliers would obtain 20 percent of Japan's huge market for computer chips by the end of this year. The market share of foreign chip companies in Japan now stands at 14.4 percent and has not been growing, making it exceedingly unlikely that the 20 percent share can be reached by the deadline.
Japanese companies say the 20 percent figure is not a guarantee, only an expectation. In recent weeks they have expressed increasing annoyance at American demands, saying it is hard for them to take on new suppliers during an economic downturn.
American semiconductor companies have been threatening to seek sanctions against Japanese companies. The American Government has also begun to express its disappointment with the lack of progress in market share. Last week, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, began a Federal review of how the existing agreement was being carried out.
Today's agreement, announced jointly by Japanese and American trade groups, seems to be aimed at staving off sanctions.
"We have agreed that we'd like to avoid any unfortunate consquences," said Shinichi Itoh, an executive with the NEC Corporation and one of the negotiators of the agreement for the Electronic Industries Association of Japan.
 
A Way to Avoid the Deadline
 But the agreement could also provide a way to postpone the end-of-the-year deadline. If the Japanese companies diligently try to carry out the new measures and the foreign market share improves, it is likely that the American companies will not push for sanctions even if their market share falls a bit short of 20 percent by the deadline.
Many times in the past, American companies have applauded some trade agreements only to see the expected results fail to materialize. In the case of semiconductors, the 20 percent goal was first expected to be achieved by 1991 under a 1986 trade agreement. When that failed, a new trade agreement was signed in 1991 putting the deadline at the end of this year.
There is also the possibility that the emergency program may provide a one-time benefit that does not lead to long-term gains in market share. For instance, a Japanese company could buy a year's worth of foreign chips in six months and stockpile the extras.
The large Japanese companies, in general, already buy 20 percent of their chips from foreign companies. American companies have complained that the smaller companies do not buy as many. Nevertheless, the larger companies are being called on now to increase their purchases even more, in part because they have the capacity to do so and also because they would stand to lose the most from sanctions.
