HEADLINE: Saving the Earth From Roasting

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
Is there yet time to save Earth from a catastrophic roasting that some experts now regard as virtually inevitable? A new show at the American Museum of Natural History offers a rare opportunity for visitors to crystallize their thinking about this monstrous prospect.
The museum and its partner in the project, the Environmental Defense Fund, recently opened a spectacular exhibition aimed not only at demonstrating the possibly imminent danger of global warming, but also at suggesting the possibility of salvation, provided that people everywhere begin pitching in. 
 The show, "Global Warming: Understanding the Forecast," occupies a substantial part of the museum's third floor and cost $3.7 million, making it one of the most expensive and elaborate temporary exhibitions the institution has mounted. It also breaks new ground.
"By attempting to look into the future, this exhibition is clearly different from anything we've done in the past," said Dr. George D. Langdon Jr., the museum's president. "We're not an advocacy organization, but our department heads agree that it's important for people to understand the scientific questions involved in the threat of global warming. We also believe that steps should be taken before it's too late."
 
A World Debate
 National leaders are meeting in Rio de Janeiro this week to consider environmental issues, and although many agree that urgent action is needed to head off global warming, President Bush, a participant in the meeting, does not. Mr. Bush's Administration contends that international regulations limiting the amount of carbon dioxide industries may emit would be enormously costly and not justified by the meager evidence that the world has already begun to warm up.
While rancorous debate among experts has not resolved this question, no one disputes the fact that carbon dioxide levels have been rising rapidly in this century and that at least in theory, their continued increase could cause global warming of up to 8 degrees in the 21st century.
The effects of the carbon dioxide may be offset, of course, by increased cloud cover reflecting sunlight away from Earth or by increased levels of sulfur dioxide produced by volcanoes (which increases cloud cover), or by many other mechanisms scientists have hypothesized -- none of them well understood.
But in some worst-case predictions, global warming could rapidly melt polar ice, raising sea levels and inundating Bangladesh, Venice and countless other places. The world's great granaries -- America's Midwest, Ukraine, Argentina and other regions -- might become arid semi-desert land, with incalculable effects on global food supplies.
A strength of the new exhibition is its wealth of displays clearly explaining some of the scientific methods and gadgets used to study Earth's climate. With money from Shearson Lehman Brothers, the National Science Foundation, the MacArthur Foundation, the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation and Turner Broadcasting Systems, the project was able to splurge on unusually elaborate displays.
For example, scientists seeking to calculate how carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere may have raised or lowered global temperatures in the past base some of their calculations on the study of ice buried deep in the Greenland and Antarctic ice caps. Ice core samples brought to the surface by drilling machines are windows into the past.
The age of such a sample can be determined accurately from its depth and the chemical and physical composition of its layers. Best of all, an ice-cap sample contains myriad tiny, highly compressed air bubbles trapped intact since the ice froze.
"Fossil" air in these tiny bubbles is immensely valuable to scientists. Not only does an ancient air bubble reveal how much carbon dioxide the atmosphere contained at a specific time in the past, but also oxygen isotopes trapped in the bubbles indicate the temperature of the atmosphere at that time as well.
 
Greenland Ice and Cows
 The display includes a freezer with a large window, through which viewers can look at a big chunk of real Greenland ice clouded by tiny bubbles of 660-year-old air.
Another eye-catcher is a model cow equipped with a gut represented by a twisted neon tube and a speaker emitting recorded cow burps. The point of the display is that hoofed animals digesting vegetable fodder burp enormous amounts of methane, which, with carbon dioxide, is one of the most potent "greenhouse" gases -- gases that prevent the sun's radiant energy from being reflected back into space. Cattle, mainstays of rural economies throughout the world, may be adding to the greenhouse problem.
An elderly woman said to a companion with whom she had just toured the exhibits: "This is just horrifying. I had no idea Earth was in such trouble. I'm so glad we came."
The climate debate is far from over, and to their credit, the museum and the Environmental Defense Fund offer viewers an assortment of dissenting views. Explanatory panels and interactive computer programs point out, for instance, that climate temperature varies widely and randomly, and that although the past decade has been unusually warm, the degree of warming is within the normal range of variability.
The museum and the Environmental Defense Fund might have skirted the contentious issue of birth control but chose instead to show how unchecked population growth is closely linked to carbon dioxide production and greenhouse warming. One display panel states that "to create a sustainable global society, we must both conserve our resources and stabilize population size" -- a view shared by most scientists but not by the Vatican, by many third world governments or by the Bush Administration.
"Our trustees properly insisted that we address this issue," Dr. Langdon said. "We've tried to do that without shaking our fingers at anyone."
Despite the publicity lavished on environmental problems in recent years, many people remain confused by or ignorant of the complicated facts and can benefit from guidance offered by the show, said Dr. Samuel M. Taylor, the museum's director of exhibitions.
The most common misconception, he said, is mistaking greenhouse warming (caused largely by carbon dioxide in the atmosphere) with the ozone hole (a completely different phenomenon probably caused by the release of chlorofluorocarbon compounds into the upper atmosphere).
Whether for education or the pleasure of strolling through an exceptionally well-conceived museum exhibition, "Global Warming" is worth an hour's visit.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Where to Learn More
 The show on global warming will remain at the American Museum of Natural History, at Central Park West and 79th Street in Manhattan, through Jan. 19, after which it will tour these museums:
Los Angeles County Natural History Museum (April 3 to July 25, 1993)
Carnegie Science Center, Pittsburgh (Sept. 24, 1993, to Feb. 13, 1994)
Milwaukee Public Museum (April 15, 1994, to Sept. 5, 1994)
Denver Museum of Natural History (Nov. 4, 1994, to March 26 1995)
St. Louis Science Center (May 26, 1995, to Oct. 15, 1995)
National Museum of Natural History in Washington (Dec. 15, 1995, to May 5, 1996)
On weekdays, the exhibition is usually crowded with school groups, but museum officials say it is much quieter on Friday and Saturday evenings. On those days the museum is open from 10 A.M. until 8:45 P.M. On other days it is open from 10 A.M. until 5:45 P.M. Suggested museum admission: $5 for adults and $2.50 for children. Information: (212) 769-5100.

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
Homage to One of Italian Art's Great Draftsmen

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH

 BODY:
The Drawing Center in SoHo typically features the work of young and unknown artists who are pushing at the limits of the medium. "Marking Time," a group show seen at the center in the fall, presented big installation pieces that took drawing into three-dimensional space. And in March a show called "Darkness Visible" followed the medium into popular culture, displaying the efforts of professional cartoonists alongside those of cartoon-oriented artists.
But each season, the center mounts at least one show that has its feet planted in the past, and that underscores the breadth of this small, exemplary institution. This year the offering is "Guercino: Drawings From Windsor Castle," an often exhilarating display of 60 sheets by the 17th-century Italian Baroque painter that should appeal to anyone interested in drawing and its traditions. 
 The show pays homage to one of Italian art's great draftsmen, a largely self-taught artist whose real name was Giovanni Francesco Barbieri and who was born in the town of Cento in Emilia-Romagna in 1591. He was known by his nickname, Il Guercino (the Squinter), because of a childhood accident.
One of several exhibitions in the United States and Europe that celebrate the 400th anniversary of Guercino's birth, the new show is a collaborative effort between the Drawing Center, the National Gallery in Washington and the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth.
The drawings are chronologically arranged from the artist's early efforts in the 1610's to near his death in 1666. They have been selected from the 350 verified Guercino drawings that were acquired by the crown of England in the mid-1700's, when George III, an especially avid collector of drawings, was king.
As a painter Guercino worked in different styles during his long and successful career. Earlier on he combined the disparate influences of Carravaggio, the Carracci and great 16th-century Venetian masters like Titian to create works that, at their best, number among the masterpieces of the Baroque. His later paintings are in the more classical style of Guido Reni.
As a draftsman Guercino was a natural virtuoso at ease in all media, the master of a fluid, endlessly varied style infused with a vivacity and freedom that his paintings often lacked. With pen and ink he could create dramatic contrasts of light and shadow, often needing just a few marks to imbue bare paper with a striking suggestion of midday sun. In oiled charcoal he created images so delicate that they seem almost atomized, more dusted than drawn onto the page.
In those media, and red or black chalk, Guercino created both quick sketches and finished studies for commissioned religious works, humorous caricatures and grotesques, and also marvelously economical landscapes that were primarily made for his own pleasure.
The drawings display a consummate awareness and even wit about the drawing process itself.
In "Three Bathers Surprised by a Monster," one of the show's most inventive works, Guercino allows accidental splashes of ink to generate the image. Some of the blots become muddy water that the bathers splash in the direction of the intruder. Other blots determine the monster's grotesque features, although they can also be read as mud being flung in his face.
In "Holy Family With Saints John the Baptist and Anne," an elaborate scene made for an engraver to convert into a print, he incorporates another amusing detail: the image is outlined to create the trompe l'oeil effect of a sheet of paper pinned to a wall.
After its virtuosity the most salient characteristic of Guercino's style is its diversity. A robust naturalism informs much of his art. In his dramatic rendering of "Apollo Flaying Marsyas," the god is shown literally tearing the skin from the satyr's arm. In "The Annunciation" the muscular angel seems depicted in the midst of landing at Mary's feet.
Nonetheless this naturalism was continually adjusted, tailored to each drawing's purpose, subject or material. His religious and mythological studies could be operatic, as in the red-chalk rendition of a recoiling, voluptuous Aurora, who draws her cape across her body.
Or they could be defined by spare flourishes of nearly abstract line. In more than one of the artist's quick pen-and-ink sketches, bodies are described by little more than elegant scribbles that can even bring to mind Picasso or Jackson Pollock. In "Semele and Jupiter," the contrast of loosely drawn, almost caricatural, bodies and carefully detailed, darkly expressive faces seems almost to presage Picasso's "Minotaur" etchings.
When Guercino's subjects were more down to earth, so was his style. In "Three Peasants Picnicking" the roughness of the peasants is matched by the artist's blunt touch and simple forms. A more understated treatment, and greater psychological depth, is seen in "Standing Beggar," where a tall haggard figure, who seems almost too proud to beg, steps tentatively forward.
While the speed and spontaneity of Guercino's sketches can be dazzling, when seen in multiple, they also reflect the care with which he considered and reconsidered an image before committing it to canvas.
In one pen-and-ink-and-wash study for "Assassination of Amnon at the Feast of His Half Brother Absalom," an image fraught with dramatic gestures and contrasts of light and dark, the attackers lunge at their victim across a table, while Absalom turns to flee, as if horrified by the execution he has masterminded.
A second sketch is remarkably different. Here the assassins stand over their victim while Absalom, wearing a plumed hat, remains seated and completely composed, watching and savoring the moment of revenge.
Pushing both the composition and the psychological content of the event in one direction and then the other, the two works show Guercino as a master of narrative invention. And, like much else in this extraordinary show, they also convey a marvelously immediate, even intimate, portrait of the artist at work.
"Guercino: Drawings from Windsor Castle" is at the Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, in SoHo, through Aug. 1.

GRAPHIC: Drawing: "Holy Family With Saints John the Baptist and Anne" by Guercino is being shown at the Drawing Center in SoHo. (Royal Library Windsor Castle)

HEADLINE: Restaurants

BYLINE: By Bryan Miller

 BODY:
Before restaurant chefs began touting homey, assertive food as the wave of the 90's, Alison on Dominick was turning out just that for its scores of faithful customers. This unassuming three-year-old spot in the western fringe of SoHo has survived the crushing recession (and a neighborhood that stumps all but the most seasoned taxi drivers) by offering consistently enticing fare and warm hospitality. A simple formula indeed but one that is often neglected.
The restaurant is named for its owner, Alison Price, an engaging and vigilant host who oversees a well-disciplined staff. Since opening day the chef has been Thomas Valenti, whom Miss Price worked with at Gotham Bar and Grill in Manhattan. 
The compact main dining room is soft and understated, with pastel-colored walls holding black-and-white photographs, royal blue banquettes and indirect lighting. The noise level is surprisingly low considering the size of the space.
If there is a minor shortcoming here, especially for repeat customers, it is a moderate-size menu that usually lacks more than one special supplement. But for first-time visitors there are ample winners from which to choose. Among starters there is a vernal vegetable tart combining slices of tomato, eggplant and zucchini all doused with a roasted tomato vinaigrette. Duck carpaccio is enriched with a well-seasoned lentil salad. And a ziggurat of gravlax is built upon a delicious chickpea pancake and garnished with salmon and whitefish eggs.
On the lighter side is a pellucid tomato consomme that evokes midsummer, holding a delicate seafood-and-leek sausage and shiitake mushrooms. And if you want to splurge, try the sparkling foie gras studded with asparagus, string beans and artichoke hearts.
Alison has a quality wine selection featuring some relatively unknown gems, especially among French labels. Prices are average.
Mr. Valenti's robust style extends to seafood, too. Exceptionally delicate sauteed skate is combined with savoy cabbage, crispy potatoes, pearl onions and cubes of smoked pork. Surprisingly, the fish was not overshadowed by this high-powered company. Halibut is roasted to perfection and served in a lustrous shellfish broth with shallots, tomato, pearl onions and tiny noodles. Tuna did not receive such beneficial treatment. The seared fillet arrived dry, sitting in a mushroom broth with a good white-bean puree on the side. And poached lobster with basil ravioli came in a complex vegetable and lobster broth. One of the best seafood options is roasted swordfish is wrapped in bacon and accompanied by lentils and sauteed potatoes.
Game is always a good bet here. Sauteed squab is ruddy and full-flavored, its breast meat fanned over a duxelle and the legs perched on top like a garnish. Roasted barley and smoked shallots are harmonious accompaniments. And talk about homey, the braised lamb shank with white and fava beans, chicory and a roasted garlic sauce could bring tears to your eyes. By comparison, roast guinea hen was not so memorable. The bird was well cooked and only slightly seasoned and came with a gluey black-olive-and-thyme risotto.
After this high-impact palate workout, a sharp lemon tart is a nice cleanser, as is a lovely mixed fruit tart with layers of plums and orange sections. Creme brulee is lightweight and passable. Try instead the chewy hazelnut torte with banana ice cream or the intense cantaloupe bavaroise.
With gutsy cooking and professional hospitality like this, it's no wonder Alison on Dominick Street continues to be one of the more popular restaurants in SoHo.
 
Alison on Dominick

HEADLINE: Denmark Needn't Derail Europe

 BODY:
Danish voters shocked the European Community by voting down ambitious plans for economic and political union. But the immediate crisis need not halt the lowering of barriers within Western Europe. And if Denmark's partners adapt to the vote imaginatively, they could make it easier for the Community to reach out to the formerly Communist East.
Denmark specifically rejected the Maastricht treaty, which provides, among other things, for the introduction of a common European currency by 1999. The referendum is the clearest sign yet that Europeans are uneasy about surrendering the attributes of sovereignty to a centralized authority. In several countries, this unease is heightened by suspicions that the new Europe may be dominated by Germany and other big states. 
 To Americans, those fears seem exaggerated. Washington rightly sees West European integration as a way to dampen old national conflicts and promote worldwide economic growth. But the U.S. also has an interest in extending integration further east, where newly capitalist countries struggle to overcome a demoralizing legacy.
Because the Maastricht treaty amended the Community's basic charter, it legally required unanimous approval by all 12 member states. That is no longer possible. Denmark's "no" vote may force the E.C. to establish different levels of membership. That, in turn, would make it much easier to embrace the East.
Some of the Community's integration plans do not directly depend on Maastricht. And others that do, like foreign policy coordination and joint citizenship, could still be agreed to by a subset of Community states. One group of Maastricht provisions, known as the social charter, already exempts Britain -- establishing a precedent for a Europe with two or more tracks.
France and Germany resist expanding Community membership at this time. Their concept of integration is premised on the existing 12 partners increasingly harmonizing their institutions. To start from scratch with outsiders, they say, particularly when they are as poor and different as the Eastern countries, threatens to dilute and delay the integration process.
But this French-German approach, formulated years ago and embodied last December in the Maastricht treaty, became obsolescent with the fall of the Berlin wall. Britain, never enthusiastic about harmonized institutions, sensibly presses for early expansion.
Now all European leaders are compelled to think anew. In accommodating Denmark and, on other issues, Britain, they may also find arrangements to accommodate the East. Denmark's "no" could yet contribute to wider European unity.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Silver Lining for Eurodoom

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Very bad week for Europe, the troubadours of doom will sing for weeks. Perhaps the idea of a united Western Europe was buried in Denmark. Southeastern Europe is going up in flames. And the great Russian experiment in democracy and free enterprise is collapsing.
But these troubles could prove beneficial. European leaders have been marching along with dreams of their cohesiveness that belie reality. Reformist technicians in Russia have been out of touch with suffering workers. The leaders need wake-up calls to address tough questions about ends and means, questions that have become politically incorrect even to ask. Midcourse corrections are now in order. 
When the shock of Tuesday's Danish vote against currency union subsides, Western Europeans will find a way to continue toward greater unity. But it will be slower and with more attention to gaining popular support -- and holding on to the security connection with the U.S.
As the horror of Yugoslavia sets in and as it becomes apparent that Europe cannot respond to such crises, Europeans may look more constructively at preserving American leadership. NATO's decision yesterday to offer peacekeeping services to Europe is thus encouraging.
As Russia struggles with economic chaos, its leaders will have to pull back and strike a balance between market reforms and public backing. Free marketeers will scream, but President Yeltsin was wise this week not to sacrifice democracy on the altar of economic reform.
The end of the cold war caused Mr. Yeltsin, Chancellor Kohl and others to hurtle toward their dreams -- political unity or collective security or capitalism -- somewhat breathlessly and without people power.
Only a bare majority of Danes voted against the Maastricht treaty and the drive to a common West European currency. But their anxiety surely resonates beyond Denmark: of having national identity swallowed up by faceless bureaucrats of the European Community and big European powers.
Many Danes who voted for the treaty did so not out of conviction, but from fear of being left off the common economic bandwagon. Their leaders were far ahead of them in abandoning sovereignty. This feeling, too, may be widely felt elsewhere in West Europe.
It may also turn out that most Danes worried about the Maastricht commitment to a common foreign and defense policy. Perhaps they saw for the first time that this would mean greater reliance on French and German military power and less on the U.S. and NATO. And perhaps that gave many Europeans a sense of unease, and prematurity. Perhaps Bonn and Paris now will reconsider their plan for a joint army corps that seems to undercut ties to Washington and NATO.
To see the importance of these old ties, Europeans have only to flip on their television sets and gaze on the Bosnian massacres. European leaders could not deal with that situation on their own. Washington nonetheless stood back in the early days of the Yugoslav crisis and let the Europeans take the lead. Soon it became painfully clear that they could agree only on exhortations of peace.
Europeans could not even pull together on economic sanctions against Serbia. The Bush Administration had to step in last week to organize such a resolution at the U.N. The experience was not pleasant for European leaders. But it must have brought home to them the indispensability of American leadership. That could prove useful when and if they realize the need for further action to stop the fighting and keep it from spreading.
Lost in the Bosnian bloodshed and the Danish vote were decisions by Boris Yeltsin to recalibrate economic reforms. He ordered the printing of more money to pay off potential strikers, thus producing higher deficits and inflation. He also replaced some reform-minded ministers with conservatives.
International Monetary Fund bureaucrats will protest and threaten to deny pending loans. But Mr. Yeltsin's goals remain the right ones. And if he is to stay in power, he has to prevent mass unemployment and compromise with a conservative Parliament.
Setbacks and retrenchment for Russian and Western European leaders could turn out well. They needed a dose of political realism.

HEADLINE: Care for Environment Doesn't Hurt Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Environment Laws Are Eased by Bush as Election Nears" (front page, May 20) highlights a phenomenon that Americans have seen before.
George Bush and Jimmy Carter both entered the White House as declared environmentalists, and both took some noteworthy steps. It is troubling to see President Bush in a campaign year succumbing to the same temptation that befell President Carter some 12 years ago: blaming environmental protection for the country's economic problems. 
 Mr. Carter, facing rampant inflation, deputized Robert Strauss to lead a White House brigade against new regulations. As Mr. Bush responds in kind to recession, only the names have changed: the White House group is now the Council on Competitiveness; the deputy is Dan Quayle.
Time and again, Democrats and Republicans facing tough economic times have tried to set up the environment as a fall guy. According to this cartoon logic, anti-environment means pro-economy. Our leaders know better. For example, United States utilities have been making more profit from conservation than they would from building new power plants, avoiding giant amounts of pollution into the bargain for years.
Like economic regulations, environmental regulations can foster competition and creativity or stifle them. It depends on how the rules are written. No one wants silly or unnecessary regulations. Government must set strong, clear, enforceable goals to protect the environment, but industry must use its smartest and most innovative methods to reach those goals. A response to that challenge must take place in the real world.
The challenge this election year is for all candidates, Republicans, Demomcrats and independents, to recognize that a healthy environment and a strong economy depend on each other.
 
FRED KRUPP
Executive Director
Environmental Defense Fund
New York, May 21, 1992

HEADLINE: Care for Environment Doesn't Hurt Economy;
Where's the Evidence?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In your May 8 front-page article on the global warming negotiations at the United Nations in preparation for the Earth Summit meeting in Rio de Janeiro, you report: "Scientists who are advising the talks here say that if the heat-trapping greenhouse gases continue to build up in the atmosphere at present rates, the earth's climate will warm by 3 to 8 degrees Fahrenheit by the end of the next century, with possibly catastrophic effects on the world's climate."
John B. Oakes (Op-Ed, May 8) writes of "a catastrophe in the making that, unless checked, will raise sea levels, drown coastal areas and change agricultural production before the end of the 21st century." 
 Those judgments cannot be supported by hard and consistent scientific evidence. Some of the country's leading scientists, working through the George C. Marshall Institute, recently concluded that "computer models have considerably exaggerated the size of the greenhouse effect" and that "the sun has been the controlling influence on climate in the last 100 years, with the greenhouse effect playing a smaller role . . . a few tenths of a degree."
According to Charles River Associates, an economics research organization also doing studies on this issue, a mandate to stabilize carbon dioxide emissions at or below current levels in the United States could require a new tax of $200 a ton of carbon burned. That would mean a new tax on oil of $26 a barrel, on natural gas of $3.20 per thousand cubic feet and on coal of $120 a ton -- more than doubling oil and natural gas prices and increasing the price of coal fivefold.
This could mean a 2 percent drop in our gross national product in the last half of the 1990's, resulting in a drastic impact on jobs, as well as on our standard of living. We are facing the equivalent of a $100 billion tax on Americans without solid scientific evidence.
 
WILLIAM F. O'KEEFE
Executive Vice President
American Petroleum Institute
Washington, May 15, 1992

HEADLINE: Care for Environment Doesn't Hurt Economy;
Clean Is Profitable

 BODY:
To the Editor:
News coverage of the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro has focused on concerns that the treaty on global warming could harm the United States economy by raising the cost of electrical power.
Yes, the United States produces almost one-quarter of the greenhouse gases, and accepting the Rio terms would require it to make a larger investment to reduce these gases to 1990 levels than any other country. 
 However, there are also potential economic benefits. The Earth Summit is the first official step in creating a global, electric power industry with opportunities for United States electric utilities to move into the global export market.
If the United States complies with the treaty, developing countries will have a greater incentive to invest in more environmentally sound power operation practices and technologies. And these countries are likely to turn to United States utilities for counsel, design and construction, perhaps even facility management.
By the end of the century, utilities such as Consolidated Edison of New York, Public Service Enterprises, General Public Utilities, Long Island Lighting Company or Allegheny Power System could well have power production or management interests in far corners of the globe.
This is not a far-fetched economic benefit. Two large United States utilities are exploring international energy opportunities. And Electricite de France, once a domestic utility, has profitable contracts or investments in more than 50 countries. It is the world's largest electricity producer and exporter, with one of the world's lowest greenhouse gas emission rates.
 
HENRY HERBIN
President, Electricite de France International, North America
Washington, May 18, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 315 words

HEADLINE: Care for Environment Doesn't Hurt Economy;
Democracy Overridden

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Bush Administration's use of appointed, unelected "Cabinet level" panels to eviscerate major environmental laws deserves more scrutiny. The stunning "override" of the Endangered Species Act by a panel of Bush appointees (front page, May 15) and the efforts of Vice President Quayle's Council on Competitiveness, another so-called Cabinet-level panel, to gut the Clean Air Act should prompt vigorous debate on whether or not the power exercised by these panels is legitimate or a flagrant abuse of the governmental process.
More is at stake than foul air and loss of old-growth forests. When people follow due process and work for a law, and it is enacted by their elected representatives, they have every right to expect it to remain intact. When laws are systematically dismantled by panels that are havens for industry lobbyists and party fund raisers who could not advance their agendas through the legislative process, fundamental questions arise. 
 Word has it that industry lobbyists no longer worry too much about what happens in Congress; they can get what they want elsewhere, outside of the pesky legislative arena.
The disturbing possibility that our air, water, old-growth forests and spotted owls are being sold to enrich Bush campaign coffers merits at least as much press attention as the Gennifer Flowers hoopla, and the latest quid pro quo was hard to miss: the day after the Republican $9 million fund-raising dinner, President Bush announced yet another three-month delay in implementing the Clean Air Act. The only question remaining here is how much the Clean Air Act sold for.
The Administration's latest accomplishment, weakening international global warming initiatives to be considered at the Rio Earth Summit, is a national disgrace.
 
SUSAN RUSSELL
Little Silver, N.J., May 18, 1992
 
The writer is a lobbyist for wildlife.

HEADLINE: THE EARTH SUMMIT;
12 Sign the Climate Treaty As Political Clouds Gather

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 4

 BODY:
In the first substantive act of the Earth Summit, a dozen nations signed a climate treaty today to curb gas emissions, but three European countries considered taking much stronger action on their own.
The new declaration by the European nations would commit signers to stabilize the emission of gases that trap heat in the atmosphere at 1990 levels, and then to make further cuts. It would also set a deadline of 2000 to reach stabilization. 
 If the new declaration gains widespread support, it would embarrass the United States, which plans to sign the climate treaty but does not want to see it tightened.
Scientists fear that rising levels of carbon dioxide, methane and other heat-trapping gases could cause a potentially catastrophic warming of the Earth's climate.
Austria, Switzerland and the Netherlands presented the new proposal.
 
U.S. Still Opposed
 A United States delegate said Washington was strongly opposed to the proposal, seeing it as an attempt to rewrite a key provision of the climate treaty governing specific commitments to be made by industrial countries. The United States had persuaded the Europeans to accept far weaker treaty language by threatening that President Bush would not attend the Earth Summit.
For the nations that endorse it, the new declaration would be in addition to the climate treaty. Countries could sign both the treaty, which would commit them to a minimum course of action, and the declaration, which would commit them to go further.
Hugo Haider, the Austrian Minister of Environment, said a decision on whether to offer the proposal formally would be made this week.
President Fernando Collor de Mello of Brazil became the first head of government to sign the climate treaty, in a 20-minute ceremony at which Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali of the United Nations acknowledged that the agreement "falls short of the initial hopes of many negotiators."
 
What Treaty Demands
 But Mr. Boutros-Ghali said the treaty contains important commitments. "One may hope," he said, "that its very modesty will motivate governments and observers to maintain constructive pressure" to strengthen the treaty as the nature of the warming threat and its economic implications become clearer.
The treaty commits signatories to stabilize concentrations of heat-trapping gases at environmentally safe levels over the long term. Because concentrations are continuing to build up at present rates of emission, the objective could be achieved only by reducing emissions.
As a first step, the treaty requires industrial countries, which emit most of the gases, to cap emissions at 1990 levels, but it sets no timetable. Instead, the industrial nations would simply recognize that returning to "earlier levels" of emissions by the end of this decade would advance the treaty's overall objective.
The treaty also sets up a process for inspecting each nation's progress and for taking stronger action, if necessary, as more becomes known about the threat.
 
The 12 That Signed
 In addition to Brazil, the treaty was signed by Antigua and Barbuda, Australia, Belgium, Finland, Iceland, Israel, Liechtenstein, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway and Uruguay.
Austria, Switzerland and the Netherlands, who offered the proposal to make the climate treaty more effective, were among the leaders in pushing for a stronger treaty in the first place.
The three countries "are very frustrated and are trying to put the limelight on the countries that have weakened the treaty," said Richard Mott, of the World Wildlife Fund. "They are trying to defeat lowest-common-denominator politics."
A separate agreement by the Europeans "would be very embarrassing to the United States," said Liz Barratt-Brown, of the Natural Resources Defense Council.
 
Why U.S. Objects
 The United States objects that the initiative seeks to return the treaty to the discussion stage rather than put its provisions into effect.
Washington maintains that energy-efficiency programs already under way will bring the United States very close to meeting a deadline of 2000, but that it does not want to be compelled to meet the deadline because it cannot be sure of doing so without cost to the nation's economy.
The climate treaty will go into effect when 50 countries ratify it. Backers said they were confident that many more than 50 nations would sign it, the first step toward ratification, before the Earth Summit ends on June 14. It will remain open for signing for a year.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 6, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about a climate treaty being signed at the Earth Summit included incorrect information from the Austrian delegation about the title of an Austrian official, Hugo Haider. He is deputy director general of the Federal Ministry of Environment, Youth and Family, not the Minister of Environment.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Third-Party Candidate;
Perot's Vision: Consensus by Computer

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5

 BODY:
Twenty-three years ago, Ross Perot had a simple idea.
The nation was splintered by the great and painful issues of the day. There had been years of disorder and disunity, and lately, terrible riots in Los Angeles and other cities. People talked of an America in crisis. The Government seemed to many to be ineffectual and out of touch. 
 What this country needed, Mr. Perot thought, was a good, long talk with itself.
The information age was dawning, and Mr. Perot, then building what would become one of the world's largest computer-processing companies, saw in its glow the answer to everything.
 
One Hour, One Issue
 Every week, Mr. Perot proposed, the television networks would broadcast an hourlong program in which one issue would be discussed. Viewers would record their opinions by marking computer cards, which they would mail to regional tabulating centers. Consensus would be reached, and the leaders would know what the people wanted.
Mr. Perot gave his idea a name that draped the old dream of pure democracy with the glossy promise of technology: "the electronic town hall."
Today, Mr. Perot's idea, essentially unchanged from 1969, is at the core of his "We the People" drive for the Presidency, and of his theory for governing.
It forms the basis of Mr. Perot's pitch, in which he presents himself, not as a politician running for President, but as a patriot willing to be drafted "as a servant of the people" to take on the "dirty, thankless" job of rescuing America from "the Establishment," and running it.
In set speeches and interviews, the Texas billionaire describes the electronic town hall as the principal tool of governance in a Perot Presidency, and he makes grand claims: "If we ever put the people back in charge of this country and make sure they understand the issues, you'll see the White House and Congress, like a ballet, pirouetting around the stage getting it done in unison."
Although Mr. Perot has repeatedly said he would not try to use the electronic town hall as a direct decision-making body, he has on other occasions suggested placing a startling degree of power in the hands of the television audience.
He has proposed at least twice -- in an interview with David Frost broadcast on April 24 and in a March 18 speech at the National Press Club -- passing a constitutional amendment that would strip Congress of its authority to levy taxes, and place that power directly in the hands of the people, in a debate and referendum orchestrated through an electronic town hall.
Once the danger of the nation's huge debt was explained properly, Mr. Perot theorized: "The people will say, 'All right, the responsible thing to do is to raise taxes on ourselves.' And that leads to the next question: What should the tax system be?" The answer to that, again, would rest in the hands of those quickest to reach for the telephone. The new Federal tax system, Mr. Perot said, "would be conceived, worked out, and agreed to by the American people through the town hall."
Mr. Perot has said he would be willing to resign the Presidency if enough people dialed in to tell him to do so, in a sort of 1-800-CAN-ROSS campaign. "I would just go through the town hall," he told Mr. Frost. "I'd say, 'Now, would you be happier if someone replaced me?' If the answer came back 'Yes,' then I would say 'That's fine.' "
 
The Magic of Technology
 To many who support Mr. Perot, and even to many who do not, the idea of an electronic town hall has a powerful appeal. It holds the promise of a magical, technological, answer to all they have come to hate about the ways of Washington -- the endless gridlocked repetition of arguments so old and tired they have been reduced to catch phrases and code words, the corruptive influence of lobbyists and interest groups, the insulation of the political elite from the rest of the population, the shallowness of a debate framed by the forces of journalism.
"The great story of 1992 is the degree to which voters feel disconnected from their political system by the insulation of a professional political class, comprising politicians, the press and the pressure elite," said Will Marshall, director of the centrist, Washington-based Progressive Policy Institute. "People are yearning to be part of a democratic conversation with their Government, their leaders, and they now feel they are isolated by the political class, which has arrogated the conversation to itself."
But Mr. Marshall, and many who study the relationship between the public and public policy -- demographers, poll takers and political scientists -- fear that Mr. Perot's idea would make worse the very ills it proposes to correct. It is, they say, an awkward, unworkable hybrid -- New England town hall meets Brave New World -- founded on a series of false assumptions, and likely to push a process already characterized by superficiality, special-interest biases and demagoguery further in that direction.
 
Ex-Astronaut Looks Back
 One who believes that strongly is the former astronaut Frank Borman, the man Mr. Perot hired to guide the concept in its first, failed go-around.
"I would not now be in favor of an electronic town hall," Mr. Borman said last week. "I don't think you can take an extremely complex issue and air it completely in a half-hour or hour of television so that people will gain an informed understanding. I don't think you can govern 250 million people with a TV set."
Mr. Borman said he had come to believe that an electronic town hall would become a "national platform" for demagoguery with "enormous potential for manipulating the emotions of people," and could intimidate Congress into abandoning itself utterly to satisfying whatever seemed the people's will that week. "I have come to see," he said, "that greatness in governing is not achieved by simply following the will of the masses."
The way Mr. Perot and his aides see it, all of this would make Government more responsive to the will of the people. "The whole point is to inform the people about what we believe is the best solution," Mr. Perot said. "I want everybody to get involved in the process, not just the elite."
But demographers and poll takers say it is not true that the response of the people choosing to telephone their sentiments would represent the real will of the people in that Congressman's district, or nationally.
"This would look like a scientific survey, but it would not be at all," said Norman Bradburn, director of the National Opinion Research Center at the University of Chicago.
Given the American television public's often-demonstrated lack of interest in public affairs programming, Mr. Bradburn predicted that the electronic town hall would regularly attract responses from only 1 or 2 percent of America's 120 million households. Computer checks to screen against repeat-callers would necessarily limit each household to only one response, regardless of the number of people dwelling within.
The people in those households, Mr. Bradburn said, would almost certainly be what demographers call "the attentive public," those people who routinely pay attention to matters of politics and policy. "These people," he said, "are richer, more educated, the kind of people who are already well connected to the political dialogue." In fact, he said, they are the very elites from whom Mr. Perot wishes to wrest control.
Other people who would respond to an electronic town hall, he said, would be "people who are already sending mail to their Congressmen" -- causists and cranks of one stripe or another, and agents of advocacy groups. "The system will quickly become the tool of special interests: just another, more expensive way for advocacy groups to bombard Congress with their views. Ultimately, it will wither away."
Moreover, the self-selecting nature of the electronic town hall would necessarily result in a false picture of what the public wanted.
Because people who choose to participate in a survey tend to be those who feel most passionately, poll takers say, an electronic town hall would necessarily present a false picture of what the public wanted.
The closest thing ever tried to Mr. Perot's town hall was a CBS News program on Jan. 28 called "America on the Line." Viewers were invited to call a toll-free number to register their opinions on the President's handling of the economy. The program drew calls from about 3 million people, and more than 300,000 calls actually got through the overburdened switchboards.
Mr. Perot has cited the CBS program as an example of how his town hall would work. But those who produced the program say what happened illustrates why an electronic town hall could not result in a true plebiscite.
The opinions recorded by those who chose to call in their views were in significant ways different from those of the scientifically selected group that CBS surveyed at the same time, said Kathleen Frankovic, the director of surveys for CBS News.
"For instance," she said, "when we asked if George Bush cared about the needs and problems of middle-class people, 70 percent of the people who chose to call in said he did not, while only 57 percent of those surveyed in the national survey of 1,241 people said this."
One reason for this is that people responding to a question are powerfully affected by what they see and hear in the moments before the question is asked.
In the case of the CBS program, for example, the unrepresentatively harsh judgment of Mr. Bush may have reflected the fact that they had just watched an interview with a weeping unemployed man.
A television program on an any emotionally charged issue would inevitably affect the views of those watching it, producing a gathering of opinion distorted by the very act of gathering it.
Since Mr. Perot's Administration would be in charge of producing the program, it would be simple to choreograph it through the selection of speakers, the scripting of questions, and the use of television-appealing "real people" testimony.
"It just gives me the shudders, the potential for manipulation, the one-sidedness, that a thing like this could do," said Mr. Bradburn.
 
 
 
'ELECTRONIC TOWN HALL': HOW IT MIGHT OPERATE<He>
Much about the electronic town hall concept has not been fully described by Mr. Perot. But, in recent interviews, Mr. Perot and two of his top political aides, Thomas D. Barr, a lawyer, and James Squires, his press spokesman, sketched out a reasonably detailed outline of the idea:
The Meeting -- The events would be staged on an irregular basis, each one devoted to a single issue: -- gun control, for instance, or abortion, or taxes. Each would be scheduled at least several weeks in advance and the Administration would ask the television networks to broadcast them, as is now the case with major Presidential addresses and news conferences.
The Discussion -- Mr. Perot's Administration would arrange a television discussion between Administration officials, Congressional leaders and selected experts. Mr. Perot suggested the discussion would focus on the arguments for and against a single course of action, the one proposed by his Administration. But Mr. Barr said the Talks would be broader than that, encompassing as many as three or four options the Government might take.
The Choice -- After the program, viewers would be asked to choose among the options. Theoretically, they could do this through push-button interactive devices attached to their television sets, or by mailing in special postcards. But interactive television is still in the planning stages, and poll takerssters doubt many people would take the trouble to take part in a mail campaign.
The Taly -- At least in the beginning, most responses would come from people with touch-tone telephones punching in their choices to computers linked with toll-free "800" telephone numbers.
The responses would be tabulated, and grouped by telephone company computers according to Congressional district. Each member of Congress would then be given a written run-down of the opinions cast by respondents in his or her Congressional district (or districts, in the case of Senators).

PUB-DATE: June 6, 1992

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1365 words

HEADLINE: U.S. BEGINS TALKS ON OUTSIDE FORCE TO STABILIZE HAITI

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5

 BODY:
Bush Administration officials said today that they have begun talks on a plan that, for the first time, would involve the dispatch of an international peacekeeping force to Haiti as part of a political settlement restoring the Government of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
The initiative being discussed with Caribbean and Latin American leaders would require the opposing forces in Haiti to commit themselves to the return of Father Aristide, who was overthrown by the military last September. 
 In return, the army would be included in the selection by consensus of a prime minister to serve under President Aristide. Simultaneously, an international force would be sent to the Caribbean country under the authority of the Organization of American States or the United Nations, and the O.A.S. embargo against Haiti would be lifted.
 
No Word Yet on Whose Troops
 Officials said the discussions have not reached the stage where the makeup of an international force had been broached.
Although other agreements have stalled in the eight months since the coup, there is now a feeling that the deteriorating situation in Haiti has added a sense of urgency.
"We believe that time is running out," a senior Administration official said, noting that civil unrest is building there amid indications that the army leader, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, is no longer in control of all his forces.
The new moves come as Congress prepares legislation that would reverse an order by President Bush to return Haitian refugees picked up at sea without giving them the opportunity to seek asylum, and as reports mount that the embargo has been ineffective.
Today, a Federal judge in Brooklyn upheld the Administration's order on forced returns. But the judge, Sterling Johnson Jr. of the Eastern District of New York, called the policy "unconscionable" in light of American commitments to international refugee agreements. He was constrained in making his decision, he said, by previous rulings on refugee policy.
A political agreement on Haiti would strengthen the Administration's argument that fleeing Haitians are not politically oppressed. The Administration has been nagged by criticism that its tough refugee policy is at odds with its publicly professed commitment to protect the Haitians' rights.
"It's just two trains heading for each other on the same track," said Holly Burkhalter, Washington director of Human Rights Watch. "The policy of forcing Haitians to return also forces the Administration to cover up abuses in Haiti. It may be that we have competing goals."
The senior Administration official said the renewed talks with governments of the region are aimed at finding a prime ministerial nominee agreeable to the broadest range of Haitians.
In February, Father Aristide and the leaders of Parliament reached an agreement under which Rene Theodore, a Communist, would serve as prime minister in a reconstructed government under an Aristide presidency. But that accord was rejected by the military leadership; by Joseph Nerette, whom the army had installed as president, and by a Supreme Court packed with military appointees.
 
Next Move May Be Aristide's
 On Wednesday, the Government proposed another formula under which Marc Bazin, a conservative economist, would be prime minister and the presidency would be left open with the resignation of Mr. Nerette.
Administration officials believe that this was a step forward by those now in control in Port-au-Prince, and that further progress depends on Father Aristide's willingness to compromise.
But the exiled President has said that he cannot accept the nominee of an illegal leadership, and he is backed in that position by the Organization of American States.
In Congress, among analysts and in some offices of government, there is a growing view that the United States Administration may be getting ready to back away from support of Father Aristide if he does not agree to another prime minister and the introduction of an O.A.S. force.
Robert E. White, Ambassador to El Salvador under President Jimmy Carter and now an analyst at the Center for International Policy, said:
"In effect, United States policy has always been to try to return Aristide, but at the same time to put limitations on his power by strengthening the traditional Haitian elites. The man who was supposedly stubborn and unwilling to deal -- Aristide -- is the man who has made all the concessions. Our friends, the military, have proved utterly intransigent."
Mr. Bush's officials disagree and say that their policy on Haiti has to be studied with a longer perspective. They say the President made a significant commitment to guaranteeing the free elections of December 1990 that brought victory with two-thirds of the vote to Father Aristide, a novice politician with a following among the poor.
 
Initial U.S. Response Lauded
 Douglas W. Payne, director of hemispheric studies at Freedom House in New York, said in an interview that the Administration's initial responses to the coup were good ones.
American aid was suspended, and the economic embargo was achieved. Mr. Payne said these policies ran into trouble because of circumstances in Haiti, where political and economic institutions have been weak or nonexistent.
Trade there, he said, is dominated by smugglers working for well-connected families. These people have been able to continue dealing in contraband, including narcotics, almost without interruption under the embargo.
Europeans' failure to back economic sanctions assisted this trade and made above-board purchases possible. An American business executive in Haiti said in a recent interview that while she preferred using American suppliers for imports, she had no trouble switching to European companies after the embargo went into effect in November.
Mr. Payne said that any political agreement that might involve Mr. Bazin should include the stipulation that aid to Haiti would be resumed on American terms and under American supervision, preferably through international relief agencies with networks in the countryside.
"If indeed the United States feels compelled, for whatever reason, to do business with Mr. Bazin," he said, "any type of aid has to bypass government agencies -- which, as reconstructed under the Duvaliers, became private endowments for those who control them." He referred to the successive dictatorships of Francois Duvalier and his son, Jean-Claude Duvalier, who ruled the country from 1957 to 1986.
Like Father Aristide and a number of analysts, Mr. Payne says he believes that blocking oil shipments to Haiti would be the most effective measure the Administration could take. But this would presumably lead to some form of military action at sea, perhaps in time a blockade.
In fact, analysts say, if the new round of talks on a political solution collapse and violence rises significantly, more than a blockade may have to be considered.
 
Rights Advocate Is Outraged
 "Intervention is the last option left," said Arthur C. Helton, director of the refugee program for the Lawyers' Committee for Human Rights, who added that the continuing flow of refugees might ultimately force the use of arms to restore order in Haiti.
Progressively harsher policies against the refugees -- rather than against the conditions that produce them -- "have made us look like international outlaws abroad," he said. "The humanitarian issues have been completely overwhelmed."
Several policy analysts said that American or O.A.S. armed intervention in Haiti might cause less of a storm in the hemipshere than it would have several years ago, although there remain important O.A.S. countries, particularly Mexico, that oppose military intervention of any kind.
Yankee imperialism is less of a rallying cry when conservative, free-market Governments are concentrating on getting development assistance and trade agreements.
"There is still some of that around," said Carol Graham, a Peruvian-born scholar at the Brookings Institution. "But on the other side there is the counterbalancing view that a more positive role by the United States in these crises would be useful."

HEADLINE: JOBLESS RATE ROSE TO 7.5% FOR MAY, HIGHEST SINCE 1984

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5

 BODY:
The nation's unemployment rate climbed to 7.5 percent in May from 7.2 percent in April, as young people and other job seekers flocked into a labor market with relatively few openings, Labor Department figures disclosed today. The report was the first broad indicator of business conditions last month.
The sizable increase, which puts the jobless rate at its highest point since 1984, was quickly seized on by Democrats to attack the Bush Administration and to press for a bill to overhaul the unemployment insurance system. The bill is expected to pass handily in a House vote scheduled for next week. 
 But the report was seen by most economists as likely to prove more a political setback to the President -- and a possible blow to consumer confidence -- than as evidence that the fledgling recovery was in jeopardy.
 
White House Is Optimistic
 "I don't think anyone questions the fact that the economy is improving in almost every sector," Marlin Fitzwater, the chief Presidential spokesman, said at the White House in response to questions about the figures. He pointed to the well-established tendency for the jobless rate to rise as recoveries take hold, as people begin looking seriously for jobs again. Those who have given up looking are not counted among the unemployed.
Michael J. Boskin, the President's chief economic adviser, declined to elaborate on Mr. Fitzwater's statement.
But the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, declared, "Unemployment is getting worse and the President doesn't realize it."
 
Many Face Loss of Benefits
 He said that high school and college graduates were failing to find work and added that he was also troubled by "the number of long-term unemployed workers -- now 3.5 million strong -- who could face an interruption in their benefits."
Among the changes in the largest states, New Jersey's jump to 9 percent from 7.8 percent was the biggest, while the rate for New York State edged up to 7.9 percent from 7.6 percent. [Page 44.]
The rate for California, which suffered an unspecified loss of jobs from the riots in Los Angeles, rose to 8.7 percent from 8 percent, while the rate for Michigan, benefiting from an automotive upturn, declined to 8.6 percent from 9.4 percent.
While the Administration could take some comfort in the reasons for the higher unemployment rate -- and in some other figures, like a further lengthening of the average workweek -- there were some clear negatives.
Among these were that sizable increases in the ranks of both the newly jobless and the hard-core jobless, a rise in the duration of spells of unemployment, a surge in the number of people who lost, rather than quit, their last jobs and a jump in number of people working part time who would have rather had full-time work.
And by both of the department's surveys, the one that samples 60,000 households and the one that samples more than 350,000 business establishments, jobs were decidedly scarce.
The household survey showed that the labor force rose 330,000 last month, continuing at the stepped-up pace that has prevailed since November, but that the number of jobs actually shrank, by 19,000. This swelled the jobless ranks by 349,000, to a total of 9,504,000, or about 40 percent more than when the latest recession began in July 1990.
Nearly half of the growth last month in the labor force, which had been anemic during most of the recession, was among those aged 16 to 24, the department noted.
Some private analysts questioned the adequacy of the department's seasonal-adjustment procedures in dealing with the end of the school year. They noted that the jobless rate rose two-tenths of a percentage point in May 1991, one of very few increases of that magnitude for the year.
 
Gain Entirely in Services
 The payroll survey, which is watched by economists, posted a gain of 68,000 jobs in May, somewhat less than expected. All of this gain was in services as opposed to goods-producing jobs. Factory jobs fell 10,000 following a 5,000 April gain.
"There's still an awful lot of caution on the part of businesses," said Robert V. Di Clemente, an economist at Salomon Brothers.
But Mr. Di Clemente and others said they were heartened by the longer workweek, which generally is taken to mean that employers will soon need to hire more workers as they exhaust their ability to squeeze more production from existing ones.
The private-sector workweek expanded by six minutes, to 34.5 hours last month, while for manufacturing alone the workweek grew 12 minutes, to 41.3 hours, the highest level since 1966. Factory overtime also rose.
Today's report also showed that the index of aggregate weekly hours, which eased slightly in March and April, rose to 121.5 last month and that the proportion of industries adding workers stood above 50 percent for the second straight month.
 
Short of Expectations
 And while the 68,000 rise in business payrolls fell short of the 100,000 or so that had been expected, analysts also noted that the gains for the two preceding months were revised upward. March now shows a 58,000 gain instead of 39,000 while April's gain is now 182,000 instead of 126,000.
"The economy is making headway, though at a painfully slow pace," said Walter M. Cadette, an economist at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.
The 76,000 gain in payroll service jobs was the sixth in a row for this sector and included 39,000 in business services, 20,000 in health services, 13,000 in local government and 11,000 in finance. Retail trade, however, lost 44,000 after rising 83,000 in April, a swing that some analysts thought might not reflect reality.
Goods-producing jobs fell 8,000, with weakness continuing in the military-dependent industries producing transportation and electronic equipment. A rise for machinery was entirely the result of a return of strikers at Caterpillar Inc.
The household survey showed that joblessness among young people, those aged 16 to 24, was worse among men. Their rate climbed to 15.9 percent from 14.9 percent while the rate for women in this age group rose to 12.9 from 12.1 percent.
But unemployment for men 25 and older also rose, by nearly 200,000, a change whose significance cannot be determined without additional months of data, William G. Barron Jr., the deputy commissioner of labor statistics, told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.
The jobless rate for adult men rose five-tenths of a point, to 7.3 percent, while that for adult women eased two-tenths of a point, to 6.1 percent.
Regionally, the jobless rate rose one-tenth of a point in the Northeast and South, to 8 percent and 7.1 percent, respectively. The increase was three-tenths of a point in the Midwest and West, to 7 percent and 7.7 percent.

HEADLINE: Britain and Japan Split With U.S. on Species Pact

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 5

 BODY:
Britain and Japan indicated today that they would sign a treaty to protect plants and animals, breaking with the United States and deepening American isolation on an accord that was to be one of the main achievements of the Earth Summit.
The British and Japanese actions left the United States as the last holdout among the major industrial nations on the treaty. American officials also said that the United States delegation was further embarrassed by the earlier disclosure that the White House had rebuffed a proposal by the chief delegate, William K. Reilly, to accept certain modifications in the treaty's language and sign it. 
 [But at a White House news conference, Mr. Bush defended Mr. Reilly and his environmental record, saying, "Mr. Reilly, a top environmentalist, has my full support." Page 6.]
Under the agreement to protect plants and animals, known as the biodiversity treaty, steps would be taken to protect endangered species and the areas they inhabit, but certain kinds of economic development activities would be allowed, including tourism, the gathering of food and the harvesting of resources for development of medicines.
The Bush Administration has argued that the treaty is flawed because it would limit biotechnology development in the United States and could infringe on American patent protection for biological inventions. The Administration is also concerned about how money for third-world countries with endangered species areas would be disbursed.
Britain and Japan have disagreed with the United States on several approaches to the environmental summit meeting, but earlier they had indicated that they would go along with American objections to the treaty.
Today in what some officials acknowledged was pressure from environmentalists in their own countries, leaders of the delegations from those countries said they would sign the accord in spite of their misgivings.
"We are carefully studying certain articles with a view to signing the convention," Shozaburo Nakamura, head of Japan's delegation, said in a speech today.
British diplomats said today that Prime Minister John Major would sign the treaty when he comes here next week. Today, the first day that the treaty was presented here for signing, 16 heads of state or government signed.
United States officials said there was a sense of political crisis surrounding deliberations involving the American delegation. In an unusual development, for example, representatives of the major industrialized nations, including the United States, held a special meeting today specifically to discuss ways to help the Washington delegation ease its isolation at the Rio conference.
One step adopted at that meeting was a decision to offer broad support for an initiative put forward last week by President Bush to put up additional funds and take other steps to protect forests.
Delegates from other nations at the Rio meetings said that the talk of the summit meeting today was what they described as the humiliation of Mr. Reilly, who is head of the Environmental Protection Agency, when it was disclosed that his appeal to change American policy on the biodiversity pact had been turned down.
"What is the White House trying to do to their man here?" said a high-ranking Brazilian diplomat. British, Japanese and Indian delegates said the disclosure of Mr. Reilly's rebuff had been the main subject of discussions in their morning meetings.
 
'Climate of Cynicism'
 As a result of the disclosure, in The New York Times, Mr. Reilly devoted much of his time today to assuring reporters that he would not resign and to defending his reputation as someone who had the confidence of his Government. In a statement issued by his office, Mr. Reilly said it was "most unfortunate that someone within our Government chose to leak information about these most important efforts -- efforts that demanded diplomatic discretion."
"I talked to the President this morning, and he is appalled and outraged by what has happened," Mr. Reilly said. "It's very unhelpful and disloyal to the President."
A senior American delegate, insisting that he not be identified by name, said the embarrassment of Mr. Reilly "contributes to a growing climate of cynicism about the U.S. in Rio." Reflecting the bitterness in Mr. Reilly's camp toward his critics in Washington, that official called the disclosure "a little hand grenade" thrown by middle-level White House officials who see "biodiversity as a disease."
 
Criticism Directed at Bush
 American environmental groups, in Rio as observers and to take part in various ancillary activities, saw the controversy surrounding Mr. Reilly as aggravating the criticism that is likely to be directed at Mr. Bush when he visits Rio next week.
"Coming on the eve of the President's visit here makes it all the more unfortunate," said Scott A. Hajost, a lawyer for the Environmental Defense Fund, a private American group that is critical of the Administration position. "He's about to swoop down here, and he has people in the White House trashing his own representative."
The criticism was echoed by Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, who has long assailed the Administration's environmental policies.
"Once again the principal official in charge of U.S. environmental policy has been overruled -- and this time the whole world is watching," said Senator Gore, who is leading a delegation from the United States Senate at the summit meeting.
The furor surrounding Mr. Reilly's actions, according to officials from various countries, was the culmination of an effort that began earlier this week to modify key provisions of the treaty to win the Administration's support.
 
'Bill Was Really Angry'
 Officials said that the idea of "fixing" the treaty arose on Monday during a meeting here between Mr. Reilly and Marcos Azambuja, Brazil's chief negotiator on the treaties. On Tuesday night, Mr. Reilly conveyed a proposal by telephone to Clayton K. Yeutter, President Bush's domestic policy chief at the White House. On Wednesday evening, he faxed to Mr. Yeutter a confidential draft of proposed language changes.
On Thursday afternoon, an official opposed to making the changes provided a copy of the memo to The New York Times.
"Bill was really angry that that memo had gotten out -- and Bill doesn't anger easily," said an official in the American delegation.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The nation's unemployment rate climbed to 7.5 percent in May, its highest point since 1984, from 7.2 percent in April, as young people and other job-seekers flocked into a labor market with relatively few openings, Labor Department figures showed. The report was the first broad indicator of business conditions last month. [Page 1.] The rate increased in both New York and New Jersey, where it surged to 9 percent from 7.8 percent in April. Economists said the jump clouded other evidence that the two states, which were among the first to enter recession, were approaching bottom. [44.]
The audacity and scope of a new insider trading case filed by the S.E.C. against seven corporate executives and investors, including a former Bear, Stearns director, have raised fresh doubts about Wall Street behavior after years of sensational prosecutions. [37.]
The Pentagon lifted its four-day-old ban on new contracts for General Electric's aircraft-engine division after the company agreed to greater Government oversight of its operations. [37.]
Chemical Bank raised its prime lending rate to 6.5 percent from 6.25 percent, ending its parade with no followers. [41.]
Travel agents' offices resembled scenes from Steve Martin movies as the frenzied half-price air ticket sales ended. [37.]
 
International
Canary Wharf said it was talking with possible investors. Hanson P.L.C. said it was exploring a joint offer with Bechtel, the American construction giant, for Olympia & York's bankrupt East London office development. But Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation was said to have lost interest. [37.]
Britain's Lloyds Bank dropped its $6.6 billion bid for rival Midland. The parent of Hongkong and Shanghai Bank previously raised its bid, which Midland managers backed, to $7.1 billion. [41.]
 
Markets
Stocks slid on the unexpectedly weak jobless news, with the Dow Jones industrials giving up 1.04 points, to 3,398.69. [40.]
Prices of Treasury securities rose and interest rates dropped amid questions of whether the big jump in unemployment would lead the Federal Reserve to cut short-term interest rates. [40.]
The dollar was mostly lower, and gold rose a bit. [46.]
Soybean and corn futures prices tumbled as rain soaked Midwestern fields, promising plentiful harvests. [46.]
 
Companies
The spirit of Sam Walton lived on as 15,000 Wal-Mart shareholders assembled in a huge University of Arkansas arena, to be inspired by big-screen videos of the late company founder. [39.]
Ford plans to make its popular Explorer sport-utility vehicle at a second site by 1995, by converting its St. Louis plant. [39.]
Banc One reached into West Virginia, with plans to buy Key Centurion Bancshares for stock valued at $536 million. [39.]
Chrysler is shipping its powerful Dodge Vipers to showrooms at last, opening with a $56,600 price, but would-be buyers are having to up the ante if they wish to drive one. [39.]
New York Telephone, raising the ire of consumer advocates, proposed a sweeping rate overhaul with rises for homes and small businesses and cuts for big corporate customers. Prices for individual calls would drop, partly offsetting the higher rates. [29.]
 
Today's Columns
Many people would give college-age children control over large sums, albeit inadvertently, by making them contingent beneficiaries of life insurance policies. Jan M. Rosen: Your Money. [38.]
A bow hunter has a breath-taking invention to throw deer off the scent of human predators. Edmund L. Andrews: Patents. [38.]
