HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DEFENDS U.S. ENVOY IN RIO

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5

 BODY:
President Bush today defended William K. Reilly, the head of the American delegation to the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro, and attacked an unidentified member of his Administration who made public a confidential memorandum in an attempt to embarrass Mr. Reilly.
"Mr. Reilly, a top environmentalist, has my full support," Mr. Bush said at a White House news conference this morning. "He conducts himself the way he should, with great dignity and great decency. That a document that he prepared properly was leaked, I find terribly offensive." 
 But even as the President called the leak "an insidious practice," a struggle over the Administration's environmental policy grew sharper as Mr. Reilly fought back. In Rio, he and his aides blamed staff members of the President's Council on Competitiveness, a group led by Vice President Dan Quayle, for the leak.
Jeffrey Nesbit, a spokesman for the Vice President, denied the accusation, saying that "the assertion that the Competitiveness Council leaked a confidential memo is totally false."
 
Appeal to Bush Fails
 The newest conflict between Mr. Reilly, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, and the Vice President began on Wednesday night when Mr. Reilly made a last-minute appeal to the White House to reverse its position and approve an international treaty to protect the earth's plants and animals. The appeal was rejected, but in Rio today the treaty was signed by delegates of 16 other countries.
Mr. Reilly's confidential memorandum was sent to Clayton K. Yeutter, the President's domestic policy chief, and included a passage that described how the Administration's refusal to sign the treaty was "the major subject of press and delegate concern here." The memorandum said that Brazil had offered to "fix" the treaty to gain the United States' approval. An Administration official, concerned that Mr. Reilly might persuade the White House to sign the treaty, gave a copy of the the memorandum to The New York Times.
The conflict between Mr. Reilly and Mr. Quayle was joined last summer when the Vice President overcame Mr. Reilly's strong opposition and issued a proposed policy that would open 50 million acres of wetlands to development. Since then, the Council on Competitiveness has become one of the Administration's most influential bodies in deciding environmental policy.
The council has been intimately involved in developing the regulatory moratorium and review that the President announced last January. It has also delayed new rules under the 1990 Clean Air Act, and last month gained the President's support for limiting public involvement in deciding how much air pollution a company can emit.
 
Treaty Is Opposed
 The influence of the council extends to international affairs. David M. McIntosh, its 33-year-old executive director, wrote a memorandum in April opposing United States' support for the treaty to protect plants, animals and other biological resources.
The memorandum, which Mr. McIntosh wrote with John Cohrssen, an associate director of the Competitiveness Council, argued that the treaty would harm the ability of biotechnology companies to protect biological inventions developed from resources collected in foreign countries.
Reducing restrictions on testing and marketing genetically engineered products has been one of the central projects undertaken by the Competitiveness Council over the last two years. The memorandum became the basis for the President's decision late last month not to sign the treaty.
"While we recognized the treaty was trying to protect habitats, some provisions were also limiting the ability for research and development of biotechnology products," Mr. McIntosh said in an interview this week. "It conflicted with the President's initiative to speed up biotechnology developments."
Mr. McIntosh said he and Mr. Cohrssen had not expected their memorandum "to stop a treaty."
"We thought people should be made aware of it and let them adjust it in negotiations," he said.
 
'Sound and Sensible'
 Mr. Quayle and his staff insist that the United States has no equal around the world in establishing comprehensive environmental laws. But they say that in many cases the laws are so restrictive and expensive that they are harming initiative and the performance of the American economy. Along with Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr., Mr. Quayle frames the debate as one that pits jobs against the environment.
During a nationally televised news conference on Thursday night, President Bush described the approach his Administration is now taking to environmental policies.
"We've got a sound and sensible record and we have a strong role on international leadership," the President said. "I wonder if the American taxpayer knows that we have spent something like $800 billion in the last 10 years on cleaning up things -- the atmosphere, the environment in many ways.
"I will not sign a treaty that in my view throws too many Americans out of work. I refuse to accept that kind of criticism from what I consider some of the extremes in the environmental movement, internationally or domestically."

HEADLINE: Your Money;
Should Children Collect Insurance?

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
MANY people who would not think of handing over hundreds of thousands of dollars, or a million or more, to their college-age children have inadvertently paved the way for doing just that. What's more, if it happens, they will not be in a position to correct it.
The issue is life insurance. It is quite common for people who have life insurance to name their spouse as primary beneficiary and their children as contingent beneficiaries. Stuart Kessler, a partner in Goldstein, Golub, Kessler & Company and head of personal financial planning for the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, said last week that that was the case with participants in seminars he has conducted for corporate and professional groups. 
 That means that should the insured die, his or her spouse should get the proceeds of the policy. But if husband and wife were killed in the same car or plane crash, for example, the proceeds would go to the children as contingent beneficiaries.
When people have wills written, care is taken not to give young children large amounts of money, Mr. Kessler said. "No one gives substantial amounts to children outright at age 18. But here the children would receive the funds without guardians, trusts or attachments at age 18. This is not what they want."
The simplest solution is to make one's estate the contingent beneficiary, he said, so that the executor can distribute the proceeds of insurance policies in accordance with the terms of the will, perhaps giving children half the assets at age 20 and half at age 30.
There is a potential drawback: If the estate exceeds $600,000, the insurance would be subject to estate tax, which is as high as 55 percent. But Mr. Kessler said this could be avoided by putting the insurance into a trust. "But if it is basically for a spouse, why have it encumbered?" he asked. "Why have a trustee doling it out to a widow?"
His recommendation for people whose estates will clearly be under $600,000 is to make the estate the contingent beneficiary. For those who have more -- or will be likely to after a few years' growth in assets -- more planning is needed.
Part of the insurance coverage will probably be for the spouse, and in that case making the estate the contingent beneficiary is probably preferable to encumbering the policy for the spouse. And part will be for the children, and it could be put into a trust to escape estate taxes.
Second-to-die insurance should always be in trust, Mr. Kessler said, because its purpose is to pay estate taxes when assets are not liquid, perhaps because they are in real estate or a family business. "The trust indenture has to be drawn before the policy is taken out," he said.
 
June 15 Estimates
 Tax professionals are howling that Congress is demanding an impossible-to-achieve pinpoint accuracy with estimated tax payments due June 15.
People whose income is not subject to withholding, or who would have too great a shortfall between withholding and taxes, must pay estimated taxes each quarter. In recent years, there have been two safe harbors for the estimates -- 90 percent of the current year's taxes or 100 percent of the previous year's, a readily available figure.
But in November, to provide money for extended unemployment benefits, Congress decided to deny certain upper-income taxpayers the second test. Those whose adjusted gross income exceeds $75,000, and whose income exceeds the previous year's by $40,000 or more and who owed estimated payments in each of the last three years are denied what Julian Block, a tax lawyer in Larchmont, N.Y., calls "the 100 percent escape hatch."
If they fail to pay 90 percent of this year's liability, they will be subject to a penalty linked to the interest rate on Treasury bills, which will be about 7 percent for 1992.
The problem, said Jack Porter, head of BDO Seidman's national tax office in Washington is that "the tax computation can be more complicated than doing an actual return because you have to annualize."
What's more, many small businesses and partnerships cannot do all their own calculations in time to make accurate estimates. If they underestimate their liability, they will have to pay the penalty. But if they overestimate, they are effectively extending to the Government an interest-free loan.
"It's outrageous," Mr. Porter said. But, since the penalty is often less than the accounting fees for calculating an accurate estimate, he advises making a best guess and paying the penalty if need be. "I tell clients who are having a hard time that it's a bona fide borrowing," he said.
Donald H. Skadden, vice president-taxation of the accountants' institute, said the institute had issued a 25-page practice guide to members and advised them to "try to calculate as accurately as you can."
The institute has asked Congress to create a second safe harbor, set at 115 percent of last year's liability. "But sadly it is not available for this period," Mr. Skadden said.

HEADLINE: Wet Shoes and Traffic Delays: A Most Blustery Day

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
Last weekend ended with a daylong downpour. This weekend started with one, leaving the Friday evening rush a blustery, squishy, waterlogged mess that tied up traffic, triggered flood alerts and pushed area commuters to the edge of their endurance.
When a pair of subway delays conspired to fling several hundred commuters at the window of a transfer agent at the 59th Street station, he ignored the crush and yelled that as far as he was concerned the trains were running on time. "I can't give out transfers," he shouted. "I'll call the police and tell them to bring shotguns." A few people shouted back. Most just trudged up the stairs to face the elements. 
 Matters were far worse for those heading to homes outside Manhattan. An early-afternoon bus accident on the New Jersey Turnpike left 45 people with minor injuries and tied up traffic for 14 miles.
The accident occurred at 1:20 P.M. when a flatbed trailer jackknifed across three lanes of the turnpike near Newark International Airport, Trooper Lee Hendrickson said.
As it twisted, the rear of the trailer slammed into a tour bus carrying 43 senior citizens on a trip to the Pennsylvania Dutch country, forcing it off the road. The bus slid to the left shoulder and into a temporary bridge abutment. Another truck then hit the jackknifed trailer. The injured were taken to five area hospitals where they were treated and released.
The police cleared the accident just before 4 P.M., but the combined force of high winds, a driving rain and Friday night traffic left the route jammed until well after dark.
 
Complaints Via Car Phones
 A shorter but no less irksome traffic stalemate tied up commuters leaving Manhattan through the Lincoln Tunnel. Flooding on Route 3 between Broad Street and Bloomfield Avenue in Clifton, N.J., choked the traffic flow for a mile and a half along that six-lane highway, leaving hundreds of cars stuck in about three feet of water.
The highway was closed just before 6 P.M., at the height of the weekend exodus from New York. Police tried to back up each car to the closest exit, causing even more confusion. The roadway remained closed until 11 P.M., the Clifton police said.
"The people are not happy," said Lieut. Lon Parrella of the Clifton police. He added that he was fielding dozens of complaints from stranded motorists calling in on their car phones. "I have to just tell them to get comfortable," he said. "I don't know if it could get much worse."
It was the soggiest June 5 that the Weather Service has recorded. At 12:20 A.M. the Weather Service reported that 2.52 inches had fallen in Central Park, surpassing the previous record of 1.76 inches, set in 1920. In Atlantic City, 2.69 inches had fallen by 12:20 A.M., erasing the previous record of .42 inches, set in 1975, the Weather Service said.
In New York City, most people grumbled about wet shoes, the absence of taxis, the high price of umbrellas and their general, though largely inaccurate, sense that this has been an unusually rainy spring.
"Why does New York go crazy in the rain?" asked Joyce Kirkpatrick, 24, a librarian with Business Week, as she stood 25th in line for a taxi outside Penn Station. "You can't get a cab. The traffic is 20 times worse. Even the subways are crowded."
Marvin Fox, an umbrella vendor standing outside Penn Station, complained that business was bad. "There's a lot of people with no umbrellas walking with bags on their heads, books, coats, even nothing," he said. "It must be the economy."
 
Some Saw Silver Linings
 But some in the city responded with elan. "I like the rain," said Joanne Lee, 19, a Boston University student who was debating whether to take a train or stay the weekend. "I like the smell after the rain. I like it because you get to stay in. I don't like always having to be in action."
Despite the complaints, the weather experts were unfazed. "It hasn't actually been that rainy," said Daniel H. Graf, a meteorologist with the Penn State Weather Communications Group in University Park, Pa.
"Three years ago was the worst May on record," he said. "We had 10.24 inches in 1989. This May we only had 4.02, which wasn't far from normal. But, I guess if it's raining today, people just forget about three years ago."

HEADLINE: Dinkins Returning from Europe, Hoping Investment Will Follow

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAMBURG, Germany, June 5

 BODY:
Wrapping up a five-day European trip in which he sold New York City to business leaders as a once and future financial center, Mayor David N. Dinkins heads home Saturday with few firm commitments but encouraging signs that European businesses are willing to invest more money in New York.
In London, the Mayor spoke to Conrad M. Black, owner of The Daily Telegraph and the leading prospective buyer of The Daily News. In Paris, he was warmly greeted by Mayor Jacques Chirac, a conservative whose remarks were seen as blessing directed toward the business community. 
 In more than 20 meetings and seminars, he has told foreign executives about falling crime rates and falling real estate prices. He has trumpeted New York's tax incentives, its communications system and its cultural life. He has called the city "the richest marketplace on the planet" and "a key center of international trade, communications, finance and tourism."
Mr. Dinkins has often said similar things at home. But while New Yorkers often respond with skepticism, Europe's business elite, for the most part, has been eager to listen to Mr. Dinkins's sales pitch. In some cases, it has been clear that he was preaching to the converted. In others, European executives said they wanted to hear more about specific incentives for doing business in New York City.
 
Positive About Investment
 "I feel very good about the trip," Mr. Dinkins said last night after the last reception. "I'm satisfied it was wise to come. Everyone has said that."
Mr. Dinkins added that he believed his presence on the trip had underscored the credibility of the delegation.
Business leaders who met with the Mayor said that New York was still perceived here as the premier place in America to invest, especially in the financial services, entertainment and fashion industries. That holds true, they said, despite worries about crime, racial tensions and the city's fiscal stability.
"The Germans are more positive about New York than the Americans themselves," said Michael Dornemann, chairman of Bertelsmann Music Group, which just bought a building at 1541 Broadway.
And Mr. Dinkins's message has been helped by a widespread perception here that the United States' economy is recovering and New York's sagging real-estate market means bargain rents.
"It's a good time," said Richard Branson, the chief executive of Virgin Holding Company, after meeting the Mayor. "The pound's strong. America has all the indications of coming out of the recession, but real estate is unlikely to come much further down. It's time to get in there now."
 
Trip Paid for by Chamber
 Other executives tempered their enthusiasm with a warning that they needed fewer sales pitches and more specifics.
"I've heard a lot of encouraging noises but I have yet to see a greater endeavor," said Roger Saul, the director of the Mulberry Company of London, a clothing concern, after a breakfast meeting with the Mayor on Monday. "To go into New York is prohibitive unless we were to be offered a package of incentives that would make it worthwhile."
Another British fashion executive, Dick Polak, said, "It doesn't appear to me that they exactly know what they are targeting. It looks like a very early stage, a fact-finding mission."
Mr. Dinkins was leading a delegation of 15 business executives from the New York Chamber of Commerce, which had planned the trip to promote the city as a base for foreign headquarters and paid for the Mayor's expenses.
The delegation's strategy was to have Mr. Dinkins make his sales pitch at business seminars for middle-sized companies interested in expanding. He also spoke to local chambers of commerce in London, Paris and Frankfurt.
The Mayor and members of the delegation also met one-on-one with bankers and several corporate executives who have expressed interest in doing business in New York. Those meeting produced the seeds of future deals, participants said.
 
Investment Ideas Discussed
 In Britain, for instance, the Mayor and Mr. Black discussed some city-owned sites for a new printing plant for The Daily News, including the Brooklyn Navy Yard, people at the meeting said.
With Mr. Branson, the delegation tried to sell him the idea of locating one of the company's giant record stores in Times Square. Mr. Branson said later the meeting "persuaded us to take a look at it much quicker than we would have done."
Members of the delegation also discussed with Pearson P.L.C., the British communications company, the possibility of building a Madame Tussaud's Wax Museum in midtown.
The delegation also held talks with the Ladbroke Group, a British company that owns betting parlors. The company's managing director, Cyril Stein, expressed interest in buying the city's Off-Track Betting Corporation. The city budget calls for selling the agency for at least $50 million.
 
Some Doubts Dispelled
 Mr. Dinkins also spent much time paying courtesy calls on businesses that have already invested in New York, his aides said. Large private luncheons were held in Paris and London for companies with North American headquarters in New York. A meeting with the Frankfurt Chamber of Commerce today, for instance, was attended by only 25 businesses, most of them consulting firms or companies with significant branches in New York.
The previous day, in Paris, Mr. Dinkins visited Galeries Lafayette, the department store, which recently opened a branch in Trump Tower, and spoke to a group of about 20 designers, all of whom have New York businesses. At a cocktail reception in London on Tuesday, he addressed a crowd of entertainment industry executives, most of whom spend half their time in New York.
"We've all been there," said Dennis Johnson, a British publisher who has offices in New York. "This is not Singapore. But you've got to give him 10 out of 10 for standing up there and saying 'this is New York City' to people who know it."
Those meetings were aimed at retaining businesses that might consider leaving.
"That's a big part of it," said a member of the Mayor's delegation who asked not to be identified. "You go. You hold their hand. You say we love you. Everybody feels better."
At the seminars for smaller firms, many of which have no link to New York, yet, many business executives said they came away with a new impression of the city.
"On the tax side, I was surprised," said Charmaine McMillan, an executive with the British company, Computer People. "You have an automatic perception that taxes are going to be higher in New York."
An interior designer who attended the London seminar, Peter J. Hines, said he would love to move his small business to New York, but he worried about crime because he has two children. He said he was encouraged by the Mayor's speech.
"New York has become a stereotype image," Mr. Hines said. "Fast, brash, violent, exciting, chic, international, broke."

TANGLED FINANCES STRAND SHIP AT SEA
Since last Saturday the ship the East Trader and its 25 sun-baked crew members have sat anchored in choppy waters 19 miles off the coast of Manhattan, with dwindling supplies of food and water and no money to enter the Port of New York. HEADLINE: $2 Billion Accord Reached On Emergency Aid to Cities

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5

 BODY:
Unwilling to wait another day for White House consent, House and Senate negotiators today established a $2 billion emergency urban aid package intended to create summer jobs for inner-city youths, expand the Head Start preschool program and rebuild businesses destroyed last month in the Los Angeles riots.
The House-Senate conference committee action was meant to increase pressure on the White House either to agree to a plan to establish thousands of summer jobs for urban teen-agers or to risk losing $800 million in grants and loans that it wants to provide Los Angeles and Chicago. 
 Afterward, Republican members read a letter from the White House Office of Management and Budget saying that senior officials would advise Mr. Bush to veto the measure.
 
Possibility of Compromise
 But Judy Smith, a White House spokeswoman, left the door open for a compromise, saying, "We continue to hope that a reasonable bill might be developed."
White House and Congressional negotiators have appeared close to an agreement on an emergency package for the past three weeks, but the talks have stalled in recent days over issues like ways to finance the legislation and tax breaks to lure businesses into inner cities. They are expected to meet again early next week.
The Bush Administration has been badly split over how much to compromise with Congressional Democrats. Several Cabinet members, led by Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp, believe that Mr. Bush must take decisive action in the aftermath of the Los Angeles riots and work toward a compromise on long-term urban programs like changes in the welfare system in the coming months.
But another faction in the Administration, led by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, has argued that the Democrats are merely setting the President up for an embarrassing veto and have no intention of compromising on items that are dear to conservatives in an election year.
 
'Weed and Seed' Program
 The emergency bill could potentially bring as much as $70 million to cities in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, much of which would go to a program called "weed and seed," which the Administration strongly supports. Under such programs, detectives and specially trained police assault teams go into inner-city neighborhoods to clean out gangs and drug dealers before educational and other social welfare programs are installed.
Over all, the measure would provide $675 million for Federal summer jobs programs, $250 million for summer Head Start programs, $250 million for summer school programs for disadvantaged elementary and secondary schools and $250 million for "weed and seed."
The appropriations conference committee made its decision by voice vote, largely along party lines. But Senators Mark Hatfield of Oregon, the ranking Republican on the Senate Appropriations Committee, and Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, another Republican, joined Democrats in supporting the legislation.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, a leading proponent of the legislation, said the legislation could "make a clear and present difference to cities across America this summer."
But Senator Thad Cochran, Republican of Mississippi, reflecting a sentiment heard from lawmakers from rural states, said, "I think it's unfair to have big cities raiding the Treasury at a time when we're hard-pressed to get money that we need for education, health care and many other important programs in our rural areas and towns." He added that the violence in Los Angeles "shouldn't be rewarded with a lot of new assistance programs for many other cities."
 
Charge of Playing Politics
 Conservative lawmakers should be able to muster enough votes to deprive Democrats of a veto-proof margin when a vote is taken on the final version of the agreement.
Jerry Lewis of California, a senior Republican on the House Appropriations Committee, accused Democrats of playing politics with the bill. "Senate Democrats decided they wanted to stick it to the President," he said in an interview. "They're breaking all the budget agreements."
The conference bill reconciled House and Senate versions of the legislation. The House version provided $822 million in emergency loans and grants to Los Angeles to rebuild after the disturbances and to Chicago to fix damages from a downtown flood in April. The Senate version added $1.5 billion more aid to 75 cities.
Mr. Bush came out in favor of the House version, but the conference committee product is far more similar to the Senate bill. The final version took about $25 million in employment aid out of the Senate measure.
The $1.5 billion extra aid in the Senate bill, a package of summer jobs, law enforcement and educational programs, was worked out by Senator Kennedy and Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah. Mr. Hatch has strenuously argued for the added aid to Republican colleagues and aides at the White House, and he made his pitch publicly to give the Congressional initiative some bipartisan impetus.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Lower On Signs of Weak Economy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mostly lower on world currency markets yesterday, after the Government released data showing that the nation's unemployment rate surged in May.
Gold prices rose slightly. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $338.70 an ounce, up 10 cents from Thursday. Later, the Republic National Bank quoted a bid of $338.60, up 20 cents. 
 Heavy morning trading reflected the bad economic news, said Renato Strauss, a foreign exchange dealer with Bank Julius Baer & Company.
The Labor Department said unemployment jumped to 7.5 percent in May, the highest level in nearly eight years. Many economists had expected the jobless rate to hold steady at April's 7.2 percent.
"The dollar reflected the market's belief that because of the poor unemployment data, U.S. interest rates might go south," said Lloyd Atkinson, chief economist for the Bank of Montreal.
In recent weeks, the Government has released conflicting reports about the strength of the economic recovery. That has prompted speculation the Federal Reserve might step in to cut interest rates to stimulate the economy.
Lower rates tend to scare the dollar market because they would make dollar-denominated securities less valuable to investors, thereby decreasing need for the currency.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 127.55 Japanese yen from 127.70 yen Thursday. Later, in London, it fell to 126.70 yen. In New York, the dollar fell to 126.65 yen, from 127.40 yen late Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.8350, from $1.8255 late Thursday. In New York, the pound fetched $1.8335, up from $1.8265.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday, were: 1.5900 German marks, down from 1.5980; 1.4525 Swiss francs, down from 1.4625; 5.3550 French francs, down from 5.3800; 1,203.00 Italian lire, down from 1,208.00, and 1.19225 Canadian dollars, down from 1.19605.

HEADLINE: Comes a Hunk of Junk, Goes a Chunk of Steel

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEDFORD, L.I., June 5

 BODY:
Sam Gershowitz warns visitors to his recycling center to park their cars outside the gates. Otherwise, their cars could end up in the shredder.
"Believe me, it's happened," said Mr. Gershowitz, who is 52 years old and has been recycling abandoned American dream machines for almost 30 years. He grinds them into metal chunks about the size of a coffee can and feeds them back into a growing world market that regards the United States as the Saudi Arabia of scrap. 
 "We've had people pull up to the office up in an old car looking for a used tire or headlight," he said. "And when they turn around, they see their car heading up the conveyor belt to the shredder. We had to buy one guy a new car."
 
A Long Idle Stretch
 For Mr. Gershowitz and others in the scrap-metal business, the recession has brought hard times, with the supply of junk cars down along with the demand for scrap metal.
"No one has to be a brain surgeon to know that car sales have been off for two and a half years," he said. "And people get rid of their old clunkers only when they buy new cars."
But Mr. Gershowitz believes the economy has bottomed out. He has seen a slight upturn in business in recent months and expects the autumn to bring a wave of junk cars as new-car sales continue to improve.
His optimism was echoed by Robert J. Garino, director of commodities for the Institute of Scrap Recycling Industries in Washington. He said the recycling industry suffered along with the rest of the country during the recession but said recent indications showed that the economy "looks more and more positive."
Last year, United States automakers produced 8 million shiny new cars for American consumers, who discarded just as many and more. The discards average one ton and 6.7 years on the road. They did not just disappear, but were chewed up by some 200 giant shredders across the country.
The $7 million shredder at the Gershow Recycling yard here did its part last year by processing more than 100,000 cars; enough to fill the Long Island Expressway for 70 miles from the Riverhead exit to Manhattan, bumper to bumper, all six lanes, said Kevin Gershowitz.
Kevin, 24, who with his twin brother, Elliot, joined their father to help run the family business after graduation from college a year ago, has computerized the operations of the three Gershow Recycling Centers on Long Island. He said that junk cars accounted for 70 percent of all Gershow's scrap products.
Mr. Garino, of the Institute of Scrap Recycling Industries, said that nationwide, recycling operations divert approximately 100 million tons of metal, paper, plastic, glass and textiles from the nation's waste stream each year, with steel being the largest component.
He said that about 40 million tons of scrap steel was consumed by mills in the United States in 1991, providing 41 percent of the 96 million tons of steel demanded by the milling industry. Iron and steel exports in 1991 totaled 9.7 million tons, with Turkey the largest importer, followed by Korea, India and Malaysia.
He said the average price for a ton of steel scrap has fallen 13 percent because of the low demand during the recession, from $107.50 in 1990, to $93.50 in the spring 1992. "But we're pretty sure the worst is behind us," Mr. Garino said. "As the economy picks up, we won't be far behind."
Mr. Gershowitz prefers not to discuss prices or profits. "We operate on narrow margins, and we don't want to tip our hand to our competitors," he said. However, he did say he paid an average of $35 for old cars that roll into his lot.
 
Eviscerated Vehicles
 Mr. Gershowitz set up his first shop in a small auto-parts yard in Central Islip in 1964. "I was riding around one day looking for discards when I spotted an enormous number of abandoned automobiles in town landfills," he said.
"The towns didn't know what to do with them then," he said. "The Town of Brookhaven was burying the cars, the Town of Islip was dumping them in a sump that was filled with water and the Town of Smithtown was stacking them in highway department garages.
"When I offered them a dollar a car, they thought I was nuts. They were accustomed to paying $5 to $10 a car for people to come and take them and strip them.
"So I began mining cars out of these old dumps, flattening them and taking them off their hands."
His business has grown along with the population in Suffolk County, which has increased from 400,000 in 1962 to the current 1.3 million. He bought his 15-acre site here in Medford in 1973, with a permit to install an automobile shredder, the first on Long Island. At the time there were 40 such shredders across the country. Eight are in the New York metropolitan area.
He said the shredder has a vacuum cleaner that picks up whatever is nonmetallic -- material from the seats and interior, floor mats and carpeting -- and therefore not marketable. The material is taken to the town landfill. The metal scrap, about 80 percent of the car, is recycled into new products.
"A big percentage of our stuff now goes domestic," Mr. Gershowitz said. "Many of the new mills that are opening up only use scrap, and one of the scraps they love is shredded scrap.
"We ship to one mini-mill, Raritan River Steel, in New Jersey. Their wire-rod products include things like bedsprings, paper clips and chain-link fencing."
 
The Final Parking Spot
 The shredding process, although strictly mechanical, is not without emotion when it comes to parting with some automobiles.
"A couple of years ago some guy brought in an old Chevy, and he was very attached to it," Mr. Gershowitz said. "We don't usually do this, but we shredded the car and gave him a couple of pieces to remember it by.
"Another guy, whose mother still had her first car, a 1962 Buick, asked if he could bring her down and watch as the crane pick it up and put it into the shredder," he said. "It was almost like a funeral."

HEADLINE: Carbon Tax: Green Twist on Oil Price

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Preparing for the Earth Summit that opened in Rio de Janeiro this week, representatives of the European Community's 12 nations proposed a carbon tax -- a tax tied to the amount of carbon dioxide that burning the fuel creates.
That step reopened an old dispute over the pricing of oil: When the importing nations talk of raising prices to hold down consumption, exporting nations threaten to do the job for them and keep the revenue for themselves. 
 After the commissioners of the European Community conditionally approved a carbon tax that would amount to $3 a barrel on oil, and would rise to $10 a barrel by 2000, Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, quickly responded that it would simply freeze its level of production, which would force up the price of oil. And sure enough, as soon as the Saudis spoke, the price rose $1 a barrel.
 As it happens, the European tax is contingent upon the United States and Japan going along -- such a huge "if" that it will probably be a stopper. The tax would be based in part on carbon-dioxide creation and in part on fuel costs, covering coal, oil, natural gas and, oddly, nuclear energy, which produces no carbon dioxide.
From the Saudis' point of view, these latest events must be exasperating. For years the governments of countries that import oil pleaded with Riyadh to invest in new pumping capacity, to permit price stability and allow the importers' economies to grow. That request became urgent after Iraq invaded Kuwait, and Saudi Arabia quickly obliged by raising its production to 8.5 million barrels a day, from 5.5 million.
Now, suddenly, at least in the European Community, governments want to increase the price of oil, to cut consumption.
There is not much new in the struggle over who will grow rich on oil. Daniel Yergin, an energy historian, pointed out that oil producers sought higher prices in the 1960's and 1970's after European countries raised taxes on oil as a means of raising revenue. "It's deja vu, but seen through green-tinted sunglasses," he said, noting that consumers might feel good about a "green tax" meant to help the environment.
But even if the industrial world eventually agrees on a carbon tax, its effects are not so clear. It might not hurt exporters, at least not as badly as it looks at first glance. And the weapon chosen by Saudi Arabia, a pre-emptive price rise, may not be useful to the kingdom.
For one thing, Saudi Arabia's thinking for a decade has been to assure a future demand for oil, because it has a supply in the ground that would last for decades. Thus in every price move it tries to engineer, it will want to avoid making oil so costly that the alternatives are economically attractive.
 
Oil May Do Well
 Even if a carbon tax emerges from the Rio meeting, oil may not do so badly. If drafted the way scientists want, such a tax would hit hardest not at oil but at coal.
Roger Dower, a climate change expert at the World Resources Institute, suggested that the European Community might soon move to reorganize its taxes, keeping total revenue constant but gathering more from high-carbon fuels like coal and less from low-carbon ones like natural gas. If fuels are taxed on the basis of their carbon content, oil is in a strong position relative to coal. "Oil could hardly lose," he said.
The proposal the European Community has on the table in Rio is essentially hypothetical, given the unlikelihood that the United States and Japan will go along. Even some members of the community may balk.
Peter Beutel, an analyst at Pegasus Econometric Associates, described the sudden price run-up in the oil markets as "a series of emotional reactions to emotional reactions."
Even if the developed world eventually imposes such a tax, this alone does not imply lower oil sales, at least not for long, although it might mean a loss of income to oil-exporting nations.
Anthony E. Reinsch, vice president of the Canadian Energy Research Institute, in Calgary, Alberta, ran a computer simulation that assumed a tax of 10 percent on light-oil products, like gasoline and diesel oil, in the major industrial countries. The result, he said, was to depress demand and therefore the world price of oil, which stimulated demand in countries that did not impose a tax.
 
Undercutting the Logic
 "The net impact from a volume standpoint was zero," he said. "There was a dip and then a recovery."
If the world economy behaved like the model, that would undercut the logic of a carbon tax, because it would put the countries that imposed the tax at a competitive disadvantage.
Mr. Reinsch described Saudi Arabia's recent move as "a little bit of soap-boxing," and Mr. Beutel suggested that if the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries actually raised the price $2 or $3 a barrel, the higher price would coax forth new supplies that would bring the price back down anyway.
But all this gives more credence to the carbon tax proposal than it may deserve. Agreeing on the details of such a tax will always be difficult for the world, and even for Europe alone.
"Because of the difference in the fuel mix, different countries have quite distinct and different perceptions of where the balance should be set," said Irving Mintzer, the coordinator of the Stockholm Environmental Institute's Climate Change and Sustainable Development Program.
A tax based strictly on carbon content would be seen by some members of the European Community as too favorable to France and its policy of nuclear power, he said. Other countries, including the United States, have politically powerful coal interests. No country relishes seeing its energy prices rise higher than its neighbor's, handicapping its industries.
 
Fear of Saudi Action
 At present, the logic that prevails in the market is the Saudi threat, with about $1 of the current price of oil representing anticipation of constricted supply. "This has very definitely affected the psychology of the market," Mr. Yergin said.
The factors that contribute to the price increase, he pointed out, include expectations for a global economic recovery and rising demand, along with anticipation of the normal increase in demand in the third quarter of every year.
Separating the other factors from the fear of Saudi action is difficult. By the time the Earth Summit ends, the possibility of a carbon tax may have faded.

HEADLINE: Employment Data Weak In Region

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
In a persistent sign of economic weakness in New York and New Jersey, the Labor Department said yesterday that unemployment rates increased in both states in May, with New Jersey's rate rising to 9 percent from 7.8 percent in April.
Economists in the region, who were surprised by the jump in unemployment, said it clouded other evidence that the two states, which were among the first to enter recession, were approaching bottom. They said they were particularly surprised by -- and could not account for -- the increase in New Jersey. 
 Jesse Benjamin, the assistant regional commissioner of the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics in New York, said job losses earlier in the year were concentrated in wholesale and retail trade in both states, and construction in New Jersey. Although the report yesterday did not provide new data for separate industries for May, he said trade and construction might have continued to shed workers in the region.
But the increase in unemployment may have resulted largely from a seasonal increase in the number of people seeking work, particularly among high school and college students who have been looking for summer jobs.
"Young people have been pouring out of colleges and schools into what was already a pretty weak labor market," said Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
She added that the increase in unemployment "shows that people think things are getting better, and are looking for work."
The Labor Department said the unemployment rate for New York State was 7.9 percent in May, compared with 7.6 percent in April and 7.2 percent in May of last year. It had reached a high of 8.9 percent in February.
The rate for New York City in May was 10.5 percent, compared with 9.5 percent in April and 8.9 percent in May a year earlier. The city's rate reached a high in February of 10.9 percent.
In New Jersey, the Labor Department said, the 9 percent rate in May compared with 6.6 percent a year earlier. It was the state's highest unemployment rate since December 1982, when it was 9.2 percent.
The Government did not report a May unemployment rate for Connecticut.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 1.04 in Reaction to Jobs Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The stock market ended with a small loss yesterday in an erratic session influenced greatly by unexpectedly weak news on employment.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which was down 25 points at midday, closed 1.04 points lower at 3,398.69. For the week, the average had a net gain of 1.81 points.
Big Board volume came to 201.4 million shares, slightly lower than the 204.4 million shares traded Thursday. Declining issues outnumbered advances, 868 to 780. 
 The broader markets were mostly flat, with the New York Stock Exchange composite index losing 0.02 point, to 227.88; the Nasdaq composite index falling 2.83 points, to 585.43; the Standard and Poor's 500 gaining 0.22 point, to 413.48, and the American Stock Exchange index dropping 0.02, to 397.16.
The Labor Department reported that the civilian unemployment rate jumped to 7.5 percent in May from 7.2 percent in April, reaching its highest level in almost eight years.
The department also said that nonfarm payroll employment increased by a smaller than expected 68,000 last month. Most analysts were expecting a rise of 100,000 jobs.
Analysts said the figures unsettled traders, who had been growing increasingly confident that a recovery from the recession was gathering momentum.
However, the jobs news seemingly enhanced the chances that the Federal Reserve might ease credit conditions further, which helped push interest rates lower in the credit markets.
That buoyed stock prices in the afternoon, because lower borrowing costs for corporations increase profit margins.
 
Active Issues
 Reebok International tumbled 2 1/2, to 23 1/2, in active trading. Late Thursday, the footwear company projected lower earnings for the second quarter, citing increased marketing expenses.
Walt Disney, also among the volume leaders, fell 3/4, to 36 1/2. Euro Disney said Thursday that it could not be certain of making a profit in the fiscal year that ends in September.
Other losers among the blue chips included Philip Morris, down 1 1/8 at 74 3/8; Merck, down 1/2 at 49 3/8; American Express, down 3/8 at 23 5/8; Procter & Gamble, down 2 3/8 at 100 5/8, and Exxon, down 1/4 at 62 3/4.
On the plus side, American President gained 2 1/2, to 46 3/8. The shipping company said it would pay $44 apiece for the 923,000 shares tendered under an offer that expired Thursday and would buy back another one million shares.
Intertan tumbled 4 7/8, to 15 1/2. The appliance retailer announced a restructuring plan involving the closing of some 200 stores, which it said would result in a larger loss than expected in its fiscal fourth quarter ending June 30.
Xoma dropped 1/2, to 14 3/4, on top of a 4 3/4 loss Thursday, when the company reported that the Food and Drug Administration said additional tests might be needed on its toxic shock drug.

HEADLINE: U.S. Bond Prices Rise on Mixed Jobs Data

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher and interest rates declined yesterday after the Government released May employment statistics that painted a mixed picture for the economy.
After looking at the data, traders and analysts said the report had elements of both strength and weakness. 
 "As a whole, the employment report was quite consistent with the sluggish but accelerating recovery we have predicted for so long," analysts at MMS International, an economic information and service company, said in their daily market commentary.
 
Some Surprising Numbers
 The increase of 68,000 reported in nonfarm payroll employment for May was well short of most Wall Street estimates, and the sharp rise in the unemployment rate, to 7.5 percent from 7.2 percent, was a surprise.
At the same time, economists noted that payroll gains recorded in March and April were revised upward.
And during May, the factory workweek rose by two-tenths of a percent, to its highest level since 1966. Rather than continue to expand hours, manufacturers at some point soon will probably start hiring more workers, the analysts said.
"When you have the length of the workweek at its highest level in 26 years and overtime at its highest level since April 1973, that has to be a precursor of more employment later on," said Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon National Bank in Pittsburgh.
The big jump in the unemployment rate raised once again the question of whether the Federal Reserve Board would cut short-term interest rates.
 
No Fed Action
 The Fed did nothing to fuel such speculation yesterday, as it refrained from open market operations.
"The political pressures on the Fed are going to be intense," Mr. Robertson said. "But I don't think it will do much to help the economy if they cut the Fed funds rate again. We are in for a period of slow, erratic growth, which is not a prescription politicians like when they are running for office."
Prices of outstanding Treasury securities rose by as much as half a point early in the session, but later gave back some of the gains.
By late yesterday, the Treasury's 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 10125/32 , up 11/32 , to yield 7.84 percent, compared with 7.87 percent late Thursday and 7.83 percent the previous Friday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 10113/32 in late trading, up 15/32 , to yield 7.29 percent. And the 5 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 1001/32 , up 1/8 point, to yield 5.10 percent.
 
Short-Terms Rates Fall
 Hopes of another Fed easing move helped to push down rates on short-term Treasury bills.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.67 percent late yesterday, down 2 basis points, or two one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 3.80 percent.
The decline in interest rates encouraged a number of corporations to price new debt securities, with offerings totaling almost $1 billion.

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
Rainbow Not Needed For Heart and Courage

BYLINE: By Douglas Martin

 BODY:
THIS old world spins so fast you're lucky if you catch the headlines, much less the stories. So we miss what's most interesting, the stories behind the stories.
Take the three-week-old strike at the fabled Rainbow Room. The facts are straightforward: 140 workers, a bit less than half the staff, are on strike for better wages, benefits and working conditions. 
 Each day on the picket line you can find one William Rodriguez, who, as a waiter at the Rockefeller Center restaurant for more than four years, suavely served monarchs, mayors, mavens and mavericks -- not to mention Barbra Streisand and Cher. His story goes to the core of what heart still beats in this city's sagging chest.
Mr. Rodriguez's mission in life for the last two years has been caring for a sister with AIDS. Her name is Elizabeth Carucci and she lives with him in his South Bronx apartment.
He was able to balance everything, until the Rainbow Room started putting him on double shifts. As a result, he began showing up late for work, something he says he repeatedly tried to explain in written memos. On the morning of March 19, he says, he arrived 45 minutes after the assigned starting time, because he had to pick up his sister's food stamps.
He was dismissed. The restaurant refused to pay him unemployment because he was fired for cause. Now, his reinstatement has become a demand of the union, Local 6 of the Hotel and Restaurant Employees International Union.
Jessica Miller, spokeswoman for the Rainbow Room, said that he was officially dismissed on March 20, but declined further comment. "We really kind of respect people's privacy," she said.
William Rodriguez was on the doorsteps of his dream, on 138th Street at an address he doesn't want publicized. It is called Mott Haven House, named for the struggling neighborhood surrounding it.
Mr. Rodriguez, dressed all in black and moving with a cat's grace, said that he had spent most of his savings on a $10,000 down payment and closing costs to buy the 110-year-old house. The deal on the $55,000 property closed on April 22, and a party was held last week to celebrate what lies ahead.
First will come a lot of cleaning, as the place has seen better days. Then the dream will begin to come true. Mr. Rodriguez, who is 41 years old, is driven by a vision that the house will be a residence for women with AIDS. He sees six women living there, including his sister.
They will go to a home that has been a woman's refuge for a long time, albeit unofficially. Several months ago, an 87-year-old woman who had lived here 67 years left to join younger family members. With her went her daughter and another, the last of a long chain of the women she preferred as boarders.
"You can feel the presence of women here," Mr. Rodriguez said, gazing at a scene that included plastic flowers and frayed lace, a faded picture of F.D.R. and another of Jesus with the lambs.
A battered upright piano already presides over the room Mr. Rodriguez sees as a library and recreation room. In the debilitated eating area, he sees a gleaming country kitchen. He sees washers and dryers, new beds and sofas, a cache of the popular videos his sister likes so much.
But the acquisition he wants first is more prosaic. A Dumpster for all the junk and rubble.
Why does a man do something like this? The first answer is Lizzie, Mr. Rodriguez's nickname for his 32-year-old sister. His life has become making her breakfasts of fresh fruit and oatmeal, massaging her back, helping her fight relatives to determine custody of her two young children.
"I'm the eldest and I love my sister," he said flatly.
Another has to do with his background. "I'm the son of a preacher man," Mr. Rodriguez said. Indeed, just down the street is the Evangelical Missionary Temple, the church his father founded and served as minister for 30 years. "It's in my blood," he declared.
There is also more than a little pride in Mr. Rodriguez, the sort that comes from achievement. He told of growing up in a tough neighborhood in East Harlem as one of eight children, escaping through brains and diligence. He is more than glad to show off his junior high medals, including one as class president.
He has worked at a dizzying array of jobs -- hairdresser, fashion coordinator, florist, window trimmer and party planner, among others. His goal at the Rainbow Room was to learn enough to start a restaurant of his own. "I'm very gifted," he volunteered.
Point taken. You could have seen this remarkable man on the picket line at Rockefeller Center yesterday from 6:30 P.M. to midnight.

HEADLINE: Finns Hope Technology Will Fill a Market Gap

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J., June 4

 BODY:
The Finnish Government, seeking new trading partners to replace those lost when the Soviet Union collapsed, sent its Ambassador to the heart of New Jersey's high technology strip today to drum up investment from New Jersey businesses.
About 100 technology concerns sent representatives from New Jersey, whose 7.5 million residents outnumber Finns by 2.5 million. The companies hoped to arrange joint ventures, subsidized by New Jersey or Finland, in part to help the state economy out of its slump and in part because they believe that in the long run Finland will be the gateway to doing business with the Russians. 
 By day's end, hundreds of business cards had traded hands and appointments been set up, but no deals had been made.
The Finns did not expect to sign agreements today in any case, their Ambassador, Jukka Valtasaari, said. Instead, he said, the event, the Finland-New Jersey Technology Partnership Symposium, was intended to open long-term relationships with American businesses. Since the collapse of the Soviet bloc, companies in the United States have become the second-largest trading partner with Finland, after Sweden.
 
'The Home of Technology'
 "America is the home of technology, and it is so huge that we have to be here," he said. He was seated in the auditorium of the David Sarnoff Research Center, the first of a dozen high-technology research and development companies to turn this stretch of Highway 1 in central New Jersey into an East Coast version of Silicon Valley.
A similar symposium was held for New York companies in Manhattan last fall. The Finnish Embassy plans to hold similar meetings in other high-technology manufacturing states in the coming months.
"I don't see anything yet," said Bill Whitney, marketing manager for the Otto H. York Company of Parsippany, a manufacturer of chemical-processing equipment, as he leafed through a thick binder listing Finnish companies looking for American money and technical skill. But he was glad to have paid the $35 fee, just to keep up with the evolving European market.
"We just opened an office in Europe," he said, "so it made sense for us to come here to find out who to contact in the Finnish Government and to see what kind of assistance they can offer, and maybe what kind of assistance the State of New Jersey can offer."
Harold K. Fletcher, president and chairman of Tel-Instrument Electronics of Carlstadt, N.J., and Williamsville, N.Y., a maker of airplane-instrument testing equipment, said his company had experienced its own version of the collapse of the Soviet threat.
 
Broadening the Base
 "The defense industry has cut back quite a bit, and so has civil aviation, so we need to broaden our product base," he said. "I think of this as a longshot, but for $35 and lunch I get the byproduct of being able to sit here and think without the phone ringing all the time."
Ambassador Valtasaari said Finland did not expect new business partners from the West to replace the Soviet Union entirely, partly because that country traded in low-tech steel and raw materials, while United States companies offer financial and technical ventures. Finland has also applied to join the European Community.
"But there is now excess capacity in several areas of our economy as a result partly of the collapse of the Soviet Union," the Ambassador said, "and this capacity has to be, to some extent, filled."
As for trading with the Russians, Mr. Valtasaari told the audience in the Sarnoff Center that Russia's resources were still there, and suggested that given time and the development of new lines of authority, markets for foreign investment would be there, too.
And the Finns would help with efforts to understand the Russians, he said.
"I can't say we know better than anyone else how the Russians work," he said, "but we have over the years had a lot of experience over there, and we hope that our knowledge is to some extent sellable."
For his part, George D. Grippo, a marketing consultant from Kinnelon, N.J., who has done business in Helsinki, offered to explain the Finns to the Americans.
"They're not big on flexibility," he said. "If they've got a particular design, that's it. They're very hierarchical, so every decision goes all the way to the top. Maybe it's from dealing with the Russians for so long. And the whole country closes down for a month in the summer."
Mr. Grippo said he had just approached a Finnish Embassy commercial attache for an appointment: "You know what he said? September!"

HEADLINE: Travel Bargains to Continue, As Half-Price Air-Fares End

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Vacation travelers can count on price cuts when they shop for transportation and lodging in the months ahead. Even though the most recent domestic and foreign airline fare war ended yesterday, experts predict that travel companies will continue to offer discounts in an effort to stimulate summer leisure travel. 
 "I don't think there has been such a turnaround in the economy that it is going to be a seller's market," said Ed Perkins, the editor of the Consumer Reports Travel Letter. "Both airlines and hotels have excess capacity."
 
Plenty of Inducements
 James V. Camissa Jr., a travel industry analyst in Miami, said he expected a deluge of price inducements to stimulate demand. "Pleasure travel tends to lag in a recovery period, so there's going to be a of a lot of bargains out there," he said.
Many bargain hunters will travel in the United States this year, according to estimates by the United States Travel Data Center, an affiliate of the Travel Industry Association of America. It forecasts a 4 percent increase in so-called summer vacation person-trips, to 326 million, tying the record set in 1990. (A person-trip is one person traveling at least 100 miles from home.)
"Taking advantage of discounts requires people to plan more in advance," said Thomas R. Crosby, the managing director of national travel for the American Automobile Association, which joined the travel data center in presenting its 1992 summer forecast. "And when you plan ahead, you tend to enjoy your vacation more."
Travel by car or other road vehicles represents the overwhelming majority of all domestic vacation transportation -- and summer expectations for this segment of the industry are particularly optimistic. The National Campground Owners Association, a trade group, reports that its economic index stands at 4.2 out of a maximum of 5.
"Summer reservations are 8 to 18 percent ahead of last year," David Gorin, the executive vice president of the campground association, said. "For a lot of older folks who are retired, this is their life style and they are not about to change that."
The biggest travel deals of the year thus far have been offered by airlines, and many travel specialists anticipate further rounds of fare reductions even in the peak summer months. Take the most recent brouhaha: a nine-day fare war led by American Airlines, which reduced domestic fares by 50 percent off the lowest advance purchase fare for tickets for flights through Sept. 13. The resulting bargains, available until yesterday, included such rock-bottom, round-trip fares as $200 for flights between New York and Los Angeles and $145 for flights between Miami and Chicago.
"There is a whole new wave of lower fares coming in," said Jeanie M. Thompson-Smith, the president of Topaz Enterprises, a travel-management consulting company in Portland, Ore. "It is very advantageous for the leisure traveler."
Patricia Law, a travel agent at Squires / Carlson Travel in Philadelphia, pointed out that many of the discounted fares in 1992 are no lower than they were in the recent past. "People still remember that around three years ago, it cost $198 to go someplace or other," she said. "So they won't pay $400 for a round-trip transcontinental air fare."
When looking for domestic air-fare bargains, "don't get hooked on any one airline's deals," said Herbert J. Teison, the editor of Travel Smart, a newsletter published in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. "Regardless of what promotions you read about, a travel agent may be able to find deals that are just as good or even better."
Similarly, hotels are offering a variety of bargain rates to help increase their business in June, July and August. Michael Ashington-Pickett, a publisher of travel newsletters based in Orlando, Fla., had this advice for travelers in the United States: "Don't call the 800 number for a hotel chain. Call the hotels directly and ask them what's the best rate they can offer you. They're dealing."
 
<SC0>Below Official Rates

 
 Consumers can get hotel rooms for less than the rack -- or official posted -- rate in Europe, too. Even in cities where major events are scheduled during the summer, packages and other special arrangements are featured at many hotels. Such cities include Seville, Spain, the site of the World's Fair, and Genoa, Italy, the home of the Columbus exposition.
"A lot of hotels are coming out with dollar rates where they guarantee the rate, including breakfast, tax and service, before you leave," Barbara Gallay, the president of Linden Travel, a New York travel agency, said. "That way you don't have to worry if the exchange rate changes."
And Michel Bouquier, the United States chairman of the European Travel Commission, said that "more sophisticated and independent visitors are shopping around. They are staying in small countryside inns outside the big cities."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Many of this year's bargain air fares are no lower than those of recent years, said Patricia Law, a travel agent. (Arthur W. Wilkinson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Max Lerner, Writer, 89, Is Dead; Humanist on Political Barricades

BYLINE: By RICHARD SEVERO

 BODY:
Max Lerner, an educator, journalist and student of American civilization who was for many years a syndicated columnist for The New York Post, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 89 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Southampton, L.I.
He died of a stroke, said his son Stephen, of Washington. 
 Mr. Lerner was one of the more conspicuous of the post-World War II nonfiction writers, a humanist whose unabashed liberal conscience led him to the political barricades for more than three decades. Many of his concerns now seem prescient.
In 1959, for example, in a speech at Douglass College in New Brunswick, N.J., Mr. Lerner called for the formation of an antiwar elite, making it clear that he was worried about what he saw as growing mediocrity among American students. "We should be less concerned about the missile gap than the intelligence gap," he said, "less worried about the missile race than the intelligence race."
 
Backed Jewish Emigration
 Mr. Lerner was also a longtime advocate of the right of Jews in the Soviet Union and elsewhere in Eastern Europe to immigrate to Israel. In a speech delivered in 1950 to the New Jersey section of the United Jewish Appeal, Mr. Lerner said that such emigration must continue, "no matter how politically impractical or economically unfeasible."
With all the turmoil of the mid- and late 20th century, Mr. Lerner insisted that he preferred the present "awful but magnificent" era to any other in history. But in a book he wrote in 1957, "America as a Civilization: Life and Thought in the United States Today," he talked of his age as a time in which there was a "fear of ideas and the tenacious cult of property."
His espousal of ideas regarded as liberal in the 1950's did not sit well with everyone. In the 50's and early 60's, he was regarded as a controversial speaker, and those who invited him to lecture were criticized by patriotic groups who regarded Mr. Lerner as rather subversive and perhaps even soft on the ideas expressed by Communists.
"Lerner's great distinction is the enemies he has made," wrote Gerald W. Johnson in 1960 in The New York Times in a review of Mr. Lerner's "Book of American Symbols." Mr. Johnson said that "few men in this country are so bitterly hated by so many of the right people."
Mr. Lerner had been struggling with serious health problems since 1981, when he was stricken with lymphatic cancer. In 1984, he had a heart attack. The prognosis was not promising but the ever-feisty and combative Mr. Lerner surprised his doctors and survived, and wrote a book entitled "Wrestling With the Angel." Published by W. W. Norton in 1990, it described his ordeal and how he overcame it.
"I would pay attention to doctors, tests and all the paraphernalia of medicine," he wrote, conceding that: "My doctors knew more than I did. But in a crisis of conflicting judgments I would never forget that the final, critical decisions were mine to take."
Mr. Lerner was born in Minsk, Russia, on Dec. 20, 1902, the son of Benjamin and Bessie Podel Lerner, who immigrated to the United States in 1907. The elder Lerner was an itinerant scholar, and his wife kept a general store in Russia. But when they came to the United States, they moved to Bayonne, N.J., where Benjamin Lerner bought some cows and sold milk door to door. Later he moved his business to the Catskill Mountains but was not successful, and the family ultimately pursued its fortunes in New Haven.
 
A Yale Undergraduate
 Max Lerner attended Hillhouse High School in New Haven, then went to Yale, where he concentrated on literature. He graduated in the Class of 1923. He studied law for a time at Yale after receiving his undergraduate degree but moved to graduate work at Washington University in St. Louis and at the Robert Brookings School of Economics and Government in Washington. After he earned his Ph.D. from Brookings in 1927, his first job was working as an assistant editor to Alvin Johnson, who was compiling an encyclopedia of social sciences.
Between 1932 and 1935, Mr. Lerner served on the faculty of both Sarah Lawrence College and the Wellesley Summer Institute. After a brief stint teaching at Harvard, he edited The Nation magazine for a time and then taught political science at Williams College from 1938 to 1943.
In 1943, he left Williams to become editorial director of PM, a New York newspaper without advertising, to eliminate the possibility of pressure from advertisers and special-interest groups. The left-of-center daily proved unprofitable and collapsed in April 1948. Before joining The Post in 1949, he also wrote columns for The New York Star, which tried to succeed PM but lasted only eight months, until January 1949. Mr. Lerner sustained his interest in education even after moving to The Post, and for a time was chairman of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences at Brandeis.
Among his books were "Ideas Are Weapons" (1939), "Ideas for the Ice Age: Studies in a Revolutionary Era" (1941), "It Is Later Than You Think" (1938, revised 1943), "The Mind and Faith of Justice Holmes" (1943), "Actions and Passions: Notes of the Multiple Revolution of Our Time" (1949), "The Unfinished Country" (1959) and "The Age of Overkill" (1962).
 
'Love and Work'
 He also made many contributions to other books and wrote for many magazines, among them The Atlantic, Saturday Review, Vogue and The New Republic. He continued writing for The Post until two weeks ago.
Mr. Lerner married Anita Marburg in 1928. The couple divorced in 1940. He married Edna Albers in 1941.
He is survived by his wife; two other sons, Michael, of Bolinas, Calif., and Adam, of Medford, Mass.; two daughters, Constance Russell-Lerner, of San Diego, and Joanna Townsend, of Dallas; nine grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.
In summing up his life for his entry in "Who's Who in America," Mr. Lerner wrote: "I have believed in love and work, and their linkage. I have believed that we are neither angels nor devils, but humans, with clusters of potentials in both directions. I am neither an optimist nor pessimist, but a possibilist."

HEADLINE: Yugoslav Denies Involvement Of Belgrade in War in Bosnia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 5

 BODY:
Portraying himself as the unjustly vilified leader of an unjustly besieged state, the President of Yugoslavia said today that he was eager to address the concerns of the United Nations to avert the effect of sanctions. But he insisted that his federal Yugoslav Government was neither involved in nor abetting the fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
"We don't want to confront the United Nations, we want to cooperate," said the President, Slobodan Milosevic, in a nearly two-hour interview today in which he appeared to be reaching out beyond the isolation of sanctions to foreign leaders. While repeatedly saying his Government was willing to accommodate the United Nations, he also declared, "We cannot say we will agree to withdraw our army from Bosnia when we already did that."
 
Letters to U.N.
 The 50-year-old President who is both a former Communist and former international banker, said the only contact his Government had with the United Nations since sanctions were approved last Saturday was to send letters to Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali "clarifying our position and seeking to make the situation one of greater trust." 
 Though he peppered his remarks, offered in fluent but heavily accented English, with such conciliatory phrases as, "After all, we cannot confront all the world," he kept insisting that the condemnation and isolation of Yugoslavia and his Government was based on inaccuracies and biased accounts conveyed in what he described as "a media war against us."
Serbian leaders have repeatedly insisted that the Serbian irregular forces in Bosnia who have been leading the onslaught against Sarajevo were not under their control, a line taken by Mr. Milosevic, a Serb, in the interview. But Western nations have been just as insistent in asserting the opposite. Today, for instance, in Washington, the State Department said Bosnia and Herzegovina is "being ravaged by Serbian armed forces which were established and equipped by Belgrade and which continue to be materially and politically supported by Belgrade."
In the interview, Mr. Milosevic (his name is pronounced SLOH-boh-dahn mee-LOH-sheh-veetch) grew angry when he said there had been little or no foreign reporting about speeches he had made in the Yugoslav Parliament denouncing the bombardment of civilians or deploring the mortar attack on civilians who had lined up to buy bread in Sarajevo. "Not one article, no TV shot," he said, his voice rising. "We are just criminals, we are wild aggressive people, we are black devils, I don't know what."
When asked why such a wide variety of countries, including nations thought to be friendly to Yugoslavia like Greece and Russia, had apparently endorsed Belgrade's culpability by joining in the sanctions, Mr. Milosevic replied that they had been under pressure to do so. In an apparent effort to avoid roiling diplomatic waters too much he declined to identify those powers, but would not dispute a suggestion that he had Germany in mind.
Essentially, Mr. Milosevic clung to his basic argument that a civil war was raging between the Serbs of Bosnia and Herzegovina on one side and the Croats and Slavic Muslims of that republic on the other. He has maintained for some time that Belgrade had little influence in the war-torn republic and could not restrain the Serbian forces that were formed and grew from Bosnian soil.
 
Disputed Assertions
 During the fighting last year in Croatia, Mr. Milosevic and his Government had similarly asserted that they had no real authority to rein in the activities of a Serbian dentist who had proclaimed himself the leader of Serbian region of Croatia, though they did just that when it became a condition for a United Nations-monitored cease-fire that Belgrade had come to want.
On the present fighting, Mr. Milosevic's view is that though there is sympathy within what remains of federal Yugoslavia, which is now overwhelmingly Serbian, for their Serbian kin across the border, there has been no military involvement or support by his Government or the Yugoslav Army, which is also Serbian dominated.
Such assertions were disputed by United Nations observers, human rights workers and diplomats before they retreated from the area of fighting. They told of air strikes on villages, and there have been many reports that the irregular forces fighting for Bosnian Serbs could not have operated at the level that they did without aid and assistance.
Mr. Milosevic said he had never seen proof to support such allegations, adding that his Government had made it a crime to organize paramilitary units or bear heavy arms.
As the interview was being conducted, across the street from the presidential office, Serbia's Parliament heard a report from the Government asserting that an investigation had determined that there were indeed groups of paramilitary units from Serbia operating in Bosnia but that these were small bands. The Serbian Government, distinct from the Yugoslav federal Government but apparently as eager as Mr. Milosevic to deflect the United Nations sanctions, said it had requested that the irregular Bosnian Serbian forces disarm and disband these men.
On questions relating to the scale of sanctions and their possible consequences as they took hold, it was clear that Mr. Milosevic was hoping that they would not truly go into effect. "There is a time lag for that sort of thing," he said as motorists continued to encircle every gas station in this city.
Revealing the combined optimism of a politician and a junk bond promoter, he said that the sanctions might even bring some positive aspects. "Sanctions will help some in the cleaning of the economy in terms of raising productivity and using all available resources," he said.
He said contingency plans that were drawn up before the sanctions call for shifting energy dependence from oil to coal and electricity. "We produce more food than we need," he said. "We will be hurt with some exports of food but we will not be hungry."
The President, who began his rise to power through the old League of Communists, was asked what he thought of Tito, the wartime Partisan leader who molded Yugoslavia into a federation that pursued an independent Communist course and brought the Balkans one of the longest periods of peace in their stormy history.
In contrast to the growing contempt that is now often expressed for Tito, Mr. Milosevic was respectful in his assessment. "He was fighting fascism and nobody can oppose his role. In many things he was absolutely one of the leaders of a policy of peace."
