HEADLINE: Where Markets Are Never Super;
Some Urban Neighborhoods Fight Absence of Major Chains

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
The names are nothing but nostalgia now -- A.& P., Pathmark, Food Pageant, Grand Union -- a roll-call of supermarkets filled with glistening vegetables and fresh cuts of meat that were once as much a fixture of suburban life in southeast Queens as the neat rows of wood-frame and Tudor houses.
But that was 20 years ago. 
 The brick buildings with the distinctive squat supermarket shape have become something else. One is an N.A.A.C.P. headquarters. Another is a shuttered fried chicken joint. A third is a used-furniture store. All along Linden Boulevard, as the surrounding neighborhoods changed from predominantly white to mostly black and Hispanic, the supermarket chains moved out.
"You're kind of powerless to do anything about it," said Herman Eastmond, a 66-year-old retired bank executive who raised nine children in Springfield Gardens. "They just close up shop and leave."
 
Right to Fresh Vegetables
 Southeast Queens, of course, is far from alone. From riot-torn South-Central Los Angeles to Queens, Brooklyn, Harlem and the Bronx, the departure of the supermarket from the nation's black and Hispanic city neighborhoods has consigned their citizens -- many of them poor, but many of them not -- to shopping in corner delis or small markets with higher prices and inferior merchandise, or traveling miles from home in search of food.
Now, though, neighborhood groups around New York City are beginning to assert their inalienable right to fresh vegetables, competitive prices and spanking clean markets near home. And with the Dinkins administration actively seeking to lure back supermarket chains, some of the companies are showing a renewed interest in urban locations.
In the largely middle-class neighborhoods of southeast Queens, people say they are only trying to reclaim one of the signature amenities of that middle-class life. They have decided they want a Pathmark, and they have gone out to woo the company.
"Anyway you're looking at it, you're talking about leaving Queens to get value," said Nola Southerland, 52, who drives from her home in St. Albans to a Waldbaum's in Nassau County to do her food shopping. "Let us have here in southeast Queens the same type of market."
The reasons for the supermarkets' flight are disputed. Some city officials and community groups say it was part of the general death of shopping strips and growth of suburban malls. Others see at least an element of racism, tying it to the urban disorders of the 1960's or to white flight.
"There are two racial stereotypes that I think are sending false signals to store owners," said Mark Green, the city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner. "First they may fear that they do not understand the minority market. But second is their knee-jerk premise that blacks are poor, and poor people are a poor market."
Supermarket executives deny racism was a factor and argue that many city stores became unprofitable as leases came up for renegotiation and as the small stores of the 1930's were supplanted by mega-markets of 30,000 square feet or more. The large stores include delicatessens, bakeries, florists, pharmacies and video sales, with high-ticket items that the executives say can offset the lower profit margin on food. Stores in the inner city also suffer from higher security costs and high rates of pilfering, the executives say.
 
Poor Pay More
 The exodus has not struck the rich and poor equally. In a study released last year, the city's Department of Consumer Affairs found that while the most affluent parts of Manhattan had a supermarket for every 6,580 people, Brooklyn's most impoverished neighborhoods had one supermarket for 17,232 people. The report said that tenants who lived in New York Housing Authority projects on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, as well as residents of the Williamsburg and Brownsville sections in Brooklyn, had virtually no access to a supermarket.
Food prices in poor neighborhoods throughout the city were found to be 8.8 percent higher on average than in middle-class neighborhoods because of small stores that could not afford bulk buying, and because of lack of competition. For a family of four that could mean an extra $350 a year in food bills. City officials found that while a fresh head of lettuce cost 59 cents in a Waldbaum's on Staten Island, wilted lettuce usually went for $1.19 in corner bodegas.
Armed with such statistics and recognizing that more than housing was needed to revitalize neighborhoods, the Dinkins administration convened a task force that has been working with a nonprofit group, the Community Food Resource Center, to develop a strategy for luring supermarkets into under-served parts of New York City. The group has been meeting for about 18 months.
In a pilot program begun last month in Brooklyn, the New York City Economic Development Corporation has also requested proposals from private developers to build supermarkets on city-owned property in Coney Island and Brownsville. As an incentive to development, the corporation is offering loan guarantees and financing at below-market rates to buy city land.
Such efforts are having results. With the Economic Development Corporation guiding it through the maze of city land use hearings, A.& P. recently broke ground on a 50,000-square-foot Waldbaum's in College Point, Queens. Michael J. Rourke, A.& P.'s vice president for communications and corporate affairs, said the city also smoothed the way for the company to open a Waldbaum's in the South Bronx a year ago. The Supermarkets General Corporation, meanwhile, is working in conjunction with a local development agency to build a Pathmark in Harlem.
In many ways, the southeastern Queens neighborhoods of Cambria Heights, St. Albans, Springfield Gardens, Laurelton and Rochdale Village are better off than the truly supermarket-starved areas of Brooklyn.
In much of the area near the Nassau County border a majority of residents have household incomes of at least $35,000, higher than the city average. They also have more choices in shopping for food. Besides the corner delis offering West Indian specialities, the area also has several of the independently owned markets that often moved in to the inner city after the large chains moved out -- a C-town, an Associated Supermarket and several Key Foods and Bravos.
But living on the border of Long Island, people like Mrs. Southerland can see the difference in cost and quality between what is available in the Five Towns area of Nassau County nearby and in their own neighborhood. And as people who invested their savings in their homes, they say they resent seeing their neighborhood lose the amenities -- like clean, well-stocked food stores -- that had made it suburbia in the city.
 
Inferior Food in Neighborhood
 "We got to see what was once a vibrant community dying," said Mrs. Southerland, a retired telephone company executive. "You're looking at slow death and you know this is going to impact economically on you."
For years, she has gone to Long Island to buy food, complaining that in her neighborhood stores she has found inferior -- and moldy -- cuts of meat, expired food, wilted vegetables and higher prices. On Long Island, she says she pays 49 cents for a can of evaporated milk that can cost 67 cents in Queens. Some local churches and centers for the elderly also run van pools and car pools to Long Island to help the elderly do their grocery shopping there.
But now, responding to such complaints, the Queens Citizens Organization, a coalition of 45 church groups, has stepped into high gear in a campaign to get the 146-store Pathmark supermarket chain to expand its empire into southeastern Queens.
The Rev. Edward Davis, the pastor of the Presbyterian Church of St. Albans, said the group chose Pathmark because it had already shown a commitment to the inner city, with stores in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the Red Hook section of Brooklyn, Newark and Camden.
 
Talk of a Mega-Store
 The Queens community group did not have a hard time making its case. A study of southeastern Queens by one major supermarket chain found that the area of 200,000 had a food buying potential of $5 million a week.
After several meetings with Pathmark executives, the Queens residents now speak rapturously of a 62,000-square-foot mega-store that would create 300 jobs and possibly include a medical clinic and a sports club on the roof.
At Supermarkets General, officials call the talks only preliminary, noting that they will need four to five acres of open land. "We're very interested in the southeast Queens area," said Harvey Gutman, the senior vice president of the retail department. "We feel confident that we can run a Pathmark to serve that community."
But so far, despite the good will -- and in an example of the problems faced by chains that want to duplicate their suburban markets in New York City -- land has remained a stumbling block.
One overgrown site near York College turned out to have a cemetery. Another parcel in an urban renewal zone along Merrick Boulevard is too small and would require demolition of nearby homes. A third plot suggested by the Queens Borough President, Claire Shulman, has been rejected by Pathmark officials who say the soil is too soft.
 
Showdown Over Park Land
 In a move that could lead to a neighborhood confrontation, Pathmark and the Queens residents have set their sights on a 4.5-acre parcel of the 54-acre Roy Wilkins Park, which was ceded by the Veterans Administration to the Southern Queens Park Association in the 1970's.
The Queens Borough President has called the supermarket "inappropriate" for the site. And the board of directors of the park association has so far been adamantly opposed.
"As of now the board remains unconvinced its a good idea," said Solomon Goodrich, executive director of the Southern Queens Park Association. "The board thinks we need all the open spaces we can have." He added, "Nobody's disputing the need for a supermarket."

HEADLINE: Why Cities?;
How to Rebuild Los Angeles

BYLINE: By Witold Rybczynski; Witold Rybczynski, author of the forthcoming "Looking Around: A Journey Through Architecture," teaches architecture at McGill University.

DATELINE: HEMMINGFORD, Quebec

 BODY:
Peter V. Ueberroth, head of Mayor Tom Bradley's panel to rebuild Los Angeles, has described his job as "the chance to dramatically impact a major inner city positively." Brave words. But while public discussion has focused on enterprise zones, tax incentives and community policing, one important question has received scant attention: How should South-Central Los Angeles be rebuilt?
The rioting that followed the Rodney King verdict destroyed or seriously damaged more than 5,000 buildings. These could be put back as they were: predominantly one-story commercial buildings backing onto large parking lots, situated on long, dreary blocks bounded by extremely wide, high-speed roads. Shopping strips over here, houses over there; it's the kind of planning that is the hallmark of most American cities, the kind of planning that only a traffic engineer could love. 
 City planning centered on the automobile is itself a part of the problem. A five-minute walk, the traditional measure of neighborhoods, represents only a quarter of a mile, but a five-minute drive is about three miles. When getting around means driving around, cities spread out and physical distances become social distances. In few cities are different income groups as isolated as in Los Angeles.
Walking in a city is much more than a question of reducing gas emissions or staying fit. Empty streets are dangerous streets. Moreover, when it's no longer convenient or pleasant to walk, one of the chief occasions for civilized mingling between neighbors and strangers has been lost. When car life replaces street life, human interaction is reduced to a primitive level: isolated drivers honking at each other, competing for parking spaces, racing for the next light.
What, then, should be done? It's no coincidence that most of the destruction took place in the commercial strips fronting the broad avenues. These mini-malls form a kind of no man's land, places to drive by, not walk through.
The exclusionary urban zoning that bans residential uses from commercial streets should be modified to produce the blend of shops, offices, and apartments we see in places like Venice, Calif., or Annapolis, Md. These are the virtues that once characterized most U.S. towns: a rich mixture of uses, lots of people and pleasant places to walk.
Walking is practical, however, only when the density of buildings allows these different uses to be close together. Modifying zoning and regulations to permit apartments and offices to be built over shops, for example, and allowing housing lots to be smaller, increases overall density and reduces sprawl. So does changing building regulations to allow garage apartments. (This also increases the supply of affordable housing.) Introducing short streets at mid-block also encourages people to walk rather than drive.
The mingling of different functions presupposes abandoning one of the worst inventions of well-meaning urban reformers: the public housing project. Warehousing the poor in quarantined districts of identical two-story apartment buildings, as is done in Los Angeles, is as destructive to the city as it is to the occupants.
If public housing must be built -- the present overcrowding in South-Central requires it -- it should only be as individual buildings, not as large-scale projects. Smaller-scale construction would also lend itself to the use of neighborhood contractors. If tenant ownership is to be encouraged, housing should consist of small rowhouses or bungalow courts, not large apartment blocks.
Another planning convention that needs re-evaluation is the separation of industry from housing. When new factories are built in South-Central, they should not be isolated in industrial parks but located within neighborhoods. If the factories are small, they can be on residential streets. Children can grow up seeing men and women at work. If some of the workers are from elsewhere, so much the better; the neighborhood becomes a place for us and them, not just for us against them.
More than 30 years ago, Jane Jacobs suggested many of these changes in "The Death and Life of Great American Cities." This landmark book was a reaction to the planning orthodoxy of the 1950's, when inner cities were devastated by urban renewal and highway construction. Unfortunately, the same policies prevailed when cities were rebuilt following the urban riots of 1965. We must do better this time.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy

BYLINE: By LAUREL GRAEBER

 BODY:
THE KITCHEN GOD'S WIFE, by Amy Tan. (Ivy, $5.99.) In Ms. Tan's second novel, a Chinese-American woman learns the history of her mother, who endured abandonment by her mother, a brutal first marriage and the loss of three children. "This is a chronicle not only of a woman's victimization, but of the unwitting conspiracy within society to ignore and therefore perpetuate the condition," Robb Forman Dew said here last year, calling the book "greatly satisfying."
MEMOIRS, by Andrei Sakharov. Translated by Richard Lourie. (Vintage, $16.) This book is itself testimony to the will of the author, a man who was largely responsible for the development of the Soviet hydrogen bomb and yet became one of the fiercest critics of the nuclear arms race and his country's repressive policies. Despite K.G.B. interference, Sakharov spent 11 years writing these memoirs, which chronicle his life until 1986, when he was allowed to return to Moscow from exile in Gorky. Two years ago our reviewer, Bernard Gwertzman, praised this as an "extraordinary work. . . . One learns, sometimes in embarrassing detail, about the stubbornness of this man, who went on hunger strikes to get his wife a visa to receive medical treatment abroad, who seemed utterly fearless and who never lost his sense of outrage at man's indecency to man." Vintage has also reissued Sakharov's MOSCOW AND BEYOND: 1986 to 1989, translated by Antonina Bouis ($11), which continues his history through the summer preceding his death. 
 THE FORESEEABLE FUTURE, by Reynolds Price. (Ballantine, $5.99.) In what our reviewer, Patricia Hampl, called a "graceful collection," Mr. Price gives the stories of three men, each currently or formerly a soldier. "These people have stories because they have lives," Ms. Hampl said last year. "They must recount them in order to live on."
INSIDE CENTRAL AMERICA: Its People, Politics, and History, by Clifford Krauss. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $11.) Almost everyone agrees that much of Central America is an economic and political disaster; not everyone agrees on who is to blame. Mr. Krauss, a correspondent for The New York Times, holds the individual nations ultimately responsible, but argues that the United States has exacerbated the situation through capricious and deceitful policies, opting, for instance, to fund a war in Nicaragua rather then negotiate with that country's Government. Last year our reviewer, Wayne S. Smith, found this "one of the most useful books yet to appear on the region." Also new in paperback is BLOOD OF BROTHERS: Life and War in Nicaragua, by Stephen Kinzer. (Anchor/Doubleday, $14.) Mr. Kinzer, who established The New York Times's bureau in Managua, analyzes the Sandinistas, asking whether they might have moderated their policies if the United States had not become involved. "It is without doubt the best contemporary history of the Sandinista decade yet to appear," Linda Robinson said here last year.
MAXIMUM BOB, by Elmore Leonard. (Dell, $5.99.) The title character is a Florida judge who routinely gives criminals the maximum sentence. Two who have received this treatment are out to kill him. Last year our reviewer, Barry Gifford, said, "Nobody I've ever read sets up pace, mood and sound better than Elmore Leonard," whom he described as "the greatest living writer of crime fiction."
LEWIS MUMFORD: A Life, by Donald L. Miller. (University of Pittsburgh, $15.95.) An urban visionary, architectural scholar, historian, critic and writer, Lewis Mumford took on many inventive roles in his 94 years. But "as Mr. Miller shrewdly observes, Mr. Mumford's most impressive work of creation was himself," Ada Louise Huxtable said here in 1989, noting that this first full-length biography is "serious and substantial."
DAISY FAY AND THE MIRACLE MAN, by Fannie Flagg. (Warner, $7.99.) Originally published as "Coming Attractions," this novel by the author of "Fried Green Tomatoes at the Whistle Stop Cafe" entertains readers with the journal of Daisy Fay Harper, a 1950's Southern girl who is the daughter of the local film projectionist. Daisy Fay "is just as sweet as her favorite movie-munchin' candy, Bit-O-Honey," our reviewer, Laura Cunningham, said in 1981.
EDUCATED IN ROMANCE: Women, Achievement, and College Culture, by Dorothy C. Holland and Margaret A. Eisenhart. (University of Chicago, $11.95.) Anthropologists who studied the lives of 23 women who graduated in the early 1980's from two Southern public universities -- one predominantly black, the other white -- conclude that for female students, the college climate usually encouraged romantic attachments over scholarship. Last year our reviewer, Joan Jacobs Brumberg, observed that this is a "powerful book," whose "most interesting portion" describes how these students "scaled down their ambitions."
WILDERNESS, by Dennis Danvers. (Pocket Star/Pocket Books, $5.50.) Alice White is both a werewolf and a Cassandra, painfully isolated from others as much by their refusal to believe in her lupine condition as she is by the phenomenon itself. Writing last year in The New York Times, Christopher Lehmann-Haupt admired this "audacious first novel," in which the reader follows the consequences of the heroine's transformation "rapt through the novel's final page."
DOGTOWN, by Mercedes Lambert. (Penguin, $4.95.) Resembling a female version of the movie "48 Hours," this novel features Whitney Logan, a lawyer, teaming up with Lupe, a Chicana prostitute, to solve a murder in East Los Angeles. "The cultural friction between Whitney and Lupe sustains this lively, if unlikely, adventure," Marilyn Stasio said here last year.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 20; Column 3; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1020 words

HEADLINE: Superpower Blues

BYLINE: By Alan Wolfe; Alan Wolfe is the dean of the graduate faculty at the New School for Social Research and editor of "America at Century's End."

 BODY:

THE DEMOCRACY TRAP
The Perils of the Post-Cold War World.
By Graham E. Fuller.
285 pp. New York:
Dutton. $20. 
 LIKE Salman Rushdie's character Saleem Sinai, who was born at precisely the moment that India achieved its independence from Britain, the largest generation of Americans came into the world simultaneously with the start of the cold war. The generation that routinely ducked under its desks through air-raid drills, attended college during the war in Vietnam, married and started families amid the energy crisis, and prospered (or failed) in the go-go 80's now faces a serious challenge. Can it cohere without the cold war, which had, for so long, defined its existence?
Graham E. Fuller -- a former Foreign Service official who now is a senior political analyst at the RAND Corporation -- believes that Americans will long for the days of the cold war when they begin to face the problems raised by its end. And that is the more optimistic account of "The Democracy Trap," for he also argues that Americans may not be able to face those problems at all.
Mr. Fuller correctly understands that the cold war period was the exception, not the rule. (So, one could argue, were the postwar economic boom, the expansion to the suburbs, the Ozzie-and-Harriet nuclear family and the space race.) For all the angst of the 60's, the baby-boom generation has lived with remarkably little international conflict, in part because of the stability produced by stalemated superpowers possessing nuclear arms. The generation that came before knew a world war and a Great Depression. The generation that comes after, Mr. Fuller argues, is likely to face a world characterized by intense nationalist conflict, frequent civil wars, religious frenzy and hatred and, inevitably, greater violence. The paramount challenge we will face, Mr. Fuller maintains, is preparing ourselves for the return to a more "normal" world of war and instability.
The author does not believe we will be able to rise to the challenge. What stands in our way is what is most precious about us: our democratic system. For all its virtues, he believes, democracy is a trap. It encourages us to indulge in the politics of immediate gratification. It enables interest groups to put their parochial needs before the needs of the whole. It rewards leaders who emphasize good news, not hard work. It exalts individualism when what we need is to work together. Mr. Fuller writes: "The United States with its contemporary designer morality just might have something to gain from looking back to societies in which moral values are less subject to the tides of social preference or the interpretations and rationalizations of sociologists."
Walter Lippmann, Reinhold Niebuhr and Hans Morgenthau were only some of the influential American intellectuals who also perceived contradictions between the domestic needs of American democracy and the international demands of superpower status. Americans, it seems, are always in need of thinkers who can cut through the cycle of can-do optimism and total withdrawal that characterizes American attitudes toward the rest of the world.
But unlike Lippmann and other realists who were as clearsighted in talking about the United States as they were in understanding the world, Mr. Fuller -- who knows much about Islam, Africa and the Soviet Union -- is dyspeptic when he discusses his own country. It may well be that his many years of service outside this country have colored his views of what takes place inside. Appalled at nearly everything he sees, he delivers a jeremiad against everything he does not like: affirmative action, ethnic consciousness, television, the underclass, drugs and litigation -- without ever demonstrating the role that any of them play in our foreign policy.
Whereas most people around the world want to copy the United States, Mr. Fuller wants this country to copy what he has learned around the world. Intrigued by Muslim notions of determinism and the frailty of man, he suggests, with some seriousness, the virtues of an Islamic republic for America. (He believes that "Arabs are still fair game in American culture for any kind of gross ethnic caricature, racial slur or outrageous stereotype -- they are the only major ethnic group left that can be treated prejudiciously with total impunity.") Surely it is the Orientalist in him who can suggest, in a passage that would make Walter Lippmann blanch, that "we need to be more conscious of the Yin and Yang, the concept of complementarity and balance of virtues that seems somehow alien to our American culture."
"The Democracy Trap" is anything but a tightly argued, well-researched and historically grounded effort to predict the future by studying the past. It is, rather, an odd mixture of whatever is on Graham Fuller's mind, some of it interesting, some trivial. Mr. Fuller is on target when he says that Americans are ill prepared to deal with such issues as global poverty or the collapse of empire. We may indeed come to wish for the good old days of the cold war, when understanding the world was so much easier. We are surely not at the end of history but rather at the start of a historical era we can barely comprehend. But we will have to wait for books more rooted in a realistic view of the world and our place in it before we can understand the paths before us.
 
 
 
CULTURE SHOCKS
 Americans generally have little recognition of the extent to which the immigrant culture and society of America, and its deep-rooted Anglo-Saxon sense of rule of law, is absolutely unique in the world. We are therefore less intuitively equipped to understand foreign cultures than almost any other country on earth. Young Americans are generally shocked the first time they encounter in depth the attitudes, thinking and culture even of a European society, much less societies of the third world. The person who grows up in Zaire is better equipped to understand the political and cultural motivations of an Egyptian, a Brazilian or an Indian than is an American. -- From "The Democracy Trap."

TYPE: Review

PUB-DATE: June 7, 1992

SECTION: Section 6; Page 25; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 5012 words

HEADLINE: The MacArthur Truffle Hunt

BYLINE: By Anne Matthews; Anne Matthews, who teaches nonfiction at Princeton University, writes frequently on higher education.

 BODY:
Like sweeping the lottery or landing a movie contract in a Hollywood soda shop, winning a MacArthur fellowship has become an American fantasy: the ringing phone, the congratulations from foundation headquarters, the neighbors' awe, the colleagues' grinding envy, the lifetime of lonely creative struggle justified, the fat quarterly checks.
Those designated MacArthur fellows have learned of their no-strings grants while mowing a suburban New Jersey lawn, dining in a San Francisco artist's loft, climbing the Wind River Range in Wyoming, camping with Australian aborigines. First reactions are seldom inventive: 
 "Oh, my God."
"Oh, my God."
"Oh, my God."
"Whooahhaiiee!" (A Southern community organizer, leaping and yelling and knocking over furniture.)
"Yes, I've been waiting for your call," said one writer, coolly.
"Can I ring you back to confirm?" a political scientist pleaded. "I played this joke on a colleague of mine last year."
And once there was only a long silence, then a distant thump: the sound of a body hitting a laboratory floor in Cambridge, Mass., as a winner fainted.
Through its MacArthur fellows program, the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation of Chicago has, since 1981, identified creative individuals and handed them aggregate sums (before tax) of $150,000 to $375,000, distributed over a five-year period, to be used however they please. Although people from all occupations are eligible, no one can apply for MacArthur fellowships -- often called, to the foundation's intense annoyance, "genius awards." Winners have ranged in age from 18 to 82; the older the recipient, the larger the sum awarded. According to a program spokesman, it was felt that older people required more money than younger people to allow them to do whatever they wished. This year's awards will be announced on June 16.
The program's romantic, supply-side view of creativity assumes that paying highly original people to do what they like will, in the long run, benefit society. "We mail the checks and get out of the way," says the program's director, Kenneth W. Hope. It's a very 1980's concept, ambitious and wildly self-confident, a public act of faith in mavericks and innovators -- and in human nature.
Fellows say a MacArthur allows them the luxury of saying no: to the lecture circuit, to second and third jobs, to the time-devouring demands of fund raising. For winners from the low-rent, high-anxiety worlds of arts and public service, MacArthur manna can be very welcome.
"When the phone call came, two years ago, I was sitting in a loft on New York's Lower East Side, broke, exhausted and depressed," says Michael Moschen, a 37-year-old juggler, as he stretches his hamstrings in the sunny front room of an 18th-century Hudson Valley farmhouse rented with MacArthur money. Behind him, a sofa is piled with the raw material of future performances: glass rods, tall wood and metal triangles, research folders bulging with photographs, sketches and movement charts.
"Without the MacArthur, I'd be playing Las Vegas to feed my family, hating every minute." Two crystal balls, then three, then four, sweep upward from his hands. "Now I can keep taking risks and stay truthful to the work. I'm up till midnight, the ideas are coming so fast. But I still wonder, 'Why me?' "
Ellen Stewart, director of La Mama Experimental Theater Club in New York, bought an ancient monastery in Umbria, in central Italy. She is restoring it as an international artists' residence. In a madcap gesture, John P. Gaventa, a community organizer and sociologist who lives in Appalachia, ordered a load of gravel for his driveway; he also used MacArthur checks to visit other organizers in Mexico and India. The novelist Leslie Marmon Silko says MacArthur money let her write the novel "Almanac of the Dead." Some fellows hire research assistants. Some pay off debts. Others spread their largesse.
Karen Uhlenbeck, 49, a professor of mathematics at the University of Texas at Austin, earmarked MacArthur money to help female mathematicians. "I was completely obscure when I won," she says. "No one had given me anything before. No one had ever believed in me this much. I feel an obligation to return their trust by living an unexpected life." The award money has allowed Uhlenbeck to retool professionally. "I finally, finally took time from my teaching to learn physics," she says.
Sam Maloof, a California woodworker, has set up youth scholarships at an Aspen, Colo., arts center, and Hipolito (Paul) Roldan, head of the Hispanic Housing Development Corporation in Chicago, established a $100,000 education fund for young Hispanic people planning careers in community development.
Some newly minted fellows, however, take to their beds, unable to handle the sudden fame and the intrusion from the outside world that comes with it. "I didn't get up for a week," recalls one social scientist. "Ate crackers under the sheets. Hid from reporters and camera crews. Cried a lot." About 1 winner in 20 seems to suffer extended creative block, or believes the prize damaged his or her career because of colleagues' jealousy, or claims that award-related stresses led to mental or physical illness. (The MacArthur fellows program thoughtfully offers winners and their families five-year insurance for medical, dental, vision and psychiatric care.)
"If you are a good person to begin with," observes William J. McGill, the former chairman of the MacArthur awards' selection committee, "a MacArthur makes you saintly and helps your work. If you have flaws, the absolute freedom of the award quickly magnifies them. If you have some deep personal weakness, some mean streak, a MacArthur will assuredly tear you apart."
So far, 350 MacArthurs have been awarded: 109 in the sciences, 81 in the arts, 70 in the humanities, 53 in public affairs, 37 in the social sciences. The tab for this experiment in encouraging creativity is now $103,833,322 and counting, a very modest slice of the foundation's asset base. With securities and real estate (the foundation is the largest owner of undeveloped land in Palm Beach County, Fla.) valued at $3.2 billion, MacArthur is the fifth-wealthiest foundation in the United States.
Inside the MacArthur foundation's South Dearborn Street headquarters -- an 1894 confection of Chicago School architecture, all Tiffany glass mosaics, bronze-gilt bas-reliefs and wrought-iron stairways -- the fellows program is only one of many financing schemes. The foundation sponsors programs on world population issues, tropical medicine, environmental conservation, peace and international cooperation, mass communications and mental-health research, as well as cultural and community aid in Illinois and Florida, the states where its founder lived and worked.
But outside the building, the fellows program stirs more controversy than all the foundation's other ventures combined. Asking for a list of major literary works, musical achievements, crusading policy reports or scientific breakthroughs achieved with MacArthur-bought freedom is a fast way to start many fellows hyperventilating. In fact, most winners simply hire a crack investment counselor.
To the question, "How did the prize alter your life and your work?" the answer, over and over, is: "It didn't, really." MacArthur demographics suggest why. Nearly three-fourths of MacArthur fellows are middle-aged and older men -- almost all of them white -- many affiliated with top research institutions on the East and West Coasts, notably Harvard, Princeton, Stanford and Berkeley.
For winners already equipped with healthy incomes as well as access to grant funds larger than any MacArthur, the MacArthur means status, not survival. "Oh, 20 years ago I might have gone to Paris to write," admits one scholar, wistfully, "but now I have a cat and a dog and kids in school and a wife who works. This windfall is going for college tuitions and high-return CD's." He thinks a moment. "All right, maybe a patio."
Overall, MacArthurs seem to favor creative people from the Northeast (of the 350 fellows, 121 live in the Northeast or New England). Questioned about this, Ken Hope, the program director, sighs. "We're trying for a redefinition of creativity here, a fracturing of national perceptions of value. It takes a while. But we've also been trying hard for nominators and selectors very definitely from nonelite institutions, or from outside the academic world altogether, representing the U.S. better in terms of race, place and gender."
Ah, gender. Why so few women (67, out of 350) receive MacArthurs has baffled the foundation from the start. A 1988 internal report reveals that more than a quarter of MacArthur nominators have been women, yet while females nominate equal numbers of men and women as candidates, males propose four men for every woman.
The foundation has tried several variations on MacArthur financing, from compensation for employers should fellows decide to go on leave or work part time, to the lifetime-income MacArthur laureate award, granted only three times (most notably to the feisty geneticist Barbara McClintock) before it was killed (after board members began to battle over who would get the money should some future laureate go mad or lapse into a coma).
Officials at other foundations note the MacArthur fellows program has never really decided if its job is to reward creativity or to stimulate it, if it wants to be an American Nobel Prize or a fairy godmother to talents unappreciated by mainstream society.
A FOUNDATION, THE cultural critic Dwight Macdonald once noted, is an island of money surrounded by people who want some. Protecting great fortunes from inheritance and estate taxes while performing public good has been the goal of private philanthropy for nearly a century. Except for a statutory requirement to give away 5 percent of investment income, American foundations, large and small, operate with few constraints.
MacArthur is the youngest of the country's top foundations -- the Rockefeller, Ford and Mellon foundations, the Getty Trust, the Pew Memorial Trust -- and, in its early days, the brashest.
John D. MacArthur (1897-1978), son of a Pennsylvania hellfire preacher, was an eighth-grade dropout who created the mail-order insurance firm of Bankers Life and Casualty during the Depression and built a Florida real estate empire. At the time of his death, he was one of two billionaires in the United States.
Puckish and aggressively eccentric, MacArthur lived for years in a Palm Beach Shores hotel, running his business from its coffee shop and reputedly saying, at the close of each deal, "Pay for your coffee on the way out." Largely to confound the Internal Revenue Service, he endowed his foundation with five million shares of Bankers Life stock but left the board of trustees no instructions. He had made the money; now they could figure out how to spend it -- thus making the MacArthur the only top-rank foundation to be created without a focused giving agenda.
Early MacArthur foundation trustees, mostly conservative Illinois businessmen and MacArthur cronies, had limited experience in world-class foundation work and limited patience with the Ivy League, Manhattan-centered world view of their Eastern peers. As the board felt its way into the alien universe of charitable donation, its early grants were a grab bag: here $25,000 to Save-a-Pet of Highland Park, Ill.; there $500,000, at the urging of Paul Harvey, the radio commentator and a board member, to buy bulletproof jackets for the Chicago police.
The foundation's first cohesive financing effort was the fellows program, with John D. MacArthur's only son, J. Roderick, as the force behind it. A lifelong liberal in politics and a social rebel, the younger MacArthur was an expatriate writer in postwar Europe until his father rejected his pleas for a larger allowance. By the 1970's, however, Rod MacArthur had amassed his own fortune by founding the Bradford Exchange, an international clearinghouse for commemorative china plates. In 1980, he acquired Hammacher Schlemmer, the specialty store and mail-order house of luxury gadgets.
"Rod MacArthur was the kind of guy who harangued total strangers in restaurants about PCB levels in whitefish," says Ken Hope, looking out his office window at the scarlet Calder stabile in Chicago's crowded civic plaza below. "But he also fiercely admired innovators and gadflies and mavericks, saw that a billion dollars of foundation money could back a program to help them, and he set off on a quest to do just that.
"Rod," Hope adds, "installed a testing lab at Hammacher Schlemmer to find the best consumer products. He was just as convinced that you could identify, evaluate and rate highly creative people."
The talent search was organized by F. Champion Ward, a former Ford Foundation vice president. Then it was staffed and directed for four years by Gerald Freund, formerly with the Rockefeller Foundation. Bitter rows over budgets and fellows nominations (especially in the arts) marked the program's early years. The foundation's fortunes proved more turbulent still; Rod MacArthur accused the board of mismanaging assets and paying themselves excessive fees. His suit to dissolve the foundation and appoint a new board was withdrawn only shortly before his death, in 1984, from pancreatic cancer, the disease that had claimed his father. Rod MacArthur's lieutenant, Ken Hope, took over the fellows program in 1982 and will leave this summer. No new director has been named.
TRUFFLE HUNTING, THE talent for recognizing talent, is crucial to the MacArthur fellows program. To become a fellow, you must first catch the attention of a rotating corps of 120 anonymous nominators (Box, page 26), who are allowed unlimited nominations during a one- to two-year term, paid $1,000 and sworn to secrecy. Impostors are a constant menace. To cause palpitations among America's gifted and talented, simply ask mysteriously for a resume "to send to Chicago."
Nominators, more than half of whom are academics, covertly gather preliminary data (publications, videotapes, names of references), some scouting for unsung originals in their own professions, others gleaning names at parties or through magazines, newspapers and television. One M.I.T. economist would nominate only short-story writers.
A staff of nine processes more than 300 nominations yearly, dodging the pitfalls and blood feuds that are inevitably a part of the file-building process. "You soon learn to spot special pleading or orchestrated campaigns by friends and enemies," explains a researcher. Staff members also check out candidates by attending lectures or performances incognito.
Candidate folders then move to the selection committee, a revolving cast of 10 to 15 scientific, academic or literary heavyweights, like Saul Bellow and Jonas Salk. Selectors meet eight times a year in Chicago hotels or at foundation headquarters. Three criteria currently govern the granting of a MacArthur: Is the person's work important for society? Is the candidate truly creative and promising? Will the award make a difference at this point in his or her career?
"Discussion of nominees becomes intellectual combat so intense it leaves you elevated and drained," recalls William McGill, president emeritus of Columbia University, who was chairman of the program's selection committee in the mid-1980's and is the first selector to speak publicly on the process of choosing MacArthur fellows. "Salk used to say we should make a bouquet of potentials and achievements. This didn't always work. One incensed board member told me that we picked so many humanists it was like an all-shortstop baseball team."
Winnowing starts in September, as selectors reject hundreds of candidates as too eccentric, too unformed, too marginal. By May, about 40 finalists remain, and the real battles begin. A farmer who has developed a blight-resistant potato? Thumbs down: not sufficiently showy. Four theoretical physicists specializing in string theory (and known henceforth in foundation circles as the String Quartet)? Yes, despite concern over giving multiple awards in the same field. A lobbyist for fireproof fabrics, a nautical archeologist from Texas, an expert in Sherpa Buddhism? All approved.
ON A WINTER MORNING IN central Wisconsin, the ornithologist George Archibald is dancing with cranes. A 1984 MacArthur fellow, Archibald is a globe-trotting expert on wildlife conservation -- at a crane-studies conference in Pakistan one day and in the Mekong Delta exploring wintering grounds for the threatened Sarus crane on another. Now, puffy-eyed and jet-lagged, he trots from enclosure to wire-mesh enclosure at the International Crane Foundation in Baraboo, Wis., greeting old friends.
"Butch!" he shouts. "Hey, Susie, how's it going?" Suddenly, Archibald leaps straight up in the air, arms waving, throws back his head and looses a raucous cry: "Broo-OO! Broo-OO!"
Four feet away, a pair of White-naped cranes point their slender bills at the pale winter sun and match Archibald's wavering note. All three leap and flap, hooting in concert. Man and cranes are much of a height, and their long blue shadows move and tangle on the snow.
"Looking good, Suze," says Archibald, panting. His crane-rescue program has raised 400 birds in the last 15 years and helped an international team save the whooping crane from extinction. Besides helping build a study center for crane research, Archibald's MacArthur money pays his way to scientific conferences and assists wildlife biologists in need.
Like many MacArthur fellows, Archibald notes that meeting other winners, like the reclusive novelist Cormac McCarthy, is one of the award's great pleasures. Official fellows reunions (attendance optional) have been held in Chicago every 18 months, with all expenses paid for fellows still receiving foundation checks. Half slumber party and half symposium, meetings feature mass forays to Rush Street in search of blues clubs and lectures by fellows on their current interests, which range from homeopathy and Nostradamus to the medical implications of applied molecular evolution to the sex life of yeast. Children and pets often attend. So do spouses.
Some fellows, wary of typecasting, avoid these get-togethers. Others -- notably Joan Abrahamson -- are pressing for professional interaction. A 1985 fellow, Abrahamson, 41 and a member of Yale's first coed class (majoring in philosophy, psychology and fine arts), has an M.A. (in education) from Stanford, a law degree from Berkeley and a Ph.D. (in learning environments) from Harvard. She was assistant chief of staff to George Bush when he was Vice President. MacArthur money, she says, let her build a new painting studio; leave corporate law to found and head a think tank, in Los Angeles, for applications of creativity to public policy, and to have two children.
Abrahamson is also an inveterate organizer of expeditions and informal gatherings of MacArthur fellows. "We hope to form working groups of fellows to think on policy issues like disabilities, environment and public education," she says. "We want to interact, evolve, explore, experiment, pool our abilities."
Seated in the dining room of the Hay-Adams Hotel in Washington after a hard day of heated arguments at a meeting of the Commission of Fine Arts -- a panel that rules on the commissioning and placement of public art in the capital -- she flips open a photo album of a 1990 expedition to Hawaii. Swimsuited policy analysts lounge at a torchlit poolside on Maui as a theoretical physicist lectures on infinity and galactic spirals. A historian of the Ottoman Empire and a biophysicist on a whale-watching cruise lean perilously over a boat rail, discussing whale song. A marine biologist scrambles up an active volcano's rocky slope.
"Not coordinating all this amazing talent seems a terrible waste," says Abrahamson, flipping tactfully past a shot of an astrophysicist balancing a lava cone on his head. "We're trying to get MacArthur scientists and artists together to improve America's science education -- maybe a film where Michael Moschen and Jacques d'Amboise illustrate physics through juggling and dance, with help from MacArthur chemists, mathematicians, educators and computer-graphics experts. It's all a way to answer the question that concerns many of us: You were handed this gift; how are you going to give something back?"
ASKED TO ANALYZE THE MacArthur roster of talented individuals, some observers of the nonprofit realm leap to praise. "Thrilling." "Enormously important." "Lots more diverse and progressive lately." "Finally getting away from academics."
Others savage. "Constipated." "Safe." "Revoltingly chichi." "Survival of the blandest." "Kafkaesque." "A godlike search for geniuses under rocks." "The usual suspects, plus the very famous and the very weird."
There are those who say that subsidized mavericks are a contradiction in terms. Or they note the fields consistently underrepresented on MacArthur lists: engineering, business, secondary education, state government, agronomy, computing, fine arts. Privately, many fellows and nominators worry that the selection committee seems to have a persistent weak spot for self-promoters. "MacArthur fellows talk beautifully," says one academic. "I'm just not sure how bright they actually are." And many nominators, former and current, complain that their most interesting talent finds rarely win awards.
Pablo Eisenberg, for example, who is executive director of the Center for Community Change in Washington, would have liked a MacArthur for Khoa Le Xuan, executive director of the Indochina Resource Action Center and former vice president of the University of Saigon. Mark Smith, a novelist teaching at the University of New Hampshire, proposed the writer and historian Shelby Foote a decade before he acquired fame as a commentator on the public-television series "The Civil War." Again, no result.
Looking for self-evaluation, the foundation sought feedback four years ago from nominators, selectors and referees in the fellows program. A sampling of their comments:
 "I view this program as an outstanding and unique American analogy to the 'national treasure' concept that exists in Denmark, Japan and presumably elsewhere."
 "I am afraid there is too much evidence that this is just a kind of payoff either to young smart alecks or old has-beens. Sorry, but someone should tell you."
 "I salute the MacArthur foundation for being bold and courageous. There are, unfortunately, too few risk takers in our times, or institutions that value romance -- romance of knowledge, of things uncertain, of things beyond measurement. . . . All society benefits when the exceptionally talented are enabled to perform, to create, to devote more time to what they do."
 "The selections made in fields I know . . . are idiosyncratic when they don't smack of patronage and cronyism. In attempting to short-circuit the long-established ways of scholarship, the foundation does nothing but mischief."
 "Almost everyone I know would like to have a MacArthur fellowship. Those that say they wouldn't are kidding themselves. . . . It would seem fairer to have some accountability built in, to ask for some productivity from the fellows."
There is talk of an independent selection panel, the names made public, as with the Pulitzer and Guggenheim boards. Ken Hope is dubious about this: "Selectors need to be perfectly frank in discussing candidates and free from any pressure." Pablo Eisenberg, a former nominator, disagrees. "There's a big unspoken class issue here. Where are the neighborhood organizers, the labor people, the social workers, the consumer advocates? The whole process badly needs sunshine."
Others would like to see a shift away from awarding MacArthurs to scientists. Stanley N. Katz, head of the American Council of Learned Societies, argues that the scientific world is already skilled at nurturing its creative, while arts and humanities talent suffers from obscurity and neglect.
"Since 1983," Katz says, "funds from private philanthropy for humanities have declined by 20 percent, as has their dollar value, just when the ratio of grant applications to acceptances is soaring. If the MacArthur foundation really cares about unsung endangered talent, they should do a grant program for young humanists."
Says Gerald Freund, first director of the fellows program: "When the program began, all manner of techniques were essayed to find and aid creative women and men. That adventurous beginning has given way, as so often happens, to entrenched routines and easy answers. Only a searching program review will determine why."
Whether the fellows program stays the same or undergoes a transformation is up to the president and the board of the MacArthur foundation to decide. Since 1989, the head of the foundation has been Adele Simmons, a former president of Hampshire College with three generations of ties to Chicago society and business. Simmons, 51, has increasingly given the foundation an activist cast, with grants going to such projects as women's health networks, Chicago school reform, energy research and rain-forest preservation.
Queried about the future of the fellows program, Simmons deftly sidesteps the question. "We are a very young foundation entering a necessary period of assessment and awareness," she says. "We will be focusing on several programs and approaches that have become outmoded. The foundation is much more than the fellows."
In the meantime, reforming the MacArthur fellows program remains a favorite parlor game in nonprofit circles. As is listing those who should get MacArthurs but haven't. Perennial favorites are the writer Eudora Welty, the consumer activist Ralph Nader, the Kansas plant geneticist Wes Jackson and the painter Richard Diebenkorn. But even the harshest critic, after hurling denunciations, will quickly add: "Of course, I wouldn't mind getting one myself."
Asked if anyone has ever turned down a MacArthur award or refused to cash the checks, Ken Hope leans back, smiling slightly. "Oh, no one refuses us," he says. "No one. Never ever."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 31; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1013 words

HEADLINE: TV VIEW;
Vive la Difference (If There Were One)

BYLINE: By Walter Goodman

 BODY:
Why an all-female political talk show? A perfectly good answer is, why not? Yet one presumes that the originators of "To the Contrary," the weekly half-hour public broadcasting series that began in April, had something grander in mind, something like bringing female perspective, insight and sensibility to a line of work dominated by men.
A recent sampling leaves some doubt that such a perspective exists. Anyone reading a transcript of the discussions would be hard put to say wherein they differ from all-male or mixed offerings like NBC's "McLaughlin Group," on which "To the Contrary" seems to have been modeled. 
 The programs are taped on Thursday and offered to public stations in time for Friday evening showing. (Channel 13 expresses its enthusiasm by carrying them at 6:30 A.M. on Tuesdays. They are also on Channel 31 at 11 A.M. on Wednesdays.) The format is straightforward. Mini-documentaries are sometimes used to lead into the discussion, but the talk is the thing.
Bonnie Erbe, a legal affairs correspondent for the Mutual/NBC Radio network, presides over a changing panel that last month included two conservatives, Linda Chavez of the American Enterprise Institute and Kate O'Beirne of the Heritage Foundation. They were joined at each outing by two women more or less to their left, like Dorothy Butler Gilliam, a Washington Post columnist; Julianne Malveaux, an economist and contributor to various publications, and Linda Wertheimer of National Public Radio. The syndicated columnist Ellen Goodman and the Democratic consultant Ann Lewis have also appeared, and Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the former United States Ambassador to the United Nations, is promised.
The subjects are up to the minute, the pace brisk, the opinions unsurprising. Although Ms. Erbe tries to allow her guests equal time, the forceful combination of Chavez-O'Beirne gave a conservative edge to the programs I watched, as they attacked big government and the welfare system, extolled the benefits of a reduction in the capital gains tax and celebrated "family values."
At least one of the liberals can be counted on to take a diametrically opposing view, and the usual positions are staked out. Where Ms. Chavez and Ms. O'Beirne traced the sources of inner-city malaise to the welfare programs of the 1960's, Ms. Malveaux and Ms. Gilliam blamed the Reagan-Bush Administrations. Ms. Malveaux attributed the Los Angeles riots to unemployment, and Ms. Gilliam said Mr. Bush is "President only of the rich."
Since only five or six minutes are allowed to an issue and Ms. Erbe has no compunction about cutting discussions off -- her role model in this regard seems to be John McLaughlin, though she cannot quite match his authoritarian style -- guests are under pressure to sloganize. Ms. Malveaux called for an "urban Marshall Plan." Ms. Gilliam said the Los Angeles riots evidenced the "alienation" of young black men. Ms. O'Beirne, quick on the draw, spoke of "the poverty lobby" and "the politics of victimization" and of inner- city people "living on a liberal plantation."
If there is such a thing as a special female sensibility regarding certain public issues, it made itself felt in a hot argument over Murphy Brown's famous decision to bear a child without benefit of husband. At times you couldn't make out what anyone was saying, just like the squalling on "The McLaughlin Group."
Chavez-O'Beirne paralleled the Dan Quayle school of criticism in decrying the decline in values exemplified by Ms. Brown, which they blamed on what Ms. O'Beirne called "the liberal media elite." Ms. Malveaux called Ms. Chavez and Ms. O'Beirne puritans and said the only problem for single mothers is jobs. Ms. Wertheimer observed mildly that Murphy Brown could hardly serve as a role model for inner-city women. "Television doesn't lead, it follows," she said. But nothing could stop the others from blasting away at their accustomed targets in the customary lingo.
Now and then, what in less enlightened times might have been interpreted as an inimitably female approach emerged in the form of stories of personal experiences. After Ms. Chavez delivered a standard lament about the breakdown in inner cities of social institutions like the family, Barbara Reynolds, of USA Today, who is black, announced that she is a single mother who was once mugged by a white man.
No one was discourteous enough to point out that she was about as typical an inner-city single mother as Murphy Brown, but Chavez-O'Beirne did hasten to the defense of the two-parent family, and Ms. Chavez provided figures on the disproportionate amount of violent crime committed by black men.
An occasional guest seems to be chosen for multicultural considerations. On the subject of racism, the main contribution of Dinah Eng, an editor for Gannett News Service, was that people ought to be nicer to one another. "We are all responsible for ourselves," she disclosed and recommended that children be raised with love. The prescription was received with polite nods.
The program's pace and spirit makes things difficult for a journalist like Ms. Wertheimer, who although of a liberal bent tended to be less doctrinaire and more measured than her accomplices. Taking the role that Jack Germond occupies on "The McLaughlin Group," she raised sensible questions about the notion of urban enterprise zones without coming down for or against. And you can't imagine her declaring, as Ms. Gilliam did about the Rodney G. King case, "With this jury, nothing would have made a difference."
Anyway, before you know it, Ms. Erbe is announcing "the wrap question," a piece of jargon she must have picked up around the studio and, with luck, will lose in time. "That's it!" she declares, and it's on to another brief give-and-take.
So that's it. The wrap question is, why an all-female talk show? Well, to repeat, why not? At the very least, or most, "To the Contrary" demonstrates that despite the stereotype about some people's penchant for changing their minds, women can be just as wearyingly predictable as men.

HEADLINE: ROMANCING THE POOR

 BODY:
Jessica Hagedorn's article "Romancing the Poor" (May 10) opens with a description of Smokey Mountain, a garbage dump on the outskirts of Metro Manila, and goes on to describe the newest megamalls in the city.
May I point out that Smokey Mountain is like any other dump site in a large city, and that megamalls are also part of a growing metropolis? But neither are representative of Metro Manila or the entire Philippines. 
 It is true that we have our share of slums, poverty and homeless people, but our Government and people are doing their best to solve these social and economic problems. And we are trying to manage our affairs through the democratic process. The national elections are part of that process.
What is important is the process of getting and respecting the popular will.
 
RODOLFO A. ARIZALA
Consul General of the Philippines
New York, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Condominiums in TriBeCa;
Shedding the Landlord Role, Gradually

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
HER specialty is design and marketing. His is construction and finance. There was financial backing in the family.
That amalgam made developers of not a few young couples in New York City in the 80's. Among them were Virginia Alexander Millhiser and Timothy M. Millhiser. They never foresaw a joint career when they were married in 1981, but three years later they bought a vacant six-story building at at 542 La Guardia Place, between Bleecker and West Third Streets in Greenwich Village. They rebuilt it into 10 fully finished apartments and sold them all within six months at an average price of $358 a square foot. 
 "We did very well," said Mr. Millhiser.
Onward they went to other projects, but downward spun the sales market in the late 80's. It reached a nadir, Mr. Millhiser said, toward the end of 1990 during the crisis over Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. So they stopped trying to sell the lavishly finished apartments in their project of the time -- the conversion of 55 White Street in TriBeCa -- and rented them out instead.
Now, with the prices down and the market marginally improved, Millhiser & Company is at a crossroads that is familiar to sponsors and other owners of new or rehabilitated, but unsold, renter-occupied condominiums,
They are starting again to market their apartments. But there are varying degrees of eagerness to sell. For some, a firmer rental market and the decline in interest rates has lessened the pressure to sell, espeicially after a substantial fraction of their apartments have already been sold. While some developers last year were so eager to sell empty apartments that they resorted to auctions, others are more inclined to bide their time. In any event, rentals in condominium buildings are likely to remain a fixture of the residential market for some time.
"We're trying to achieve a balance," Mr. Millhiser said. "We would like to sell a couple of units but we're not in a rush because some of the apartments make money for us. We can take our time."
The White Street project had adjustable-rate financing, so it has benefited in the last three years by the decline in interest rates, Mr. Millhiser said.
Tenants are often at a crossroads as well. Many of them made housing decisions in the late 80's and early 90's that they considered short-term at the time. Among the renters at 55 White Street, for example, are Michael Connolly and his wife, Jamie Stern, lawyers with two young sons who sold their apartment on lower Broadway two years ago because they outgrew it and have rented a 1,900-square-foot condominium for $3,400 a month while trying to decide on their next step.
"We are discussing buying apartments, and looking in Brooklyn Heights -- our older son is in school there -- and we're also looking at houses in the suburbs, but then we would be commuters," Mr. Connolly said. "For the life of us we can't decide what to do."
Another renter is Gerry Kagan and his wife, Kristina Boden, who moved from the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn into a 2,300-square-foot apartment renting for $3,500 a month. Now they and a friend are rebuilding two vacant four-story buildings on Harrison Street for their own use. "The prices now are down to the point where they make sense," said Mr. Kagan, an investor who has rebuilt small brownstones in Brooklyn himself.
In some cases, developers say they always intended to hold some of the units they built as long-term investments. Douglas Gardner,partner in the group that built Reade House, an 80-unit condominium at 311 Greenwich Street in TriBeCa, where the developers had successful sales, held 25 apartments as rentals. The same pattern was followed at the same developer's 52-unit new building at 108 Fifth Avenue, at 16th Street.
FIGURES on condominium sales in Manhattan compiled by Yale Robbins, the real estate publishing and consulting firm, show that the total dollar volume last year was $732 million on 2,006 sales. That compares with $918 million for 2,586 sales in 1990. The high for the 80's was $1.9 billion on 4,858 sales in 1989.
The figures are based on closings, not contract signings, so the 1992 numbers so far don't reflect spring sales, said Henry Robbins, a principal at Yale Robbins. But closings in the first quarter of this year were running well ahead of last year's first quarter. The figures are 453 closings this year against 327 last year. The total dollar volume rose to $140 million, against $127 million last year.
Throughout the 80's the total inventory of condominiums itself was rising sharply, as condominiums replaced rentals and co-ops as the main form of new multifamily housing. Ten years ago there were 4,100 condominium apartments in Manhattan, Yale Robbins said. This year there are 50,400.
Riding out sales cycles isn't easy for small development companies, and it requires changes in direction. The Millhisers now work, for example, for co-op owners who are enlarging their apartments, and they provide construction services to co-op corporations. They also plan to bid for work on vacant city-owned buildings.
They started out with the purchase 542 LaGuardia Place in partnership with family members, including Mr. Millhiser's father, Ross, the retired vice chairman of the Philip Morris Inc. They developed the taste for reconstruction from buying and restoring a family summer home with sisters and brothers in Long Branch, N.J.
They sold 10 luxuriously appointed apart ments at an average of $350 a square foot on La Guardia Place, Mr. Millhiser said, and went on to convert two floors of former doctors' offices in a postwar co-op at 111 East 85th Street. These sold for an average of $310 a square foot.
Then they took on a floor in the mixed-use building at 105 Fifth Avenue, near 18th Street, which Barnes & Noble was vacating. Finally they bought 55 White Street. The cast-iron building was built in 1860 and used as a saddlery. The Millhisers intended to preserve the facade but demolish the rear portion and building and construct a 23-story tower.
They had been led to expect support from Community Board 1, Mrs. Millhiser said, but instead they faced an ultimately successful neighborhood campaign to landmark the property. Ultimately, the Landmarks Preservation Commission approved the facade restoration as part of a conversion to 16 apartments and 4,000 square feet of ground-floor commercial space, which was sold to a company that installs telephone systems, Whitcom Communications.
Twelve of the apartments have about 2,000 square feet of space, and came on the market in 1989 at about $285 a square foot, or roughly $570,000. But after nine sales, the Millhisers began to rent at an average rent of $3,400 a month for the 2,000-square-foot units, with one-year leases and renewal options. Apartments have woodburning fireplaces in living-dining rooms 24 feet by 40 feet, two baths, walk-in closets, ceiling heights of 13 to 17 feet and large arched windows. The Liebman Melting Partnership, a Manhattan firm, was the architect.
Sales prices are down substantially from the late 80's. One 2,000-square-foot unit on White Street, for example, was priced at $705,000 in 1989 and is listed at $625,000 now. Mrs. Millhiser, who is handling sales through a brokerage firm, Robert Eychner Associates, said she was looking for average prices of $250 to $275 a square foot in her sales effort, depending on the location of the unit in the building.
The building gets the benefit of the J-51 tax abatement, which is modest. To unit owners, it is worth an average of $1,300 a year in forgone taxes over a six-year period. These owners are nevertheless paying about $4,800 a year in taxes, because the abatement is limited to "50 percent of certified eligible costs" in most of Manhattan.
The eligible costs amounted to $256,000 in a building that cost about $3 million to rebuild. The apartments may use up to 8 1/3 percent of that amount a year -- $21,400 -- as a credit to reduce annual taxes until 50 percent of the total is reached. That will take about six years.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Mount Olive Child Care;
Kids in the Corporate Scene

 BODY:
As many as 16 infants, 40 toddlers (16 months to 3 years old) and 60 preschoolers (up to 6 years old) could liven up the corporate landscape of the 670-acre International Trade Center (ITC) in Mount Olive, N.J., next spring.
Bright Horizons, a five-year-old Cambridge, Mass., child-care company, will open its 46th center there in a 6,200-square-foot, one-story building at 450 International Drive. 
 "As the owner of a very large mixed-use business park we saw the need for this amenity," said Leslie R. Smith Jr., executive director of ITC. The Rockefeller Group, which is still developing the complex that includes the New Jersey Foreign Trade Zone, is financing construction of the $1.2 million project.
The day-care center's exterior "will be sympathetic to other buildings," said Richard C. Ashcroft of Cooper, Robertson + Partners, Manhattan architects. Inside, there will be an infants' room with a food preparation counter, refrigerator, changing tables and two sleep areas; a toddlers' area with changing tables and bathroom and playspace; and a preschoolers area adjoining a kitchen with low countertops for snacks. There will also be outdoor play areas.
The design also calls for a nursing nook and a reception-resource area where parents -- who will pay tuition not yet set up -- can stop by for coffee or parenting tips.
"We strive for a home-like environment," said Heather Samson, field manager for Bright Horizons.

GRAPHIC: Drawing: Drawing of children's facility at the International Trade Center, Mount Olive, N.J. (Cooper, Robertson + Partners)
