HEADLINE: An Uptick for Home Sales in the Region

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
SPURRED by low interest rates and lower prices, the residential real estate market in the New York metropolitan region, which has been dramatically deflated by a three-year recession and rapidly changing demographics, appears, for the most part, to be taking a slight upward turn.
Few real estate analysts, however, expect a sharp rise in sales volume for one-family homes, co-op apartments or condominiums anytime soon. Nor do they expect sale prices in the foreseeable future to return to the heights of the middle to late 80's. 
 "Modest priced housing is moving because interest rates are down, and prices are down, and in many cases it is affordable for people when it wasn't before," said Marc A. Weiss, director of the real estate development research center at Columbia University's Graduate School of Architecture Planning and Preservation. "And I think that will continue."
The degree of recovery in the New York area will vary depending on location and the type of housing. The market, for example, seems to be improving the most for moderately priced one-family homes in New Jersey, Westchester County and Long Island and the least in Connecticut.
"The recovery is stronger and the market is better than it has been at any time in the past 24 months," said Alan Yassky, former regional vice president of the National Association of Realtors and the president of Rockland Realty-Better Homes and Gardens in Spring Valley, N.Y. "And some areas are seeing it sooner than others. Connecticut is really plagued by some heavy fear of unemployment. People there are just paralyzed."
The outlook remains even bleaker for those selling condominiums in suburban areas throughout the region or studios and small one-bedroom co-ops in Manhattan. "The prices of the smaller co-ops were so inflated, and there is now a huge oversupply that has to be absorbed," said Edward J. Howe 3d, vice president of the National Cooperative Bank in Washington. The organization is one of the largest providers of co-op financing in the New York area, having originated more than $500 million in underlying mortgages since 1986.
Measuring the movements of the region's real estate market can be dicey, as disparities often develop not only between micromarkets, but over analysts' assessments and brokers' sales figures. These deviations often result from differing survey samples or methodologies as well as from efforts to paint the best possible statistical picture to help increase business.
Drawing conclusions from these movements can be even more difficult, particularly when comparing the first quarter of 1992 with the same period in 1991, when the onset of the Persian Gulf War sparked a steep drop and the war's end a short-lived resurgence in sales and prices.
For example, the 99,000 one-family homes sold during the first quarter of 1992 in the Northeast -- which according to the National Association of Realtors survey consists of New England, New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania -- marked a 16.4 percent increase over the first quarter 1991 level. The 1992 figure, however, falls far short of the number of homes sold during the first quarters of 1986, 1987, 1988 or 1989.
And the $142,900 median sale price of a one-family home in the Northeast for the first quarter of 1992 was 3.7 percent higher than the $137,700 in the first quarter of 1991. The 1992 figure, however, was still lower than the median sale prices prices for the first quarters of 1990 and 1989, which were $144,900 and $143,400, respectively.
MOREOVER, virtually all of the sales taking place these days are resales because of the dearth of new construction. This factor could help stimulate the resale market for the next couple of years. But at the same time there are many rental units -- condominiums and co-ops, as well as houses -- that have been pulled off the "for sale" market and are awaiting re-entry. And when they re-enter, it could depress the market further.
"Prices certainly have not kept up with inflation," said Harvard economist N. Gregory Mankiw, the co-author of a controversial 1989 study that forecast an annual decline in residential real estate values of about 3 percent through the 1990's, chiefly because of the aging of the baby boom generation and the smaller number of new home-buying families behind them.
Co-ops in New York City have seen some of the largest declines in value. Mr. Howe said that preliminary figures of a study to be released in late June show that the overall resale price of about 900 co-ops dropped about 10 percent from the first quarter of 1991 to the first quarter of 1992, and, in some parts of the city, such as the Upper East Side and the Upper West Side, the declines may be greater. The bank's survey was based on appraisals of properties it financed as well as other comparable co-ops.
"It is dropping the most in areas where it appreciated the most," he said. "And, in a free-fall, it is scary to buy something."
"My personal belief is we're at bottom," he added.
But such an assessment offers little solace to Richard C. Hirschl. He has been hearing the same "we're at the bottom" song annually since 1989, when he put his 500-square-foot, one-bedroom co-op at 160 West 77th Street on the market for $200,000.
After receiving a few initial inquiries but no offers, he lowered his asking price in 1990 to $165,000. Then he lowered it again in 1991 to $120,000. And this year, he lowered it to $90,000, which is what he paid for the apartment in 1984.
"I am amazed at the situation," said Mr. Hirschl, a stockbroker living in Washington, Mo., who originally bought the unit for his son and daughter, who were attending the Juilliard School of Music.
"What I'm hearing is that only the larger ones are selling."
A brighter picture, though, is painted by many of the city's real estate brokers. For example, Clark Halstead, owner and manager of the Halstead Property Company, a real estate brokerage firm in Manhattan, said his company's sales for the first quarter of 1992 were close to 50 percent higher than for the comparable period in 1991.
Mr. Halstead also said that the average sale price per room rose to $88,863 for the first quarter of 1992 from $81,301 for the first quarter of last year. "In general, prices have edged up slightly, particularly on the West Side," he said. "The market is not weak at all. New York-bashing seems to be a thing of the past."
As for Manhattan condominium prices, Yale Robbins, a Manhattan real estate publishing and consulting firm named for its founder, reported that 453 units were sold in the first quarter of 1992 in the borough against 327 for the first quarter of 1991. Mr. Robbins said, though, that the average sale price was $310,000 this year, down from $390,000 for the first quarter of last year. "In general, prices this year are less than prices last year," he said.
"Short-term, things are pretty much going to stay the same," Mr. Robbins added. "Long-term, it all depends on the economy. And no one is making strong predictions on the economy for the next year, and no one is making accurate predictions for the next two or three years."
Some condominium brokers, however, believe that prices have already started to rebound. Louise M. Sunshine, president of the Sunshine Group, a real estate brokerage and consulting firm in Manhattan, noted that 30 percent of the units at the 123-unit condominium at 2250 Broadway at 81st Street have been sold since it opened six months ago. She said most buyers of the units, which cost from $295,000 to $500,000, were Americans, a change from past years, when foreign buyers dominated the condominium market.
Ms. Sunshine said that sales have been increasing for high-end condominiums, such as the 283-unit Trump Palace at 200 East 69th Street, where she said an average of 14 units a month have been sold since January. The condominium has been offering a 20 percent discount off original asking prices, but that will be reduced to 10 percent next month, she said. The average condominium costs about $800,000.
"The condo market is really revived," she said.
IN some suburban regions, however, the condominium market is still troubled. In Stamford, Conn., for example, there were 72 condominium sales for the first quarter of 1992 against 43 for the first quarter of 1991 and 69 for the first quarter of 1990. The average sale price for the first quarter of 1992, though, has plummeted to $123,016 from $136,279 in 1991 and $164,168 in 1990.
Thomas I. Purcell, the executive director of the Stamford Board of Realtors, said that condominium prices in the area have been dropping 10 percent a year for for the last four years, as opposed to 5 percent annual drops for one-family homes. "They are just so hard to get rid of," he said.
No one believes that the housing market will recover completely until the region's job losses are stemmed. For example, for New York City alone, 167,000 jobs disappeared between November 1990 and November 1991, the United States Labor Department said. The figure is close to a quarter million since the winter of 1988, when the recession started in New York City, long before it did in most of the rest of the nation.
Suburban single-family homes, however, have shown some recent improvement in price as well as volume. In Stamford, for example, the number of one-family-home sales rose to 118 in the first quarter of 1992, compared with 105 in the first quarter of 1991 and 125 in the first quarter of 1990. The average sale price also rose -- to $342,875 from $332,995 during the first quarter of 1991, but it still fell short of the $358,143 first quarter average for 1990.
"Things are better than they have been the past couple of years," Mr. Purcell said. "Prices are down about as low as they are going to get. People are not reducing them as much as they were before. And I think it all has to do with the interest rates, and the banks giving people the opportunity to buy.
"But I don't think you are ever going to see prices like those of 1985," he said. "It would take a miracle to get prices up that high again."
IN Westchester County, there were 645 sales in the first quarter of 1992, against 521 in the first quarter of 1991 and 659 in the first quarter of 1990, according to the Westchester County Board of Realtors. Average first-quarter sale prices for the county rose to $270,000 in 1992 from $265,000 in 1991 but still fell short of the $290,000 recorded in 1990.
Statistics compiled by the New York Association of Realtors for Nassau County, Suffolk County and Queens showed that the number of one-family homes sold during the first-quarter of 1992 rose 16.8 percent to 2,963 compared to the 2,537 in the first quarter of 1991, but still remained 4.4 percent lower than the 3,098 sold in the first quarter of 1990.
Average sale prices of one-family homes for Long Island and Queens rose 1.7 percent to $174,532 in the first quarter of 1992 over the $171,683 for the first quarter of 1991 but still remained 4.8 percent lower than the $183,390 reported in the first quarter of 1990.
On Staten Island, the pattern continued, as the number of one-family homes sold rose by 6.7 percent to 144 during the first quarter of 1992 over the 135 for same period in 1991, but the figure was 0.7 percent lower than the 145 sales in the first quarter of 1990.
Average sale prices for the borough, however, showed no signs of improvement, as they fell 5 percent to $178,807 in the first quarter of 1992 compared to $188,163 for the first quarter of 1991 and were down 11.4 percent compared to average first quarter price of $201,855 in 1990.
In Northern New Jersey, the median sale price of a one-family home rose 1.3 percent in the first quarter of 1992 versus the first quarter of 1991, from $177,300 to $179,600. Prices, however, remained 5 percent below the $189,100 average for the first quarter of 1990.
THE volume of sales in Northern New Jersey was up 16.3 percent to 56,300 for the first quarter of 1992 over the 48,400 for the first quarter of 1991 and up 1.6 percent against the 55,400 for the first quarter of 1990. "What you are going to see over the next few years are 3-to-5 percent per year increases," said Ron De Piro, president of De Piro Realtors in Nutley, N.J., and the executive director of the Bloomfield, Glen Ridge, Nutley and Belleville Board of Realtors. "People are buying now as shelter, not as investment. They are going to end up making money but not that big killing."
Sellers who accept reductions in their offering prices can also expect to benefit when they buy their next home at a price that is probably lower than they would have paid two or three years ago.
Indeed, that was the result for Steven Tannenbaum when he bought an $825,000 home in Muttontown, L.I., after selling his condominium in Roslyn Heights, L.I., for $395,000 -- $130,000 less than he paid for it in 1989.
"Even though we took a bath in Roslyn," said Mr. Tannenbaum, who owns a lumber home center in Brooklyn, "we could afford the house in Muttontown only because prices were down a third from what they originally offered."

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Mortgage Adjustment
 
Question: I have a mortgage on a condominium in New Jersey that I rent out and I have been unemployed for more than a year. My mortgage is held by Chase Mortgage Corporation. When I called to discuss a way of reducing my monthly payments to avoid foreclosure, I was told such assistance is available only after a mortgage holder becomes delinquent. Apparently the mortgage had been sold to Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation and Chase must follow its rules when it comes to changes. It seems to me that since I would not qualify for a regular re-financing, the lender would be willing to do something to help me stay out of foreclosure. Is there anything I can do? . . . Terence Wall, Hillsdale, N.J.
 
Answer: Probably not. Ken Mills, a spokesman for Chase Manhattan Bank, of which Chase Manhattan Mortgage Corporation is a subsidiary, said that it is not a Chase policy to wait until a mortgage holder has fallen behind in payments to assist with a loan payment adjustment. But it is true that any adjustments on loans sold to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, would have to be made with its approval. 
 But Mr. Mills said that the main reason an adjustment in your payments has not been offered to you is that the mortgage is on a home that no longer serves as your prime residence.
 
Maintenance Rebate
 
Question: In June 1988, I bought the one-bedroom apartment I had rented for more than 8 years. When the building was converted to a co-op the sponsor agreed to a rebate of 15 percent of the maintenance to all "insiders" for a period of five years. The rebate was paid in 1989 and was months late in 1990. Last July, the sponsor declared bankruptcy.
My understanding was that money to cover the rebate was to be held in escrow account and managed by a trustee. Do my rights in this matter include include withholding 15 percent from our monthly maintenance? . . . Anna Shuster, Manhattan
 
Answer: No. Withholding a portion of your maintenance would be risky. According to Bruce Friedberg, an attorney who specializes in real estate matters, there are no provisions of the co-op and condominium laws that obligate the co-op to honor your sponsor's maintenance rebate program.
Moreover, by reducing your maintenance payments you could risk being in violation of the proprietary lease thus jeopardizing your right to occupy your apartment.
"Assuming that other inside buyers took advantage of the maintenance rebate offer," said Mr. Friedberg, "the loss of income when those buyers cut their payments, could make the co-op vulnerable if it resulted in a shortfall."
Mr. Friedberg said that if the maintenance rebate is a provision of the conversion plan or any of its amendments, its language would tell you if the sponsor was required to post any form of security like an escrow fund or letter of credit. There may also be a provision requiring any entity taking over the sponsor's position in case of default to assume the maintenance rebate obligation.
Mr. Friedberg suggested that you check your conversion documents. If it appears that any of its terms have been violated, you should file a complaint with the Attorney General's Real Estate Financing Bureau. The address is 120 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10271.
 
Rights of Spouse
 
Question: I have been living in my rent-controlled apartment for 28 years, moving in with my husband in 1963. We were divorced in 1967. I have continued to live in the apartment since then, paying the rent myself. I recently remarried and now my husband and I live in the apartment together. Will I jeopardize my right to the apartment by informing the landlord of my new status? . . . Rhoda Cooperman, Queens.
 
Answer: No. There are laws or rules governing rent-controlled tenants that would reduce or alter your status after you remarry. But your landlord has the right to know of any new permanent occupants.

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Empty Banks: Imposing, but Hard to Use

BYLINE: By DAVID J. WALLACE

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
Darkened bank branches in huge and inefficient but architecturally magnificent buildings in this city's former financial district pose a challenge to real estate brokers.
The question is how to reutilize the space. 
 The buildings are concentrated just south and west of City Hall, at Broad and Market Streets, the center of Philadelphia.
Walnut Street, for example, gained luster with the arrival in the last two years of prestige shops such as Louis Vuitton and Tiffany near Broad Street and of the Bombay Company and Talbots a few blocks farther west, close to Rittenhouse Square. But retailing has not been the answer for all the available space.
At least six bank branches stand vacant within three blocks of the former First Pennsylvania Bank at 15th and Chestnut Streets, which closed March 25. Four of those banks no longer exist. First Pennsylvania is still in business, and the branch's accounts were moved to other offices of the CoreStates Financial Corporation, its parent, according to a bank spokeswoman, Linda Stryker.
The closed branch, with black iron gates 40 feet high, was in the historic 1924 Packard Building, one of the neighborhood's prestige addresses.
Nearby were the city's grandest hotels and private clubs and banks, all within a block or two of the Broad Street Station.
Inside the Packard Building, the architects Ritter & Shay created two cavernous vault basements for the Pennsylvania Company, predecessor of First Pennsylvania. Two rows of structural Ionic columns, which dominate the banking floor, once set off banking counters to the left and accounts desks on the right.
CoreStates controls the property until its lease expires in July, said Jeffrey R. Seligsohn, a vice president with The Binswanger Company, which manages the building for its owner, Investcorp of New York.
"We tried to keep them, but they have three other branches within a stone's throw and price wasn't a factor," Mr. Seligsohn said. "The average new bank branch is about 4,000 square feet and this one has 12,000 square feet."
Much of the interior space is unusable, inefficient and -- since the building is on the National Register of Historic Places -- untouchable. For example, said Mr. Seligsohn, the interior bank floor might span three stories in current construction if not for the columns, which would stymie renovation efforts even if such work were allowed.
Richard Tyler, historic preservation officer of the Philadelphia Historical Commission, said the National Register has several historic districts in the downtown area, covering most buildings that are more than 50 years old, among them the Drexel & Company, Butcher & Singer and Packard buildings.
The Drexel building also was certified by the city's historical commission in 1971, and any renovation work requiring a building permit or masonry cleaning must be reviewed by Mr. Tyler's office.
National Register buildings may qualify for Federal tax credits for substantial renovation, but approval of the state's historic preservation officer and the Federal Department of the Interior is needed.
The city's commodity/financial market goes back to Colonial days but its center has been moving westward -- at near-glacial speed -- since then, and is now around 20th and Market. The First Bank of the United States, created by Alexander Hamilton, still stands in the imposing Federal-style building built in the 1790's and used until 1926. It and other venerable buildings are part of the Independence Park Historic District.
The Stock Exchange also dates to 1790 in the historic district and has had two more modern homes in the financial center, first in a 1911 building at 1411 Walnut Street designed by Horace Trumbauer and from 1964 to 1981 in a newer building at 17th and Sansom streets, according to the Philadelphia Historical Commission.
By the late 80's, as new names such as Fidelity Investments replaced Drexel & Company, Butcher & Singer or Hopper Soliday, prominent retailers opened stores from fashionable Rittenhouse Square east to Broad Street. A block north, at 15th and Walnut Streets, Dimensions, a men's clothier, in the mid-80's occupied the first floor of what had been Drexel's building.
On March 1, 1991, Dimensions filed for bankruptcy. Now that site and others are available, but both tenants and owners are leery of making long-term deals for large properties.
Built between 1925 and 1927, the space yielded some surprises when its broker, CB Commercial, prepared to market it last year. For example, a shooting gallery had been built in the basement below the 15th Street sidewalk and beautiful marble slabs were found cracked from earlier renovations, said Bill Deasey, a senior associate of CB.
"You wait for the phone to ring with good news, but it requires a real destination store because those windows aren't great for merchandise displays," Mr. Deasey said. "They're very high up off the street."
Many properties have similar design drawbacks for today's tenants, he said -- large, high windows unsuitable for merchandise display, multiple levels that deter some customers and much higher heating, cooling and lighting costs.
Several large retailers considered leasing big blocks on Walnut Street. Among them were Staples, the office-supply retailer; a British bookstore, Waterstone's Booksellers, and a British record store, HMV. But none signed a lease.
After months of fruitless negotiations, Waterstone's chose to open stores elsewhere rather than lease space in Philadelphia. And Staples, which had been developing a downtown prototype store in New York City, chose to wait until 1993 to open its Staples Express stores, said Beth Stone, a company spokeswoman.
Retailers have shifted also, said Thomas Anastasi, managing director of the Galbreath Company. Walnut Street has maintained its reputation as a Fifth Avenue, but the Shops at Liberty Place has drawn some retail luster only a few blocks north to its stores between Chestnut and Market, 16th and 17th Streets, Mr. Anastasi said.
And the uncertain retail environment has made all the parties to a lease more circumspect about committing to as large a site as the 23,000-square-foot Butcher & Singer facility, said Mr. Anastasi, who represents the property.
"It's a lot of space for someone to use because it can't be subdivided," he said. "And it's scary for a tenant or owner to put out a couple of million dollars for a retail retrofit in this economy."
Carriage House Clothiers agreed to lease 2,700 square feet in the Butcher & Singer space for a store, Mr. Anastasi said, after a separate entrance was built next to the main banking floor.
Nightclubs have been successful for several years at two buildings distinguished by their designers as well as by their current occupants. An 1837 Greek Revival bank by the architect William Strickland now houses a nightclub appropriately named Revival. And, just as appropriately, an 1872 building by Furness and Hewitt is now The Bank.
The phenomenon is not unique to downtown areas, said Ms. Stryker of CoreStates. A suburban branch in an Ardmore strip shopping center 20 minutes away required additional safe deposit boxes to accommodate some of the customers displaced when a branch closed in October 1990 at the former Merion Title & Trust Company building. The four-story building is the tallest in Ardmore's commercial district and is for sale, she said.
Across the Delaware River in Camden, N.J., preservationists identified 19 significant structures from the city's once-vibrant banking, insurance and legal economy. The buildings date from 1873 and many are in use as banks, churches, community centers and stores, said Edward Fox, president of the Camden Preservation Trust.

HEADLINE: Focus: Philadelphia;
Empty Banks: Imposing, but Hard to Use

BYLINE: By DAVID J. WALLACE

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
DARKENED bank branches in huge and inefficient but architecturally magnificent buildings in this city's former financial district pose a challenge to real estate brokers.
The question is how to reutilize the space. 
 The buildings are concentrated just south and west of City Hall, at Broad and Market Streets, the center of Philadelphia.
Walnut Street, for example, gained luster with the arrival in the last two years of prestige shops such as Louis Vuitton and Tiffany near Broad Street and of the Bombay Company and Talbots a few blocks farther west, close to Rittenhouse Square. But retailing has not been the answer for all the available space.
At least six bank branches stand vacant within three blocks of the former First Pennsylvania Bank at 15th and Chestnut Streets, which closed March 25. Four of those banks no longer exist. First Pennsylvania is still in business, and the branch's accounts were moved to other offices of the CoreStates Financial Corporation, its parent, according to a bank spokeswoman, Linda Stryker.
The closed branch, with black iron gates 40 feet high, was in the historic 1924 Packard Building, one of the neighborhood's prestige addresses. Nearby were the city's grandest hotels, private clubs and banks, within a block or two of Broad Street Station.
Inside the Packard Building, the architects Ritter & Shay created two cavernous vault basements for the Pennsylvania Company, predecessor of First Pennsylvania. Two rows of structural Ionic columns, which dominate the banking floor, once set off banking counters to the left and accounts desks on the right.
CoreStates controls the property until its lease expires in July, said Jeffrey R. Seligsohn, a vice president with The Binswanger Company, which manages the building for its owner, Investcorp of New York.
"We tried to keep them, but they have three other branches within a stone's throw and price wasn't a factor," Mr. Seligsohn said. "The average new bank branch is about 4,000 square feet and this one has 12,000 square feet."
Much of the interior space is unusable, inefficient and -- since the building is on the National Register of Historic Places -- untouchable. For example, said Mr. Seligsohn, the interior bank floor might span three stories in current construction if not for the columns, which would stymie renovation efforts even if such work were allowed.
Richard Tyler, historic preservation officer of the Philadelphia Historical Commission, said the National Register has several historic districts in the downtown area, covering most buildings that are more than 50 years old, among them the Drexel & Company, Butcher & Singer and Packard buildings.
The Drexel building also was certified by the city's historical commission in 1971, and any renovation work requiring a building permit or masonry cleaning must be reviewed by Mr. Tyler's office.
National Register buildings may qualify for Federal tax credits for substantial renovation, but approval of the state's historic preservation officer and the Federal Department of the Interior is needed.
The city's commodity/financial market goes back to Colonial days but its center has been moving westward -- at near-glacial speed -- since then, and is now around 20th and Market. The First Bank of the United States, created by Alexander Hamilton, still stands in the imposing Federal-style building built in the 1790's and used until 1926. It and other venerable buildings are part of the Independence Park Historic District.
THE Stock Exchange also dates to 1790 in the historic district and has had two more modern homes in the financial center, first in a 1911 building at 1411 Walnut Street designed by Horace Trumbauer and from 1964 to 1981 in a newer building at 17th and Sansom streets, according to the Philadelphia Historical Commission.
By the late 80's, as new names such as Fidelity Investments replaced Drexel & Company, Butcher & Singer or Hopper Soliday, prominent retailers opened stores from fashionable Rittenhouse Square east to Broad Street. A block north, at 15th and Walnut Streets, Dimensions, a men's clothier, in the mid-80's occupied the first floor of what had been Drexel's building.
On March 1, 1991, Dimensions filed for bankruptcy. Now that site and others are available, but both tenants and owners are leery of making long-term deals for large properties.
Built between 1925 and 1927, the space yielded some surprises when its broker, CB Commercial, prepared to market it last year. For example, a shooting gallery had been built in the basement below the 15th Street sidewalk and beautiful marble slabs were found cracked from earlier renovations, said Bill Deasey, a senior associate of CB.
"You wait for the phone to ring with good news, but it requires a real destination store because those windows aren't great for merchandise displays," Mr. Deasey said. "They're very high up off the street."
Many properties have similar design drawbacks for today's tenants, he said -- large, high windows unsuitable for merchandise display, multiple levels that deter some customers and much higher heating, cooling and lighting costs.
Several large retailers considered leasing big blocks on Walnut Street. Among them were Staples, the office-supply retailer; a British bookstore, Waterstone's Booksellers, and a British record store, HMV. But but none signed a lease.
After months of fruitless negotiations, Waterstone's chose to open stores elsewhere rather than lease space in Philadelphia. And, Staples, which had been developing a downtown prototype store in New York City, chose to wait until 1993 to open its Staples Express stores, said Beth Stone, a company spokeswoman.
Retailers have shifted also, said Thomas Anastasi, managing director of the Galbreath Company. Walnut Street has maintained its reputation as a Fifth Avenue, but the Shops at Liberty Place has drawn some retail luster only a few blocks north to its stores between Chestnut and Market, 16th and 17th Streets, Mr. Anastasi said.
And the uncertain retail environment has made all the parties to a lease more circumspect about committing to as large a site as the 23,000-square-foot Butcher & Singer facility, said Mr. Anastasi, who represents the property.
"It's a lot of space for someone to use because it can't be subdivided," he said. "And it's scary for a tenant or owner to put out a couple of million dollars for a retail retrofit in this economy."
Carriage House Clothiers agreed to lease 2,700 square feet in the Butcher & Singer space for a store, Mr. Anastasi said, after a separate entrance was built next to the main banking floor.
NIGHTCLUBS have been successful at two buildings distinguished by their designers as well as by their current occupants. An 1837 Greek Revival bank by the architect William Strickland now houses a nightclub appropriately named Revival. And, just as appropriately, an 1872 building by Furness and Hewitt is now The Bank.
The phenomenon is not unique to downtown areas, said Ms. Stryker of CoreStates. A suburban branch in an Ardmore strip shopping center 20 minutes away required additional safe deposit boxes to accommodate some of the customers displaced when a branch closed in October 1990 at the former Merion Title & Trust Company building. The four-story building is the tallest in Ardmore's commercial district and is for sale, she said.
Across the Delaware River in Camden, N.J., preservationists identified 19 significant structures from the city's once-vibrant banking, insurance and legal economy. The buildings date from 1873 and many are in use as banks, churches, community centers and stores, said Edward Fox, president of the Camden Preservation Trust.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Grappling With the Revaluation Problem

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
IN the final week of the Connecticut legislative session last month, a bill was passed giving municipalities a one-time extension to Oct. 1, 1993, for revising property revaluations made in the later-80's boom market.
The measure will give towns that rejected their mandatory 10-year revaluations -- made by companies they hired -- more time to re-examine lower market prices. 
 Revaluations are the basis for assessments and, subsequently, taxes. In towns revalued from 1986 to 1990 -- when real estate prices peaked or remained relatively high, particularly in Fairfield County -- many householders now find their assessments larger than the market value of their homes. In some communities the precipitous drop in commercial property values shifted more of the tax burden to residences.
As a result, a deluge of protests from irate taxpayers caused delays in approving revaluations and setting new tax rates. By last spring more than 40 of the state's 169 communities had rejected revaluations, for which the towns had paid from $500,000 to more than $1 million.
Now, a year later, some 90 towns are seeking redress, says Walter A. Lawrence, president of the Connecticut Assessors Association and the assessor for Tolland. "The 10-year cycle of revaluations was set when property didn't appreciate as fast as it has since the 1970's," he said. "Most of the country is on a two- to five-year revaluation schedule. Fewer than 10 states require revaluations as infrequently as Connecticut."
His association has proposed bills backing five-year revaluations, but the Legislature has not responded. "Revaluation usually means an upward adjustment of taxes and a large expenditure by the town to hire a revaluation company," he said, something that legislators are not likely to impose on their constituents.
In Stamford, where the grand list, or value of all taxable property, declined this year by almost $20 million, to $6 billion, a 1991 revaluation was rejected and the city received permission from the state to set its tax rate on a 10-year-old revaluation until a new one is done in 1993.
The average property-tax rate for the fiscal year beginning July 1 is $37.80 for every $1,000 in assessed value, 1.9 percent more than the current fiscal year. Rural residences without sewers are assessed lower than heavily serviced downtowns with the most commercial development.
"From now on we are going to have an adjustment every five years," said Edward Faski, Stamford's acting tax assessor. Sales will be tracked and analyzed by computer and property values will be adjusted accordingly after five years. At the end of 10 years a complete revaluation, with on-site inspections, will be done as usual.
Greenwich and Norwalk are among other towns preparing computerized five-year systems. "The technology now permits data bases to be set up in-house," said State Senator George Jepsen, a Stamford Democrat whose Planning and Development Committee proposed the revaluation extension bill.
After causing such upheavals, will real estate take another roller-coaster ride in the foreseeable future? "Maybe not to the same degree, but yes, the wheel goes around," said Peter Helie, vice president of William Pitt, Stamford realtors. "The mid-80's boom was the largest I've seen in my lifetime in the business, but when inventories are low, prices are driven up. It's the old economics of supply and demand."
However, he predicts only 3 to 4 percent appreciation starting in 1993 instead of the 25 to 30 percent that prevailed in the 80's. He also predicts that commercial properties will lag behind residential properties until 1995.
SHARING that view is James Fagan, vice president of the CB Commercial brokerage in Stamford. The sale of 595 Summer Street by the First Constitution Bank for $3.4 million a year ago, he said, "is considered a premium deal now; it was sold before people realized how much more prices would go down." The asking price had been up to $8 million.
Mr. Fagan suggests that taxing systems in smaller towns like Westport, where one rate is set for the entire town, can be unfair to commercial property owners. "Homes are not in the same kind of trouble as commercial property," he said, "because there is still a lot of mortgage money for dwellings. Banks bundle up residential mortgages and sell them. There is no money for commercial mortgages. For example, a 30,000-square-foot-building on Charles Street sold for $4.6 million in 1984, but it is now marketed at $1.7 million. The owner couldn't protest his assessment in 1985 when the last revaluation was done, but in 1995 he will have a good argument."
Kenneth C. Carvell, Westport's assessor, said, "We had a drastic run-up of real estate values on all fronts." A revaluation in 1980 "was not satisfactory," he said, "and the town decided to do another one in 1985, which is now our base year."
Westport's property-tax rate went up by only .2 percent, to $21.50 for eached $1,000 of assessed value, and the town not encouraging more commercial development or seeking tenants for its vacant business buildings to keep taxes down. "I wouldn't want to project out to the 1995 revaluation," Mr. Carvell said, "but current trends indicate that a shift to higher residential taxes will occur."
Greenwich's rejected 1989 revaluation brought its grand list up to $10 billion from $3 billion a decade earlier. The town was given an extension to submit another revaluation by Oct. 1 of this year. William J. Bliss, the town comptroller, said it should total around $8 billion. "The market has gone down," he said, "and it will definitely lower the tax rate."
At $33.20 per $1,000, or 5.4 percent over last year, Greenwich no longer holds the record for the lowest property-tax rate in the state. "Lately it's been going up 4 to 5 percent a year," Mr. Bliss said.
New Canaan, Darien and Ridgefield had revaluations in 1988 but their mostly residential grand lists were not as sharply skewed and there were fewer complaints. The assessors do not favor more frequent revaluations because of of their cost.
"Twenty-five years after the development of a new central business district began here," said Jon Smith, Stamford's city planner, "everyone is taking a hard look at economic planning. They are not looking for an end result with no forethought, as they did then in a market that seemed endlessly beneficent."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Office building at 595 Summer Street in Stamford was sold by the First Constitution Bank for $3.4 million a year ago. The original asking price had been $8 million. (CB Commercial)

HEADLINE: ART;
Story of Portugal Unfolds Through A Varied Collection

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
THE Newark Public Library is widely known for its holding in prints as well as books and for the expertise of its supervising librarian of special collections, William Dane.
There being neither the space nor the money for costly installations in these marble halls, at 5 Washington Street, the library shows are not glamorous. But they can be counted on for items rare, beautiful, instructive or entertaining -- or all three -- and they are always well documented. 
 Sad to say, "Portugal, a Romantic Journey" is none of the above. Integral to the festival of the same name, being held in Newark, the show is billed as a joint effort by the library and the Portuguese Heritage Foundation, but it is emphatically not a Dane production. Indeed, it seems less an exhibition than a package left on the library's doorstep. The politest way of summing it up would be to say that it depends on what you mean by "romantic."
All the same, the era so named is considered by some historians to have begun in Portugal by way of the unprecedented earthquake of 1755, which demolished much of Lisbon and left its mark on the European psyche. Without the guidance of labels, however, visitors have no way of telling if the earthquake is mentioned, much less the catastrophic fire that hit the capital a few years ago.
In other words, this is a chamber of commerce-style miscellany of posters, photographs aimed at tourists, reproductions, a few books and prints, medals, ceramics, flags, dolls, lace and souvenirs like the filigree silver caravel shown on this page. Since the reviewer's visit, the label problem has been rectified, but clearly there is nothing to be done about the lack of focus.
Visitors from Newark's Portuguese community will doubtless take pleasure in familiar craft items like the tall crowns of paper flowers worn in festivals and in the pictures of their homeland. It seems unlikely that they will be overjoyed to see pictures of a TAP Air Portugal building and a Portuguese sports club, both in Newark, but you never know.
As for those ignorant of the country, some may pick up scraps of knowledge along the way, but most will leave no wiser than they were on entering and rather more confused. Still, given the current interest in things Brazilian, it may be that a few will consult the library's reference section and discover that, for example, Brazil was the largest of the many colonies established by Portugal. To be fair, though, the posters do cover the empire.
In view of the price still being paid for colonialism, it is hard to contemplate its beginnings with equanimity but just as hard not to be impressed by them. The Portuguese honor roll begins with the prince known as Henry the Navigator (even though he never went to sea), who masterminded the exploration of coastal Africa and began the European slave trade by bringing Africans to Portugal, the better to Christianize them.
After that comes Vasco da Gama, whose first voyage to India netted booty that was worth 60 times the cost of the trip, including the loss of two ships and two-thirds of the explorer's crew. Other pioneers include Magellan, whose fleet circumnavigated the globe, albeit in the pay of Spain; Pedro Cabral, whose discovery of Brazil was accidental, and Bartolomeo Diaz, the first to round the Cape of Good Hope.
It was thanks to these extraordinary men (and to the scientific legacy bequeathed by the Moors) that Portugal, by the end of the 16th century, controlled the sea lanes all the way to China and the East Indies, occupying key sites in countries along the way. All this from a kingdom roughly the same size as Maine.
Evidence of Portugal's golden age (and its Moorish influence) can be glimpsed in the photographs, one of a window grille, others of the Batalha Monastery and all resembling masterpieces in pastry. The outside of the monastery is all flying buttresses, "spirelets" and crocketing, with the door set in a dramatic ogee arch. Inside, the ornament on walls and piers recalls Max Ernst's experiments in decalcomania.
When Spain occupied the country from 1580 to 1640, the golden age began to subside, but the country recovered economically when the Duke of Braganza led a successful rebellion and founded the last of its dynasties, whose present representative presides over the festival.
Apparently Portugal's glittering past does not include massive industrialization. As a result, the country remains rural and evidently very beautiful. Somewhere in this jumble of objects there may be the germ of the show that it deserves.
This one will be on view through July 30. Currently, the library is open Monday, Friday and Saturday from 9 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. and Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday from 9 A.M. to 8:30 P.M. Starting June 29, the summer hours are Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Friday from 9 A.M. to 5:30 P.M., Wednesday from 9 A.M. to 8:30 P.M. and Saturday from 10 A.M. to 1 P.M.

GRAPHIC: Photos: A silver caravel, far left, and other items from "Portugal, a Romantic Journey" at the Newark Public Library. (Photographs by Sam D'Amico for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

MAKING KOCHINA DOLLS
 Marlon Huma, a member of the Hopi tribe, will demonstrate the making of Kochina dolls in Yonkers Thursday through Saturday from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Kochina is the religion of the Hopi Indians. The dolls and dances represent various elements of the cycle of life and their interconnection.
The demonstrations will take place at Steve's Trading Post, 471 Tuckahoe Road, where Steve Katz, the owner, sells jewelry, pottery, basketry, rugs, sculpture, headdresses, drums and other crafts from more than 30 tribes he visits nationwide.
The dolls are carved from cottonwood roots and can be 1 to 18 inches tall. They can be male or female, shaped and painted to depict clowns, spirits, the seasons, maidens and braves. They sometimes have eagle feather headdresses, leather boots and jewelry that has been handed down from previous generations. They are a common sight hanging on the walls in Hopi households.
Mr. Huma is from the village of First Mesa on the 40,000-acre Navajo Reservation near Flagstaff, Ariz. "Marlon has become a special friend," Mr. Katz said, "and I am returning his hospitality to me by inviting him here for awhile to see how I live." Mr. Huma, 30 years old, is married and has three children. He has traveled outside Arizona only once, to a powwow in Oklahoma.
"There are only 9,000 Hopis left," Mr. Katz said, "and they survive by making and selling their handiwork." The dolls take about two weeks to complete, not because the work is so time consuming but because Hopis have a different perception of time.
The dolls sell for $250 to $1,400. A few will be for sale, and others can be ordered from Mr. Huma. The number to call for more information is 779-9613.
 
BOOK AND AUTHOR LUNCH
 Four noted authors will speak at the Westchester Library Association's Book and Author Luncheon tomorrow at noon at the Tarrytown Hilton. This is to be the first of a series of yearly luncheons featuring speakers and giving the libraries an opportunity to promote themselves in a time of economic constraint.
George J. Delaney, vice president of Consolidated Edison, which helped underwrite the event, will serve as chairman.
The authors will talk about their most recent books, all published within the last year. They are Robert Stone, author of "Outerbridge Reach," published by Ticknor & Fields; Belva Plain, whose "Treasures" was published by Delacorte; Gary Sick, author of "October Surprise," published by Times Books, and Robert Kotlowitz, whose "His Master's Voice" is from Knopf.
Packages containing information and souvenirs from the county's 38 libraries will be placed on each chair, and tickets at $30 may be purchased at the hotel or at the Getty Square, Grinton I. Will and Crestwood library branches in Yonkers.
 
RUSSIAN ART SHOW
 The Russians are coming to the Somerstown Gallery today, depicted in paintings and photographs, which will remain on exhibition through July 5.
Oils by Sergei Polyakov, now living in Moscow but originally from Belarus (formerly Byelorussia), are exuberant, bold and colorful, evoking the myths and fairy tales of Old Russia with humor and style.
Marjorie Michael has produced a series of paintings of Russia's massive and elaborate medieval churches, restored during the last few decades by the Soviet Government. She followed the route of the so- called Golden Ring of churches from Moscow through the Yaroslavi, Kostroma and Vladimir regions of northeastern Russia.
Two Russians, Anatoly Loshmanov and Sergei Kuzmin, and one American, Lisa Toto, contributed the photographic images in the show, capitalizing on the increased freedom of photojournalists to record what they wish on film.
Mr. Kuzmin has been a photographer for Pravda and the Free Trade Union Journal, while Mr. Loshmanov was director of photography for the Kiev Movie Studio before branching out on his own to maintain a freelance photography studio.
Ms. Toto left her job at the Bridgeport Post to make three trips to Russia, where she photographed the wasteland created by the Chernobyl nuclear accident and former President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, among other subjects.
During the opening reception today from 2 to 5 P.M. a slide presentation of Russian landmarks, sculpture and art will be given by Leonid Hushmatov. The gallery, on Route 100 in Somers, is open Tuesdays through Sundays from 1 to 5 P.M. More information is available by calling 277-3461.
 
VASSAR BOOK SALE
 More than 300 Westchester students have obtained scholarships to Vassar through a book sale that the college has held each year since 1959. In the process, more than 1.25 million books and related items have been sold. The 1992 sale will be held at the County Center in White Plains Friday through Sunday from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.
A collector's corner will feature first editions, unusual illustrated books, autographed and rare books and books noted mainly for their tiny size and great age. In addition there will be a collection of books on the archeology of the South Pacific and pre-Columbian regions, books on antiques, Japanese dolls and fine art, cookbooks, children's books, records, mysteries and languages, including Spanish, French, German, Swedish, Russian, Hungarian and Japanese.
Paperbacks will cost 50 cents, and 40,000 hardcovers, $1 and more. At unscheduled times, instant bargain sales, a Vassar tradition, will occur, giving patrons a half-hour to buy all they can carry for half price or purchase any book with a red cover for 25 cents for 10 minutes or take advantage of other quick-sale incentives. The phone number for more information is 948-4115 or 761-8376.
 
NEW SUNNYSIDE WALK
 A walk in the woods that Washington Irving himself used to stroll has been reopened at Sunnyside, his home in Tarrytown. Historic Hudson Valley, with a grant of $50,000, expanded the half-mile trail and installed a wooden bridge and benches at scenic overlooks along the Hudson River.
Using as reference material drawings from 1856 that show a path and benches near the stream, the project, which took more than a year, afforded an opportunity to open up eight acres of formerly inaccessible property and create a picnic area.
Guided walks and discussions of the Romantic Landscape tradition will be held every Saturday from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. on the hour through the end of August. The trail is open to visitors on their own daily except Tuesdays from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. From July 4 through Labor Day, the trail will be open until 8 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, offering views of sunsets across the river.
Sunnyside is just off Route 9, one mile south of the Tappan Zee Bridge. Admission to the grounds is $3 and includes the guided and unguided walks. Those who wish to take guided tours of Irving's house will be charged $3 in addition to the grounds admission. The number to call for more information is 631-8200.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A 19th-century illustration shows brook path where Washington Irving strolled at Sunnyside, his Tarrytown home.

HEADLINE: The Collaboration In the Night Kitchen

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON

DATELINE: PURCHASE

 BODY:
CHRISTOPHER BEACH, director of the Performing Arts Center here on the campus of the State University of New York, did more than name-drop when he announced the center's impressive lineup of artists for next season. He also introduced a literary figure as beloved to parents as to the children who happily snuggle up with his books.
Maurice Sendak, the author and illustrator of such books as "Where the Wild Things Are" and "In the Night Kitchen," took the podium on the stage of Theater B to describe to an invited audience his new venture, the Night Kitchen: A National Children's Theater. 
 With him at the announcement, which was made in March, was Arthur Yorinks, a prize-winning author of children's books himself, who is the associate artistic director of the new theater company. Both men expressed their excitement at being able to present sophisticated plays, operas and musical comedies to children in productions developed especially for the Night Kitchen.
The company will be in residence here and perform in Theater B as part of the Performing Arts Center's next Familyfare series, beginning in October. Mr. Yorinks, a North Salem resident who has also written for the stage, screen and opera, said that the plays would be presented in workshop form before their formal premieres as co-productions of such other theaters as the Houston Grand Opera and the Kennedy Center.
 
Chamber Opera Planned
 The company's first work, to be presented here next January, is "Really Rosie," a musical written by Mr. Sendak and the songwriter Carole King and designed and directed by Mr. Sendak. The character of Rosie comes from several earlier books by Mr. Sendak, and the play itself was expanded from an animated television special presented by CBS in 1975.
Next March, the company will present an as-yet-unnamed short comedy, written and directed by Mr. Yorinks and Bill Irwin, a movement artist. Future works, planned for late next year and early 1994, include "Hey, Al," a chamber opera based on an award-winning book of the same name by Mr. Yorinks, and a new dramatic version of "Peter Pan."
The opera "Hey, Al," which was written by Mr. Yorinks and the composer Peter Schickele -- who is known for such musical antics as P.D.Q. Bach -- will feature designs based on the book's illustrations by Richard Egielski.
"Peter Pan" was adapted by Mr. Sendak and Mr. Yorinks and written by Mr. Yorinks; Mr. Sendak, who has designed costumes and stage sets for many operas, also designed "Peter Pan."
 
Mickey Picked for the Logo
 After making his remarks on the stage where his own "wild rumpus" will begin next year, the man who created Max, the king of all wild things, was besieged by autograph seekers. But it is not Max, the young hero of "Where the Wild Things Are," who adorns the new company's logo. Rather, it is Mickey, the pajamaless pilot of the bread-dough airplane that flew through the pages of "In the Night Kitchen," who smiles out from a starry sky.
It seemed fitting to name the company for that book, the two men said, because they began the theater project on the 20th anniversary of the publication of "In the Night Kitchen" in 1970. In addition, the partners met while Mr. Sendak was completing the book; Mr. Yorinks, then 17 years old, rang the already famous author's doorbell in Greenwich Village, hoping to show him some of his own writings, and the two have been friends ever since.
The uninhibited character of Mickey, the little boy who swam nude in a giant bottle of milk, upset some people when "In the Night Kitchen" was published. But Mr. Sendak, in a recent conversation, said he "didn't set out to do anything controversial" in any of his books.
Instead, he said, he was inspired by his editor, the late Ursula Nordstrom, at what was then Harper and Row Publishers and is now HarperCollins, to be as "bold, honest and fierce" as she was in her belief in children's literature.
 
Avoiding Condescension
 Guided by "her imagination and instinct," Mr. Sendak said, he grew as an artist "by doing her bidding, turning in on myself for her approval."
This meant, he added, not thinking of works meant for children in a condescending way. The notion of "a children's book," Mr. Sendak said, in itself can be "a sloppy idea."
Although the author has no children, he said that "in an instinctual sense, I'm living with them all the time." Like Max, the "wild thing" who wore his wolf suit and threatened to eat his mother up, children can be "barbaric, cannibalistic and ruthless," Mr. Sendak said. "These are the weapons by which they get through childhood, to defend themselves against us."
He gave an example of how well-meaning parents can unwittingly terrify their children. One time, he said, a mother forcibly took one of Mr. Sendak's books out of her child's hand so that the author could autograph it. "Here she had taught him never to write in his books, and she is giving his favorite book to a strange man -- me -- to write in!" Mr. Sendak recalled. The boy shouted at him not to mess up his book; the mother slapped the boy, and the author himself "was horrified," he said. The incident summed up, he added, "the entirety of childhood."
 
Film Company Started
 He will turn 64 on Wednesday, but Mr. Sendak, who lives and works in Ridgefield, Conn., is hardly slowing down. Besides working for the last two years to start the Night Kitchen, he began what he calls "a little film company in California" about six weeks ago. The company doesn't have a name yet, but the artist said he would like to call it Wild Things Productions.
"I'm extending myself in all directions, quadrupling my efforts and happy about it," Mr. Sendak said, adding that he would still write books that were "worth doing." He said the vulnerability of children in today's world had made him "a foot soldier again," unable to settle back comfortably "in this beautiful nook" of the state in which he lives.
"It's a mission; we have a job to do," he said. "With air going out of a hole in the sky, AIDS, L.A. burning, a Government terrifying and useless, how can you live the smug life anymore?"
The 38-year-old Mr. Yorinks said raising money for the Night Kitchen's $1.5 million budget was "a hard sell," not only because of the tight economy but because of "an implicit condescension."
 
Seed Money From HarperCollins
 "When it really comes down to people putting their hands in their pockets, there is a slight hypocrisy," Mr. Yorinks said. "They say, 'Why does it cost so much? It's only for children.' But we're trying to bring kids into the theater for a real experience. It's a very ambitious project, and it needs a lot of support."
Seed money for the Night Kitchen came from HarperCollins, now the publishing company of both authors, and enabled the fledgling company to rent office space in Manhattan and hire an administrative staff.
The directors consider the Performing Arts Center home, however. "Purchase has wonderful facilities, and they are interested in the kinds of things we're doing," Mr. Yorinks said of the college. "We're making a marriage of this."

HEADLINE: Business Diary/May 30-June 7

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Life Styles of the Rich, Famous Insider Traders 

The seven investors charged last week with insider trading by the Securities and Exchange Commission were part of the celebrity set. Among them: Edward R. Downe Jr., husband of the automobile heiress Charlotte Ford and a major collector of American art. Martin E. Revson was co-founder of Revlon cosmetics. Steven A. Greenberg is a flashy public relations executive. The S.E.C. charged that from 1987 to 1989 Mr. Downe and Mr. Greenberg exploited their access to inside information to generate at least $23 million in illegal gains. One instance involved contracts for call options for the Bally Manufacturing Corporation, whose shares soared 45 percent. The S.E.C. says Mr. Greenberg slipped Mr. Downe information on his yacht in the Caribbean and at his Southampton house. "This is a classic -- very significant -- insider trading case," said Richard Walker, the New York regional S.E.C. administrator.

Travelmania
 
By all accounts, the airline industry's half-price summer sale, which ended last week, was an overwhelming success. During the 10-day sale, American Airlines sold out almost its entire allotment of discounted seats. Delta Airlines sold more than five million tickets during the sale. Telephone traffic to ticket agents was so overwhelming some customers were put on hold for hours. Altogether, the airlines sold 25 million tickets worth $2.6 billion. And since passengers need somewhere to stay once they reach their destinations, hotel reservations are up. For the nation's ailing airlines -- they lost $4.5 billion last year -- the sales could be a boon since other fares have actually risen. They "could even end up making a few bucks," said Richard P. Firese, publisher of Travel Agent magazine.
 
Elvis, the Thin Version
 
It was a question only an organization like the Postal Service could pose to the nation: Which image of Elvis Presley do you prefer? A paunchy, middle-aged king, wearing glasses and a too-tight spandex suit, or the young, hip-swiveling Elvis clutching the mike. The Postal Service asked people to send in post cards to register their votes. Last week, at a ceremony at Graceland, Elvis's palatial home in Memphis, the winning image was revealed. Not surprisingly, the svelte Elvis won. That image will be the first in a series called Legends in American Music. The Postal Service makes about $200 million a year from commemorative stamp sales.

Perot Campaign Goes Pro
 
In the political consulting business, they may be the dream ticket: spin-doctor Edward J. Rollins, who managed Ronald Reagan's 1984 re-election campaign, and Hamilton Jordan, the strategist who managed Jimmy Carter's successful 1976 Presidential race. Though Mr. Jordan is a Democrat and Mr. Rollins a Republican, last week they signed on as co-managers of billionaire Ross Perot's still-undeclared Presidential campaign. Mr. Jordan will handle strategy; Mr. Rollins will take over day-to-day tactics. The two consultants will be rewarded handsomely. Rumors have been circulating that Mr. Perot would pay them each $5 million, but Mr. Perot said, "When you're spending your own money, you don't do things like that."

The Inscrutable Buffett
 
For weeks Wall Street was speculating over who would replace Warren E. Buffett, the Omaha investor who took over as interim chairman of Salomon Brothers Inc., after the firm admitted manipulating the Treasury-bill market. Mr. Buffett worked tirelessly to change Solly's kamikaze corporate culture and rehabilitate its name. Last week, he stunned the street by appointing Robert E. Denham, Salomon's general counsel, as chairman. Mr. Denham has guided Salomon through investigations, which ended in a settlement for $290 million. "It was a classic Warren Buffett move," said Deryck C. Maughan, chairman Salomon's investment banking subsidiary. "Everybody's predicting one thing and he thinks in a new way."

Punishing G.E.
 
For the General Electric Company, the nation's third-largest military contractor, justice was swift. At the beginning of the week, G.E., which sold the Pentagon $2.7 billion of jet engines last year, was barred from renewing engine contracts with the Pentagon and from negotiating new ones. The ban resulted from charges that G.E. executives bribed Gen. Rami Dotan of Israel to help the company sell its engines there. The Pentagon asked G.E. to tighten up internal controls and discipline its employees. But after only five days, the Pentagon lifted its ban. A Justice Department criminal investigation is under way.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
The Villain of Rio
 
Last week, William K. Reilly, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said the United States "will have one of the less desirable jobs of the Earth Summit, that of party pooper." That's because the White House said it would boycott the global warming treaty unless the carbon dioxide emissions cap was removed (it was) and that it would not sign the biodiversity treaty -- which Mr. Reilly supported. Just before the summit meeting opened President Bush offered a plan to save forests. He said the White House would increase aid to other nations' forestry programs by $150 million to $270 million. But environmentalists were not impressed. They pointed out that the White House recently agreed to clear-cutting of the nation's old-growth forests.
 
If President Bush is the Earth Summit's villain -- "Uncle Grubby," the Brazilian press calls him -- the Europeans and Japanese are its heroes. Europe announced a "carbon tax" on oil last week and Japan pledged $773 million to Brazil to help clean up Guanabara Bay off Rio de Janeiro.
 
From Bread Line to Ruble Line
 
The latest shortage in Russia is not bread but money. The Government has run out of 5,000-ruble notes and other forms of cash. The shortage is so bad that on a recent trip to Siberia, Russia's President, Boris N. Yeltsin, had to load his plane with 500 million rubles to pay workers' salaries there. The Government -- Russia's main employer -- owes workers a trillion rubles. Yegor T. Gaidar, Moscow's top economist, went on TV last week to tell the nation that relief was on the way: Russia's presses would turn out new notes worth 142 billion rubles by July, 2.5 times the amount printed last month, and they would keep running until 270 billion rubles were printed. When the ink is dry, Russian workers will get their pay, he said, plus an 80 percent annual interest rate on the money past due. Western economists blanched. With prices rising at a 300 percent rate, they fear hyperinflation.
 
The former Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, warned that economic reforms had put Russia on "the verge of an explosion."

Are Japan's Banks Too Big?
 
Japanese banks, like many Japanese companies, have favored market share over profits. Their share of international lending rose to 40 percent in 1989. But now they are hitting the brakes. Japan's biggest banks have a record number of corporate bankruptcies to contend with. Their share of international lending is now about 30 percent. "We may need to think more about profits than expansion," said Hisao Kobayahi, a managing director of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank

An Uncertain Community
 
Until last week, the European Community's march toward political and monetary union seemed like a certainty. Then the Danes went to the polls and voted down the Maastricht treaty, which provides a timetable for creating a single currency. That's a problem for Europe's leaders since the treaty, which was signed last December, requires approval by all 12 E.C. members. "It's a bad blow at a sensitive time," said Dominique Moisi, of the French Institute for International Relations.

Slimmer Trade Gap
 
The nation's first-quarter trade gap declined by 4.48 percent to $14.9 billion, the Commerce Department said.

 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Bad Economic News for Bush
 
When the Labor Department reported last week that unemployment moved up to 7.5 percent in May from 7.2 in April, it was bad news, but not just for the economy. It "will also create some flak for President Bush," said Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities Inc. According to the Labor Department, although the economy is recovering, job growth has been sluggish.

Jobs in the Works
 
According to a quarterly survey by Dun & Bradstreet of 3,000 companies, businesses may soon start hiring. The survey reported that 60 percent of the chief executives polled were optimistic about business conditions this summer and about hiring. But there are jobs and there are jobs. "The larger the firm, the higher the wages and benefits," said Charles McMillion, president of MBG, a business information firm in Washington. "One mass layoff can overwhelm the hiring plans of many smaller companies."

When Not to Balance the Budget
 
At his news conference last week, President Bush urged passage of the balanced budget amendment. But last week a petition against that amendment was delivered to Congress by the Economic Policy Institute; it was signed by 447 economists, including seven Nobel Prize winners. The statement said: "When the private economy is in recession, a constitutional requirement that would force cuts in public spending or tax increases could worsen the economic downturn causing greater loss of jobs, production and income."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
A Danish Earthquake Shakes Europe

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Statesmanship is not a characteristic widely associated with the current crop of politicians, on this or any other continent. But there is one area where the politicians clearly have been trying to do what they are convinced is the right thing.
That area is international economic integration. Whether in Europe or the Americas, national leaders have been willing to push for freer trade despite the possibility that such moves will damage local interests. And few national political parties have chosen to seek cheap gains by inflaming local emotions. 
 Then came Denmark. In a vote that stunned politicians throughout Europe, the Danes narrowly voted against the Maastricht Treaty last week. When that treaty for European monetary union was negotiated, it seems to never have occurred to the politicians that ratification might be a problem.
The vote roiled European markets, generally strengthening the German mark while pushing interest rates up throughout the continent. Share prices were especially weak in France, where the CAC 40 index fell 2.5 percent for the week, and where the Government hurriedly decided that French ratification would be put to the voters rather than left up to Parliament. Now it is remembered that, as Lehman Brothers strategist Steven Nagourney noted, there was no real debate on Maastricht in any country except Britain before the deal was struck.
For many, it is unthinkable that anything will derail the move to (Western) European monetary union, which has proceeded even as central Europe has been torn apart by old ethnic and religious hatreds. "It has to succeed," said Olivier Lacoin of Banque Nationale de Paris. "There is a momentum for Europe."
If he proves wrong, there is a fair chance that Europe, beset by weak economies at the moment, could see a round of competitive currency devaluations. Already the threat of higher interest rates in much of Europe is making economic recovery in Britain a bit less likely. And rising nationalism could derail the tender compromise on farm subsidies that has renewed hopes for a world trade deal. French farmers are furious about that deal, and might just vote against Europe to demonstrate their fury.
In this hemisphere, the leaders of Mexico, Canada and the United States have been moving toward a free trade agreement. It is nowhere near as comprehensive as Maastricht, but the spirit is the same. The belief is that freer trade raises living standards for all.
It is not clear if voting majorities are willing to endorse such long-range thinking. The rise of right-wing splinter parties in France and Germany, and the groundswell of support for Ross Perot, may reflect frustration at the unwillingness of political establishments to let the public be heard on one of the most important economic issues of the era. To advocates of free trade, keeping the issue above the political fray is evidence of statesmanship. To others it just appears undemocratic.
