HEADLINE: The Coming Crisis of the American Work Force

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In the wake of the Los Angeles riots, many public officials are pointing out that minority workers will represent more than half of the growth in the labor force in the next decade. They worry that these workers are badly equipped for the demanding jobs of the 21st century, prompting politicians to propose several measures to deal with the problem.
Economists are increasingly concerned that the American economy will pay the price through lower growth in productivity if something is not done soon to address the problem of inadequate education and training. 
 These experts say the prosperity of all Americans, even those with advanced degrees, could be hurt if new workers -- whether in factories, offices or hospitals -- do not have the required skills for tomorrow's workplace. They also say the profound changes in the work force expected in the next decade point to an increased interdependence between America's whites and nonwhites.
"Since we're doing such a lousy job providing these young people with education and training now, it simply implies a lower standard of living for all Americans, not just blacks and Hispanics," said Bill Brock, the former Secretary of Labor who is chairman of a high-level commission on the skills needed for the workplace of tomorrow.
Economists and a growing number of politicians say an increasingly diverse work force that lacks the proper skills will make it harder for American companies to survive against German and Japanese competition. And by failing to produce sufficient economic growth, the Government will have a harder time maintaining Social Security and Medicare benefits at current levels for Americans who retire early next century.
Economists and educators say vastly increased efforts are needed to improve schooling and training for the minority workers entering the labor force, many of whom are dropouts or attended inferior schools. While noting that American youths in general are less well educated and less prepared for work than German or Japanese youths, these experts say special efforts need to be made for minority youths, who often grow up in a climate of poverty, violence and despair.
"The level of poverty among kids in this country is more than twice that of any industrial country with which we compete," said Marc S. Tucker, president of the National Center on Education and the Economy, a nonprofit group based in Rochester. "It's not reasonable to expect those who grow up in poverty to achieve world-class levels in school and in the workplace."
As part of a post-Los Angeles urban package, some members of Congress are pushing for several hundred million dollars more annually for education and training for inner-city youths, but many experts say these efforts are far too small considering the scope of the problem.
One idea that has picked up steam on Capitol Hill since the riots is to set up a program like the 1930's Civilian Conservation Corps, in which some ghetto youths would be placed in residential work programs in the country to receive training and job experience. These workers might repair roads and renovate public buildings, for instance.
To increase opportunities for all Americans, Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, is sponsoring a separate bill to make up to $30,000 in college loans available to 18-year-olds fresh out of high school or to 28-year-olds who have worked in factories for 10 years.
Mr. Bradley has repeatedly argued that if America's whites seek to shun the needs of the nation's black and Hispanic children, including their need for better education and training, everyone, including whites, will suffer.
"Children of white America and their future will depend increasingly on the talents of nonwhite America," he said in an interview. "If we have fewer people with sufficient skill levels, we won't compete as well against other national economies. Children of white America will have a future where their economic prospects will be less than they might otherwise be. This is a matter of real enlightened self-interest."
Economists and educators say all American youths -- not just nonwhites -- are less prepared for the workplace than youths from other industrial countries. On tests of math and science, American students often perform significantly worse than not only Japanese and German students but even those of some developing nations.
"Our larger problem is we don't stack up very well generally against our competitors," said Billy J. Tidwell, chief economist for the National Urban League. "Then, our minority population, which is growing faster than the population at large, doesn't even stack up by our own standards."
The Labor Secretary's Commission on Achieving Necessary Skills found that 60 percent of Americans between the ages of 21 and 25 lack the basic reading and writing skills needed in the modern workplace. And a recent Urban League report notes that while 68 percent of white adults read at the 11th grade level, only 31 percent of African-Americans do.
Executives at many companies complain that job applicants are woefully unprepared, and they say the skills required for the jobs of tomorrow will be far greater than those of today. Not only will future workers be expected to understand more about computers and mathematics, but as management removes layers of bureaucracy and passes on more responsibility to lower levels, workers will have to be more adept at solving problems and communicating.
At Motorola, the electronics company based in Schaumburg, Ill., 50 percent of job applicants fail to satisfy seventh-grade reading levels and fifth-grade math levels. Motorola says it plans to spend $30 million in the next five years just to bring many of its workers up to those basic levels.
"The business community needs to do a better job communicating to schools the dramatic changes going on in the workplace," said James D. Burge, a Motorola vice president for personnel affairs.
According to Bureau of Labor Statistics estimates, the work force will increase from 124.7 million workers in 1990 to 150.7 million in 2005, an increase of 26 million workers. Because a disproportionate number of people leaving the work force to retire will be white and because minority members represent a growing percentage of new people entering the labor force, minority workers will represent 54 percent of the net increase in the labor force.
Hispanic workers will represent 27.8 percentage points of the increased labor force, blacks will account for 15.8 points and Asian Americans, 10.1 points.
"It's not just the fact that a disproportionate number of people entering the work force are black, Hispanic and poor," said Mr. Tucker, head of the center on education and the economy. "It's also that there are fewer people available coming into the work force. Companies have to reach further down into the queue of qualified people."
Economists and educators agree that the 30 percent of Americans who receive degrees from colleges or community colleges are among the best educated people the world. The problem, they say, is the 70 percent of young Americans who do not receive college degrees, most of whom receive little training for the occupations they enter.
"This country cannot survive in a competitive world on the basis of a highly trained and skilled 30 percent of its work force," said Mr. Brock, the former Labor Secretary.
Many labor experts say that the United States does less than any other leading industrial country to help youths make the transition from school to the workplace. This, they say, especially hurts those who do not go to college because they obtain little guidance in finding jobs and little training for specific occupations.
School systems spend about $5,000 a year for high school students, but often nothing is spent to educate or train dropouts. This hurts not just the dropouts but also the quality of the labor force.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, is sponsoring a bill aimed at helping those who do not go to college to make the transition to the work force. The bill follows recommendations of the Commission on the Skills of the American Work Force, which calls for setting up a tough new basic education performance standard for all students -- a move intended to push students and schools to work harder. This standard, which most students would be expected to meet by age 16, would be established nationally and pegged to the highest standard in the world.
The report calls on states to insure that all students, even ones who drop out, meet the basic performance standards on reading, writing, math and other areas. For instance, the states might finance job-training programs for dropouts that would also provide remedial education in the basics.
Borrowing an idea from Germany's apprenticeship programs, the report also calls for establishing a wide range of technical and professional certificates. These would go to youths who do not pursue bachelor's degrees, but instead complete multiyear programs of work and study. These certificates would signal that students have the entry-level skills for specific occupations. The certificates should thus help raise skill levels, and when certificate holders are hired, they will be rewarded for their training.
"If we continue with the same proportion of unskilled workers that we used to have, the situation for American competitiveness and improving the American standard of living is rather bleak," said Arnold H. Packer, a labor expert at Johns Hopkins University.
In a report advocating a Marshall Plan to help America's economy, the Urban League calls for vastly expanding the Jobs Corps, a residential program, mainly in cities, that provides intensive job training, remedial education and counseling. The report notes that the corps enrolls 70,000 youths a year, or 5 percent of eligible dropouts. The Urban League says the Job Corps should be expanded to 400,000 spots annually.
Senator Bradley says the work force's increased diversity can be a plus for the economy for numerous reasons, including greater knowledge of languages and greater cultural affinities with markets overseas.
The increased diversity "could be an enormous opportunity," he said. "On the other hand, it means that to the extent the nonwhite work force is unskilled, we're not going to be as competitive in the world market."
 
 
 
A LACK OF PROBLEM-SOLVERS
 Recent studies show that the failure of minority workers to develop advanced skills is cutting into their earning power as a more sophisticated economy demands higher skill levels.
Citing a study by Sheldon Danziger, an economics professor at the University of Michigan, the commission headed by Mr. Brock noted that the percentage of minority men with high school degrees who do not earn enough to support a family of four above the poverty line has soared.
According to that study, the proportion of all African-American men with 12 years of education, aged 25 to 54, who had low earnings rose to 42.7 percent in 1989 from 20 percent in 1969. The percentage among Hispanic men jumped to 35.9 percent from 16.4 percent. There was also a jump for white men: to 22.6 percent from 8.3 percent.
The commission said that sufficient data were not available to make similar comparisons for working women.
"I don't think we do a very good job educating children beyond the requirements of the industrial agrarian society that we are leaving behind," said Robert F. Peterkin, a former superintendent of Milwaukee's schools, who now directs the urban superintendents' program at the Harvard Graduate School of Education. "We're not preparing them for the information-technology society that is being created."
Mr. Peterkin complained that American schools are "continuing to do the drill-and-kill exercises" around basic information that do not prepare youngsters to be agile-minded, problem-solving workers. Nor, he added, are schools preparing American workers to be leaders in the economy of tomorrow.
Mr. Peterkin said these problems are far more severe in urban public schools, not only because of violence, poverty and broken families but also because the money spent on each pupil is generally far lower than in wealthier suburbs.

HEADLINE: Got a Perot Headache? 8-Way Relief: REPUBLICANS;
Overcoming Fear

BYLINE: By Nancy Kassebaum; Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican, is Senator from Kansas.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The cliche of the 1992 election is that this campaign is about "the future" and will be won by the candidate who is "for change." The driving force is not the desire for change but the fear of it. The old world order is gone. The restructuring of our economy threatens even the most secure worker. Government appears gridlocked by indecision, and voters wonder whom to hold accountable.
While some seek to make this an indictment of George Bush, the problem is a crisis of confidence in our entire political system. Thus, the popularity of "outsider" Ross Perot. Whatever his personal attributes, he, and his style of buccaneer politics, is not the cure for what ails America. 
 But competition is healthy. Mixing it up may add some needed vitality. The President should reach out and fight for all Perot supporters anxious about jobs, health care, crime and the general breakdown of everything that has given them a sense of security, stability and purpose.
George Bush is widely viewed, even among nonsupporters, as a decent, sincere man of integrity. This is not a bad place to start a campaign. But there must be more.
I would suggest that when he goes to Camp David next weekend with Barbara and Millie he take no advisers, briefing books or poll results. He shouldn't take any calls. Instead, he should think in peace and quiet about his three most important objectives for the next four years, and then state plainly how he will accomplish them.

HEADLINE: Warnings About More Than Ecology

 BODY:
Re "Builders Rally to Free Up Pine Barrens Development" [May 17], the Nobel Prize-winning author Octavio Paz asked not long ago whether our economic system would be changed by human wisdom or destroyed by its own excesses and contradictions. In the latter case, he worried that it could drag our democratic institutions with it.
The proposal by Long Island developers and their allies to "modify" laws protecting the pine barrens because it interfered with business interests mirrors the efforts by the Bush Administration to weaken national environmental legislation for the same reasons. One gets the impression that economic interests establish the rules of the political game to favor themselves, and when citizens manage to achieve some degree of success such as the Long Island Pine Barrens Society, those with economic power simply go outside the rules or change them. 
 If that analysis is correct, then our political structures have become welded to the interests of business itself and our democratic values in more trouble than we realize. Environmentalists may be inadvertently sounding the alarm for more than ecology.
 
BILL HAFNER
Mastic

HEADLINE: In China, Capitalism and Friendship for West Grow Side by Side

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was stunned by "Roots of Hostility" (letter, May 19), in which Ted Pritikin argues that the next generation of Chinese will be more imbued with nationalism and therefore more hostile to Western capitalist countries, particularly the United States. Even more outrageous, he tries to lend credence to this assertion by referring to his two years in China. 
 I'm not sure if there is a root of hostility in China to the United States. Even if there is one, it is largely caused by the cold war environment in the aftermath of the Korean War, which forced Mao Zedong to woo Stalin, whom Mao never liked, and Chinese Communist Party attempts to create outside enemies to maintain political control.
I am surprised Mr. Pritikin did not observe how little effect Communist Party propaganda had on the Chinese. The Chinese are still the same Chinese, even after years of being told that capitalist countries are trying to exploit China or contaminate China's moral standard. I am even more surprised that Mr. Pritikin did not experience hospitality during his stay in China. The Chinese are very friendly to foreigners. Oftentimes indeed they treat foreigners better than they treat their own people.
The Chinese are born capitalists. We all know what a successful capitalist wants: freedom, rather than oppression; internationalism, rather than protectionism. The success of China's economic reform and the unbalanced growth between China's state and nonstate sectors reflect nothing but the spirit of capitalism unleashed.
As the new generation of Chinese more bravely embrace a capitalist market system, political liberalization will be an inevitable consequence of economic reform. So one can hardly imagine that the new generation of Chinese who are yearning for a social system with economic and political freedom -- the two essential characteristics of democratic capitalism -- will be the enemy of the United States.
 
JEFFREY LIANG
Economic Researcher, American Enterprise Institute
Washington, May 22, 1992

HEADLINE: Down The Middle;
Perot's Appeal to the Mainstream Keeps Two-Party Politics Off Stride

BYLINE: By HOWELL RAINES

 BODY:
All week, the candidacy of Ross Perot was like a tidal wave roaring across the big island called Two-Party-Politics-as-Usual. For the moment, the Republicans, the Democrats and their newly minted nominees are following a strategy dictated by the situation. That is, they are lashing themselves to the palm trees and hoping that something can be salvaged from the backwash.
What is driving the Perot wave? For weeks, President Bush and his advisers have believed it was pushed by a freshet of discontent that would blow itself out once the economic barometer rose a bit. Bill Clinton and the Democrats have been hoping that this was another of those hot blasts from Dixie that would raise a lot of dust but do little real damage, as was the case with Huey P. Long, Strom Thurmond and George C. Wallace. 
 But many strategists and political scientists believe that the Perot storm surge is being pushed by a big typhoon that could keep ripping until November. And worse luck for the two established political parties, its energy source may not be the standard, anti-politician apathy that consultants in both parties know how to manipulate on election eve with feel-good commercials or racial scare tactics. "This is not apathy. This is antipathy," said Theodore J. Lowi, a political science professor at Cornell University who is president of the American Political Science Association. "We've had antipathy before, but what makes this close to being unprecedented is the positive side of it," he added, referring to a poll conducted last week for USA Today. "Very few polls have given respondents an opportunity to talk about a third party," Mr. Lowi said, adding that 55 to 60 percent like the idea. "What's unusual is that the spread is large, but it's also in the middle. I refer to it as the radicalization of the middle."
A protest candidacy arising from a radicalized center rather than from some fragment of regional, economic or racial discontent would represent a unique threat to what Mr. Bush calls "the fantastic historical stability" provided by -- and depended upon by -- the Republicans and the Democrats.
So far, the Perot phenomenon seems to have one central feature in common with the 100 third-party efforts that have arisen since 1840. "Third party voting occurs when citizens feel the major parties have failed to live up to their implicit contractual obligations," according to "Third Parties in America," by Steven J. Rosenstone, Roy L. Behr and Edward H. Lazarus (Princeton University Press, 1984). The authors conclude that "only the most egregious violations" of this implied contract can cause Americans to turn against their two traditional parties.
Belatedly, Bush and Clinton strategists seem to be realizing that this is what makes Mr. Perot such a danger to the major party candidates. He is trying to corral them both in "egregious violation" territory, and for weeks, both candidates and their parties have been clip-clopping blindly along while the pesky Mr. Perot cracked his whip over their heads.
Indeed, both the Clinton and Bush camps last week emanated a deep sense of puzzlement that none of the old tricks seems to work. It is the uniquely devilish gift of the little man from Texas that he can make Mr. Clinton and Mr. Bush look like vacuous hacks every time they reach for the Standard Manual of Political Response.
As a case in point, take Mr. Bush's floundering performance on television Thursday night when he tried the time-honored trick of tickling the polls with a nationally televised news conference. For several days, his surrogates, Vice President Dan Quayle and White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater, had been test-marketing various attack lines. But the emotional high point of the conference was Mr. Bush's announcement that he was going to keep hiding behind his seconds. "I'm glad they're putting their focus on these problems," he said when asked about their criticism of Mr. Perot's lack of experience and authoritarian streak. "But I'm not going to do it myself."
Not-going-to-do-it pretty well sums up Mr. Clinton's fumbling response to his best recent opportunity to assert himself as a major force in this three-cornered contest. That chance, of course, was the Los Angeles riots. The White House has only a skeletal urban policy. Mr. Perot's plan to jump on a plane and fly toward smoking cities was earnest but hardly impressive as an intellectual response to urban blight.
With a passionate speech and a detailed urban plan, Mr. Clinton might have dominated the campaign debate, proven his superiority to Mr. Perot as an architect of detailed responses and underscored the brain-dead state of the Administration policy apparatus. But as late as Thursday night, Mr. Clinton was in Mr. Perot's favorite venue -- "Larry King Live," a call-in show -- gamely and lamely pledging to oppose lawlessness in riot areas.
Mr. Clinton got one thing he needed to soothe his worried party, and that was a victory over California's native son, Jerry Brown, in the primary there last week. Once again, Mr. Bush beat Patrick J. Buchanan. But the exit polls showed that Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton would have been hard put to defeat Mr. Perot had he been on their primary ballots.
 
'Sic 'Em'
 From both the White House and the Clinton research bunker in Little Rock come assurances that the best minds in both camps are pondering the Perot problem. But the depth of their bewilderment is demonstrated by both teams, which share a hearty dislike of journalists, counting on them to knock the top off the Perot appeal. "I can understand that appeal: 'I'm from outside. I'll solve all the problems'," Mr. Bush said at his news conference before adding hopefully: "And then some day you guys are going to start: 'How are you going to do it?' "
This was the President saying "sic 'em" to the press. His statement reflects the bipartisan faith that sustains both camps right now: that this heretic candidacy will crumble once Mr. Perot is forced to reveal his personality more fully and to "get specific." But Jimmy Carter in 1976 and Ronald Reagan in 1980 were hounded to get specific, and each won in large measure because he spoke in generalities that embodied the spirit of the moment. Jody Powell, the Carter aide who was a central player in 1976 and 1980, said that in both those contests there was still an undergirding sense that the political system worked. "Boy, you don't get that now," he said. "There's a sense out there that we've got all these things wrong and we're not doing anything about it, that both Bush and Clinton are so entangled with their parties' interests that they're not going to be able to do anything."
Mr. Rosenstone, the historian of third parties, said protest candidates usually weaken when the major parties "dig in" with their critical attacks. But he added quickly, "The caveat on all of this is money." No recent third-party candidate has matched the two parties' spending nor reached as deeply into their ranks as Mr. Perot did in hiring Hamilton Jordan, a former Carter aide, and Ed Rollins, a former Republican Party official, to run his campaign. No third-party candidate has ever been able to match the two parties' spending as Mr. Perot says he will.
The Democratic convention July 13 and the Republican convention Aug. 17 will provide the two major parties with their best chances to refute their images as joint stockholders in a national gridlock. If Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton do not do more with the opportunities of summer than they did with those of the spring, it may be time for them to look toward the tidal wave and start humming the old Johnny Cash number, "How High's the Water, Momma?"

LENGTH: 1143 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Japan's Slowed Economy Offers A New Chance for Wishful Thinking

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
With the Tokyo stock market at half its 1990 value, Japan's once-invincible banks reeling from billions of dollars in bad loans, and signs that the American economy is slowly rebounding, the new common wisdom in the United States seems to be that maybe the Japanese are not so tough, after all.
"Americans who want to see America outperform Japan ought now to be humming the 'Hallelujah' Chorus -- not in glee at Japan's difficulties, but in confidence that America need not fear Japan," wrote Karen Elliott House on the opinion page of The Wall Street Journal, in one of many such recent articles that struck similar themes. The Japanese, she concluded, "were never the economic terminators of America's imaginings." 
 Maybe not, but much of what is being written these days seems more rooted in wishful thinking than economic reality. Though Japan's financial world is reeling, very little seems to have changed in Tokyo's factories and laboratories.
Time and again in recent years, predictions have abounded that the Japanese economy was about to be brought to its knees. And every one has proven wrong. The "oil shock" in 1973 was supposed to hit Japanese manufacturers especially hard; instead Japan became one of the most energy-efficient industrialized nations on earth. The Plaza Accord in 1985, an agreement by the major industrial nations to increase the value of the yen to make Japanese exports less competitive on world markets, was supposed to end Japan's giant trade surpluses. It led to a revolution in Japanese manufacturing strategy, and the world's trade gap with Japan is now higher than ever. What reason is there to believe that the current Japanese financial crisis -- severe as it is -- will accomplish what the Arabs and trade negotiators could not?
"Americans always tend to overestimate Japan, and then underestimate Japan," said Naohiro Amaya, a former vice minister of Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry and an architect of the country's industrial policy. Indeed, American perceptions of Japan have vacillated wildly in the 125 years since Admiral Perry sailed into Tokyo Bay. Japan seemed quaint until it defeated the Russian fleet in 1904. Thirty years later, many American Japan experts averted their eyes when evidence indicated that militarism was driving the country. In the 1970's, Detroit ignored equally clear signals of the rising power of Japanese industry.
Richard Samuels, a political scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who studies Japan's industrial policy, says that such shifts tend to say more about Americans than about the Japanese: "We change our perceptions of competitors and institutions on a dime." Such shifts make it even harder for the United States to fashion a consistent strategic plan for competing with Japan in the long term, no matter who is in office. The subtle message that's been conveyed to American manufacturers in recent months is just the opposite: The Japanese are in trouble, so you can afford to roll over and catch that extra hour of sleep.
No one is suggesting that Japan isn't facing serious problems. The fallout from the financial crises will slow the Japanese down for years to come. They will be lucky if their economy grows by 2.5 percent this year, which is down from the heady 6 or 8 percent growth of the late 1980's. The days of cheap, easy credit, which fueled Japan's investment boom in the 1980's, are over. Japanese companies are already announcing cutbacks in research and development and capital spending -- though they are generally relatively minor declines from stratospheric levels.
 
Squeezing Profits
 The number of bankruptcies is suddenly surging, mostly among smaller companies that live at the bottom of the food chain of Japan's industrial structure. Their profits are being squeezed by the giant corporations they supply, the downside of the feudal "keiretsu" -- families of interlinked companies -- that are supposedly one of Japan's secret weapons. Japan's once-feared Fifth Generation project in advanced computing ended a 10-year run last week with few useful results, and many wonder whether the country's industrial planners are losing their touch. They may prove to be better at catching up than at leading the way.
Few Japanese would trade their economic problems for America's, and anyone who lives here need only walk through the streets to see why. Unemployment rates still linger at about 2 percent, though that figure does not include part-time workers, particularly women who have been laid off recently from the jobs they took in the boom times. Mercedes sales are down, and so is lavish entertainment at restaurants in the Ginza, home of the $1,000 business dinner. Land prices have fallen 20 to 30 percent, though they are still among the world's highest. But neither does this add up to a portrait of urban decay: Public works projects abound, and cities like Tokyo spend enormous sums building trains and replacing bridges that by New York standards are brand new.
A decline in wealth should not be mistaken for a decline in industrial competitiveness. "There is still a well-educated, highly skilled, massively deployed, overemployed workforce," said Mr. Samuels. "It is sort of hard to understand why we don't see it as the economic challenge we once did." Squeezed profits have made Japanese firms look at reducing the fat that built up in headier days.
More important, every downturn in recent Japanese history has been turned to some advantage by Japan, with top executives using the arrival of a "crisis" as a goad to achieve some goal they have long sought. This moment in time seems no exception.
 
Raising Prices
 Companies from Matsushita to Toyota are reducing the number of products they make by upward of 20 percent. The car makers are all raising their prices, betting that Detroit -- as it did in the 1980's -- will be unable to resist the temptation to follow suit rather than use the opportunity to retake market share. Akio Morita, the founder of Sony Corporation, has been calling on Japanese companies to abandon what he described as their mindless pursuit of market share over profits. The result, as he admitted to journalists recently, will probably be higher prices.
"The economy will not only be cleaned, and go through another cycle of cost reduction, but it will probably emerge more concentrated as the fat of the 1980's is being melted off," said Kenneth L. Courtis, the chief economist for Deutsche Bank in Tokyo. "In the end it will come out tougher, harder, with a base of more powerful, big companies." By that time, the American perception will most likely have shifted again.
The question is whether the United States will have used Tokyo's era of troubles to good advantage, or wasted another chance to regain ground it has lost.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 20; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 935 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
When Social Services Have a Bottom Line

BYLINE: By KAREN DeWITT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Corporate America has increasingly found itself in recent years plugging some holes in the nation's social welfare system. As various levels of government have scaled back or declined to increase their roles in meeting both old and emerging social needs, corporations have stepped forward into areas they didn't anticipate entering even a decade ago. And as they supply services ranging from prenatal care to job training, the lines between the traditional roles of business and government sometimes blur, raising questions of accountability and responsiveness.
Employers like A.T.& T., I.B.M., Kraft, Corning, Texas Instruments, Primerica, Johnson & Johnson, Honeywell and Stride Rite have steadily moved into providing social services, primarily for employees but also, on occasion, the wider community. For example, the Prudential Insurance Company finances a program to pay doctors and nurses for the Head Start program at community health clinics in Newark and Patterson, N.J., and Cessna Aircraft built a training factory in a depressed area of Wichita, Kan. 
 While corporate involvement in such programs is clearly growing, there are no accurate figures on how much money businesses are spending or how many people are affected. "No one catalogs it and there is no standard definition of what social service is across companies," said Sandra Hamburg, director of education programs for the Committee for Economic Development, a 50-year-old nonprofit organization of 250 business leaders and university presidents. Tracking only education programs from kindergarten through high school, the Council for Aid to Education, a New York-based non-profit organization, reported that companies spent $400 million in 1989, the latest figure available.
Though some American businesses have long had socially conscious policies -- providing employees' children with scholarships, for example -- a rising realization in recent years of the importance of education to the availability of a qualified work force has caused many companies to expand their traditional roles. One influential factor was "A Nation at Risk," the Federal government's 1983 report on the state of the U.S. education system.
"Certainly the education movement has been mostly responsible for getting corporations to understand the connections between early childhood learning and health,"Ms. Hamburg said.
The Prudential is a good example of corporate involvement. In 1991, the company spent $41 million on social welfare programs. It distributes money in three ways. Its foundation emphasizes children and early childhood projects such as the health care facilities for Head Start. A social investment program provides loans and investments of up to $1 million for economic revitalization, helping, for example, to build a Pathmark supermarket for downtown Newark, the first major supermarket there since the 1967 riots. The Prudential also has a program through which employees and executives provide leadership and expertise to groups like the New Jersey Food Bank.
"Business is providing these services because they want a productive work force," said Dr. Mary Jane England, president of the Washington Business Group, a coalition of businesses interested in keeping health insurance rates down. "It's not entirely altruistic."
Corporate largess to social welfare programs also raises unanswered questions about equity and access. Will corporate benevolence exacerbate a decline in public services by draining away the most skilled professionals? What if a company pays doctors and nurses more to work in its program than the public coffers can provide? Does giving stipends and enhancing one or two local child care facilities skew the market for workers whose companies either can't afford or don't offer similar benefits? And will the more sophisticated, highly paid professionals either negotiate for or work for companies willing to provide them with social services while needier, unskilled workers at less benevolent companies go wanting?
Ellen Galinsky, a co-founder of the Families and Work Institute, a non-profit New York-based organization, encourages companies to consider their impact. Otherwise, she said, "There is the danger of creating a larger wedge between the haves and the have-nots.'
Making it possible for have-nots to become haves is the goal at Cessna Aircraft. Russell W. Meyer, chairman and chief executive officer, said 85 percent of the people who have been accepted at their two-year old training factory have gone on to jobs at the main Cessna plant.
 
Teaching the Basics
 "We didn't realize at first how many problems these people have," Mr. Meyer said, citing drug addiction, lack of support and sometimes jealousy from relatives and acquaintances who were not in the program.
"We always assume that everybody is as independent as we are," Mr. Meyer said. "We discovered that a lot of people needed a kind of buddy support system because they were a little bit intimidated when they graduated to the big plant." Trainees, who get paid from their first day in the program, had to be shown, for example, how to open a checking account and manage their money from paycheck to paycheck.
Cessna's success has convinced Mr. Meyer that businesses should become more involved in job training programs. "I think this is absolutely not a job for government," he said. "I think business has to do it. We have to have a basic welfare system as a safety net, but in order to take the next step, it's a business and community resonsibility to train and meaningfully employ people."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Trainees learning metalworking skills for production positions in a program sponsored by Cessna Aircraft Company in Wichita, Kan. (Steve Rasmussen for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
After a Fresh Look, U.S. Decides to Still Steer Clear of Iran

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In the course of three and a half years, Bush Administration officials have made it a habit, when asked about the state of relations between the United States and Iran, to respond in the same kind of shorthand President Bush used in his inaugural address in January, 1989. "Good will begets good will," said the President, who in 1990 seemed so open to improving ties to Teheran that he took what he thought was a phone call from Iran's President, Hashemi Rafsanjani, only to discover well into the conversation that he was talking to an impostor.
So it seemed natural that Washington might reward Teheran after it stayed neutral in the Persian Gulf war in early 1991 and used its influence -- and its money -- to persuade Iranian-backed groups in Lebanon to free the last American hostage last December. Indeed, earlier this year, Richard N. Haass, the chief White House aide on the Middle East, launched the first formal review of American policy toward Iran since the first months of the Bush Administration. He floated the idea that the Administration consider a strategy of "constructive engagement" by lifting some economic sanctions, according to participants in the review process. 
 The review was motivated less by benevolence than by conditions that were changing the geopolitical balance: the weakening of Iraq, instability in the formerly Soviet republics of Central Asia, nervousness in the Gulf Arab states and, in Iran, the combination of political consolidation, economic reconstruction and a military buildup. "People recognized that Iran is in a position -- and over time will increasingly be in a position -- to affect U.S. interests in this part of the world," said one official who sought to explain the reasons for the review.
But when the review was completed in April, the policy team concluded that this was not the moment for good will.
Iran, after all, had been the foreign policy Bermuda Triangle for both Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan, and there was no compelling reason why George Bush should sail into those dangerous waters so close to the election. The review concluded that any gesture that might be politically meaningful in Teheran -- lifting the ban on oil sales to America, for example -- would have been politically impossible at home. On the other hand, a reward small enough to be painless in American political terms, such as lifting the ban on exports of carpets and pistachios, would have seemed too paltry to Teheran.
A second factor was that Iran suffers from the Saddam syndrome. Constructive engagement clearly failed in Iraq in the months before Saddam Hussein's forces invaded Kuwait, and the Administration was not eager to open itself to accusations that it was repeating a flawed policy strategy by making conciliatory gestures toward Teheran.
A third element is Washington's elevation of weapons proliferation to the status of a major security threat, where it used to end up at the bottom of the foreign policy agenda along with drugs and human rights. The fear that Iran will follow the lead of Iraq and try to develop nuclear weapons has figured prominently in the discussions on this issue. No matter that the late Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi also harbored a secret desire to turn his country into a nuclear power, in the days when Iran was on the side of the United States. The policy review's conclusion was, in the words of one Administration official, that "we missed once in Iraq and we won't do it twice."
Finally, Iran is its own worst enemy when it comes to breaking the impasse in relations with the United States. While Iranian officials, such as Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati, have expressed disappointment that their intervention in winning the release of American hostages was not rewarded, Washington can tick off numerous examples of Iran's unacceptable behavior. Despite his courting of the West, for example, Mr. Rafsanjani urged Palestinians in May 1989 to "kill and execute -- and not just inside Palestine -- five Americans, or Britons or French" for every martyr of their own. His attacks on the American-sponsored peace process that is fitfully under way between Israel and the Arabs, and his sponsorship of an alternate conference in Iran last year -- at which some of the most distasteful Middle Eastern terrorists were guests -- were most unwelcome in Washington.
Administration officials cite Iran's continued involvement in terrorism, its poor human rights record, and its support for Islamic fundamentalist movements in Algeria and the Sudan as continued obstacles to improving relations. Most serious, they say, is Iran's transfer of substantial amounts of new aid to Shiite Muslim groups in Lebanon since the release of the American hostages. In the last two weeks, some officials believe, Iran through its surrogates in Lebanon has tried to engineer a war between Syria and Israel to sabotage the Middle East peace talks.
 
Bewilderment
 The Administration's policy decision essentially leaves it to the next Administration to decide whether to constructively engage with Iran. Small wonder: Even those analysts who defend the use of incentives to moderate behavior are bewildered about how to treat Iran. Morton I. Abramowitz, president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, argues that Iran under President Rafsanjani may well be far more susceptible to change than Iraq has been under Mr. Hussein. "Still," Mr. Abramowitz said, "I am not necessarily advocating change."
What confuses the picture is that there is no answer to a fundamental question about Mr. Rafsanjani's moves to curb radical elements in his regime and expand ties with Western industrialized countries. Do his actions represent a strategic shift in the course of Iran's 13-year revolution, or are they only a tactical maneuver that could be reversed once Iran succeeds in reconstructing its economy? Mr. Rafsanjani himself may not know the answer to the question, proving that making policy even with the best of intentions is anything but foolproof.

HEADLINE: Conversations/Two Families in Tajikistan;
An Empire's Retreat Strands Exiles In a Place They Had Called Home

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

DATELINE: DUSHANBE, Tajikistan

 BODY:
Valery B. Akhadov, a film maker who is half-Tajik but speaks only Russian, is charming, impish, cosmopolitan and increasingly at sea in the country of Tajikistan, a fragment of the broken Soviet Union that is defining itself by its Persian and Islamic roots. He tells a lot of silly and extremely funny jokes over a long and lavish dinner, and then, suddenly, one full of poignancy. A Georgian walking on a beach hears someone out at sea, crying for help, but in Russian. He walks on as the cries continue, and then finally turns and yells out toward the water: "Better than learning Russian you should have learned how to swim!"
Mr. Akhadov's wife, Zulfiya Mirshakar, an ethnic Pamir and professor of Russian, has no doubt heard this joke before, but still averts her face. 
 Are you crying for help, a visitor asks Mr. Akhadov. "Not yet," he says, laughing through his thick mustache. "But soon, and it will be in Russian."
In another home, Vladimir V. Chekan and his wife, Tamara, who have built their lives here for the last 31 years and have no Tajik blood, are crying for help now. They've sent their daughter, Natasha, a pianist, to stay with friends in Moscow, but they have no apartment or residence permission there. Their son, Andrei, 16 years old, is in America on an exchange program, and they think about how they can go to join him.
Their lives and nationalities are a wrenching example of the mess the death of the Soviet Union has left behind. Most empires, when they retreat, go back across an ocean. Russia can hardly absorb all its colonists, and some of them aren't even officially Russian. National distinctions that once meant nothing now mean everything, or seem to, particularly as newly independent nations, like Tajikistan, try to create a sense of nationhood out of a long-held sense of nationality suppressed by Soviet power.
Mr. Chekan, who moved here from Georgia, is half-Russian and half-Ukrainian but his nationality, on his passport, is Ukrainian, since that is what his father was. But he speaks only Russian and Georgian. His wife is half-Russian and half-Armenian, but her nationality is Armenian, even though she speaks only Russian and was born and has lived her whole life in Dushanbe. Their children, with a Ukrainian father, are Ukrainian. "Even when I go to Russia," says Mrs. Chekan, crying, "I feel like a white crow."
 
'Where Will We Go?'
 "In one family, we have four nations," said Mr. Chekan, clenching his fists. "I think there will be more blood here, I tell you. But now where will we go? I tell you frankly, for me, the end of the union is a catastrophe."
Its deep blue sky etched by the icy peaks of mountains that stretch toward Afghanistan, Tajikistan is among the most beautiful, and poorest, remnants of the old Russian empire. Even before the Soviet deformation, Russians regarded their sway over Central Asia as in large part a civilizing mission; later, a great deal of money and sweat went to turn what was a feudal, imperial backwater into a model of Soviet socialism -- modern, collective, denationalized, atheistic.
Unsurprisingly, the collapse of Communism and the empire itself has revealed the absurdity of this attempted transformation of poor, Muslim nationalists into a new, Russian-speaking Homo Sovieticus.
But as the Russian tide recedes, there are 25 million ethnic Russians stranded outside Russia proper, uncertain about their national loyalties and the future of themselves and their families. Like Vladimir and Tamara Chekan. "We feel more and more unwelcome here, and as Russians, we have no future in the new Tajikistan, which will without doubt become more narrow and more Islamic," he says. "But we have nowhere to go."
Also stranded are a kind of half-species, a Russified national elite who bought into the imperial culture, and who have their own deep anxieties about a future increasingly Tajik and Islamic. Like Valery Akhadov, whose father was Tajik and whose mother was a German Jew, the daughter of revolutionaries who came to build Communism and then got sent to Stalin's gulag for their pains. "By tongue I'm Russian," he said. "My education is pan-European. But in the end, I consider myself Tajik. But what matters is if the Tajiks consider me to be one of them." And do they? He laughed. "Many don't."
But there is also a sense of being subsumed in a smaller and alien culture, and there is a strong desire that their three daughters inhabit the larger world of Russian language, literature and relative sexual equality. "If Islam comes here, I'll never cover my head," said Mrs. Mirshakar. "I'll leave."
Mr. Akhadov cradled the head of his youngest daughter, 10-year-old Negina. Takhmina, 23, and Jamila, 19, came quietly into the room. "I can't imagine a future anywhere but here," Takhmina said. "In Moscow you are not theirs and here you aren't theirs. I feel a foreigner among foreigners."
"Where did Soviet power bring us?" Jamila asked. "Was it necessary to go through 70 years of all this pain and then find yourself back at the beginning? In school they taught us that there is only progress, and no regression. But here we are back at the beginning of the beginning."
 
The Family Tomb
 At the Chekans, Tamara, now a schoolteacher, considered how it felt to go from being a citizen of a superpower to being a citizen of impoverished Tajikistan. "I'm lonely," she said. "Some of our best friends have moved away, some to Germany. And Moscow? But here is my family tomb, with my father and my young daughter, who died at 8. I was born 49 years ago, and here I've lived all my life.
"As for the union," she said, working her hands into a tight ball, "I worked as an economist for 20 years, under Brezhnev and Gorbachev, and I've seen it all, and I believed in all this" -- gesturing to the city beyond. "And it's a tragedy when a person loses all his beliefs."
Mr. Chekan, a city engineer, helped build Dushanbe: roads, bridges, housing. And he loves to fish for trout in Tajikistan. "I love this nature and this life here. And if it comes to leave, I think I must leave the old union altogether. I think of going to Andrei, my son, in America, and then I think of all the problems, and finding a sponsor and everything. Really, I just don't know."
Here Tamara stood behind him and touched his shoulders. "Do you understand? Do you understand? Two years ago we thought of getting a container to move all these things away, in which we've invested our lives. I hate it. What we need is to feel calmer inside, and not feel all these tensions. This is not a cry from the heart. It's a shout -- a cry of the heart."
They talked of America and their son, to an American who might be able to help; but they found it hard to ask, as he would find it hard to answer. To telephone Andrei, they book a call two days ahead, for three minutes at 54 rubles (about 54 cents) a minute. Why not reserve more time, asks the American, unthinking, and she laughs bitterly: "Ten minutes is half my monthly salary."
Four days later, in Moscow, Vladimir was on the phone. How could they get to America? Who would sponsor them? The American, unsurprised by the call, which he had dreaded, had no answer, as he knew he would not.

HEADLINE: Good News, Then Bad News, but Good Spin

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
A wave of upbeat numbers early last week depicting a broad, if hardly booming, recovery ended on a decidedly downbeat note with Friday's report that unemployment had risen in May. Early in the week, the Dow Jones industrial average broke 3,400 for the first time, corporate purchasing reached a level not seen since 1988, consumer spending rose and the Federal Reserve Board's chairman said inflation was not likely to threaten the economy in the next couple of years. But on Friday, the Labor Department said the unemployment rate had jumped to 7.5 percent, its highest in almost eight years.
While the jobless report was widely taken as rotten news -- both for the economy and, at the White House, for George Bush's re-election prospects -- it actually contained more than a little evidence that the modest recovery remains alive and well. 
 To wit: a surge in the number of people who were actively looking for jobs -- a precondition for being counted as unemployed -- accounted for most of the rise in the jobless rate.
"People are a good deal more positive about current and future job prospects than they were three or four months ago," said Fabian Linden, who conducts monthly consumer confidence polls.
More important, business is hiring again. About 250,000 jobs sprouted in the last two months, the Labor Department said. More than half of the businesses surveyed said their payrolls had grown over the last month.
To keep up with rising sales, companies are also making those who have jobs work more overtime. The factory work week is the longest it's been since 1966 and the demand for temporary help is up sharply.
Business executives, more confident than a year ago that the recovery will last, plan to do more hiring, according to several polls. "We will increase employment this year," said F. Kenneth Iverson, chief executive of Nucor, the Charlotte, N.C., steelmaker. But even if business merely keeps up its modest pace, there will be at least one million new jobs by year's end.
New jobs and more overtime, economists say, are lifting consumers' incomes just enough to keep the slow recovery from relapsing.
What's not in the cards, though, is a repeat of the Reagan recovery of 1983, which drove the unemployment rate -- which reached 10.8 percent in the 1982 recession -- down 2 full percentage points in the first 12 months. Even optimists in the forecasting fraternity say that President Bush will be lucky if the unemployment rate dips below 7 percent by Election Day.
Most economists expect new jobs to be created at just half the rate of the Reagan boom. The service sector -- source of 21 million new jobs back then -- is now struggling to streamline. Some big manufacturers -- makers of computers, cars, military hardware -- are shrinking. And the glut in commercial real estate all but guarantees that there won't be as many construction jobs as there were in the 1980's for a long time.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Environmental Policy: It's a Jungle in There

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Is President Bush a brave and lonely voice of reason against a tide of environmental protection that could be disastrous to the economy?
Or is he managing environmental policy to gain support from conservative interests who use warnings of economic harm and loss of liberty to weaken environmental regulation? Those questions were at the center of a week of conflict over environmental policy that engulfed the White House and then tumbled out before the world in the opening days of the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development in Brazil. 
 The strain opened to public view the Administration's deep internal divisions over ecological safeguards and raised questions about the United States role in a world in which national security may be as affected by global environmental threats as by military ones.
It began on Wednesday when the chief of the United States delegation in Rio, William K. Reilly, came under international attack for the Administration's refusal to sign a treaty to protect wild plants and animals.
This biodiversity treaty is a centerpiece of the summit. Mr. Reilly, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency and a professional environmentalist, supported it. But before he arrived in Rio, the State Department announced that the President would not sign it because American biotechnology companies might be hurt by its requirement that they share profits and technologies with any countries whose biological resources they used.
The White House felt comfortable with that decision until Germany, England, Canada, India and Japan announced they would join virtually every other nation in approving the plan.
Suddenly, the American delegation and its chief were defending themselves against accusations that the United States had replaced the Soviet Union as an international outlaw. Late on Wednesday, Mr. Reilly made a last-minute appeal that the White House consider changes in the treaty that might go far enough to allow the President to sign it.
But in the White House and elsewhere in the Government, Mr. Reilly's critics became so concerned that he might succeed that they leaked to The New York Times a copy of the confidential memorandum he sent to Clayton K. Yeutter, the President's domestic policy chief. The disclosure, meant to embarrass Mr. Reilly, rattled him and embarrassed the President, who later told reporters that the leak was "terribly offensive" and that Mr. Reilly had his "full support."
 
Confusion
The week's furor showed just how much confusion the Administration's environmental policy is in. On Monday, during a speech at the Goddard Space Flight Center outside Washington, Mr. Bush proposed spending $150 million annually to save world forests. Two days later, the chief of the United States Forest Service announced plans to largely end clear-cutting on 191 million acres of national forests. But only three weeks ago, Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. proposed legislation approved by the President that would open four million acres of ancient forests in the Pacific Northwest to clear-cutting.
Many such contradictions have appeared in Mr. Bush's environmental policy. In 1990, he lobbied for and signed a powerful Clean Air Act. But this year, critics say, he allowed budget officials and Vice President Dan Quayle's Council on Competitiveness to weaken it. Two weeks ago, for example, he sided with the Vice President and directed Mr. Reilly to let companies exceed their permitted air pollution levels without public notice or comment.
Three years ago, Mr. Bush sought to separate himself from the angry anti-environmentalist policies of his predecessor, Ronald Reagan. He broke a 13-year stalemate in Congress to pass a new Clean Air Act and halted much offshore oil drilling.
White House officials say the President's philosophy of balancing ecological and economic goals hasn't changed but that the emphasis, driven by concern over the economy, has.
The Administration sees exploitable weaknesses in the national environmental movement and in Congress. Environmental groups have laid off employees in the recession and Democratic leaders, damaged by the House bank and post office scandals, are avoiding attacks on the President.
Encouraging the White House is a network of timber industry executives, coal miners, farmers and big landowners who have formed a coalition they call the "Wise Use" movement. The President's political advisers hope it will help protect the conservative Republican constituency in the West that the President needs to win any three-way race.
 
Quayle's Voice
 It is also clear that Mr. Quayle has become, for the moment, a distinctive and influential voice on domestic issues. Two weeks ago he grabbed headlines by attacking Murphy Brown. He has won a string of environmental victories over Mr. Reilly, including his proposal last summer to open 50 million acres of wetlands to development.
Mr. Quayle frames the debate as one that pits environmental extremists against hard-working Americans in danger of losing their jobs. In Thursday night's news conference, Mr. Bush took the same tack when asked about the biodiversity treaty. "I will not sign a treaty that in my view throws too many Americans out of work," he said. "I refuse to accept that kind of criticism from what I consider some of the extremes in the environmental movement, internationally and domestically."
Mr. Reilly and some other White House officials grimace at such statements. They believe the regulations create jobs. According to Environmental Economics, a research company in Philadelphia, strict rules have forced companies to cut waste and become more efficient, and have spurred the development of up to 70,000 environmental companies with $130 billion in sales. Roughly two million Americans earn a living doing some kind of environmental cleanup work.
Last week, conservationists expressed dismay at the country's isolation at the summit and the Administration's line. Thirty years ago this month, the modern environmental movement was born with serialized publication in The New Yorker of Rachel Carson's "Silent Spring," a devastating critique of the damage that pesticides were doing to wildlife.
"It's painful to a person like me," said Stewart L. Udall, the Secretary of the Interior under Presidents Kennedy and Johnson and author of the Wilderness Act of 1964. "We are the cradle of the environmental movement. We spawned this new way of looking at the world. And now we're the laggard."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Vice President Quayle: Point man on environmental deregulation. (Steve Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Dreams Deferred: A Class of '85, 7 Years Later/A special report.;
Certain Only of Uncertainty, Ex-Classmates Seek a Future

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SISTERSVILLE, W. Va.

 BODY:
The smokestacks along the Ohio River Valley still make the nighttime mists glow red, but they barely warm the economies of old river communities like Marietta, Ohio; Parkersburg, W. Va., and the once-prosperous town of Sistersville.
If these towering cylinders are already an icon of America's past, the young men and women of Sistersville are an emblem of its uncertain present. Seven years after graduation, two-thirds of the Sistersville High School Class of 1985 is still here, 25-year-old men and women depending on dead-end jobs or part-time work, or scrambling for one of the dwindling number of lucrative factory jobs.
 
Like Many Towns
 Some who have good jobs are upbeat about their futures. Others, though flush with annual incomes of $35,000 or $40,000, have little confidence that the good times will last or that they can find something better elsewhere. 
 Though perched at the northwest edge of the state whose name is synonymous with rural poverty, the largely Republican populace of Sistersville seems closer in income and outlook to residents of the industrial towns and farm market centers of the Midwest. Like many of these towns, it has a historical society and carefully preserved landmarks. And like many of these, it is watching its high school, its link between past and future, close.
The loss of this touchstone only underlines the uncertainty facing the young people of Sistersville, which had its origins in the decline of the country's heavy industries. But they are by no means unique. In some ways, having been a little bit poorer a little bit longer, their last seven years may offer other young people in this recession-ridden country a preview of their near-term future.
"A lot of the jobs I was trained for don't exist any more," said Michael Malone, who completed an M.B.A. program at West Virginia University in 1991 hoping to work in one of the industries near his hometown. Smiling ruefully, he scanned the patchwork vista of Sistersville, where turn-of-the-century brick coexists with 1950's aluminum siding. His new plan, he said, is to work as an insurance salesman and eventually start a business.
"I'm getting used to not having security," he said.
About one-third of the 29 women and 34 men in the 1985 class are seeking their futures elsewhere in places where the computer and health care industries are flourishing or in the shipyards of Virginia or on military bases from Hawaii to Georgia.
Some,like a warehouse manager in Florida and a computer programmer in North Carolina, have found the coveted security and opportunity. Others thought they had, only to find military spending cuts or recession threatening their plans. One just returned home from the shipbuilding yards of Newport News, Va., leaving before the cutbacks he expects.
"The rest of the nation is catching up with West Virginia," said Kelley Lucas Stewart, who lives in Sistersville and is planning to get a degree in education. "Things are starting to crumble around them." Although her husband, Richard, 26 years old, makes $45,000 at a PPG Industries plant, she says: "Security isn't there, no matter what you're doing, no matter where. If you make it today, that's great. But what about tomorrow?"
 
Few Are Surprised
 Few of the 20 classmates interviewed for this article have found a future they can trust. They are not surprised. Back in junior high school, when many of their fathers were laid off in an earlier round of industrial cuts, they became accustomed to the disappearance of jobs.
Right after graduation, about half of the 63 class members left to look for better things in the booming Sun Belt or the military. Of those, at least eight have come back frustrated. If they must shiver in a chilly economy, they say it is better to shiver among friends and family.
Their successes and failures have resonance far beyond their own small industrial enclave 75 miles southwest of Pittsburgh where men mix chemicals and bend metal between the dark brown river and the dark green hills.
"This is true up the Ohio River Valley and industrial areas up to southern Michigan," said Calvin Beale, a demographer with the United States Department of Agriculture. "This same thing is going on all through the farm belt."
 
Very Few Young Adults
 "A large number of the young people will not stick close to home," he added.
The 1990 census found that the population of West Virginia, like that of South Dakota, Maine and Wyoming ranked near the bottom in the proportion of residents between the ages of 18 and 24. In each of those states, young adults made up barely 10 percent of the population.
While many young people are leaving, not everyone from a small town like Sistersville, whose population dropped to 1,797 in 1990, is comfortable in larger places. "I had a job in Virginia, in Alexandria, as an apprentice to an electrician," said Kenneth Barker Jr. "The cost of living was too high, and I couldn't make it." After another move to Columbus, Ohio, he came home to a job at American Cyanamid's plant 25 miles to the south in Waverly.
"There were 5,000 applications," he said. "Twenty-three of us got hired."
Others found the fear of crime and the loneliness of bigger places pushed them home. But whether they stayed at home, left or came back, most of those interviewed said their options were very different from those available when their parents were young. A few said the options were better. Most said that although they were more comfortable than their parents had been, they had fewer options.
 
Staying
Waiting for Work Is the Watchword
 "I knew what to expect," said Daron Palmer. "I saw all my brothers and my friends going through it. But I wanted to be near my family. Better to live in a place you grew up in and like than a place where you don't know anybody."
In 1989, after four years in the Navy, Mr. Palmer came home to Sistersville. "I had unemployment for 26 weeks. I had some savings. Then I worked for a carpenter. Then I laid brick walks. If you wait around long enough, you have a chance at a halfway decent job."
In 1991, he got a job at the Ormet Corporation's plant in Hannibal, Ohio, a 25-minute drive from Sistersville. For $12.98 an hour, he regulates the temperature in huge vats of molten metal. A few months after he was hired, he was laid off for five months. Ormet took him back in April.
"Materially, I have pretty much everything I need," he said. "But it's hard to get a job around here and hard to keep it. People just take things day to day."
Mr. Palmer's old classmate Joseph Wilson is more upbeat. Star fullback on the 1984 state championship high school team, he enrolled in Ball State University in Indiana, but left to follow his high school coach to Glenville State College in West Virginia, where he majored in biology and education.
He graduated from Glenville a year ago and was hired as the football coach at the Parkersburg high school. He also teaches biology at a junior high school but expects that position to be eliminated in upcoming job cuts. But he isn't worried because he is securing a place as a permanent substitute.
"I don't feel insecurity," he said "You have to think ahead and pick what's going to be open for you."
 
Leaving
Seeking the Future Amid Uncertainty
 "For a long time, probably since high school, I knew I was going away," said John Orr. "It was just a question of where.
"It was really the guidance counselor at the time who got me thinking toward college. If I had been on my own, I wouldn't have considered going. I didn't come from a very wealthy family and wasn't aware of the financial aid and everything."
Mr. Orr was speaking from his seat in front of a computer at Computer Sciences Corporation at Research Triangle Park near Raleigh, N.C., where he began work late last year.
While in high school, he had applied to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, but backed off, awed by the size and foreignness of the campus in Cambridge, Mass. With classmates David Worth, now an assistant supermarket manager, and Douglas Reed, now a Marine in South Korea, Mr. Orr enrolled at West Virginia University.
After a lackadaisical academic performance, he said, he transferred to Marietta College within a year. With breaks to earn tuition money, he finished college last summer.
"The whole time I was going to school I knew I was going to have to go somewhere else to get a job in the field I'm in," he said.
Sabrina Brothers didn't know where she would end up, but went to beauty college for a year after school to train for a portable career. After that year, she married John Hunter, who had been a year ahead of her in school.
Now living in Mountain Home, Idaho, Mrs. Hunter, like at least 10 of the other women in her class, has small children. Unlike most others, she also has a job, running a beauty parlor near her husband's Air Force base. She handled both the job and the two children alone last year, while her husband served in the Persian Gulf war.
But the military career they had envisioned did not seem so sure when he came back. "We thought we were going to stay in the military for 20 years," she said. "Right now, if he could find any kind of good job at home, with good medical benefits and good pay, we'd think of going back.
"I'm not really worried. We're both young enough to go somewhere and start over."
 
Returning
Uncertainty Seems Less So at Home
 Victoria Evans Barnhart is determined to bring up her two boys in Sistersville, where they can wander by any house and find someone they know. Fiercely attached to her hometown, Mrs. Barnhardt tried to live elsewhere, but could not.
"Someone came by after school and told the guy I was dating they were hiring in Georgia. So we went down there and he worked. They were doing outriggers for an oil company near Savannah. It was a nice little place. But the crime there! You couldn't go down to the laundromat and wash your clothes without being afraid.
"I've seen what other places are like. My roots are here.
"There's not a lot to keep people here," she admitted, as she spoke of the old days, when her grandparents came here. At the turn of the century, Sistersville was bristling with oil derricks and had more millionaires per capita than any other town in the country, said the high school principal, Charles Heinlein. The oil is a distant memory now. "We don't have a clothing store any more. If you want to buy a piece of underwear, you can't buy it in this town."
Mrs. Barnhart's husband, Brian, earns $35,000 a year as an operator at Monongahela Power. "It's a secure job," she said. "Everyone needs electricity."
Michelle Smith has no job, secure or otherwise. But she is happier here than in Norcross, Ga., where she worked as a file clerk in an insurance office.
"There's always something that you'll make more money at than you do here," Ms. Smith said. "I thought I wanted to get away from this little town to a big city." Her classmate Lisa Lovely, she said, "kept calling and writing me letters and saying, 'It's great down here.' "
She joined her friend, met a man, had a little girl and then broke up with the man and brought her daughter home. They live with her parents. She once thought of training to be an X-ray technician, but now is not sure. In any case, she wants to stay home until her 2-year-old daughter is in school.
"You can't look into the future and plan any more," she said. "Taking things day to day makes me mad."
Mr. Malone, whose M.B.A. had thus far done little for him, said: "Being mad is the tough part. It's a logical point of view to be angry, but you can't blame it on anyone. That's frustrating. The person you wind up looking at is the person in the mirror."
